column1: Forget about false modesty, not to mention its nonfalse counterpart. , came to Madison Square Garden on Monday night to celebrate his favorite singer, his favorite actor, his favorite comedian, his favorite sex symbol and his favorite storyteller, who all  happen to share his name. Near the end, Mr. Foxx morphed into , â€” only to thank himself for doing such a good job playing himself in â€œRay.â€ù,As you can tell, one of Mr. Foxxâ€™s greatest assets is his shamelessness. And he needed every bit to make it through this night â€” billed as an evening of music and comedy â€” more or less unscathed. He faced a big (though not quite full) crowd, armed with only a pretty good voice and a handful of rather thin, slow jams. A performerâ€™s nightmare, you might think, but not for Mr. Foxx, and his good humor was contagious. Itâ€™s hard to stay mad at a one-track-minded crooner who announces his intention to ignore half the crowd: â€œFellas, you can stick around if you want to.â€ù,He had some help: the â€œAmerican Idolâ€ù winner Fantasia delivered a short, fierce set of screaming R&B, and the stand-up comedian known as Speedy did a familiar but effective routine, gleefully roasting audience members who had good seats and bad timing.,But this was essentially a one-man show, and it started with a nod to the past. Before he was a crooner or â€œa Oscar winnerâ€ù (as he often referred to himself), Mr. Foxx was a comedian. So he spent his first half-hour telling stories and ridiculing celebrities, including O. J. Simpson (it was gruesome) and Britney Spears (even more gruesome). Like most successful comedians, Mr. Foxx knows that the delivery is usually more important than the material. Recalling the R&B group Jodeci, he said, â€œThat was back when it was a cassetteâ€ù; thatâ€™s not really a joke, but he hit that last word so hard that the audience chuckled anyway.,Mr. Foxx released a little-noticed record in 1994, but his chart-topping 2005 album, â€œUnpredictableâ€ù (J Records/Sony BMG), felt like a debut. He has clearly been influenced by R. Kelly, who excels at turning ridiculous boasts and promises (â€œYou remind me of my jeep/I wanna ride itâ€ù) into glorious R&B songs. Of course, Mr. Kelly has two things that Mr. Foxx lacks: a gorgeous voice and a first-rate catalog of hits.,If ever there was a show crying out for more guest stars, this was it. You can imagine Mr. Foxx as the leader of an old-fashioned variety show: bringing out some friends, singing a few songs, doing some skits and parodies. Instead he began with a lackluster version of the albumâ€™s hit title track (Ludacris, who contributes a great verse to the album version, was sorely missed), then spent much of the rest of the night killing time. This is a guy who can get women to scream just by crooning Zodiac signs â€” and at one point, he did exactly that.,Still, there is something satisfying about watching Mr. Foxx bask in his well-deserved success. And, for that matter, his less-well-deserved success too. â€œLove Changes,â€ù his duet with Mary J. Blige, has been nominated for a Grammy; the category is most unnecessary cover version of a late-80s R&B hit, or something. He sang it without her, and asked the people in the front â€” â€œAll the good tickets!â€ù â€” to sing along. He asked the men to stand up and sing the chorus to their women. He asked the women to stand up and sing the chorus to their men. And how can you say no to a Oscar winner?
column4: Itâ€™s a Deal: You Like Me and I Like Me Too

column1: On the night of Jan. 21, 1998,  Stanley N. Alpert was heading home in Greenwich Village with pleasant thoughts on his mind. The next day he would turn 38. By chance, he had struck up a conversation with an attractive woman on the subway, and it looked as if a date were in the cards. As he walked, he mused, and as he mused, he failed to notice two armed men closing in on him from behind. Before he knew it, he was in the back seat of a new Lexus, about to experience the most terrifying 25 hours of his life.,â€œThe Birthday Partyâ€ù is Mr. Alpertâ€™s harrowing, often hilarious reconstruction of what should have been a garden-variety New York street crime. He gives a taut, hour-by-hour account of a simple robbery that became a kidnapping and then, by a quirk of fate, a ghetto version of â€œThe Ransom of Red Chief,â€ù as Mr. Alpert, by all appearances Grade A victim material, turned into a colossal headache for his captors. Precisely how this nebbishy Brooklyn boy, partial to peach-flavored Snapple iced tea and chocolate chip cookies, induced reverse Stockholm syndrome and maneuvered his way to freedom makes â€œThe Birthday Partyâ€ù one of the most exhilarating, improbable New York stories ever told.,The original plan was simple:  drive the victim to an A.T.M. and force him to withdraw money. When Lucky, the gangâ€™s ringleader, discovered that Mr. Alpert had $110,000 in his savings account,  the plan changed. After a quick visit to the A.T.M., Mr. Alpert found himself sitting blindfolded in an apartment somewhere in Brooklyn, watched over by three armed men, three prostitutes employed by Lucky and one very nervous landlord.,In the morning, Lucky informs him, he will be driven to his bank to withdraw $50,000 that Lucky, in a telephone transaction, has shifted from savings to checking. There is nothing to worry about, one captor insists: â€œYou got your fine education, your good job. It donâ€™t matter to you if I get your money. Youâ€™ll just make it again.â€ù,At this point it has not quite dawned on the gang exactly what Mr. Alpert meant when he informed them that he was an assistant federal attorney and that they might have made a small miscalculation in choosing him.,The ordeal of captivity is horrific yet ridiculous, like a demented episode of MTVâ€™s â€œReal World.â€ù Mr. Alpert himself wavers between the two points of view. All around him, a chaotic scene unfolds, as Ren and Sen, the two henchmen, play with their guns, philosophize, smoke marijuana and have sex with the prostitutes. Occasionally Lucky, attending to pressing business concerns in the outside world, pops in to restore order and refine the crime plans.,Mr. Alpert concentrates, very hard, on exuding a cooperative spirit and winning the sympathy of those around him, all the while filing away small bits of information that will help convict everyone in the room if he ever gets out alive.,There are many tense moments. Sen, without warning, begins raving, screaming out sick, violent fantasies of murder and mayhem. â€œI remained frozen in sheer terror, silent and unflinching, hoping he would not act,â€ù Mr. Alpert writes. Gradually,  he realizes that Sen is singing along to a Busta Rhymes rap on the radio.,When the gang offers Mr. Alpert free sex with one of the women, he calculates feverishly. A refusal might be interpreted as racism. On the other hand, the loss of dignity might make him seem less sympathetic, easier to inflict pain on. He says no, very politely.,Mr. Alpert and his captors inhabit different worlds. The men laugh at Mr. Alpertâ€™s $49 Florsheim shoes. They examine his watch and ring with contempt. They cannot understand why, at his age, he is not married with children. Mr. Alpert tells them that his parents wonder the same thing. His money earns him a measure of respect, and, as the hours drag on, Ren and Sen ask for free, much appreciated legal advice.,A bond develops. â€œYo, Stanley, you should join our gang,â€ù Sen tells him. â€œYou could recommend friends that we could kidnap.â€ù After a momentâ€™s reflection, Sen amends his suggestion â€œNaw, I mean you could recommend your , for us to kidnap.â€ù Mr. Alpert decides a cryptic smile is the best response.,Eventually Lucky decides that going into a bank with Mr. Alpert might be a high-risk operation. Further, he has come to realize that he is holding a hot potato. Mr. Alpert is bundled into the Lexus late at night and driven somewhere eerily quiet. With good reason, he suspects that his luck has run out. Rather than spoil one of the bookâ€™s most bleakly funny moments, let me just note that few sounds have quite the sensory impact of duct tape being ripped from a roll.,Mr. Alpert may be no hero, but he survived his kidnapping by remaining extraordinarily cool under pressure, and keeping his lawyerly wits about him. Observant and shrewd, he amassed a dossierâ€™s worth of evidence to present to the police, who were, in fact, deeply impressed by what they heard: they judged his story to be the biggest pack of lies ever bundled together by an unaided human being.,Only after crucial details panned out did the chase begin in earnest. The pursuit and capture of Lucky and the rest of the crew, an operation successfully completed in about 48 hours, make  a rousing conclusion to a crazy adventure.,New Yorkers enjoy playing one-upmanship when it comes to crime. Iâ€™ll see your mugging and raise you two break-ins and a carjacking. Mr. Alpert suffered terribly, but he does have something to show for the experience. For the rest of his life, no one will ever beat him in this little game.
column4: A Hostage Who Stayed a Few Steps Ahead

column1: Lonelygirl15 wants a career. Sheâ€™s considering becoming a forest ranger but lacks the stomach for herd-thinning. Teaching aerobics is another option, but sheâ€™s worried sheâ€™s too smart for that.,Lonelygirl15 â€” thatâ€™s Bree (Jessica Lee Rose), the star of the hit online serial that clicks along at , â€” also wants female friends, like, say, Katharine McPhee, the â€œAmerican Idolâ€ù runner-up she met in the low-key but lively episode that made its debut last Friday. That girl seems cool. She has a loud laugh, no manifest cult involvements and a song on the episodeâ€™s soundtrack.,She even dares to  pose a blockbuster question to Bree and her two Webcam-happy boyfriends: â€œDo you guys film everything?â€ù,Yeah, they do. As milowent, a longtime student of the series, observed on a fan site: â€œThe McPhee character ,. She is the audience. She pointed out a lot of ridiculous things about the show.â€ù,Bree has plenty of reasons to take stock of her life right now. Ever since she  fled the luminous bedroom where she started her tantalizing video blog on June 16, 2006, and soon after seeing her authoritarian father murdered on New Yearâ€™s Eve, our lady of YouTube has been stuck in peculiar straits. The â€œLonelygirl15â€ù phenomenon that initially teased viewers with its pseudo-reality has evolved into a vaguely supernatural thriller with hints  of â€œBuffy, the Vampire Slayer.â€ù Itâ€™s inventive, with highs and lows. On balance, itâ€™s entertaining. But devoted fans love to complain that itâ€™s not as good as it used to be, or as it could be.,Bree is now shacked up with Jonas (Jackson Davis), an alpha-dog rich kid who just wants to help her, and Daniel (Yousef Abu-Taleb), a beta-dog penniless kid who just wants to help her. Both seem besotted. She seems freaked out.,And the presence of Ms. McPhee, the anodyne pop star who is said to be the first of several guest stars on the series, has thrown into relief still more dimensions to Breeâ€™s freakiness. Thatâ€™s what makes Ms. McPheeâ€™s episode enlightening. Itâ€™s called â€œTruth or Dare,â€ù and at just under four  minutes, itâ€™s one of the longest in the series.,In the episode Ms. McPhee plays a nameless young woman who is recruited into a night of Texas Hold â€™Em, Truth or Dare and mild debauchery with Breeâ€™s mÃ©nage. She also manages, in her innocence,  to stumble onto some dark details of the plot, including Danielâ€™s careless mention of the Order (the cult that Bree escaped) and the Watcher (a figure from the Order who may be trying to get Bree back).,Ms. McPhee dexterously underplays her character, who in ratty hair and a T-shirt is presented in contrast to Ms. McPheeâ€™s own public dazzle; she looks great. Throaty, game, no-nonsense: something in the bright capability of Ms. McPheeâ€™s character further makes Bree look high-strung, a hothouse flower whose stuffed animals are not cute but creepily regressive.,In this clash of sensibilities too, â€œLonelygirl15,â€ù the series, comes off as twee compared with the boisterous, puppyish â€œAmerican Idol.â€ù (Indeed, what doesnâ€™t?) In the midst of this introvert-extrovert collision, Ms. Rose, who has become a truly terrific actress, chooses to strangle Breeâ€™s confidence and become childish, as when she faces Ms. McPhee for the first time. â€œWho are you?â€ù she asks, sounding threatened, and meek.,If Bree is jealous, the immediate reason is that Ms. McPheeâ€™s character has come home with Daniel, who has gotten drunk at a bowling alley and leaned on this new girl as he stumbled out to Jonasâ€™s car for a ride home. Though it struck some viewers as reckless, the McPhee characterâ€™s willingness to hang out with these guys for the night seemed a typical nothing-better-to-do small town calculation.,But what is coolest about â€œTruth or Dareâ€ù is whatâ€™s been admirable about the series all along: its deep familiarity with and integration of the conventions of online video. â€œTruth or Dare,â€ù like a  majority of the â€œLonelygirl15â€ù installments, has an organic reason for being. It exists, in other words, not just to showcase Katharine McPhee, nor to advance the adolescent farrago. Rather, this episode is a stand-alone drunk-shaming video, one of YouTubeâ€™s many answers to the pillory.,In the drunk-shaming microgenre, videos show people passed out from drinking as theyâ€™re  decorated with Magic Markers, made to urinate or brought to consciousness with fireworks. (For the connoisseur,, offers a nicely sordid collection.) Daniel is slurry or unconscious for the length of â€œTruth or Dare,â€ù and the episode ends with Jonas resolving to do something â€œmeanâ€ù to him. We see the results in the next episode, when Daniel appears with a mustache and beard in ink.,Keeping together a rollicking plot with murder, a cult, imposture and teenage romance â€” making it exciting but not ludicrous â€” isnâ€™t easy. Striving for continuity while relaying plot information in short bytes is an especially tall order. Viewers are standing by on fan sites official and unofficial to play gotcha anytime they decide Bree and company wouldnâ€™t have had enough time while on the lam, say, to make it to an Internet cafe for video editing and uploading between chase scenes. Theyâ€™re a tough crowd. And this policing still goes on, even though fans know the series is fiction.,But in spite of this scrutiny, the team behind â€œLonelygirl15â€ùâ€” by and large, the same team that started the series,  including Ramesh Flinders, Miles Beckett and Greg Goodfried â€” has continued to produce regular videos, maintain an active fan site, spin off a Lonelygirl15 alternative-reality game, line up guest stars and otherwise sustain the momentum they created.,As a serial drama   too, â€œLonelygirl15â€ù has kept its first unbeatable asset, the one that  has nothing to do with new technology. Itâ€™s the girl: Jessica Lee Rose. As the series goes on, Ms. Rose continues to mix moodiness, charm and precociousness, and her witchcraft casts a serious spell. For every fan whoâ€™s mad at her for jerking Daniel around, there are 10 who are newly in love. And the fact that sheâ€™s now out of her parentsâ€™ clutches and in the wide worldâ€”Ã  la Lolita, in motels and guest housesâ€”makes her suddenly more available.,But Lonelygirl15 is formidable. Though gawked at by fans worldwide, she looks back only through the palm-size porthole on our computers. No wonder she now says she wants a life in the latest episode. Her story has always been about a girl looking into a camera, planning an escape. And surely she can dream. One day Lonelygirl15 will shake off these guys, teach some aerobics, get her Ranger badge, grab a gun and thin the thundering herds.
column4: As Her World Turns, Lonelygirl15 Seeks New Thrills

column1: When books or paintings become too dizzying, you can walk away until youâ€™re ready for more. But performance art keeps coming at you, ready or not. Though audience members can practice some form of pacing, much of the effect depends on the artistâ€™s skill in knowing how much is too much, or when too much is just enough.,In â€œA Page Out of Order: M,â€ù Yoshiko Chuma is constantly rearranging, layering and shifting to reveal another view â€” much like the movable cubes that are a staple of her choreography. Using black-and-white film, text, dance, singing and a marvelous onstage band, for 90 minutes she stirs an uneasy brew of war, identity and dislocation.,The vocalist Sizzle Ohtaka narrates, in Japanese, as text snippets of stories about failed relationships and ethnic strife flash onto screens. Then she sings mournfully over a recording of wind.,The wonderfully astute American dancer Christopher Williams crouches and stretches among the metal cube frames. The musicians dart here and there on their many instruments, evoking Latin jazz and conjuring old movie soundtracks or what sounds like Romanian gypsy music. Images of desolate landscapes come and go.,At moments the results are sophisticated, exhilarating and transformative in ways only half understood but strongly felt. At other times the chaos seems banal, a simple case of clutter; perhaps, you think, Ms. Chuma could play her cards a bit closer to her chest.,But then she is off in another direction, and you follow, ready or not.,â€œI could say we are moving from one system to the other,â€ù the Macedonian dancer Iskra Sukarova explains early on, though she is actually sitting quite still in her chair. â€œIâ€™m moving, too. Iâ€™m not sure that I really like to move so much, though. It kind of makes me sick sometimes.â€ù,Ms. Sukarova, who functions as the performanceâ€™s quiet heart, is referring to her countryâ€™s political situation, both the tedium and upset that come with such upheaval.,But, of course, she is also talking about art, how maddening it can be. The pages are out of order, you think. This is impossible. Then something clicks, and you never want the experience to end.
column4: Stirring Many Ingredients Into a Strangely Blended Brew

column1: In 1955, shortly after â€œThe Lord of the Ringsâ€ù was published, J. R. R. Tolkien began to worry his creation had become a â€œvast gameâ€ù for some readers. This was not good, he wrote, even â€œfor me, who find that kind of thing only too fatally attractive.â€ù,Now, Tolkienâ€™s â€œLord of the Ringsâ€ù and the imaginary setting he painstakingly built, Middle-earth, has become that â€œvast game.â€ù,Tomorrow in Las Vegas,  Turbine Inc. of Westwood, Mass., is to  announce an  April 24 release date for The Lord of the Rings Online: Shadows of Angmar, the yearâ€™s most anticipated massively multiplayer online game, or M.M.O.  A digital Middle-earth will open its gates to thousands of virtual characters embarking on quests, plumbing subterranean realms and slaughtering plenty of goblins and trolls.,â€œExpectations are fairly high for this game,â€ù said Michael Goodman, digital entertainment program manager for the consumer research division of the Yankee Group, a consulting firm. â€œThis is literally a franchise with a brand that spans the globe. There arenâ€™t a lot of those around.â€ù,Some 200 million copies of â€œThe Lord of the Ringsâ€ù have been published in 39 languages. The 2001-2003 , film trilogy amassed gross revenues of more than $3 billion worldwide.,Yet for the online â€œRingsâ€ù to succeed, Turbine cannot depend on existing gamers alone. It also needs to lure Tolkien devotees who donâ€™t play video games by making it â€œaccessible to just about anyone,â€ù Andrew Park, senior editor at GameSpot, an online gaming news and review site, said in an e-mail interview.,â€œFrom what I gather, Turbine is targeting two different audiences for this game: hard-core online game players,â€ù Mr. Park said, â€œand more-casual or nongame-players who are fans of Tolkienâ€™s works.â€ù,But visualizing hobbit villages and evil armies for Tolkienâ€™s Middle-earth, an already meticulously detailed and plotted world, is complicated. Fans expect its parameters â€” the languages, geographies, histories, races, nomenclature, mythologies and what Tolkien called the legendarium â€” to be strictly obeyed.,â€œBasically, the main challenge of creating an authentic Tolkien experience is building something that wonâ€™t make Tolkienâ€™s many fans angry by straying too far away from the original works,â€ù Mr. Park said. Sticklers for detail will be quick to point out any inconsistencies. Even a characterâ€™s eye color, Mr. Park said, canâ€™t be off, not by a â€œnanometer.â€ù,A further challenge is that immersive M.M.O. worlds must entertain for hours, days, even years of play. They have to be infinitely detailed and vast enough that tens of thousands of players can interact with one  another at the same time.,Since September some 300,000 users have beta-tested the fates of elvish lore masters and hobbit burglars in a 50-million-square-meter Middle-earth still under construction (and giving the game great advance word of mouth). Most players expect  â€œcreative leapsâ€ù to adapt a reading experience into compelling play, said Larry Curtis of ,, a Tolkien fan site.,â€œYouâ€™ve got to have a good game,â€ù he added. â€œItâ€™s not an easy balance.â€ù,Many readers of the novels feared their dumbing-down when the films were first released, Mr. Curtis said. To head off such criticism of the game, Turbine hired â€œRingsâ€ù experts to ensure that any ideas or inventions were consistent with the rules of Middle-earth.,The consultants â€œwould write back with notes on a script: â€˜an elf might not do that,â€™ or, â€˜if youâ€™re looking for a more dwarven name, this might work as a family tree,â€™ â€ù recounted Jeffrey Anderson, Turbineâ€™s chief executive. His team also worked closely with Tolkien Enterprises, which manages â€œRingâ€ù merchandising and film rights, seeking its approval for any major departure from the books.,Turbine created Asheronâ€™s Call, its first online role-playing game, in 1999. Last year, the company released Dungeons & Dragons Online, based on the original pen-and-paper role-playing game. (Loosely based on Tolkienâ€™s milieu, D & D was credited with establishing the fantasy gaming genre.) And this isnâ€™t the first time â€œRingsâ€ù has gone digital: Tolkien-esque computer games â€” some authorized, some not â€” have been around since the early 1980s.,But Turbineâ€™s is the first Tolkien-based M.M.O. Like the immensely popular World of Warcraft, it will allow anyone â€” anyone willing to pay about $50 for the software and a monthly subscription fee of up to $15, that is â€” to not only battle monsters, but also increase virtual skills, wealth and renown. The game makes provisions for the peaceful: Some gamers may be content with their characters weaving and talking (via voice-chat technology), jamming in bands at the local tavern (using an in-game music system) or raising crops and families.,A game this size is bound to  invite some dissent among the dedicated. On the , forum, one observer, Draeconea, grumbled that character movements appeared â€œunnatural ...They run as if having a sore back, and got several planks of wood underneath their clothes.â€ù In another thread,  players argued about whether their avatars, or online beings, should be as powerful as a main Tolkien character like Aragorn.,Concerning these and other details, Mr. Anderson said that â€œthereâ€™s been lots of debate about it.â€ù He added,  â€œWeâ€™re going to continue to listen to the community about these topics.â€ù,Until recently, the job of interpreting Tolkien has fallen to Tolkien experts, not film or video-game directors. While many scholars are tolerant of the blockbuster adaptations, a few would prefer that  â€œRingsâ€ù remain a reading experience, not a virtual playground.,An online game â€œmay indeed trivialize Tolkienâ€™s legacy,â€ù Wayne G. Hammond, co-author of the â€œJ. R. R. Tolkien Companion and Guide,â€ù said in an e-mail interview, â€œif one comes to view â€˜The Lord of the Ringsâ€™ as popular culture more than as a work of literature, or feels that it cannot be a serious work of literature if it has outgrowths in popular culture.â€ù,The game may signal â€œdemocratization,â€ù he said, â€œbut it isnâ€™t Tolkien.â€ù,So far, reviews on sites like , and , have been positive. Tolkienâ€™s United States publisher, Houghton Mifflin, also is enthusiastic. â€œOur hope for the new game is the same hope we held during the time of the films,â€ù said Webster Younce, senior editor at Houghton Mifflin, â€œthat people who might not have read Tolkien will want to go directly to the source.â€ù
column4: Building Middle-Earth: â€˜The Lord of the Ringsâ€™ Online

column1: It is mystifying that the Mexican pianist Jorge Federico Osorio does not have more of a presence in the New York concert world. Having won several competitions in the early 1970s, he waited until 1997 to make his New York recital debut. He hasnâ€™t been back much since, but his recordings of Spanish and Mexican music have attracted notice, and on Monday evening he played a hefty, colorful program at Alice Tully Hall that reinforced the impression he made a decade ago.,Three Soler sonatas established several of Mr. Osarioâ€™s strengths at the outset. Not least among them are a bright but warm tone, the technique and finger power required for Solerâ€™s rapid-fire repeating notes, and the elegance to illuminate the exotic Classicism that drives these works and is their link to Scarlatti on one hand, and Mozart on the other.,The Romantic and picturesque side of the Spanish repertory turned up on the second half of the program, when Mr. Osorio offered AlbÃ©nizâ€™s â€œSuite EspaÃ±olaâ€ù No. 1 in a reading notable for its high-energy performances of â€œGranada,â€ù with its lilting melody weaving through guitarlike figuration, and â€œAsturias,â€ù in which a serpentine theme is wrapped in a hypnotic tremolando figure.,Between the Soler and the AlbÃ©niz, Mr. Osorio played a vibrant, tempestuous account of Beethovenâ€™s Sonata No. 30 (Op. 109), with a magnificently cathartic finale, and a group of Debussyâ€™s Preludes that drew on Mr. Osorioâ€™s considerable imagination for subtle timbres and vivid characterization. He closed the program with two Liszt works, a beautifully articulated â€œJeux dâ€™eau Ã  la Villa dâ€™Esteâ€ù and an explosively virtuosic â€œVallÃ©e dâ€™Oberman.â€ù,Occasionally, the forcefulness of Mr. Osorioâ€™s style led him to step on melodies, particularly at phrase endings, or to smudge a texture here or a harmony there. But the sweep and freshness of his readings made his performance impossible to resist, technical quibbles notwithstanding.
column4: Returning to New York, Forcefully

column1: Who would have imagined that watching a stranger undress could ever be tedious?,Well, over the past few years choreographers have managed the impossible, making every effort to yank skivvies off whenever remotely necessary, and especially when it isnâ€™t.,But fear not. The French are here to save the day. Really.,On Thursday Martine Pisaniâ€™s â€œBande Ã  Partâ€ù (â€œBand of Outsidersâ€ù) opened at ,. There was plenty of nudity: indeed, you could make the case that the performance hinged on it. Itâ€™s just that none of it was actual.,The work began with ThÃ©o Kooijman walking the audience through his conceptual disrobing. â€œO.K., I got through the first part,â€ù he explained after a pause in which nothing happened, and in which you realized that nothing was going to. The joke, of course, is that you felt his nakedness all the more.,Such absurd and obvious manipulation of reality lay at the heart of this hourlong solo, cleverly disguised as a quartet. Christophe Ives, Eduard Mont de Palol, Olivier Schram and Mr. Kooijman, delightful dancers all, took turns performing a simple movement monologue, which included things like losing yourself for 23 seconds and finding yourself in seven; warming up and then passing that heat on to the audience through methods like vigorous rubbing and fanning, and that old standby, disappearing.,Each man interpreted this script (the â€œsoloistâ€™s storyâ€ù was read early on) in his own way and seemingly off the cuff, often ceding the soloist role to another performer in midstream.,The revolving backup threesome served to enhance and frame the action; think of the peanut gallery, not a Greek chorus. They burbled and chirped when it seemed their lead was in danger of nodding off. They created sound effects through methods that give new meaning to the description â€œlow techâ€ù; at one point Mr. Mont de Palol zipped and unzipped his fly to great effect. They galloped around awkwardly like men who canâ€™t quite get their minds around the concept.,And they created, through such winning and inane shenanigans, a reality that was just as forceful as the workaday version youâ€™re normally told to believe. You know, the one that says to be naked, you mustnâ€™t wear clothes.
column4: This Emperor Does Have Clothes (but He Says He Doesnâ€™t)

column1: A disputed report on the Web site of a conservative magazine about ,â€™s childhood schooling kicked off a pointed exchange this week between the rival cable news networks CNN and Fox News, when CNN seemed to make an overt effort both to debunk the report and to question the quality of Fox Newsâ€™s journalism.,The original report, posted on the online version of Insight, a magazine owned by The Washington Times, said that as a child in Indonesia, Mr. Obama had attended a madrassa, a school that teaches a radical version of the Muslim faith. Mr. Obama, who spent a few years in Jakarta as a boy, is a Christian.,Adding to the political volatility of the report was the attribution of the news to â€œresearchers connected toâ€ù Senator ,.,The two senators are expected to be the leading candidates for the 2008 Democratic presidential nomination, attracting intense news coverage, and the sparring between CNN and Fox News, which are often described as ideological opposites, may be a prelude to more accusations of inaccurate reporting.,The back-and-forth also comes amid a backdrop of increasingly nasty competition between the two networks, with CNN trying to promote the quality of its journalism as a counter to Foxâ€™s ratings. Fox continues to command by far the largest news audience in cable television.,Representatives of Mr. Obama of Illinois and Mrs. Clinton of New York denounced the Insight report, calling it false and an effort by a conservative publication to smear two Democratic contenders at the same time.,The Fox News Channel discussed the report on two of its programs. It was also picked up by The New York Post, which shares ownership with Fox News, and was discussed by several conservative talk-radio hosts.,Yesterday, a spokesman for Mrs. Clinton, Howard Wolfson, said in an e-mail message: â€œThis is a textbook example of how the other side works. A right-wing rag makes up a scurrilous charge and prints it with no real attribution. The smear gets injected into the atmosphere and picked up by talk radio. In this case both Senator Obama and Senator Clinton were victimized.â€ù,A spokesman for Mr. Obama had previously been quoted in The Washington Post as calling the report â€œappallingly irresponsible.â€ù,On its Web site yesterday, Insight defended its report, saying, â€œOur reporterâ€™s sources close to the Clinton opposition research war room confirm the truth of the story.â€ù,CNNâ€™s political director, Sam Feist, said he had seen the Insight report discussed on â€œFox and Friends.â€ù Mr. Feist said he wanted to determine the validity of what he said, if true, would be a â€œholy-cow political story,â€ù so he sent a correspondent, John Vause, to Jakarta from Beijing. Mr. Vauseâ€™s report, broadcast Monday on CNN, described the Jakarta school as unaffiliated with Islamic fundamentalism. The school headmaster said it was a â€œpublic schoolâ€ù that did not â€œfocus on religion.â€ù,The president of CNN US, Jon Klein, said that his networkâ€™s report was â€œnot a response to Fox per se, though they did seem to relish repeating the Insight-reported rumor without bothering to â€” or being able to â€” ascertain the facts.â€ù,In its report, CNN included a clip from the Fox News program â€œThe Big Story With John Gibson.â€ù Mr. Gibson interviewed a Republican political strategist about Mrs. Clintonâ€™s reported role in the Obama rumors. As Fox News has in every story on the madrassa accusations, Mr. Gibson used the attribution â€œaccording to Insight magazine.â€ù But he also said: â€œLook at what some anti-Obama Democrats are doing to her political rival now. They are playing the Muslim phobia card.â€ù,On Monday, the hosts of â€œFox and Friendsâ€ù said they wanted to clarify earlier comments after Mr. Obamaâ€™s office contacted the show, declaring its report â€œabsolutely false.â€ù,In comments after Mr. Vauseâ€™s report, the CNN anchors Wolf Blitzer and Anderson Cooper seemed to chide others for not practicing legitimate journalism on the story. â€œCNN did what any serious news organization is supposed to do in this kind of a situation,â€ù Mr. Blitzer said. â€œWe actually conducted an exclusive firsthand investigation inside Indonesia to check out the school.â€ù,Mr. Cooper said: â€œThatâ€™s the difference between talking about news and reporting it. You send a reporter, check the facts, and you decide at home.â€ù,A Fox News spokeswoman, Irena Briganti, said CNN was mainly looking for publicity in attacking its higher-rated rival. Of Mr. Cooperâ€™s comment, she said, â€œYet another cry for attention by the Paris Hilton of television news, Anderson Cooper.â€ù
column4: Rivals CNN and Fox News Spar Over Obama Report

column1: Merrill Lynchâ€™s chief executive, ,,  made more than $48 million last year, an increase of 30 percent from 2005, the company said yesterday in a regulatory filing .,Mr. Oâ€™Neal received $700,000 in salary for 2006, a cash bonus of $18.5 million and stock valued at $28.8 million. The previous year, Merrill gave Mr. Oâ€™Neal $37 million in salary and bonuses.,The five largest Wall Street firms paid their employees a total of more than $60 billion last year, up more than 32 percent from 2005, as profits shattered records. The Goldman Sachs Group, which led the industry with a 70 percent surge in earnings, paid its chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, $53.5 million.,Mr. Oâ€™Neal, 55, took a larger percentage of his pay in shares than Mr. Blankfein, whose stock bonus was $15.7 million. Merrillâ€™s net income rose 37 percent to $7.5 billion last year.
column4: $48 Million Paid to Merrillâ€™s Chief

column1: BERLIN, Jan. 24 â€” SAP, the biggest maker of business management software, said Wednesday that it would invest as much as $520 million over two years on an organization aimed at smaller business clients.,Some analysts said the plan for the investment showed that the company had exhausted its lucrative focus on large global corporations.,The  move, which SAP said would trim its profit margin to 26 percent to 27 percent this year, from a previously announced 30 percent, sent shares of the company plunging as much as 6 percent.,Investors focused on the cost of the initiative, even though SAP reported that profit rose 29 percent in the fourth quarter, to $1.03 billion, as sales rose 7 percent, to almost $3.9 billion.,Analysts said the focus on smaller clients showed that SAPâ€™s business was maturing and that its days of rapid growth might be coming to an end.,â€œBasically I think the financial markets are going to have to adjust their perception of SAP,â€ù said John Segrich, a software analyst at JPMorgan in London. â€œIn the past, the markets have become accustomed to turbocharged growth rates from SAP, but their core business is changing.â€ù,In two of four quarters in the last year, SAP failed to meet analystsâ€™ expectations. For 2006, SAP had predicted that software sales would rise 15 to 17 percent, but sales rose only 11 percent from 2005. Analysts tied the slowdown to reduced business spending on corporate software, the rise of niche competitors nibbling at SAPâ€™s market and the  saturation of SAPâ€™s traditional pool of clients, the large multinational companies.,SAPâ€™s chief executive, Henning Kagermann, said SAP was accelerating efforts begun a few years ago to cater to smaller businesses, which were not  a priority when the company was expanding to become the biggest software maker in Germany and the third-largest in the world after Microsoft and I.B.M.,Mr. Kagermann said SAP would aggressively serve smaller clients with its All-in-One business software suite in 2007.,In an interview, the companyâ€™s president, Leo Apotheker, disputed the notion that SAPâ€™s profit and sales prospects were dimming, saying that SAPâ€™s accelerated focus on small and midsize clients was expected to produce 10,000 new customers and $1.3 billion in new sales revenue by 2010.,â€œWe donâ€™t know where this feeling is coming from,â€ù Mr. Apotheker said. â€œWe have produced double-digit growth for the third straight year. We doubled our software revenue in the U.S. in three years. We said today that we believe our traditional business will grow at double-digit rates for the considerable future. We just want to accelerate that growth.â€ù,But Theo Kitz, an analyst at Merck Finck, a private bank in Munich, said SAPâ€™s growth prospects peaked a few years ago.,The company, founded in 1972, equips 38,000 businesses with software for internal functions like accounting, personnel, sales and executive controls. In a sense, SAP is becoming a victim of its own success, Mr. Kitz said.,Serving smaller businesses is more costly for companies like SAP because there are many of them and their needs tend to be more varied, requiring bigger sales and support teams, Mr. Kitz said. Smaller businesses typically also take longer to make buying decisions and require more intensive sales advice than larger enterprises.
column4: SAP Plans New Venture for Serving Small Clients

column1: WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (Reuters) â€” The American militaryâ€™s chief medical officer for , was among a group of 12  soldiers killed Saturday in a helicopter crash outside Baghdad, the Pentagon said Wednesday.,The medical officer, Col. Brian D. Allgood, 46, was an orthopedic surgeon serving as command surgeon in Iraq.,He and 11 other officers, mostly combat support personnel, were on what Defense officials said was probably an â€œorientation flightâ€ù ahead of the arrival of other soldiers. Defense officials, however, declined to discuss the groupâ€™s specific mission at the time of the crash.,The group included two colonels, a lieutenant colonel, a major and a captain. Army officials declined to say why so many officers were traveling together.,The crash is under investigation.
column4: Medical Officer Killed in Crash

column1: A front-page article  on Jan. 5 about the tendency of criminal suspects in New York City to give revealing and usually damaging statements to the police, despite their right to remain silent, included excerpts from the statement of James Barbour, a Broadway actor accused of sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl. According to his statement, Mr. Barbour told the police that he had lain on a bed with the girl and that they had kissed.,But the article should have made it clear that in the statement, Mr. Barbour does not admit or confess to having sexually assaulted the girl, and that he has pleaded not guilty.
column4: Editorsâ€™ Note

column1: Washington,HERE we are in another flu season, and this time there is plenty of vaccine to go around. The federal government helped increase  the supply by subsidizing factories that make pandemic flu vaccine and by recommending that a total of 218 million Americans get flu shots â€” the sick, the elderly, the late middle-aged and children under 5.,But now state and county officials expect to throw away millions of doses. This situation reflects our blasÃ© attitude toward vaccination. Most of us consider influenza more a nuisance than a danger, except in old people. Of the 36,000 Americans who die of flu each year, most are over 65. And we assume that the elderly take their doctorsâ€™ advice to get vaccinated.,In fact, the immune systems of the old and infirm donâ€™t respond efficiently to the flu vaccine. A better way to protect the elderly from flu, studies have shown, is to vaccinate their nurses and caretakers, their children and grandchildren.,The logic behind giving shots to those who are not as vulnerable (children generally experience flu as a mild disease) is part of a concept called herd immunity. We protect the weaker lambs by bolstering the foldâ€™s communal defenses.,Unfortunately, the idea of herd immunity has lost respect. In the past decade, the number of parents who refuse vaccinations of any kind for their children has more than doubled.,But our dismissive attitude toward flu shots amounts to a  poor public health strategy. It not only makes the weakest more vulnerable, it also destabilizes the demand for vaccine in general, prompting vaccine makers to limit production â€” and that could lead to a critical shortage in the event of a flu pandemic.,Vaccination has inspired a degree of public loathing in America ever since 1721, when Cotton Mather introduced variolation, a primitive form of vaccination against smallpox, in Boston. It involved scratching live smallpox virus into a personâ€™s arm, and Bostonians found it alarming.,Over the next 200 years, vaccines improved, but public skepticism persisted. During the smallpox epidemics of the early 20th century, Americans rightly worried that unsanitary smallpox vaccinations could infect their children with tetanus and other bacterial diseases. People protested vaccination orders, sometimes violently. In one episode in Greenwood, Del., in 1926, a gang led by a former army lieutenant engaged in street fights that lasted several days.,But  World War II changed peopleâ€™s attitudes toward vaccines. Medics inoculated military recruits with vaccines against diseases like typhoid, yellow fever, tetanus and typhus. Some of the vaccines were pretty near experimental, yet our men survived, whipped the Axis powers and came home with a positive attitude toward public health.,By 1947, when a dozen people in Manhattan were infected by smallpox, six million New Yorkers lined up to have the vaccine scratched into the skin of their arms and legs upon the urging of Israel Weinstein, the city health commissioner.,The smallpox vaccine turned out to be far more lethal than the disease outbreak itself, which had claimed only two lives. The vaccine killed at least eight and in as many as 100 other people it caused side effects including severe rashes and brain damage. Yet no one publicly complained about this risk.,In the spring of 1955, Jonas Salkâ€™s polio vaccine was licensed. And although some early bad batches of it killed or paralyzed 174 people, a relieved nation recognized its greater benefit. Salk floated across the public stage like a white-jacketed saint.,With the advent of vaccines against measles, rubella and mumps, the 1960s became the golden age of vaccination. But gradually, people grew complacent about the good vaccines could do; the more vaccines eliminated disease, the less important they seemed.,Public apathy turned to distrust in 1998, when a new vaccine against rotavirus, which causes gastrointestinal illness in infants, showed signs of causing a bowel obstruction in very rare cases. The next year, Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories,withdrew the vaccine, RotaShield,  from the market.,Around the same time, pediatricians raised concerns about the use of a preservative, thimerosal,   in vaccines for children. Thimerosal contains only minuscule amounts of mercury, but as a precaution, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention asked vaccine makers to remove the preservative from pediatric vaccines.,By and large this new safety consciousness was a good thing, but caution also has its costs. The withdrawal of the RotaShield vaccine, which caused bowel obstruction in only about 1 in 20,000 children, meant that thousands of American infants who would otherwise have been vaccinated suffered severely dehydrating diarrhea. And in developing countries, where rotavirus kills hundreds of thousands of babies each year, the vaccine was never introduced.,The removal of thimerosal set off angry recriminations against vaccines in general. Thousands of parents of autistic children, searching for a way to explain their childrenâ€™s illness, settled on thimerosal-containing vaccines and began suing the drug industry and the government. Although these suits seem unlikely to succeed â€” no clear evidence of a link between thimerosal and autism has been found â€” they have already cost the industry hundreds of millions of dollars in court costs, and they have helped undercut public confidence in vaccination.,Parents are now especially reluctant to inoculate children against flu, because many flu vaccines contain thimerosal. But the tiny amount of thimerosal in the vaccines is not a health threat. There is always a small risk of unforeseen side effects, but it pales next to the harm done by influenza every year â€” and the harm it could do in the future if we have an inadequate supply of vaccine.,We donâ€™t know whether the deadly avian flu virus, which has claimed a small number of victims in Asia and Africa, will evolve in a way that allows it to sweep across the globe. But the experts are certain that it is only a matter of time before a flu pandemic strikes. Keeping the vaccine pipeline running and building immunity against all types of flu will  help us prepare. Even in apparently humdrum flu years like this one, it behooves us to join the herd and be vaccinated.
column4: For the Good of the Herd

column1: Charles Roselli set out to discover what makes some sheep gay. Then the news media and the blogosphere got hold of the story.,Dr. Roselli, a researcher at the Oregon Health and Science University, has searched for the past five years for physiological factors that might explain why about 8 percent of rams seek sex exclusively with other rams instead of ewes. The goal, he says, is to understand the fundamental mechanisms of sexual orientation in sheep. Other researchers might some day build on his findings to seek ways to determine which rams are likeliest to breed, he said.,But since last fall, when People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals started a campaign against the research, it has drawn a torrent of outrage from animal rights activists, gay advocates and ordinary citizens around the world â€” all of it based, Dr. Roselli and colleagues say, on a bizarre misinterpretation of what the work is about.,The story of the gay sheep became a textbook example of the distortion and vituperation that can result when science meets the global news cycle.,The news media storm reached its zenith last month, when The Sunday Times in London published an article under the headline â€œScience Told: Hands Off Gay Sheep.â€ù It asserted, incorrectly, that Dr. Roselli had worked successfully to â€œcureâ€ù homosexual rams with hormone treatments, and added that â€œcritics fearâ€ù that the research â€œcould pave the way for breeding out homosexuality in humans.â€ù,Martina Navratilova, the tennis star who is both openly gay and a PETA ally, wrote in an open letter that the research â€œcan only be surmised as an attempt to develop a prenatal treatmentâ€ù for sexual conditions.,The controversy spilled into the blog world, with attacks on Dr. Roselli, his university and Oregon State University, which is also involved in the research. PETA began an e-mail campaign that the universities say resulted in 20,000 protests, some with language like â€œyou are a worthless animal killer and you should be shot,â€ù â€œI hope you burn in hellâ€ù and â€œplease, die.â€ù,The news coverage, which has been heaviest in England and Australia, focused on smirk and titillation â€” and, of course, puns. Headlines included â€œEwe Turn for Gay Rams on Hormonesâ€ù and â€œHeâ€™s Just Not That Into Ewe.â€ù,In recent weeks, the tide has begun to turn, with Dr. Roselli and Jim Newman, an Oregon Health and Science publicist, saying they have been working to correct the record in print and online. The university has sent responses to senders of each PETA-generated e-mail message.,Dr. Roselli, whose research is supported by the National Institutes of Health and is published in leading scientific journals, insists that he is as repulsed as his critics by the thought of sexual eugenics in humans. He said  human sexuality was a complex phenomenon that could not be reduced to interactions of brain structure and hormones.,On blogs where attacks have appeared, the researchers point out that many of the accusations, like The Sunday Timesâ€™s assertion that the scientists implant devices in the brains of the sheep, are simply false.,The researchers acknowledge that the sheep are killed in the course of the research so  their brain structure can be analyzed, but they say they follow animal welfare guidelines to prevent suffering.,The authors of the Sunday Times article, Chris Gourlay and Isabel Oakeshott, referred questions to a managing editor, who they said was traveling and could not be reached.,Dr. Roselli and Mr. Newman persuaded some prominent bloggers, including Andrew Sullivan, who writes an online column for Time, to correct postings that had uncritically quoted The Sunday Timesâ€™s article. They also found an ally in the blog world: a scientist who writes under the pseudonym emptypockets and has taken up Dr. Roselliâ€™s cause.  The blogger, who spoke on the condition of anonymity because he said a public stand could hurt his career, said he had been cheered by the number of bloggers who dropped their opposition when presented with the facts.,Ms. Navratilova, who also received a response from the university, said she remained unconvinced.,â€œThe more we play God or try to improve on Mother Nature, the more damage we are doing with all kinds of experiments that either have already turned or will turn into nightmares,â€ù she wrote in an e-mail reply to a reporterâ€™s query. â€œHow in the world could straight or gay sheep help humanity?â€ù,In an interview, Shalin Gala, a PETA representative working on the sheep campaign, said controlling or altering sexual orientation was a â€œnatural implicationâ€ù of the work of Dr. Roselli and his colleagues.,Mr. Gala, who asked that he be identified as openly gay, cited the news release for a 2004 paper in the journal Endocrinology that showed differences in brain structure between homosexual and heterosexual sheep.,The release quoted Dr. Roselli as saying that the research â€œalso has broader implications for understanding the development and control of sexual motivation and mate selection across mammalian species, including humans.â€ù,Mr. Newman, who wrote the release, said the word â€œcontrolâ€ù was used in the scientific sense of understanding the bodyâ€™s internal controls, not in the sense of trying to control sexual orientation.,â€œItâ€™s discouraging that PETA can pick one word, try to add weight to it or shift its meaning to suggest that you are doing something that you clearly are not,â€ù he said.,Dr. Roselli said that merely mentioning possible human implications of basic research was wildly different from intending to carry the work over to humans.,Mentioning human implications, he said, is â€œin the nature of the way we write our grantsâ€ù and talk to reporters. Scientists who do basic research find themselves in a bind, he said, adding,  â€œWe have been forced to draw connections in a way that we can justify our research.â€ù,As for whether the deaths of the sheep are justified, he said, â€œwhy would you pick on a guy whoâ€™s killing maybe 18 sheep a year, when thereâ€™s maybe four million killed for food and clothing in this country?â€ù,Paul Root Wolpe, a professor of psychiatry at the University of Pennsylvania and a senior fellow at the universityâ€™s Center for Bioethics, said that although he supported Dr. Roselliâ€™s research, â€œIâ€™m not sure I would let him off the hook quite as easily as he wants to be let off the hook.â€ù,By discussing the human implications of the research, even in a somewhat careful way, Dr. Roselli â€œopened the doorâ€ù to the reaction, Dr. Wolpe said, and â€œhe has to take responsibility for the public response.â€ù,If the mechanisms underlying sexual orientation can be discovered and manipulated, Dr. Wolpe continued, then the argument that sexual orientation is based in biology and is immutable â€œevaporates.â€ù,The prospect of parentsâ€™ eventually being able to choose not to have children who would become gay is a real concern for the future, Dr. Wolpe said. But he added, â€œThis concern is best addressed by trying to change public perceptions of homosexuality rather than stop basic science on sexuality.â€ù
column4: Of Gay Sheep, Modern Science and Bad Publicity

column1: Scientists have built a memory chip that is roughly the size of a white blood cell,  about one-2,000th of an inch on a side.,Although the chip is modest in capacity â€” with 160,000 bits of information â€” the bits are crammed together so tightly that it is the densest ever made. The achievement points to a possible path toward continuing the exponential growth of computing power even after current silicon chip-making technology hits fundamental limits in 10 to 20 years.,The scientists, led by James R. Heath of the California Institute of Technology and J. Fraser Stoddart of the University of California, Los Angeles, will report their findings today in the journal Nature. As far back as 1999, Dr. Heath and Dr. Stoddart reported on aspects of their work , which included specially designed molecular switches and a novel technique for making ultrathin wires. The new work pulls the components into an integrated circuit.,â€œOur goal always was to develop a manufacturing technique that works at the molecular scale,â€ù said Dr. Heath, a professor of chemistry. â€œItâ€™s a scientific demonstration, but itâ€™s a sort of a stake in the ground.â€ù,The density of bits on the chip â€” about 100 billion per square centimeter â€” is about 40 times as much as current memory chips, Dr. Heath said. Improvements to the technique could increase the density by a factor of 10, he said.,But Dr. Heath said he did not know if this technique would be commercially useful. â€œI donâ€™t know if the world needs memory like this,â€ù he said. â€œI do know if you can manufacture at these dimensions, itâ€™s a fundamentally enabling capability.â€ù,For example, the wires used in the chip are about the same width as proteins, and that could make possible tiny circuits that could detect cancer or other diseases. The researchers are making transistors and simple logic circuits using similar techniques, Dr. Heath said.,A crucial component of the chip is its molecular switch, designed by Dr. Stoddart. The switch, which belongs to a class of molecules known as rotaxanes, looks like a dumbbell with a ring that can slide along the central bar. Voltage pulses push the ring between two positions on the bar, which represent the zeros and ones used by computers to store data. The dumbbell shape keeps the ring from sliding off.,To build the chip, the researchers etched 400 parallel wires, each less than a millionth of an inch wide and separated by about one-750,000th of an inch from its neighbors. On top of the wires, they deposited a layer of the molecular switches, the dumbbells standing vertically, and then a second set of 400 wires turned 90 degrees to the first set.,Each crossing point between two perpendicular wires, with about 100 of the molecular switches wedged in between, is the storage location of one bit of information.,While many researchers are looking for ways to make molecular-size electronics, most are still building circuits containing only a handful of bits, compared with the 160,000 in the new chip. That suggests the new process Dr. Heath and Dr. Stoddart developed can be scaled up to a viable manufacturing process, said Vivek Subramanian, a professor of electrical engineering and computer sciences at the University of California, Berkeley.,â€œThis is sort of the capstone in that theyâ€™ve pulled all this together,â€ù said Dr. Subramanian, who was not involved in the research.,Not everything about the chip works yet. When the researchers tested a small part of it, they found that only 30 percent of the bits actually worked.  But it is possible to use only the working parts of the chip, and the researchers successfully wrote and read information to those parts, though even there the success was temporary. The switches routinely broke after being flipped about 10 times.,The researchers readily  concede that their chip is merely a demonstration and is not refined enough for any applications. â€œWeâ€™re just happy it works,â€ù Dr. Heath said.
column4: Researchers Go Molecular in Design of a Denser Chip

column1: AT this time of year there isnâ€™t a lot to do in Warroad, Minn., a little town at the southwestern end of the Lake of the Woods, just a few miles from the Canadian border. There is no movie theater, the one bowling alley closed a while ago and the nearest shopping mall is in Grand Forks, N.D., two and half hours away across a windswept plain. You can snowmobile, but the snowfall has been a little skimpy so far this winter. Or you can ice fish, though until just a couple of weeks ago, when the temperature finally plunged to double digits below, it might have been unwise to drive a pickup out onto the lake.,Or like many Warroad residents, you can flock to the Gardens, the townâ€™s main ice rink, especially on a night when the Warroad High School Warriors are playing. What basketball is to Indiana and football is to Texas, hockey is to ,, a passion so intense that it borders on civic religion. And even in this hockey-mad state, Warroad, which bills itself as Hockeytown U.S.A. and displays a pair of crossed hockey sticks on the town water tower, is legendary for its fervor.,The Gardens is a kind of oasis â€” a place to see your neighbors, escape from the grind of a long northern winter and even enjoy a vicarious thrill or two, watching the Warriors cream Crookston or Thief River. Teenagers flirt here. Friends catch up on the news. Mothers bring their kids and let them zip around the lobby on their wheeled sneakers. The railbirds, the guys too nervous to sit, stand in the corner and never take their eyes off the ice.,â€œWhat else are you going to do up here?â€ù said Ruben Bjorkman, a longtime observer of the local hockey culture. â€œItâ€™s cold.â€ù,There are people who even make a point of attending not just the games but even the high school practice every afternoon, among them such local eminences as Mr. Bjorkman, a two-time Olympic player (1948 and 1952) who went on to a successful college coaching career and now keeps an eye on his grandson, Andy Stoskopf, a sophomore Warrior; and Gordon Christian, known for some reason as Ginny, who played for the 1956 Olympic team and is now the townâ€™s walking repository of hockey lore. For these men, and for lots of people in town, watching hockey isnâ€™t just a pastime, itâ€™s part of the fabric of small-town life.,The neighboring town of Roseau, 20 miles down Highway 11, is just as besotted, maybe more so, and the rivalry between them, going back 60 years or so, is probably the most famous and most intense in the  state. The teams play each other twice every season, and those two evenings are among the biggest events all winter. People look forward to them for weeks, and replay them in conversations for days afterward.,Like most great rivalries, this one is between two places that are more alike than not, and entails unspoken elements of fondness and respect as well as of enmity. There was some genuinely bad blood a couple of years ago when it was proposed that the county courthouse be moved from Roseau to Warroad, but in most respects Warroad and Roseau are siblings of a sort â€” little towns in the middle of nowhere that have evolved in much the same way and see each other almost as mirror images, real-life Lake Woebegons. Breanna Jackson, an 11th grader at Warroad High, explained the delicate nature of the relationship this way: â€œI could date a boy from Roseau, but I would never root for them.â€ù,ROSEAU, the county seat, is larger, with a population of 2,700, and to judge from some of the big, two-story houses in the residential neighborhoods, a little more prosperous. Warroad (population 1,700) has the prettier setting, along the lake and the Warroad River, and is socially more diverse, with a sizable Ojibwe population and a growing number of Hmong people from Laos. Both towns are the kinds of places where in wintertime people leave their cars and trucks running and unlocked while they do errands or stop off for a cup of coffee, the unofficial state beverage. And far from being wary or standoffish, the townspeople in both are startlingly, almost unnaturally friendly.,For places so small, both towns have nurtured an exceptional amount of standout hockey talent. This is in part because Warroad, with two rinks, and Roseau, with three, not to mention a couple of well-maintained outdoor rinks, offer hours and hours of instruction and ice time (all free) to local kids; and in part, no doubt, because the local culture inevitably turns hockey players into celebrities.,â€œThey , hockey here,â€ù said a Warroad student who was apparently one of the few nonbelievers in town.,Warroad has the edge in former Olympians, thanks mostly to a single family, the Christians: Ginny played on the 1956 team, his brothers Bill and Roger won gold medals with the 1960 team and also played in â€™64, and Billâ€™s son Dave played on the gold-medal-winning 1980 team. Roseau boasts more National Hockey League players, including four from a single block: Bryan Erickson, who played for four clubs in the â€™80s and early â€™90s, and the three Brotens: Neal, Aaron and Paul.,â€œGrowing up, I never dreamed of playing pro hockey,â€ù Mr. Erickson said recently. â€œI wasnâ€™t even the best player on my street.â€ù Neal Broten (one of the stars of the 1980 Olympic team) is considered by many the best college player in Minnesota history. The best high school player is probably Warroadâ€™s Henry Boucha, who spent parts of six seasons in the N.H.L. before getting butt-ended in the eye. But he is more famous for his heroic performance in what is often recalled as the best high school game ever, the 1969 state final between Warroad and Edina. Hockey fans in Minnesota actually remember these things.,This year, Roseau, ranked seventh in the state, was in theory a slight favorite, but the nature of the rivalry is such that rankings donâ€™t matter much and upsets happen all the time. To complicate matters, the brand-new Warroad coach, Bruce Olson, is himself a Roseau alumnus, and the most likely starting goalie for the Warriors, Jacob Vatnsdal, is a Roseau resident who  transferred to Warroad to get more playing time. The prospect of Jacob representing Warroad against Roseau delighted some in town but made others uneasy. â€œI wouldnâ€™t feel right doing that,â€ù said John Heneman, a banker and one of the town fathers. â€œPlay for my rival?â€ù,For budgetary reasons, Warroad had to cut out cheerleading this year, so on game day, Jan. 11, there werenâ€™t as many hallway signs as usual at the high school. But lots of girls and even some teachers turned up wearing yellow and black, the team colors, and some of them â€” the students, that is â€” were also in shorts or miniskirts. (Going bare-legged in midwinter is apparently a form of Minnesota machisma.) As is customary on game days, the members of the hockey team were all wearing neckties, and most of them were so wound up that going to class was torture.,In midafternoon, just as school was letting out, Tim Oshie, the junior varsity coach, organized what was billed as â€œA Night With the Roseau-Warroad Hockey Legends,â€ù 10 veterans from each town who happened to include six Olympians and five former N.H.L.â€™ers. They joked, swapped war stories and ribbed each other until Henry Boucha got serious for a minute.,â€œOne of the highlights of my career was playing in that state final that year,â€ù he said. â€œJust playing for your community, thatâ€™s the greatest gift for an athlete. The Olympics was the same type of deal, only there we were playing for a national community, the United States. Itâ€™s an immense feeling, like having sex for the first time.â€ù,An hour before game time the rink was more than half full, with people continuing to stream in from the parking lot â€” or lumber in, rather. It was 10 below, and the wind so sharp it sawed at your ears. Many families had made a night of it, with dinner beforehand at the Main Street Bar and Grill or at Shirleyâ€™s, across the street from the rink. The final attendance was estimated to be 2,800, not quite standing-room only because the game was televised on Fox Sports North, but nevertheless more than half the combined populations of the two towns, who greeted each other like relatives at a family reunion.,The crowd included at least four generations of hockey fans, if you count babies in plastic carriers, and all the essential high school subgroups: jocks, band kids, theater kids, bare-legged cuties, even a few goths. The Warroad band, which has a big-school percussion section, played â€œLouie Louieâ€ù and, when the team took the ice, the Atlanta Bravesâ€™ â€œTomahawk Chopâ€ù song. Over on the Roseau side, a kid wearing a giant green ramâ€™s head led a green-suited (and, in some cases, green-faced) cheering section. You could hardly hear yourself think.,THE game itself was about as good as high-school hockey gets, which is to say, as good as hockey gets: fast, intense and full of passion. Warroad jumped off to an early one-goal lead and clung to it through the first period, with the help of some acrobatic saves by Jacob Vatnsdal, who had been greeted by a hail of boos from the Roseau side but won  a lot of admirers among the locals, many of whom had never seen him play before. Still, Roseau scored a couple of power-play goals early in the second period and a third goal halfway through the third.,Warroad tried to rally behind the efforts of Aaron Marvin, who is among the best players in the state but was shadowed so closely it seemed as if vines were clinging to him. In the end Alex Bjerk, in the net for Roseau, made a couple of key saves and the clock ran down with Vatnsdal benched for an additional skater and the Warroad fans, down 3-1, still shrieking for one more chance. Afterward, the Roseau coach, Scott Oliver, who is from Winnipeg, said, â€œWhen I got here, I knew this game was big, but until youâ€™re in it, you have no idea.â€ù,Outside, it had dropped seven more degrees, and many fans drove home to hook their engine-block heaters up to electrical umbilical cords.,In just a couple of weeks, on Jan. 30, everyone would get to do this all over again cheer, suffer, exult, despair â€” only in Roseau this time, where the rink is much older than Warroadâ€™s 14-year-old building. The Roseau Memorial Arena is an old, wood-ceilinged ark of a place with a pine-paneled lobby dinged from decades of floor hockey games.,There is actually a brand-new rink in town, right next to the high school, but the Rams prefer the old one, where they and their fans can commune with the past.
column4: A Game? No, Itâ€™s a Life.

column1: If thereâ€™s one sure thing about the future, itâ€™s that it always takes longer to arrive than you think it will.,Here we are in 2007, and the interstellar space travel depicted in â€œ2001â€ù is still a sci-fi fantasy. Heck, we havenâ€™t even reached the society of mind control imagined in â€œ1984.â€ù (Insert your own joke about politics or advertising here.),So when the pundits tell you that the death of the DVD is imminent, that weâ€™ll soon get all our movies instantaneously from the Internet, some skepticism is in order.,Already, you can buy movies from iTunes, for example, but the selection is tiny (250 movies), and you pay about as much as you would for a DVD. CinemaNow and MovieLink offer online movie â€œrentalsâ€ù for about $4. But again, the selection is fairly small, at least once you subtract the mind-boggling gigabytes of B movies â€” more like C or D movies â€” like â€œAddicted to Murder III: Bloodlustâ€ù and â€œWitchcraft XI: Sisters in Blood.â€ù The copy protection is a bit overbearing, too. You can download a movie, all right, but it self-destructs 24 hours later.,All of these services permit you to start watching a movie after only a minute or so, before itâ€™s been fully downloaded â€” but you canâ€™t fast forward (or, in some cases, even rewind) until youâ€™ve got the whole thing on your hard drive.,Last week, a new contender entered the field with a radically different approach to Internet movies: Netflix.,Now, this isnâ€™t the first time â€œradically differentâ€ù was applied to a Netflix business model. Its main service, renting DVDs by mail, entails no per-movie fee, no late fees and no shipping fees.,Instead, you pay a flat monthly fee to â€œcheck outâ€ù a certain number of DVDs at a time â€” $18 for three, for example. You keep them as long as you like. When you mail one back in its postage-paid, pre-addressed envelope, Netflix sends you the next one on your wish list automatically. So far, about six million people have signed up. (Blockbusterâ€™s similar DVD-by-mail service is also increasingly popular, thanks in part to a recently introduced twist: if you return a DVD to a Blockbuster store instead of mailing it, you get a free in-store rental on the spot.),Once again, Netflix has rewritten the rules â€” this time, of the online movie-rental game. The company has done away with expiration dates, copy protection and multi-megabyte downloads. Thatâ€™s because you donâ€™t actually download any of Netflixâ€™s movies; instead, they â€œstreamâ€ù in real time from the Internet to your computer. (This advantage comes with a key disadvantage: you must be connected to the Internet. Wireless hot spots at airports and hotels are fair game, but movies canâ€™t be carried around on a laptop.),Netflix has also done away with per-movie fees â€” in fact,  there are no additional fees for watching movies online at all. Instead, the Netflix service is free if youâ€™re already a Netflix DVD-by-mail subscriber. When you log in to Netflix.com, you see a new tab called Watch Now. It opens what looks like a duplicate set of the companyâ€™s usual excellent movie-finding and movie-recommending tools, except that you now see ,buttons beneath each movieâ€™s icon: Rent and Play.,(If you donâ€™t see the Watch Now tab yet, itâ€™s because Netflix is rolling out this service in phases to  250,000 customers at a time, to be completed by June. The idea is to avoid a technical meltdown. Your time will come.),The first time you click Play, youâ€™re sent a tiny software blob that takes under a minute to install, and doesnâ€™t require restarting your browser or PC. After that, when you click Play, the movie loads for a few seconds and then begins playing, right there in your Web browser. Thatâ€™s it: one click. No special program, no confirmation boxes, no credit card charges, no copy-protection hassles. The movie just begins to play â€” full-screen, if you wish. You can jump to any spot in the movie, although the movie takes a few seconds to â€œcatch upâ€ù each time you use the scroll bar.,Even more startling: Your movie watching is measured by time, not by individual movie title or by individual viewing.,The hours of movie watching you get each month depends on which DVD-by-mail plan you have. You get one hour of online movies per dollar of your monthly fee. So if you pay $6 a month (for the one-DVD-at-a-time plan), you can watch six hours of movies online; if you pay $18 (for the three-DVD plan), you can gorge yourself on 18 hours of online movies. And so on.,This innovative metering system has one minor drawback: rewinding to watch a favorite scene eats up a few more minutes of your monthly allotment.,But the huge, mind-bending, game-changing advantage of this model is that you can channel-surf movies just the way you channel-surf TV. You can watch 15 minutes of â€œSingle White Female,â€ù decide youâ€™re more in the mood for a documentary, and switch over to â€œSuper Size Me.â€ù When a buddy tells you that â€œTwisterâ€ù is lame except for the climactic final sequence, you can fast-forward right to that part. You can watch the beginning of â€œGladiatorâ€ù tonight, and watch the rest of it a month later, without having to re-rent it or pay late fees.,Or you can casually sample one movie after another, looking for something that grabs you.,Movie surfing like this has never been possible before. All other movie delivery formats require you to make your movie choice based only on the box shot, the movie trailer and a synopsis.,(Starzâ€™s Vongo service comes close; it offers unlimited movies for a flat $10 monthly. But you have to download a movie before you can watch it, which rules out this sort of casual real-time movie surfing.),Netflix-by-Internet, in other words, is deliciously immediate, incredibly economical and, because it introduces movie surfing, impressively convention-shattering.,It will not, however, change the way most people watch movies in the short term, for many reasons.,First, it works only on Windows PCs at the moment; a Macintosh version is in the works.,Second, only 1,000 movies and TV shows are on the Play list. Thereâ€™s lots of good, brand-name stuff here â€” â€œZoolander,â€ù â€œChinatown,â€ù â€œJaws,â€ù â€œSleepless in Seattle,â€ù â€œTwisterâ€ù and so on â€” but Netflixâ€™s lawyers and movie-studio negotiators have a long way to go before the number of movies online equals the number of DVDs available from Netflix (70,000). Still, the company says that at least 5,000 movies will be on the list by yearâ€™s end. So far, the sole holdout among major movie studios is Disney, perhaps because of its partnership with Appleâ€™s movie service.,Third, you generally get only the movie â€” not the DVD featurettes, alternate languages, subtitles, directorâ€™s commentary and so on.,Fourth, you canâ€™t control the video quality you get. Your movies arrive in one of three resolutions, depending solely on the speed of your broadband Internet connection. In the Basic version (for slow connections), the image is blurry and somewhat unsatisfying, like bad VHS. At Good, the picture looks about like regular TV. At High, youâ€™d swear youâ€™re looking at a DVD: razor-sharp image, superb color and shadows, perfect smooth motion. (Note to geeks: the Basic, Good and High versions correspond to minimum broadband speeds of 0.5, 1 and 1.6 megabits per second.),A prominent speed meter on the Netflix page tells you which version youâ€™ll get. You can click this graph repeatedly as you move your laptop around in an effort to improve your wireless signal.,Finally, remember the biggest drawback of Internet movie services: Only a nerd would gather the family around the PC to watch a movie.,The masses have yet to connect their computers to their TV sets. Only then will the decline of the DVD begin in earnest. Only then will the futuristsâ€™ fantasy of instant access to any movie, any time become a reality.,When that day arrives, Netflix, for one, will be ready.
column4: A Stream of Movies, Sort of Free

column1: Waterfront residential and hotel development., Miami Beach., A marina and a rooftop bar and garden, among others., Residences range from $400,000 to $6 million., Expected to open in December., Morgans Hotel Group., (877) 809-0007 or ,., Fronting Biscayne Bay on the west side of Miami Beach, this is the first project by Morgans Hotel Group â€” the owner of the nearby , hotel, the Royalton in New York,  the Mondrian in , and a new Mondrian expected to open next week in ,, Ariz. â€” that will include residences. There will be 342 units, including  studios, one- and  two-bedroom suites and four penthouses, all in a renovated 16-story  apartment building. The units will include furniture by Marcel Wanders, who is also the interior and landscaping designer of the project, and  will be sold in whole ownership. They  may be placed in a revenue-sharing rental program when owners are away. A bar in the lobby will extend outdoors to a pool area, which will have a cafe and cabanas, and inside there  will be a fine-dining restaurant, a lounge and a spa and fitness center. Residents and guests will have access to the beach at the Delano., Residential project at a ski area., ,, Colo., Ski-in, ski-out access, a full-service spa and a fitness center, among others., Residences range from $415,000 to $4.5 million., Construction is scheduled to begin this spring and should be finished in 2009., Timbers Resorts and SV Capital., (866) 599-4626 or ,., This project, approved earlier this month, is at the base of 10,568-foot Mount Werner in Steamboat Springs, about 150 miles northwest of ,. It will include 78 residences in a six-story building adjacent to a gondola. All units will range from 2,500 to 4,700 square feet, and they will be divided into 36 whole-ownership units with four to five bedrooms and 42 furnished units with four bedrooms that will be sold in one-eighth shares.
