Yet while most of his new album was recorded in Nashville, Mr. Seger hasnâ€™t gone country so much as country has pumped itself up.,Mr. Segerâ€™s new songs are grounded in riffs that echo the Rolling Stones, Bruce Springsteen and the Who, and they have a growing streak of middle-aged disillusionment. â€œNo Matter Who You Are,â€ù with piano chords out of the Whoâ€™s â€œBaba Oâ€™Riley,â€ù observes, â€œThis is an ancient test, this is a shiny lie/Discover somethinâ€™ pure then sit and watch it die.â€ù,The album also has some political songs â€” the anti-Iraq-war song â€œNo Moreâ€ù and the environmentalist â€œBetweenâ€ù â€” but Mr. Seger left them out of the live set. The concert was an affirmation of tenacity, of coming to terms with time; not defying it, like a Rolling Stones concert, but living with its consequences. One of the ballads Mr. Seger sang was â€œBeautiful Loserâ€ù: â€œHe wants to dream like a young man, with the wisdom of an old man.â€ù It was a song he released back in 1975.
column4: A Rocker Whoâ€™s Come to Terms With Time

column1: Long viewed as the domain of grandmothers, needlework has undergone an image makeover in the last decade. Snowboarders, the old torchbearers of alt.culture, have embraced crocheting, making beanies to wear on the slopes; coffeehouses and subways are filled with fashion-conscious types busily knitting or doing needlepoint. And contemporary artists like Andrea Zittel, Lisa Anne Auerbach, Orly Genger and Jim Drain and the Forcefield collective have given crafts a coolly conceptual edge.,Time then for an exhibition celebrating the unfrumpiness of craft, and, sigh, what better institution than one that recently went through its own makeover, changing its name from the American Craft Museum to the sexier Museum of Arts & Design?,The sorry news is that, despite its title, â€œRadical Lace & Subversive Knitting,â€ù with around 40 works by 27 artists, is not a benchmark for introducing such craftsâ€™ coolness or radicalism to a vast art audience. Rather than exploring transgressive takes on knitting, the exhibition, organized by David Revere McFadden, the museumâ€™s chief curator, devotes most of its space to art that mimics the look or logic of knitting and lace and translates it into different materials.,In an essay in the showâ€™s catalog, Mr. McFadden does invoke interactive performances held in abandoned warehouses and the London Underground and people who knit sweaters for â€œoil-spill-damaged penguins to wear in Antarcticaâ€ù â€” the kind of activities you might associate with radical or subversive practice.,But in choosing the work for the show, he cites somewhat dated textile and crafts-based artists like Sophie Taeuber, Sonia Delaunay, Judy Chicago and Magdalena Abakanowicz as his models.,Much of the art on view is in the large-scale, virtuosic craft vein. Henk Wolversâ€™s flat sculptures created with porcelain slip, a form of liquid clay, borrow the tracery if not the actual patterns of lace. Piper Shepardâ€™s â€œLace Meanderâ€ù is a series of hanging muslin scrolls into which the artist cut lace patterns with an X-Acto knife. Bennett Battaileâ€™s delicate sculpture of thin glass rods and Barbara Zuckerâ€™s rubber sculptures both invoke lace-tracery in heavier materials.,Some of the artists address â€œissues of politics, gender and ethics,â€ù as a wall text puts it, in a general way. Janet Echelmanâ€™s giant, hand-knotted nylon net hanging from the ceiling in the museumâ€™s entryway recreates the look of a nuclear mushroom cloud. Freddie Robinsâ€™s sinister-looking gray-knit bodysuit, with the words â€œCraft Killsâ€ù emblazoned across the chest, alludes to the airline ban on knitting needles in the post-9/11 era.,The works most in keeping with the showâ€™s politically charged title are more interactive and collective, or more related to performance. For example, Cat Mazzaâ€™s collectively crocheted â€œNike Blanket Petition,â€ù a campaign against sweatshop practices represented here in a series of photographs, will be sent to Nikeâ€™s corporate headquarters.,A video of Dave Coleâ€™s â€œKnitting Machineâ€ù project shows two John Deere excavators wielding telephone poles tapered to look like knitting needles â€” and missiles â€” to knit a giant American flag in the courtyard of the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art in North Adams, Mass.,Sabrina Gschwandtner, an artist and founder of KnitKnit magazine, has set up a â€œWartime Knitting Circleâ€ù surrounded by panels made of industrially knitted photos of Vietnam War protesters knitting, British women knitting woolen covers for World War II hand grenades, soldiers knitting during World War I.,She invites people to join her in knitting â€œblankets for recoveryâ€ù for people in Afghanistan and troops convalescing in military hospitals, among other projects. (On the exhibitionâ€™s opening day, Ms. Gschwandtner was chatting and knitting with Phyllis Rodriguez, whose son died in the north tower of the World Trade Center on 9/11 and who has since befriended AÃ¯cha el-Wafi, mother of Zacarias Moussaoui, a French citizen of Moroccan descent serving a life sentence  after his conspiracy conviction in the 9/11 attacks.,Needlework indeed has a radical past. William Morris, a mainstay of the Royal School of Needlework and the Arts and Crafts movement in England, protested late-19th-century industrial production. Feminist art in the 1970s drew heavily on so-called womenâ€™s work, and Rosemarie Trockelâ€™s â€œknitting picturesâ€ù of the 1980s cleverly drew on political themes.,So many more artists might have been included whose work explores the social aspects of knitting and lace or who more radically recast these forms: Simon Perotin, of the punk-doily creations; the artisans in the Church of Craft; Ms. Zittel; Ms. Auerbach;, Mr. Drain; and so on.,Given the showâ€™s title, some visitors will arrive wanting to know how needlework, which runs counter to our technology-  and information-saturated age, has become such a cultural juggernaut, and how it might serve to break down the barriers between artist and amateur, art and craft. A few works here may well satisfy that desire. Most will not.,â€œRadical Lace & Subversive Knittingâ€ù runs through June 17 at the Museum of Arts & Design, 40 West 53rd Street, Manhattan. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 8 p.m. on Thursdays); closed on holidays. Admission: $9; $7 for students and 65+; and pay-what-you-wish on Thursdays after 6 p.m. Information: (212) 956-3535;,.,A series of public programs related to the exhibition is planned, including lectures, panel discussions, performance pieces and workshops in knitting, lace-making, crocheting, fabric-making, fabric-printing and digital design. Some events are free with museum admission;  others require an additional fee that includes admission.,Beginning tomorrow and running every Sunday from 2 to 4 p.m. through June 3 will be â€œWell Crafted Weekends: Inter-Generational Workshops,â€ù for those 6 and older;  $7 per person or per family  (up to four  people). A detailed schedule is on the Web site.
column4: Flair and Flash, Not Frumpiness

column1: A silhouette of old lace blows across a screen above the stage, tangling with  the shadows of the performers singing below. Then the shadows free themselves of the singers and begin to dance, as if giving life to the dreams in the music.,Visuals were an important part of the Austrian Cultural Forumâ€™s two-week â€œMostly Operettaâ€ù festival, which ended on Thursday with a program that fell into the â€œmostlyâ€ù category: the American songs of Kurt Weill. Enhancing each of the festivalâ€™s five recital programs was a subtle screen-play of shadow and light by the installation artist Victoria Coeln. The shadows mingled with photographs and videos taken in Ms. Coelnâ€™s studio to create moving shadow images like pressed flowers with wisps of color at their edges. Smoky and ephemeral and restrained so that they enhanced but never intruded on the performances, they were a thoughtful visualization of nostalgia.,The festival focused on the â€œsilver ageâ€ù of operetta in 20th-century Vienna (following the 19th-century â€œgolden ageâ€ù of Strauss and Offenbach). Operetta is tricky: potentially as sparkling and sophisticated as Champagne, it is often produced today as a kind of Kool-Aid punch, overbright and oversweet and with very little appeal to a discriminating audience.,Ms. Coelnâ€™s visuals were a wonderful antidote. The difficulty  â€” to judge from Jan. 18â€™s program, focusing on composers forced to emigrate by the Nazis, and Thursdayâ€™s Weill evening  â€” appeared to lie in freeing the performers from stock clichÃ©s to attain the same kind of sophistication.,The concept of presenting operetta excerpts like lieder, in an intimate setting with piano accompaniment, was partly dictated by the limitations of the forumâ€™s tiny concert hall. It ran a bit aground on the realities of a form that emulates the climactic bigness of opera. In the program of â€œexiledâ€ù composers, Elisabeth Flechl and Johannes FÃ¶ttinger belied the notion that native specialists bring more insight or liedlike subtlety to operetta by simply pumping out one number after another until their voices were spent.,Ms. Flechl was the more vocally limber, but sang even â€œMeine Lippen, sie kÃ_ssen so heissâ€ù (â€œMy lips give hot kisses,â€ù the signature aria from Franz Leharâ€™s â€œGiudittaâ€ù) with generic earnestness, failing to convey an ounce of seductive sexuality.,More successful was Ute Gfrerer, the soloist in the Weill program (also accompanied by Markus Vorzellner, a staunch pianist), who arranged the songs into a kind of dramatic monologue, was more attuned to the nuances of her texts and tempered her singing with a cabaret sensibility, digging into her chest voice when appropriate. She was helped by some pretty great songs like â€œLost in the Stars.â€ù The evening made a strong case for both Weill and his lyricists.,But all this did, alas, was reinforce the idea that operettaâ€™s main value in this country was as a precursor of the classic Broadway musical. To truly reanimate the genre on a level consistent with Ms. Coelnâ€™s visuals, it would take a singer like the 94-year-old Marta Eggerth, who in the course of a discussion/performance on Jan. 11 sang a piece by Lehar, her old friend, â€œWarum hast du mich wachgekÃ_sst?â€ù from â€œFriederike.â€ù She showed how a pro can breathe life into an operetta excerpt  â€” and also that the form is a dying art unless other singers can learn from her and save it.
column4: Operetta and Weill in Front; Moving Shadows in Back

column1: As any nature show will demonstrate, mammals use several methods for marking their territory.,The species commonly known as artist has untold ways, however; one might, for example, perch on the lap of every audience member, as Trajal Harrell did to start his â€œShowponyâ€ù on Thursday night at ,. Straddling crossed legs, he seemed at once defiant and helpless, simultaneously driven by and luxuriating in the ritualistic task.,This duality textured the length of the 70-minute performance, which took the shape of a fashion show. Two rows, each with 43 chairs, flanked a corridor of vinyl flooring, giving everyone a front-row seat to watch Mr. Harrell, Katy Hernan and Christina Vassiliou strut their stuff.,Both women are strong performers, and Ms. Vassiliou possesses a perfectly stony, of-course-Iâ€™m-sexy modelâ€™s mien. (You sensed that the expression never changed even when she donned a ridiculously grotesque clownâ€™s mask). But Mr. Harrell owned the runway, from his rigidly thrown-out hips to his wonderfully expressive fingertips.,At the same time, he fractured the audienceâ€™s attention. As the dancers, matching Mr. Harrellâ€™s restless soundtrack, changed clothes frequently and rapidly, they moved from jagged, hyper interpretations of runway behavior to robotic movement phrases reminiscent of early postmodern dance in their mundane repetition, but undertaken with a desperate urgency.,At one point Ms. Hernan was transported by what you assume  was a simulated orgasm, head thrown back and body writhing in one of three empty seats in the audience that the performers employed; the middle-aged woman next to her crossed her arms and legs defensively, and the athletic man on her other side smiled and looked away. Both concentrated on the other dancers; nobody else could look away from Ms. Hernan.,Such extravagance of desire elevated material that was also unapologetically camp and sentimental and silly. His territory claimed, Mr. Harrell made it completely his own, even including a lengthy photographic slide show of his choreographer peers. Edited by David BergÃ©, the pictures slid by one after the next, as mesmerizing as they were banal.,Audience members and performers sat together in the darkness of St. Markâ€™s Church, properly reverent in what is, after all, a place of worship.
column4: Fashion Rituals and Runway

column1: â€™s streamlined readings of the Russian and German repertory are an acquired taste (though one worth acquiring), and his relatively rare forays into American repertory have been well meaning, if unpersuasive. But there is no one to touch him in Italian music, and that was what he brought to the , on Thursday evening, the start of his second week of subscription programs with the orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall.,Mr. Mutiâ€™s message was that there is more to Italian Romanticism than opera â€” although he touched on opera as well â€” and to that end he devoted the first half of his program to Giuseppe Martucciâ€™s enormous Piano Concerto No. 2 in B flat minor (Op. 66), with Gerhard Oppitz as the soloist. Martucci has been scarce in New York: the Philharmonic last performed this concerto in 1911. But Mr. Muti recorded it (along with Martucciâ€™s evocative â€œCanzone dei Ricordiâ€ù) for Sony Classical in 1995, and he has kept it in his repertory, perhaps betting that accidental encounters will win this composer a new audience.,He is on to something. This is a virtuoso concerto (Martucci was, not surprisingly, a pianist), so solidly packed with explosive, daredevil keyboard writing that it isnâ€™t until well into the 20-minute first movement that the orchestra has much of substance to offer. When the orchestra does take its stand, its contributions are currents of lyricism or subtle but ear-catching shifts in color, to contrast with the showiness of the piano writing.,Still, itâ€™s the piano that rivets the ear, and if you look past the layer of surface bluster youâ€™ll find magnificently detailed and at times almost Brahmsian keyboard writing.,Mr. Oppitz was an ideal soloist. He attacked the work with all the vigor it demanded, and played with muscularity, clarity and, in the central Larghetto, a poetic touch. He and Mr. Muti made a powerful case: this concerto may not be the Beethoven â€œEmperor,â€ù but it makes a welcome change from, say, the Tchaikovsky First.,After the intermission, Mr. Muti led a taut account of the ballet music from Verdiâ€™s â€œMacbeth,â€ù a fine warm-up for the real business of the second half, Respighiâ€™s â€œFeste Romane.â€ù Pictorialism runs deep in Italian music as far back as Monteverdi, and Respighi reveled in it. Here the orchestra evokes everything from the roaring lions at the ancient Circus Maximus, to parades of chanting penitents, to sloppy inebriates, all vividly.,Mr. Muti had the Philharmonic playing at full throttle, with no loss of either tone or precision. This orchestraâ€™s brasses, which got a thorough workout, have rarely sounded better.
column4: Italian Romanticism From a Rarely Heard Source

column1: If Rossini had been in the audience on Thursday night at the Harry de Jur Playhouse, he would surely have found the stylish and witty new production of â€œIl Signor Bruschinoâ€ù by the Gotham Chamber Opera as cheekily funny as everyone else did.,The revival was overdue. â€œIl Signor Bruschino,â€ù the last of five one-act farces Rossini wrote for the Teatro San MoisÃ¨ in Venice between 1810 and 1813, was last staged in New York in 1933, according to the Gotham company.,In this frothy, youthful comedy, Rossini experiments with the comic gift for mistaken identities evident in his later opera â€œIl Barbiere di Siviglia.â€ù The Venetian poet Giuseppe Maria Foppa wrote the libretto for â€œBruschino,â€ù based on â€œLe Fils par Hazard,â€ù a French farce. Two young lovers, Florville and Sofia, want to marry. But Florville is the son of an enemy of Gaudenzio, Sofiaâ€™s guardian, who in any event has already promised her to the eminent Bruschino family. Florville waylays and impersonates the legitimate groom, then convinces Gaudenzio that he is Bruschinoâ€™s son.,Thanks to Robin Guarinoâ€™s clever directing, an opera that could be mere bumbling slapstick is sharp, with snappy comic timing. Donald Eastmanâ€™s set updates the action to the Via Veneto in Rome in about 1960. The costume designer Martin Pakledinaz presents Florville, sung by Alek Shrader, as a sort of ,, and Sofia, sung by Lisa Hopkins, as a demurely dressed ,.,There were other Felliniesque touches, like a Vespa, a bicycle, a priest and a scampering little boy who knocks on a door to mirror the moment in the overture when the violinists tap their music stands with their bows.,â€œIl Signor Bruschinoâ€ù has plenty of tongue-twisting recitative and vocal acrobatics, but none of the strong cast seemed trapped in a coloratura torture chamber. At times they even made a merry farce of Rossiniâ€™s bel canto obstacle course.,There was fiery chemistry between Ms. Hopkins and Mr. Shrader, both promising performers, who sang with good phrasing and control. Eric Jordan gave a fine, confident performance as the jovial,  fabulously named Gaudenzio Strappapuppole, who almost seems a personification of Rossini, a cheery, witty gourmand.,Signor Bruschino was updated from a generic buffo character to an oily, scholarly-looking, suit-clad neurotic, excellently acted and sung by Marco Nistico.,As the maid Marianna, Emily Langford Johnson was a sexy, Sophia Loren-like flirt, while Filiberto, the burly barman, was sung with aplomb by Matthew Lau.  Steven Goldstein, as the police commissioner and priest, was also strong.,Neal Goren, Gothamâ€™s artistic director, conducted a lively, tight performance of the chirpy score. Rossini reportedly declared that he was â€œborn for opera buffa.â€ù On Thursday night it seemed that this cast had been as well.
column4: Young Lovers, a Vespa and a Frolic by Rossini

column1: Not everyone wants to perform pure traditional gypsy flamenco. A grass-roots genre of flamenco Latino has sprung up in New York in recent years. The program presented by Andrea Del Conte Danza EspaÃ±a on Thursday night at the Joyce SoHo fits somewhere between those styles, but never created the crucial flamenco feeling of an internal fire reaching up into the soul from the core of the earth.,Ms. Del Conte, an American who trained in ballet before taking on Spanish dancing, was closer to the traditional in her Seguiriyas and Farruca, but without that fire. A sweet-faced, elegant woman, she might have been the youngish director of a school for young  dancers. Barbara Martinez, who sang and danced, made something fresh of the Latino style in several numbers. But Marco de Ana was unprepossessing, a major problem for a male flamenco artist, in a company of dancers completed by Mieko Sato and Sol Koeraus.,The musicians were more fun, in an ensemble that included Alfonso Cid, Arturo Martinez, Cristian Puig and Sean Kupisz. The eveningâ€™s choreographers included Juana Cala and JosÃ© Galvan.
column4: Flamenco That Finds Its Fit in a Space Between Two Styles

column1: Four men, their backs to the audience, stand in a line upstage at the beginning of George Balanchineâ€™s â€œAgon.â€ù Then they turn, and Stravinskyâ€™s bright fanfare of trumpets heralds the start of the ballet that, in Balanchineâ€™s words, used history as â€œthe takeoff point.â€ù,Stravinsky used a French Baroque dance manual as the basis for his score; Balanchine deployed the academic vocabulary of classical ballet. And yet dance history was changed by â€œAgon,â€ù with its angular, tensile movements that perfectly matched the composerâ€™s astringent forays into 12-tone technique.,Audiences must have been hardly able to register visually the compressed, unconventional movement when the ballet had its premiere in 1957; even today the choreography, with its unexpected transitions and acrobatic tension, can surprise, and in the best performances always does.,One of those performances came from an almost all-new cast at the New York City Ballet on Thursday night, when â€œAgonâ€ù was danced with a uniformly spiky intensity and a sensitivity to the rhythmic interplay between the music and the movement. Andrew Veyette gave a lovely sinuousness to his â€œSarabandeâ€ù solo, and Ellen Bar was coolly seductive in her â€œBransle Gayâ€ù solo and the subsequent pas de trois, balancing unworriedly in arabesque as her two partners switched sides.,But it was Maria Kowroski, more familiar with her part, who electrified the whole work in the pas de deux that is at its heart. With her long, hyper-flexible limbs, Ms. Kowroski can sometimes look unanchored in space, but here every movement was diamond sharp and dazzling. SÃ©bastien Marcovici, making his debut, partnered with subtlety and skill.,Another explosive performance came at the end of the evening, from Sterling Hyltin, new to her role in â€œSymphony in Three Movements,â€ù and just as riveting. Ms. Hyltin came flying onto the stage with huge, traveling jumps â€” Balanchineâ€™s jazzy knees-together surprise opener to another major Stravinsky score â€” and she often looked as if she might rocket offstage. In a good way.,Amar Ramasar, new to the cryptic yet poignant central pas de deux, worked well with Jennie Somogyi â€” curiously sluggish in her solo sections â€” and nicely conveyed the wit and humor within the balletâ€™s jagged, lighting-bolt aesthetic.,Also on the all-Stravinsky-Balanchine program was â€œMonumentum Pro Gesualdoâ€ù and â€œMovements for Piano and Orchestra,â€ù both authoritatively headed by Charles Askegard and Rebecca Krohn; and â€œDuo Concertant,â€ù in which Nikolaj Hubbe,  partnering Yvonne Borree, was a spirited delight.,The orchestra, conducted by FayÃ§al Karoui,  occasionally sounded patchy, but gave â€œSymphony in Three Movementsâ€ù a fine, propulsive performance.
column4: Finding a Famous Pairâ€™s Intensity and Sensitivity

column1: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26 â€” Use of Genentechâ€™s new eye drug, Lucentis, might raise the ,, the company said Friday.,The company posted on its Web site a letter it  sent to retina specialists this week. According to the letter, 1.2 percent of patients treated with a high dose of Lucentis in a clinical trial suffered a stroke, compared with only 0.3 percent of those treated with a low dose. The difference was statistically significant.,The new findings could conceivably damp some demand for Lucentis, because the high dose, 0.5 milligrams per injection, is the one that is marketed. Shares of Genentech  fell 89 cents, or 1 percent, to $86.57.,Dawn Kalmar, a spokeswoman for Genentech, said Friday that the company wanted to move quickly to communicate the information. But she  said the company did not expect  the new data to prompt a change in the drugâ€™s label, which already contains a warning about risks of blood-clotting events like strokes.,Lucentis, also called ranibizumab,  is approved to treat age-related macular degeneration, the leading cause of blindness in the elderly. It is the first drug shown in clinical trials to improve eyesight for a significant number of patients, as opposed to merely slowing the rate of vision loss.,Approved in June, the drug had sales of $380 million for the rest of 2006, an amount that greatly exceeded some analystsâ€™ expectations.  Genentech executives have cautioned, though, that sales growth may moderate as patients on the drug are treated less frequently.,The new data was preliminary, from 2,400 patients who had been followed for an average of 230 days since beginning treatment. The full study will continue and will follow them   for a year.,Dr. Philip J. Rosenfeld, a retina specialist, said the preliminary data would not influence him because it could later change.,â€œRight now, it will have no impact on my use of Lucentis,â€ù Dr. Rosenfeld, who is at the Bascom Palmer Eye Institute of the University of Miami, said in an e-mail message. â€œWhen given a choice between a high likelihood of blindness or a 1 percent risk of stroke, I think most patients will choose their vision.â€ù,The label for Lucentis notes a theoretical risk of blood-clotting events like strokes and heart attacks, though it says the rate seen in studies was â€œlow,â€ù at less than 4 percent.,In the new study, the rate of heart attacks and deaths from cardiovascular incidents did not differ significantly between the  dosages, the company said.,The new findings could also raise questions about the risks of Avastin, a , drug sold by Genentech. It is  being used off-label to treat macular degeneration because it is far cheaper than Lucentis, which costs about $2,000 per monthly injection. Both drugs work by a similar mechanism, although Lucentis was specifically designed to be injected into the eye.,Doctors who use Avastin say they have experienced few if any safety problems. But Avastin has not been tested in extensive controlled clinical trials as Lucentis has.
column4: Eye Drug Might Raise Risk of Stroke, Genentech Says

column1: â€™s chauffeur was so stressed by his job that eight of his teeth fell out because he was grinding them at night, according to court papers filed by his lawyer.,The chauffeur, Koral Karsan, 50, complained about his teeth in a taped conversation with Ms. Onoâ€™s lawyer, Jonas Herbsman, which the prosecution turned over to Mr. Karsanâ€™s lawyer, Robert Gottlieb, in advance of a bail hearing yesterday.,Mr. Karsan has been charged with trying to extort $2 million from Ms. Ono, and prosecutors said he threatened to kill her if she did not comply.,But in  court papers, submitted as part of a bail application for Mr. Karsan, Mr. Gottlieb said the accusation that Mr. Karsan had people waiting to kill Ms. Ono was â€œjust plain false.â€ù,On the recording, Mr. Gottlieb said that Mr. Karsan can be heard saying that there are â€œa lot of people out there who want to getâ€ù Ms. Ono.,The chauffeur then went on to describe those people as â€œmy psychiatrist, my dentist, my lawyer,â€ù Mr. Gottlieb said. Mr. Karsan added, according to his lawyer, that â€œtheyâ€™re all Beatles fans and they hate her. So they all want to use me.â€ù,Commenting on this part of the tape, Mr. Gottlieb said in his papers, â€œWe respectfully submit that this should come as no shock to anyone who is at all familiar with Yoko Ono and the Beatles.â€ù,Mr. Gottlieb added that the tape showed that the demand for money was not extortion, but a demand for compensation for pain and suffering.,Prosecutors have described this tape as one of their most important pieces of evidence â€” along with a letter from Mr. Karsan to Ms. Ono â€” in the extortion case against Mr. Karsan.,But Mr. Gottlieb said that the only reference to killing came when Ms. Onoâ€™s lawyer asked for the name of Mr. Karsanâ€™s lawyer, and Mr. Karsan refused, saying that his legal team was â€œready to kill Yoko.â€ù,To which Ms. Onoâ€™s lawyer asked if he was speaking metaphorically. Mr. Karsan, a Turkish immigrant, replied, â€œNo, no, no, no metaphorically, Iâ€™m telling it literally.â€ù By this, Mr. Gottlieb said, Mr. Karsan clearly meant that his lawyers â€œwould literally kill her in court.â€ù,Barbara Thompson, a spokeswoman for the Manhattan district attorney, declined comment last night on Mr. Gottliebâ€™s account of the tape.,Mr. Gottlieb quoted from the tape in a letter to Justice Daniel P. FitzGerald of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, in an effort to have his client released on bail.,In a brief hearing yesterday, Justice FitzGerald declined to set bail because of the risk that Mr. Karsan would flee to Turkey. He said that after listening to the tape, he saw â€œno substantial change in the material facts,â€ù that is, the demand for $2 million and the threat to release confidential information about Ms. Ono.,But he agreed to Mr. Gottliebâ€™s request for a speedy trial, setting a tentative trial date of Feb. 12.
column4: Onoâ€™s Driver Complained About Stress on Recording

column1: Herding freelancers is a bit like herding cats. Both are notoriously independent.,Nonetheless, Sara Horowitz has figured out a way to bring together tens of thousands of freelancers â€” Web designers, video editors, writers, dancers and graphic artists â€” into a thriving organization.,Ms. Horowitz has founded the Freelancers Union, offering members lower-cost health coverage and other benefits that many freelancers often have a hard time getting.,A former labor lawyer, Ms. Horowitz intends to form a forceful advocacy group for freelancers and independent contractors,  the most mobile members of an increasingly mobile work force. In addition, she is trying to adapt unions to a world far different from yesteryear, when workers often remained with one employer for two or three decades.,â€œThis really is about a new unionism,â€ù she said, â€œand what it means is to bring people together to solve their problems.â€ù,Having signed up 40,000 freelancers from the New York area, she is now planting her groupâ€™s flag across the nation, hoping to herd far more of the nationâ€™s 20 million freelancers and independent contractors into her union.,â€œThese workers are the backbone for so many industries vital to our nationâ€™s economy â€” I.T., financial services, the arts, advertising and publishing,â€ù she said. â€œYet these same workers are not afforded simple job protections or a social safety net.â€ù,By creating a new type of union for nontraditional workers, Ms. Horowitz hopes to help revive the labor movement. Its membership has slipped to just 7.4 percent of the private-sector work force, down from one-third in 1960.,Unlike traditional unions, the Freelancers Union has no intention of bargaining with employers. Still, Ms. Horowitz says her groupâ€™s main goal is identical to that of all unions â€” providing mutual aid, in this case health benefits, to their members.,â€œMore and more people are not going to get their benefits from an employer,â€ù Ms. Horowitz said. â€œOur ultimate goal is to update the New Deal. It is to create a new safety net thatâ€™s connected to the individual as they move from job to job.â€ù,Jennifer Lebin joined the Freelancers Union while living in Manhattan after seeing one of its subway ads that say, â€œWelcome to Middle-Class Poverty.â€ù Ms. Lebin, a political consultant, bought the groupâ€™s health coverage and paid $20 to attend a union-sponsored seminar offering tax advice to consultants and independent contractors.,Ms. Lebin, who has moved to Chicago, expressed disappointment that she could no longer use the unionâ€™s health plan â€” doctors in Illinois are not part of the network. â€œIf there is a way that the Freelancers Union could offer the same benefits to members outside the New York area, Iâ€™d sign up in a heartbeat,â€ù she said.,The Freelancers Union, which sells benefits Ã  la carte, hopes to offer health benefits in 10 states by the end of this year. It is already offering its discounted disability and life insurance nationwide.,More than 14,000 freelancers in the New York area have bought  its health insurance, generally for about $300 a month, some 40 percent below what they would normally pay elsewhere. The organization has also used its group purchasing power to help freelancers obtain discounted dental, disability and life insurance.,Membership in the Freelancers Union is free. To finance itself, the group uses an entrepreneurial model:  it earns modest commissions on the benefits that its members buy.,Robert Bruno, a professor of labor relations at the University of Illinois at Chicago, praised the groupâ€™s innovative approach, although he said it could not replace traditional unions.,â€œThis needs to be part of laborâ€™s repertoire,â€ù Professor Bruno  said. â€œTo the degree it helps to reshape what weâ€™ve come to understand what a labor organization is, itâ€™s all to the good.â€ù,Ms. Horowitz, 44, won a MacArthur genius award in 1999 after she established Working Today, a  group based in Brooklyn that focused on providing benefits to New Yorkers in flexible work arrangements. She founded the Freelancers Union in 2003, with a more ambitious vision.,The group intends to do advocacy work just like a labor union. In New York, it is backing legislation to let freelancers obtain unemployment insurance. Even if freelancers are laid off after working for an employer for two years, they cannot receive unemployment benefits because they are considered independent contractors.,Some members do not expect the group to play the role of a traditional union.,â€œUnions represent members in negotiating wages and benefits,â€ù said Barbara Scott, an artist in Berlin Center, Ohio. â€œI donâ€™t see the Freelancers Union functioning that way. I see it as a networking tool.â€ù,Bobby Ambrose, a graphic designer in Chicago, disagreed.,â€œI was hoping that they would be like a labor union,â€ù Mr. Ambrose said. â€œThere are a lot of situations that freelancers face regarding pay rates and job hours, like when youâ€™re doing full-time work when youâ€™re only hired to be part time. It would be nice if they could push to make things better.â€ù,Several traditional unions are studying the freelance unionâ€™s progress, perhaps to borrow some  ideas on organizing nonunion workers and offering benefits.,â€œThe labor movement,â€ù Ms. Horowitz said, â€œwent from guilds through mutual aid societies through craft unions and through industrial unionism. Youâ€™re not going to persuade me that there is not going to be a new form of unionism. The storyâ€™s not over on what weâ€™re creating.â€ù
column4: Labor Union, Redefined, for Freelance Workers

column1: Just off the tip of Venezuela, Trinidad and Tobago is a small dual-island nation where three distinctive musical sounds â€” steel pan drum, calypso and soca â€” evolved. Calypso, a lilting style of Afro-Caribbean music, developed as a means of communication between African slaves. Soca is a modern form of calypso with an up-tempo beat. Half a century ago, Trinidadian percussionists invented pan by hammering out the ends of discarded oil drums. Today, visitors will find musicians practicing at so-called panyards throughout Port of Spain, the capital, especially in the weeks leading up to the islandâ€™s winter Carnival, which begins just after Christmas and runs into February.,Highlights of the celebration, which takes place in Trinidad, include Panorama, an annual steel pan drum competition to be held on Feb. 17 this year; Kings and Queens Costume Competition (Feb. 18),  in which  leaders of each masquerade band don elaborate costumes that can reach up to 30 feet in height and weigh as much as 200 pounds; and the final two days of Carnival bacchanal (Feb. 19 and 20).,Tobago will host its third annual jazz festival the last week in April. This year, Elton John and Gladys Knight are among the stars scheduled to perform.,A word of caution:  incidents of violent crime, including armed robberies of tourists, have been on the rise on both islands. The United States Embassy advises that when making reservations at private accommodations, visitors ensure that 24-hour security is provided. The government of Trinidad and Tobago has stepped up police patrols in tourist areas to deter crime.,Share your own suggestions for where to go out on , and ,., During Carnival, hotel rates range from $300 to $500 a night at the Courtyard by Marriott (888-236-2427, ,), Hilton Trinidad & Conference Center (800-445-8667, ,) and Coblentz Inn (868-621-0541, ,).,Share your own suggestions for where to stay on , and ,.
column4: For Clubgoers: Trinidad and Tobago

column1: A former executive with Computer Associates who pleaded guilty to securities fraud and who prosecutors said was instrumental in the prosecution of the companyâ€™s former chief executive, Sanjay Kumar, was sentenced to seven months in prison and seven months of home detention.,The executive, Ira Zar, the former chief financial officer, pleaded guilty in 2004 and has cooperated with authorities in the prosecution of Mr. Kumar and the companyâ€™s former sales chief, Stephen Richards.,Mr. Zar, 45, also pleaded guilty to two counts of conspiracy and was sentenced by Judge I. Leo Glasser of United States District Court in Brooklyn. He was also ordered to serve two years of supervised release after the completion of his sentence. No fine was imposed and restitution will be determined at a later date.,The company, based in Islandia, N.Y., has since changed its name to CA Inc.
column4: Ex-Executive of Computer Associates Receives Prison Sentence

column1: TRENTON, Jan. 26 â€” Five people have been arrested on charges that they ran a drug ring that had sold more than  $20 million worth of painkillers, or one million pills, law enforcement officials in New Jersey announced on Friday.,Attorney General Stuart Rabner, flanked by state police and federal Drug Enforcement Agency officials, said at a news conference that the scheme had been operating for more than a year, and that it had sold 20,000 to 30,000 OxyContin and Percocet pills per week, mostly through  distributors based in the Bronx. Mr. Rabner also said  the drugs found their way to people seeking a heroin substitute in New York, Pennsylvania, Connecticut and Massachusetts.,OxyContin, a narcotic pain reliever similar to morphine, has become a popular street drug in recent years. In perhaps the most celebrated case, Rush Limbaugh, the conservative talk-radio host, settled a prescription drug fraud charge  against him last spring after  an inquiry into whether he illegally obtained OxyContin from more than one doctor.,In the New Jersey case, the authorities said that Mohmed Hassanain, 41, ran the operation out of his business, Lyons Avenue Auto Sales in Newark.,But the operation had a suburban sheen to it as well, according to officials. Mr. Hassanain ran some of the business out of his house in West Orange, just a couple of blocks from the Essex County Country Club.,He employed a doctor from Livingston, Mario Comesanas, 51, who wrote 300 fraudulent prescriptions a week in exchange for $30,000 cash each week,  the authorities said. They contend that Mr. Hassanainâ€™s cousin, Ahmed Felix Aly, a pharmacist who lives in Union Township, would then fill the  prescriptions at his business, RGN Pharmacy, in Newark.,Mr. Rabner and Gerard P. McAleer, special agent in charge of the D.E.A.â€™s New Jersey division, described the operation as significant when compared with other pharmaceutical rings in the state.,New Jersey officials acknowledged that a statewide tracking system meant to monitor possible abuses did not provide investigators with the initial lead; rather, a member of the general public did. Asked whether that system needed to be improved, Mr. Rabner said, â€œAs with all investigations, we learn a great deal about how people operateâ€ù and added that state officials planned to â€œfollow up on those lessons.â€ù,The five people accused of being members of the drug ring were arrested late Thursday in a sweep of 10 places in New Jersey. The authorities  found several guns, including a .357 Magnum, and at Dr. Comesanasâ€™s home was several hundred thousand dollars in cash, they said. Mr. Hassanain, meanwhile, had $10,000 in his sleeve when he was arrested, they said.,Mr. Hassanain and Mr. Comesanas pleaded not guilty to the charges Friday afternoon in Essex County Superior Court in Newark. Mr. Hassanain was being held in $1.5 million bail and Mr. Comesanas in $1 million.  Judge Michael J. Nelson ordered that both men surrender their passports and scheduled a bail hearing for Wednesday.,Lawyers for both men said they had just received copies of the complaint and declined to comment.
column4: Five Arrested in New Jersey in Illegal Sales of Painkillers

column1: For many years, foreign chefs â€” many of whom were brought in to run the kitchens of Anguilla's high-end resorts â€” dominated the culinary scene on this northernmost of the Leeward Islands in the Lesser Antilles. But over the last several years, local chefs who trained at those same resorts have been opening their own restaurants and adding  new twists to traditional dishes.,Among the best known is Dale Carty, who worked at Malliouhana, before opening a high-end restaurant  called , in 1999. His interpretations of traditional Anguilla cuisine include Stewed Chicken Grandmas Style and Steamed Fish n' Fungi with Provisions, which Mr. Carty said uses a polenta-like cornmeal and â€œfood from the earthâ€ù like yams, sweet potatoes and pumpkins.,In 2004, Gwendolyn Smith, a native Anguillian, was made executive chef at ,, a restaurant in a building originally constructed in the 1700s as part of a sugar and cotton plantation. While most of her experience in the kitchen was gained on the island, Ms. Smith also honed her pasta skills at Il Bottaccio di Montignoso, a Relais & ChÃ¢teaux hotel in northern Tuscany. On her menu: Island Pea Soup made with pigeon peas and local sweet potato and Rock Oven Chicken, which is slow-roasted in a 200-year-old-oven and must be ordered 24-hours in advance.,Another native, Vernon Hughes, who began his career as a dishwasher at Anguilla's Cinnamon Reef resort, has opened his own restaurant, called E's Oven, on the site of his mother's old stone oven. His cousin and mentor, George Reid, the executive chef at Cap Juluca, has been fostering local talent for the last four years by hiring high school graduates to work as apprentices in the resort's three restaurants. Many of them go on to work at any of the island's 100 restaurants.,., ,, on the southwest coast of the island, has a beautiful beach, Moorish-style villas and three restaurants. Rates start at $825 a night through mid-April (888-858-5822,  ,). , grows its own vegetables on a hydroponic farm. Rooms start at $685 a night in season (800-943-3210,  ,). Carimar Beach Club at the water's edge on Mead's Bay has rooms for $365 in season (800-235-8667,  ,).,.
column4: For Foodies: Anguilla

column1: Finding the perfect island to satisfy everyone on a family vacation can be quite a challenge. The kids are tired of the beach by noon and need something else to do. Dad wants to golf all morning and lie on the beach all afternoon. And Mom just wants to retreat to the spa. Plus, any place that requires changing planes is too much of a hassle, and if you or your spouse want any chance of watching the sunset in peace, a resort without a babysitting program is out of the question.,Consider Aruba, 15 miles off the coast of Venezuela. It takes less than five hours to fly there nonstop from New York. Many major airlines offer direct flights from the United States, with some advance fares running as low as $129 each way not including taxes or fees. Regular rates are in the $400 range.,Families will find a wide variety of kid-friendly accommodations with activities ranging from windsurfing to snorkeling to scavenger hunts. There is no shortage of chain hotels, ranging from the Holiday Inn to the Hyatt Regency, each offering its own kids program. And, yes, many of them also have elaborate spas.,Beyond the resorts, the island has dozens of quirky attractions that appeal to a kid's curiosity, including a butterfly farm, a donkey sanctuary and â€œSnubaâ€ù tours, which involve a breathing apparatus that allows kids as young as 8 to descend to a depth of 20 feet with the aid of an instructor. And for grown-ups, there are dozens of casinos and nightclubs.,Still not convinced? Because United States Customs and Immigration agents are stationed at Aruba's airport, American travelers can clear customs before they leave the island, eliminating long lines â€” and children's whining  â€” back home.,., The all-inclusive , is popular with families who don't like hidden costs. Rates start at  $454 a night now through March for up to two adults and two children in one room. Meals and snacks at seven dining spots and many  activities are included (800 554-2008,  ,). Prices start at $235 a night at the ,, from Jan. 27 to March 2 (800-465-4329,  ,). Rates start at $449 a night at the Aruba Marriott Resort & Stellaris Casino through mid-April (800-223-6388,  ,).,.
column4: For Families: Aruba

column1: Like Aspen and St.-Tropez â€” this tiny island in the French West Indies, better known as St. Barts, remains a preferred playground of the rich and famous.,For years, models, music moguls, and corporate tycoons have flocked there for its elite hotels, water-side restaurants, unspoiled beaches and laid-back attitude.  David Letterman and Diddy, a k a Sean Combs,  are among the regulars. In November, the pop star Usher was spotted on the island. So was Paul McCartney. Jon Bon Jovi was there just after Christmas. And the fashion designer and former model Kimora Lee Simmons spent the holidays on the island â€” an annual family ritual.,Want to join them? Be prepared to pay. Demand is high at the two-dozen hotels on the island, which pushes room rates up. During high season, which runs from November to April, it's not unusual to find prices for basic rooms starting around $600. One-bedroom villas, which are more plentiful, can often be had for less.,There are plenty of restaurants.  With views of the harbor and sunsets beyond, Maya's is one of the most popular for dinner. ,, perched high on a hill, is another favorite  spot that serves Thai-influenced dishes. For a break from the glitterati, head to Le Select, one of the island's oldest and most laid-back bars.,The main dock in Gustavia Harbor is the place to see the big wigs and their big boats. Ron Perelman's 187-foot yacht Ultima III was among the megayachts parked there at the end of December.,Among the newest options for travelers: the ,l St. Barths has just completed a $25 million renovation. Five new beachfront villas and eight beachfront rooms have been added bringing the total to 32. Scheduled to open later this year is a four-bedroom villa dubbed the Rock Star Heaven House that will feature a 14-seat  dining table, a garage stocked with cars and motorbikes and a media room with sound and film editing capabilities.,Partied out? Saline Beach is said to be the island's best stretch of sand.,., The Eden Rock, St. Jean Bay, St.-BarthÃ©lemy. Prices start at 650 euros (about $840 at one euro to  $1.29) a night in the high season, which runs through April 15 (590-590-29-79-99, ,). ,,  on the northeast side of the island, overlooking Marigot Bay; rates start at 565 euros  including breakfast (590-590-27-66-60, ,). ,, about a 10-minute drive from the beach, offers 15 basic rooms starting at 170 euros a night  (590-590-52-95-50, ,).,.
column4: For the Celebrity-Starved: St.-BarthÃ©lemy

column1: AT a tasting in 1984 at the International Wine Center, a wine school in Manhattan, Peter M. F.  Sichel, a seasonal South Fork resident, pointed to a bottle labeled Vin de lâ€™Ile Blanc and said, â€œTry that.â€ù Mr. Sichel,  then a major figure in Germanyâ€™s wine industry (he has since retired),  has a masterly understanding of whites. I tried it, and was charmed.,A semidry riesling, it resembled a Mosel wine. Vin de lâ€™Ile Blanc, whose name  translates as White Wine of the Island, was made by Ray Blum, a grape-grower who lived in Peconic and had founded Peconic Bay Vineyards in Cutchogue in 1980. It was that bottle that sparked my interest in the local industry .,Mr. Blum, a genial, seemingly ever-smiling man, died of cancer  on Jan. 10 at the age of 62.  The owner of Ackerly Pond Vineyards in Peconic, he sold grapes and wine under that label and planted and maintained othersâ€™ vineyards.,Vin de lâ€™Ile Blanc symbolizes the debt that early colleagues and their successors owe to Ray Blumâ€™s risk-taking.,At the outset, conventional wisdom doubted the prospects for riesling on the East End. It was as if nature and man told Mr. Blum,  â€œYou canâ€™t,â€ù and he replied, â€œOh, yeah?â€ù   He prevailed, attracting  customers to  his homey tasting room on Main Road with his Vin de lâ€™Ile Blanc and other wines.  Today, respectable rieslings remain minor gems at some North Fork wineries.,Mr. Blum sold his property in 1999   to  Ursula and Paul Lowerre, who  renamed it Peconic Bay Winery.   The winemaker, Greg Gove,  said, â€œWe were going to do away with Vin de lâ€™Ile Blanc, but we discovered there was a following for it, so we kept it.â€ù  He went on producing the wine, but recently the owners decided to replace it with another wine in a different style, he said.  After the last 28 cases are sold, it will be history.,The nonvintage Vin de lâ€™Ile Blanc, now a $12 riesling-chardonnay blend, is described by the winery as having  â€œluxuriant notes of pineapple, honeysuckle, fresh apple and pear.â€ù,Mr.  Blum bequeathed Long Islanders a sweet memory.
column4: In the East End, Riesling Legacy

column1: ALBANY, Jan. 26â€” Gov. , said on Friday that he would seek billions of dollars in Medicaid and health care cost savings when he unveils his first executive budget on Wednesday.,But while he repeatedly used the word â€œreformâ€ù in a speech here, hospital groups heard the word â€œcut.â€ù That dissonance will probably set the stage for what could be a fierce battle in the Legislature over the governorâ€™s plan.,â€œFor too long, we have financed the health care system we have, not the health care system we need, so weâ€™re left pumping billions of dollars into a broken system,â€ù Mr. Spitzer said. â€œWhat went wrong is that health care decision making became co-opted by every interest other than the patientâ€™s interest.â€ù,Among the governorâ€™s proposals were eliminating the annual inflation adjustments on Medicaid payments to hospitals and nursing homes and substantially changing the way the state subsidizes health care providers and graduate medical programs.,â€œNew York spends more on hospitals and nursing-home care than any state in the nation,â€ù he said. â€œThis spending is unsustainable and unwise.â€ù,He said his administration would seek to save $200 million annually by taking steps to reduce Medicaid prescription drug costs and overhaul the Department of Health. He said he would also follow up on his campaign pledge to provide coverage for the stateâ€™s 400,000 uninsured children.,The proposals sent shudders through some corners of the health care world.,â€œThese are many of the same budget cuts that Governor Pataki proposed, and they were rejected because, frankly, they arenâ€™t reforms,â€ù said Daniel Sisto, the president of the Healthcare Association of New York State.,â€œBy his tone today, he intends to make it a serious fight,â€ù he said. â€œThe Legislature knows that these cuts, now two decades old, do not constitute reform. Iâ€™m working on the assumption we can persuade them to reject them.â€ù,But many were pleased by what they heard, from fiscal conservatives who have called for an end to Albanyâ€™s spending growth to  health care advocacy groups.,â€œWe think he is taking a very bold step and putting New York in the lead in the nation in terms of providing health care coverage for children,â€ù said Donna Lawrence, executive director of the Childrenâ€™s Defense Fund New York.,Edmund J. McMahon, the director of the Empire Center for New York State Policy, an affiliate of the policy group the Manhattan Institute, said, â€œI think he set exactly the right tone. The patient-first premise is exactly where we need to be, and I think itâ€™s a very positive step.â€ù,Mr. Spitzer said the state was paying far more on graduate medical education than other states â€” $77,000 per  medical resident  compared with $21,000 in California.,â€œWe discovered that many of those dollars are going to pay for phantom residents and doctors who donâ€™t even exist,â€ù he said.,Mr. Sisto said he objected to what he called the â€œprosecutorial rhetoricâ€ù in the governorâ€™s speech and his description of past deals.,â€œWe should be having a policy debate about the future, not lamenting the past,â€ù he said.,Mr. Spitzer specifically criticized a 2002 deal involving Gov. George E. Pataki and 1199 S.E.I.U. United Healthcare Workers East that was used in part to provide raises for health care workers. â€œAs a result of this deal, well over $3 billion alone was pumped into the health care delivery system with little or no accountability,â€ù he said. A spokeswoman for the union did not return calls seeking comment.,Kenneth E. Raske, the president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said, â€œCuts to me do not spell reform, particularly when the hospital sector is not at all driving the increases in Medicaid.â€ù,Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, a Manhattan Democrat who is chairman of the Assemblyâ€™s Health Committee, said getting the proposals through the Legislature would â€œdepend on a lot of the details.â€ù,â€œSome of the Medicaid cuts will create problems, but I think the policy directions are terrific,â€ù he said. â€œThere is certainly an enormous amount here that I will fight very hard to enact.â€ù
column4: Spitzer Sees Health Savings; Hospitals Call Them Cuts

column1: ITâ€™S like Restaurant Week all year long at Gabrielleâ€™s Brasserie in ,. This appealing spot,  formerly 22 North Park under the same owners, changed its name, its chef and its menu in late November.  It  now offers a three-course dinner for $25 that is sure to be a hit with patrons who love good food but donâ€™t want to break the bank every time they eat out. That price includes everything on the menu: no exceptions, no supplements. It is offered all night â€” not just during â€œearly birdâ€ù hours â€”   every night of the week. It was even in place on New Yearâ€™s Eve.,The $25 meal is a story;  the quality and quantity of the food here, which is intensely flavorful and stylishly presented,  make it a compelling one.  Jeffrey C. DeVille,    a graduate of the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y.,  is the executive chef.   He has  worked alongside Susan Spicer at Bayona in New Orleans and under Mario Batali at Lupa in Manhattan;  his last position was as sous chef at 105 Harbor in Cold Spring Harbor.,Tom Schaudel, Long Islandâ€™s peripatetic restaurateur, served as the consulting chef  and helped develop the new menu.,It is an exciting one, with a dozen appetizer picks, the same number of entree choices and about a half-dozen desserts. (There are also specials.) The appetizer Iâ€™d make a beeline for is pan-seared rock shrimp cakes with a perfect avocado-pineapple salsa. There was also a pleasing crabcake special atop a crunchy kimchi salad, but the shrimp cakes,  with their arresting, chunky texture,  put it in the shade.,Fork-tender ribs (four meaty ones), accompanied by a green papaya slaw and a log of cornbread, were a hearty and delicious opener.  So was  the gratin of Long Island oysters: four large ones in their shells combined with Boursin cheese and cubes of spicy andouille sausage. The grilled and roasted veggie plate sounded light but was actually large enough to pass as an entree. It included mounds of hummus, tapenade and roasted red peppers and arrived with grilled pita.,The adventurous were rewarded with a special of grilled smelts atop a mÃ©lange of roasted sweet potato cubes and what our waiter called fava beans.  They looked and tasted like   black beans; in any case,  they were seductively good.,Entrees were  equally appealing. The braised lamb shank was a fall-away-tender success atop roasted root vegetables and three-cheese polenta. Other winners were perfectly turned-out salmon over a barley pilaf, pan-seared flounder with leeks, tomato and capers and a chewy yet flavorful hanger steak with crunchy toasted gnocchi and spinach.,Speaking of gnocchi, the menu offers  these light potato dumplings in a flavor-packed sauce with tomato, zucchini, lemon and cheese, generously crowned  with grilled shrimp. (I counted nine in my dish.) Also hitting the high notes was fettuccine in a Bolognese sauce that had a bit of a spicy kick.,The eight-ounce Kobe burger was cooked medium-rare as ordered and came with terrific crisp fries and the desired sautÃ©ed onions but also sported a cap of unadvertised melted mozzarella. I would have preferred it without the  cheese.,Desserts also delivered. I loved the  New Orleans-style bread pudding with sourmash custard and the exceptionally moist and rich molten chocolate cake. A shortbread shortcake with mixed berries was another winner.,Servers were as excited about the new restaurant and its food as the diners were. On one evening, the service was nearly perfect; on a second night, our server was enthusiastic but tended to guess about ingredients rather than check with the kitchen. On  both nights, busboys did a great job refilling water glasses and replacing bread baskets with fresh ones. (The rolls in those baskets were just average, though.),The restaurant may look just like its predecessor, but the $25 three-course dinner makes this more than just the same old place with a new name., Striking yet sedate dining room with an aquarium and arresting curved panels of multicolored stained glass hanging from the ceiling. Complete wheelchair access.,Casual small groups and couples. Very few children., A wall of colored glass squares forms an ever-changing color and light show. There are a few cozy booths for two and an adjacent lounge area with leather chairs and  couch. Diverse wine list of 36 bottles, $22 to $35; 19 wines by the glass, $6 to $14., Three-course lunch, $10 or $15. Sunday brunch, $20,  includes a cocktail. Three-course dinner, $25 (higher Ã  la carte). American Express, MasterCard, Visa and Discover Card accepted.,Rock shrimp cakes, spare ribs, gratin of Long Island oysters, grilled and roasted veggie plate, grilled smelts, salmon, flounder, lamb shank, hanger steak, fettuccine Bolognese, gnocchi with shrimp, molten chocolate cake, bread pudding, berry shortcake.,Lunch Tuesday through Saturday, noon to 4 p.m.; Sunday brunch, 11 a.m. till 3 p.m. Dinner 5 to 10 p.m. Sunday and Tuesday through Thursday, till 11 p.m. Friday and Saturday. Closed Monday. Reservations  for parties of six or more.,Reviewed  Jan. 28, 2007
column4: Three Courses for $25, All Night, Every Night

column1: Norma Turner, 14, is her motherâ€™s daughter. Her mother, Kareen Brown, held a recent portrait of the two of them, which showed  their striking resemblance.  The same eyes, same face, same tendrils of  hair, the same happiness shines out of the picture.,They also suffer from  a disorder  that puts them both at high risk for developing cancer and subjects them to numerous preventive operations. â€œItâ€™s in the family, the genes,â€ù Ms. Brown, 35, said.,In 2002, Ms. Brown  was sick. She was in the hospital, but she did not know what was causing the terrible pain in her stomach  or the bleeding from her rectum.,Norma, who keeps all the details of the treatment in order, told the story:   â€œShe felt something wet. She just got up and saw the bed was messed up with blood.â€ù,Ms. Brown had colon cancer. She was in the operating room before she even knew what was happening. Afterward, she spoke to the doctor. â€œHe said, â€˜Do you know what you have inside of you?â€™ I said, â€˜No,â€™ â€ù she remembered. â€œIt was a tumor. I was so sad.â€ù,â€œI didnâ€™t know what to do, like Iâ€™m lost,â€ù she continued. â€œI was saying, â€˜Iâ€™m going to die? Leave her? Whatâ€™s going to happen?â€™ It was scary. A lot of people die of cancer.â€ù,Ms. Brown received a diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis, a genetic condition that causes thousands of tiny polyps to develop on the wall of the colon.  If left untreated, the polyps usually develop into cancer.,â€œThey say it was just ready to spread. Iâ€™m lucky. Iâ€™m lucky,â€ù Ms. Brown said. But the polyps keep coming. Ms. Brown had four operations in as many years. From November 2005 to February 2006, a major  infection kept  her in the hospital. Norma lived with a great-aunt and Ms. Brown, on life support and unable to eat, lost 80 pounds.,Ms. Brown was the first in her family to receive the diagnosis. Her father, two brothers, and a twin sister  have the same disorder. In May, Norma also received a diagnosis of the disorder. The polyps in her colon would require surgery.,Ms. Brown said she was in disbelief after learning that her daughter would have to be operated on.  â€œOh my God, at the age of 14,â€ù Ms. Brown said. â€œShe was too young.â€ù,In September, Norma underwent a seven-hour surgery to remove the polyps. â€œThere was a 50-50 percent chance of me getting a colostomy bag,â€ù Norma said.,The night before the surgery, â€œThey put a tube up my nose and inserted it in my stomach,â€ù Norma said. It was awful, she said, adding that she remembered asking, â€œWhy did my grandfather have to have this sickness?â€ù,She does not remember much of that morning. â€œAll I remember, I said goodbye to my mother,â€ù she said. Ms. Brown added: â€œShe was strong. She was brave.â€ù,â€œI remember I woke up,â€ù Norma continued. â€œI remember seeing Stephanie there.â€ù Stephanie Mendell, a social worker at New Alternatives for Children, has been working with Norma since shortly after the disorder was diagnosed.,New Alternatives provides preventive services for families with medically fragile children and is a member agency of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, one of seven agencies supported by The ,.,Because doctors were able to save enough of Normaâ€™s colon, she did not need a  colostomy bag. Every six months she will require a colonoscopy to check for polyps. Ms. Brown hopes that her own colostomy bag will  be removed this spring. But the disorder remains: doctors found two more polyps in Ms. Brownâ€™s intestines in December.,While struggling to treat the disease, Norma and Ms. Brown were also struggling with not having a stable home environment. In August 2005, they moved into a basement apartment in the Bronx after spending about six months in a homeless shelter.,The $825 rent is covered by Housing Stability Plus, a Department of Homeless Services program, and a preventive subsidy from the cityâ€™s Administration for Childrenâ€™s Services. Ms. Brownâ€™s monthly income is $178.50 from public assistance, supplemented with $144 in food stamps.,The disease should qualify her for Supplemental Security Income. But Ms. Brown, an immigrant from Jamaica and a legal resident, is not a citizen, which makes her ineligible. â€œShe canâ€™t qualify for S.S.I., and she absolutely canâ€™t work,â€ù said Ms. Mendell, who is helping her apply for citizenship.,This winter, $1,070 from Neediest Cases was used to buy them winter clothing, bedding and pajamas.  The money was also used to buy twin beds, an improvement over the one bed they had to share. â€œOne, Iâ€™m not kicking her,â€ù Norma said. â€œAnd two, weâ€™re not fighting for blankets.â€ù,Norma, an eighth grader, is still catching up on school work that she missed while she was recovering from surgery. â€œNormaâ€™s an amazing kid,â€ù said Ms. Mendell, noting the girlâ€™s resilience. â€œI just look at her as someone with a lot of potential, who really wants to do well, and can do well, given the right opportunity.â€ù
column4: In Fighting Disorder, Family Stays Vigilant

column1: Thereâ€™s an autumnal air surrounding  â€œThe Cocktail Hour,â€ù A. R. Gurneyâ€™s 1988 play,  and not just because of the necklace of orange and brown leaves encircling the Long Wharf stage. The play deals with a waning world. Two, in fact.,Mr. Gurney still writes wonderfully thoughtful and witty plays that range widely in theme and subject matter. But his best-known works are those that chronicle the withering of what we must call, for lack of a better term, WASP America. Itâ€™s an America well known in ,, where itâ€™s easy to imagine the Prescott Bushes saying things like â€œDonâ€™t be unattractiveâ€ù to one another as they sip Scotch before dinner, their living room filled with antiques and the piano topped with family photos.,Long Wharfâ€™s first-rate revival  takes place in just such a living room (courtesy of Michael Yeargan, the set designer), and while the family having drinks includes neither senators nor presidents-to-be, Mr. Gurney deftly conveys the way Americaâ€™s ruling elite maintained its place at the head of the social, political and economic pecking order through much of the 20th century. Sons who might have preferred to build boats went into business instead. Daughters who might have preferred to go to work stayed instead to tend the home fires. Wives aching for adventure doused their desires with alcohol.,And everyone followed the rules: You didnâ€™t use a word like â€œpenisâ€ù in the living room; you avoided self-scrutiny of any kind, especially the kind abetted by psychiatrists; you didnâ€™t sell your blue chips, ever; and you didnâ€™t sully the graceful flow of conversation with anything as jarring as a fact.,Similar rules applied in the theater you went to. But like John, whose visit home is the occasion for the cocktails in â€œThe Cocktail Hour,â€ù Mr. Gurney has lost patience with the rules. So he bends them: John has returned to ask his parents, Bradley and Ann, for permission to mount the play he has written about them â€” a play that sounds suspiciously like the one weâ€™re watching.,So there are two narratives unfolding here. One is Mr. Gurneyâ€™s gently acerbic take on Bradley and Ann; their docile daughter, Nina; and their not-so-docile son John, who , use the word â€œpenisâ€ù in the living room. The other is Mr. Gurneyâ€™s slyly amusing commentary on the play he has written â€” the script sits on the coffee table throughout the performance â€” and on theater itself. And both are very well served in this production, directed by Long Wharfâ€™s associate artistic director, Kim Rubinstein.,Ms. Rubinstein gets special credit for hiring John Cunningham to play the old-school dad â€” a poseur whoâ€™s also the real deal, a skinflint whoâ€™s also ready to write a $20,000 check to get his son to do what he wants. Mr. Cunningham, mixing drinks at the crystal-laden bar cart in tweed jacket and plaid tie, embodies these contradictions with ease. Never losing his cool, he reveals Bradleyâ€™s shifts in feeling with tiny alterations in body language and inflection. It is a commanding performance by an actor perhaps born to play this character.,Matching him nearly stroke for stroke is Mary Beth Peil as Ann. The role was played Off Broadway by the imposingly grand Nancy Marchand. Ms. Peilâ€™s Ann is more delicate, still ravishingly pretty and something of a coquette. In a navy blue twin set accented with a rope of pearls, her hair in an elegant French twist, she folds herself neatly into a chair, the picture of a proper lady. But her eyes sparkle with something hidden, a possibly naughty secret that John is determined to pry from her.,At first glance, it looks as though the productionâ€™s impeccable casting goes awry in the younger generation. Rob Campbell and Ann Talman donâ€™t really look like they could be the children of this Bradley and Ann. Heâ€™s too swarthy and scruffy (the rumpled jeans donâ€™t help) and sheâ€™s too blunt and prickly. But they so completely inhabit their characters â€” he with an exquisitely aware irony, she with an emphatic heartiness â€” that you soon wonder why you ever thought they werenâ€™t family.,Mr. Gurneyâ€™s wonderful ear for dialogue keeps the play rippling along, like one of those flowing conversations Bradley prizes. And the bifurcated structure adds a layer of double entendre that sharpens even the more mundane exchanges about the play-within-the-play.,With a golden blush outside the living room windows, the dimmer, contrasting hues of the interior and the leanly upholstered furniture, Ms. Rubinstein, Mr. Yeargan and their lighting designer, Pat Collins, have given the play a Chekhovian melancholy that feels very right but doesnâ€™t detract from its many laughs.,And its many laughs donâ€™t detract from its ultimate truth â€” a truth thatâ€™s been underlined in the years since Mr. Gurney wrote it. John tells his father that the play he has written looks at their family with â€œwarmth, respect and an abiding affection.â€ù What he canâ€™t say, because itâ€™s only 1988, is something that struck at least one viewer:  that the father-son  struggle  in the play can shed some unexpected light on father-son relationships everywhere â€” including those with wider implications.
column4: An America Where Much Was Left Unsaid

column1: There are diners and there are diners, but few like Whiteâ€™s Diner in Bridgeport, which has been owned for 30 years by the same couple â€” Greg and Linda Cerminara, with Greg in charge of the cooking. They kept the name Whiteâ€™s (for the original owner, who opened the diner around 1935), and over time the place has become a local institution.,â€œWe still have some of our original patrons,â€ù Ms. Cerminara said.,Now their children and grandchildren come  for the traditional diner  fare â€” super-large cholesterol-be-darned breakfasts featuring more than a dozen omelets (try the spinach and feta cheese) and other egg dishes, griddlecakes and French toast, and sides like bacon, sausage, ham and  home fries. A favorite omelet is the Farmerâ€™s Market, with onions, peppers, tomatoes, bacon, ham and sausage, at $7.95.  (For the dieting faithful, Egg Beater omelets  are also available.),Whiteâ€™s also features  hearty lunch dishes like thick, hambone-simmered split-pea soup; goulash; escarole and beans; and  scores of sandwich combinations. Gregâ€™s   creamy rice pudding   â€” he  prides himself on cooking almost everything from scratch â€” has devotees returning just for it.,In appearance, Whiteâ€™s is as authentic as diners come, with stools lining a long, long counter and booths edging the windows. Vintage photos of old Bridgeport decorate the walls; the only modern touches are the bamboo shades on  the overhead lamps above each booth.,The diner seats 85, with space for an additional 50 in the adjoining dining room (used on weekends for family parties). Anyone seeking a cross section of local life will find it all day long at Whiteâ€™s, where clothes, class, income and ethnicity mingle over coffee, pancakes,  omelets and other full-bodied fare.,PATRICIA BROOKS
column4: As Authentic as They Come

column1: , who developed a national reputation for decisive and reassuring leadership after 9/11, now faces the odd challenge of having to reassure some supporters that he can be decisive about a very different issue: running for president.,Even as his fellow Republican John McCain and fellow New Yorker Hillary Rodham Clinton have all but formally declared their candidacies, Mr. Giuliani has proceeded more cautiously.,Since last month, he has formed an exploratory committee, more aggressively recruited a campaign staff and moved to divest himself of one of his companies. And he is  now visiting New Hampshire, home to the first primary, for the second time in three months. But he has studiously avoided making a public commitment to run.,Asked recently in Delaware about his political plans, he offered an ambiguous reply: â€œI think the biggest question you have to ask is, â€˜Can you really lead the country?â€™ If I believe that I can do it, then I will, and if I donâ€™t, then Iâ€™ll support somebody else.â€ù,He ducked the question again yesterday, telling reporters in Bretton Woods, N.H., that he would not be rushed by contenders who are already entering the race. â€œYou should do it when you feel itâ€™s the right time,â€ù he said.,Despite the delay, his aides argue that the accelerated pace of early primaries next year actually benefits a well-established figure like Mr. Giuliani â€” much, they say, as his national stature will enable him to close whatever gaps now exist in fund-raising and organization.,Frank Luntz, a Republican consultant who is not now working for any of the presidential campaigns, described Mr. Giuliani as â€œthe only candidate who can set his own timetable, because he is so established in the minds of the voters.â€ù,Nonetheless, doubts have been raised about the proverbial fire in his belly. Some New Yorkers in particular recall his decision to quit the Senate race against Mrs. Clinton in 2000 after running for months and raising millions of dollars but never formally declaring his candidacy.,Mr. Giuliani, already hobbled then by a messy separation from his wife, withdrew after finding that he had prostate cancer. But he was also ambivalent about the prospect of being a legislator.,Wrestling then with which course of medical treatment to pursue,  he said on the day he withdrew: â€œAnd about the decision to run: I was almost in the same position, not being able to make it, which has never really happened to me. Iâ€™ve always been able to make decisions.â€ù,David Garth, a media consultant who helped steer the Giuliani mayoral campaigns, said that while he had no reason to doubt a candidacy this time, â€œitâ€™s a question of where his head is, as it was in the Senate race.â€ù,Michael R. Long, chairman of the New York State Conservative Party, voiced uncertainty.,â€œHe called me before Thanksgiving just to touch base and said heâ€™d like to talk, and I havenâ€™t heard from him since,â€ù Mr. Long said. â€œWe went through this in the United States Senate race. Whether he pulls the trigger or not, I donâ€™t know.â€ù,Fred Siegel, a Cooper Union historian and Giuliani biographer, dismissed the analogy to 2000. â€œThe question is there in Washington,â€ù Mr. Siegel said, but â€œI think itâ€™s mistaken.â€ù,Mr. Giulianiâ€™s aides maintain that he is being held to a standard different from that of other prospective candidates who have not formally declared. And anyway, they say, his ambivalence, whether real or merely perceived, may well vanish soon. Mr. Giuliani, who will address  the Republican State Convention in New Hampshire today, is to travel to California and South Carolina next month, and supporters in New Jersey are preparing to announce endorsements next week.,California and New Jersey are two of a number of populous states that are expected to shift their 2008 primaries to February, very early in the campaign season, and South Carolinaâ€™s comes even earlier, a week after New Hampshireâ€™s.,â€œFolks who believe he is not running do so at their own peril,â€ù said Michael DuHaime, former political director of the Republican National Committee, who is heading Mr. Giulianiâ€™s exploratory effort.,â€œThere is a spin out there that the campaign is further behind than it is, that Rudy may not be serious, and that is being done deliberately to keep us from certain fund-raisers,â€ù said Mr. DuHaime, a native New Jerseyan who begins working for Mr. Giuliani full time next week.,Kieran Mahoney, a Republican consultant in New York who is working for another presidential prospect, former Gov. James S. Gilmore III of Virginia, said he had been unconvinced of a Giuliani run until recently, when the former mayor stepped up the pace of hiring a campaign staff and reports emerged that he had taken steps to sell the biggest division of his consulting business.,â€œStop listening to what they say and look at their behavior,â€ù Mr. Mahoney said of potential candidates in general. â€œGiuliani is, in fact, an active participant in the marketplace in terms of scooping up talent and making business decisions that are economically injurious and politically positive. I have been a skeptic. I am now a believer.â€ù,Even Mr. Giuliani himself, though continuing to demur, did drop a hint or two in New Hampshire yesterday, saying at a Chamber of Commerce dinner  that he might return later this year to play golf, or for other reasons.,Some consultants to Mr. Giulianiâ€™s rivals, and even some of his supporters, say that given the campaignâ€™s relatively late start, his inner circle may be overconfident about his ability to build a respectable war chest by March 31, the first of the deadlines for reporting campaign contributions. A poor sum  then would make it all the harder to attract further donations, and, with more candidates now choosing not to participate in the federal campaign financing system, the importance of fund-raising has increased, as has competition for the  millions at stake.,Already, Mr. Giuliani is being measured against a 140-page game plan drafted by a member of his campaign staff last fall. That document, which Giuliani advisers say was stolen from them, set a fund-raising goal of at least $25 million by the end of March, but some potential fund-raisers and donors whom it identified have already enlisted in support of other candidates.,Asked about the $25 million figure, Mr. DuHaime, who did not join the campaign until after the document was drafted, replied: â€œWhat is important to us is we have a strong number in that first period, and Iâ€™m not going to put the number out there publicly. Weâ€™re certain weâ€™re going to have enough money to be competitive.â€ù,In New Jersey, where two fund-raisers have been scheduled and a spectrum of local politicians are expected to endorse Mr. Giuliani next week, one supporter, Steven E. Some, said that he had worked in five presidential campaigns and that â€œselling Rudy is the easiest sell Iâ€™ve ever had in my life.â€ù,â€œI have no doubt whatever that heâ€™s in this for the long term,â€ù said Mr. Some, a veteran  political consultant. â€œIâ€™ve never had anyone come up to me to raise any doubt about whether heâ€™s going to go the course.â€ù,Still, an underlying perception exists, and is being stoked, that Mr. Giuliani has not committed himself to a campaign, in part because he is reluctant to relinquish the lucrative consulting business that he founded after he left the mayorâ€™s office five years ago. Referring to Mr. Giulianiâ€™s exploratory activity, Harold M. Ickes, a longtime adviser to Mrs. Clinton, said, â€œI thought he was just advertising so he can increase his fees.â€ù,Mr. Mahoney, the Republican consultant, acknowledged that one challenge facing Mr. Giuliani would be determining how to expand his political base rightward.,â€œIn order to become the mayor of New York City,â€ù Mr. Mahoney said, â€œyou have to do things that are not wholly consistent with being the Republican nominee for president.â€ù
column4: Giuliani Is Cautious as He Weighs â€™08 Decision

column1: Intel, the worldâ€™s largest chip maker,  has overhauled the basic building block of the information age, paving the way for a new generation of faster and more energy-efficient processors.,Company researchers said the advance represented the most significant change in the materials used to manufacture silicon chips since Intel pioneered the modern integrated-circuit transistor more than four decades ago.,The microprocessor chips, which Intel plans to begin making in the second half of this year, are designed for computers but they could also have applications in consumer devices.
