Their combination of processing power and energy efficiency could make it possible, for example, for cellphones to play video at length â€” a demanding digital task â€” with less battery drain.,The work by Intel overcomes a potentially crippling technical obstacle that has arisen as a transistorâ€™s tiny switches are made ever smaller: their tendency to leak current as the insulating material gets thinner. The Intel advance uses new metallic alloys in the insulation itself and in adjacent components.,Word of the announcement, which is planned for Monday, touched off a war of dueling statements as I.B.M. rushed to announce that  it was on the verge of a similar advance.,I.B.M. executives said their company was planning to introduce a comparable type of transistor in the first quarter of 2008.,Many industry analysts say that Intel retains a six-month to nine-month lead over the rest of the industry, but I.B.M. executives disputed the claim and said the two companies were focused on different markets in the computing industry.,The I.B.M. technology has been developed in partnership with Advanced Micro Devices, Intelâ€™s main rival. Modern microprocessor and memory chips are created from an interconnected fabric of hundreds of millions and even billions of the tiny switches that process the  ones and zeros that are the foundation of digital computing.,They are made using a manufacturing process that has been constantly improving for more than four decades. Today transistors, for example, are made with systems that can create wires and other features that are finer than the resolving power of a single wavelength of light.,The Intel announcement is new evidence that the chip maker is maintaining the pace of Mooreâ€™s Law, the technology axiom that states that the number of transistors on a chip doubles roughly every two years, giving rise to a constant escalation of computing power at lower costs.,â€œThis is evolutionary as opposed to revolutionary, but it will generate a big sigh of relief,â€ù said Vivek Subramanian, associate professor of electrical engineering and computer sciences at the University of California, Berkeley.,For several decades there have been repeated warnings about the impending end of the Mooreâ€™s Law pace for chip makers. In response the semiconductor industry has repeatedly found its way around fundamental technical obstacles, inventing techniques that at times seem to defy basic laws of physics.,The chip industry measures its progress by manufacturing standards defined by a width of one of the smallest features of a transistor for each generation. Currently much of the industry is building chips in what is known as 90-nanometer technology. At that scale, about 1,000 transistors would fit in the width of a human hair. Intel began making chips at 65 nanometers in 2005, about nine months before its closest competitors.,Now the company is moving on to the next stage of refinement, defined by a minimum feature size of 45 nanometers. Other researchers have recently reported progress on molecular computing technologies that could reduce the scale even further by the end of the decade.,Intelâ€™s imminent advance to 45 nanometers will have a huge impact on the industry, Mr. Subramanian said.   â€œPeople have been working on it for over a decade, and this is tremendously significant that Intel has made it work,â€ù he said.,Intelâ€™s advance was in part in finding a new insulator composed of an alloy of hafnium, a metallic element that has previously been used in filaments and electrodes and as a neutron absorber in nuclear power plants. They will replace the use of silicon dioxide â€” essentially the material that window glass is made of, but only several atoms thick.,Intel is also shifting to new metallic alloy materials â€” it is not identifying them specifically â€” in transistor components known as gates, which sit directly on top of the insulator. These are ordinarily made from a particular form of silicon called polysilicon.,The new approach to insulation appears at least temporarily to conquer one of the most significant obstacles confronting the semiconductor industry: the tendency of tiny switches to leak electricity as they are reduced in size. The leakage makes chips run hotter and consume more power.,Many executives in the industry say  that Intel is still recovering from a strategic wrong turn it made when the company pushed its chips to extremely high clock speeds â€” the ability of a processor to calculate more quickly. That obsession with speed at any cost left the company behind its competitors in shifting to low-power alternatives.,Now Intel is coming back. Although the chip maker led in the speed race for many years, the company has in recent years shifted its focus to low-power microprocessors that gain speed by breaking up each chip into multiple computing â€œcores.â€ù In its new 45-nanometer generation, Intel will gain the freedom to seek either higher performance or substantially lower power, while at the same time increasing the number of cores per chip.,â€œThey can adjust the transistor for high performance or low power,â€ù said David Lammers, director of ,, a Web portal for technical professionals.,The Intel development effort has gone on in a vast automated factory in Hillsboro, Ore., that the company calls D1D. It features huge open manufacturing rooms that are kept surgically clean to prevent dust from contaminating the silicon wafers that are whisked around the factory by a robotic conveyor system.,The technology effort was led by Mark T.  Bohr, a longtime Intel physicist who is director of process architecture and integration. The breakthrough, he said, was in finding a way to deal with the leakage of current. â€œUp until five years ago, leakage was thought to increase with each generation,â€ù he said.,Several analysts said that the technology advance could give Intel a meaningful advantage over competitors in the race to build ever more powerful microprocessors.,â€œItâ€™s going to be a nightmare for Intelâ€™s competitors,â€ù said G. Dan Hutcheson, chief executive of VLSI Research. â€œA lot of Mark Bohrâ€™s counterparts are going to wake up in terror.â€ù,An I.B.M. executive said yesterday that the company had also chosen hafnium as its primary  insulator, but that it would not release details of its new process until technical papers are presented  at coming conferences.,â€œItâ€™s the difference between can openers and Ferraris,â€ù said Bernard S. Meyerson, vice president and chief technologist for the systems and technology group at I.B.M. He insisted that industry analysts who have asserted that Intel has a technology lead are not accurate and that I.B.M. had simply chosen to deploy its new process in chips that are part of high-performance systems aimed at the high end of the computer industry.,Intel said it had already manufactured prototype microprocessor chips in the new 45-nanometer process that run on three major operating systems: Windows, Mac OS X and  Linux.
column4: Intel Says Chips Will Run Faster, Using Less Power

column1: ONE of the few times I have seen Paul Newman in person was at dinner at Luna, on the grounds of the Westport Country Playhouse. He was at the table next to mine â€” and now he and a new chef run the place, which opened last fall, totally revamped and renamed Dressing Room.,The new look conveys sophisticated rusticity, with a roaring fire, vintage wood floors, and swags of dried magnolia leaves and gigantic sugar pine cones looped along the walls, interspersed with Playhouse posters.,Subtitled â€œA Homegrown Restaurant,â€ù Dressing Room features the cooking of Michel Nischan,  a co-owner and an experienced chef who once ran Miche Mache in South Norwalk and North Stamford. The menu emphasizes fresh, seasonal, mostly organic foods in wholesome dishes, usually with a modern twist, often made with local ingredients.,Oysters, as a starter, are from ,. The feta cheese in the spoon salad is from Sankowâ€™s Beaver Brook Farm in Lyme and the varied artisanal cheeses as a dessert choice are from Cato Corner Farm in Colchester.,In the hands of an imaginative chef like Mr. Nischan, wholesome is anything but boring. Three delicious appetizers prove the point. Fried calamari, lightly battered, are enlivened by soft cheese grits and Cape gooseberries. Kona Kampachi,  a farmed fish, forms a tartare with chopped oysters, shallots, fresh chives and extra virgin olive oil. Best of all, though it sounds mundane, is the Maryland crab cocktail â€”  attractive clusters of fresh crabmeat alongside tiny portions of pumpkin-seed frissÃ©e salad and rutabaga sauerkraut, with a cumin accent, in a tangy blood-orange dressing.,A really special dish, farro, a cereal grain similar to spelt, is available as an entree with butternut squash and truffles. I ordered it as a side, prepared risotto-style, with foraged mushrooms and a foam of mascarpone cheese. The farroâ€™s nutty flavor and firmness worked well with the mushrooms.,Another pleasing combination was Berkshire pig, consisting of three cuts of pork  â€” prime roasting cut, prime braising cut and seared pork belly, served with a pungent parsnip horseradish purÃ©e and large heirloom shell beans in natural pan juices.,Accessories at Dressing Room are often unusual  â€” wilted kale, collard greens, brussels sprouts, parsnips, salsify.  But sometimes  they overwhelm the main attraction, like the simply grilled John Dory fish, drowned out  by the collard greens and salsify in ham hock stock that accompanied it.,A better combination was paper-thin slices of Coxâ€™s Orange Pippin apples layered with pan-roasted trout, garnished with creamy scalloped potatoes.,Desserts, a Nischan specialty, make grand finales. Especially rich was the chocolate bread pudding. Sticky toffee pudding with red wine-soaked poached pear and maple ice cream was also memorable. My favorite was lemon meringue pie, a miniature individual tart with a piquant lemon-sour cream filling, mile-high meringue and a crust that looked commercial but was buttery, house-made and superb.,Almost everything is made on the premises, from the ketchup used in the loose-textured Dressing Room meatloaf and the cured bacon on the P. L. Newman burger to all the ice creams and sour cherry sorbet. But the  excellent sourdough breads come from the SoNo Baking Company in South Norwalk.,Dressing Room is off to a flying start and what promises to be an extended run., A houselike building of vivid-green clapboard with  a front terrace, next to the Westport Country Playhouse. The first of two handsome dining rooms has high ceilings, post-and-beam construction and a stone fireplace; the rear room has banquettes, oak barn-siding walls and an exposed-beam ceiling. Wheelchair accessible., Casually well-dressed couples, foursomes and small groups make up the chatty, conversational crowd. The staff is  friendly, unpretentious and eager to please., A full bar, slightly separated from the front dining room, with  concise but well-chosen wine,  beer and ale selections., Lunch entrees, $14 to $20; dinner entrees, $20 to $34. All major credit cards., Maryland crab cocktail, Kona Kampachi, fried calamari; farro, Berkshire pig, meatloaf, pan-roasted trout; lemon meringue pie, sticky toffee pudding, chocolate bread pudding, cherry sorbet., Lunch: Wednesday to  Sunday,,11:30 a.m. to 2 p.m. Dinner:  Tuesday to  Thursday and Sunday, 5 to 9:30 p.m.; Friday and Saturday, 5 to 10:30 p.m.   Large free parking lot in front of the theater  and the restaurant.
column4: Homegrown, and (Partly) Newmanâ€™s Own

column1: A State Senate panel recommended the censure of a lawmaker accused of groping a male page in a motel room bed. The full Senate could vote next week on the proposed punishment for the lawmaker, Senator Daniel Sutton, a Democrat from Flandreau. Censure would carry no loss of Mr. Suttonâ€™s powers. The nine-member panel, which voted, 6 to 3, in favor of censure, could have recommended instead that the lawmaker be expelled or exonerated. The page, Austin Wiese, 19, testified this week that Mr. Sutton, a longtime family friend, touched his genitals through his shorts while the two shared a king-size bed at a motel last February. Mr. Wiese was 18 at the time. No criminal charges have been filed. Mr. Sutton acknowledged sharing a bed with the young man but denied groping him.
column4: South Dakota: Censure of Senator Is Advised

column1: With more bromides than a Hallmark shop, â€œThe Pavilion,â€ù by Craig Wright, is receiving a gentle,  at times sweetly engaging,  production at the Two River Theater Company in Red Bank. By turns  lyrical  and  sophomoric, the play, directed by   Aaron Posner, is a kind of â€œOur Townâ€ù or â€œTalleyâ€™s Follyâ€ù without the nuance.,Try this on for size: â€œTime only goes in one direction.â€ù   Or this:  â€œItâ€™s life! Bearableâ€™s the best we can hope for!â€ù You get the idea.,Mr. Wright,  an Emmy-nominated writer for the  television  shows  â€œLostâ€ù and â€œSix Feet Under,â€ù has set his play at a 20th high school reunion in rural Pine City, Minn.  Gathered at the townâ€™s  lakeside pavilion, a century-old dance hall scheduled to be destroyed at the end of the evening in the name of progress, are members of the class of 1986:  the Boy Most Likely to Succeed, now a Microsoft millionaire; the Girl With the Best Sense of Humor, still single; and, most important,  both halves of the Cutest Senior Couple.,The lives of the couple in question took  separate paths on a  fateful September day when Peter went out of town to college,  leaving Kari pregnant and facing an ,.,Kari is tenderly played  by Kate Eastwood Norris as a woman determined to cope. With her face frozen in a wan smile of regret, she clutches her sweater closed as though trying to hide  her broken heart. Still working at the bank, down in the basement among the safe-deposit boxes, and still married to Hans, the local golf pro who rescued her in her time of need, she hates golf almost as much as she despises the memory of Peter and their unborn child.,The desperately clueless Peter, played   by Erik Steele, went to graduate school to become  a shrink. Lonely, unable to establish any meaningful relationships except with artistic 20-somethings, he remains  obsessed with the idea of reconnecting with Kari. He actually appears at the dance with a bouquet of flowers clutched in his hand, seeking forgiveness. Kari is not feeling charitable.,Andrew Polk rounds out the cast as the Narrator, for whom Mr. Wright has written some richly poetic segues. In a vocal tour de force,  Mr. Polk  also assumes the personas of a dozen or so of the classâ€™s most colorful, if condescendingly local-yokel, â€œFargoâ€ù-inflected characters. They  include    Pudge, the dense suicide hot line counselor; Kent Luneburg, Pine Cityâ€™s chief of police, whose wife,  Angie,  is having an affair  with the paranoid, often stoned mayor, Cookie Brustad; and  Angie herself, who  believes  in  â€œchanging the rules if youâ€™re not happy.â€ù,Recriminations, followed by the  sharing of burdened  hearts, followed by a tenuous pas de deux of reconciliation and redemption,  bring â€œThe Pavilionâ€ù to a close. Whether the final â€œSweethearts Danceâ€ù at midnight will send Kari and Peter off  happily ever after is not to be revealed here. With little enough dramatic tension in the  second act, Iâ€™m not about to give  away the ending.
column4: The â€˜Cutest Senior Couple,â€™ a Bit Frayed After 20 Years

column1: Three illegal immigrants have been found dead from exposure to the cold in the past few days in Duval County, in the southern part of the state, sheriffâ€™s officials said. The immigrants were found wearing light, rain-soaked clothing during a period when nighttime temperatures had been dipping to 34 degrees, Cmdr. Romeo Ramirez of the sheriffâ€™s office said. A 22-year-old woman from Nicaragua was found early Wednesday in brush on private ranch land after other immigrants told officials that she had been unable to keep up with them. A 28-year-old woman from El Salvador was found around 4 p.m. on Wednesday under a bridge north of Route 16. And Border Patrol agents found a man from El Salvador around 4 a.m. on Thursday in brush about a mile from where the first body had been found.
column4: Texas: 3 Illegal Immigrants Die of Exposure

column1: Farmers and ranchers in storm-plagued areas of southeastern Colorado who lost livestock in recent back-to-back blizzards will be able to obtain low-interest emergency loans of up to $500,000 from the United States Agriculture Department, federal officials said. As many as 10,000 head of cattle may have been killed by the storms, but the final count remains uncertain because many animals remain buried in snow. Losses are also mounting from the deaths of weakened animals. President Bush signed a declaration this month qualifying parts of Colorado, Kansas and Nebraska for federal disaster relief.
column4: Colorado: Ranchers Getting Loans

column1: WHEN the Flying Pig first flew into Mount Kiscoâ€™s Metro-North station house, the concept of a market-cafe emphasizing fresh local and organic products was laudable, and it still is. But those wings wilted as the ambitious owners tried to accomplish too many missions in a small, ungainly space.,In early December, the Pig took off again, this time settling into  roomier quarters last occupied by Cafe Antico. The basic architectural details remain intact â€” the barrel ceiling of the upper floor and the glass walls wrapping the first-floor dining area â€” but the new Pig is a more sober affair. Gone is Anticoâ€™s dazzle of ornate candelabras, strings of glittery pin lights and masses of candles â€” an atmosphere that canâ€™t quite be replaced by the collection of pig figures and figurines. The new ownershipâ€™s commitment to serving nutritious, chemical-free food is a serious one, and it may be that the pared-down dÃ©cor better delivers the earnest message.,Most of the Flying Pigâ€™s meat and vegetable products come from Cabbage Hill Farm, a local supplier that, like the restaurantâ€™s other sources, is committed to the humane treatment of free-ranging livestock and the cultivation of pesticide-free vegetables. Quality  like this goes a long way but doesnâ€™t always guarantee the success of a dish.,During my recent visits, the cooking  wasnâ€™t as vigilant as it could be and lacked consistency. At best, promised herbs were absent; at worst, much of a rib-eye steak was globby fat. But this new Flying Pig is still coming to terms with the responsibilities involved in running a full-scale restaurant. Meanwhile, it makes a sunny destination for lunch â€” perhaps a sandwich and a bowl of thick, purÃ©ed vegetable soup, delicious and warming. And dinner had some high points as well.,A couple of starters proved quite satisfying. Although the promised rosemary was undetectable, grilled shrimp were still appealing under a light wash of lemony broth and on a bed of cannellini beans and shredded arugula; and the liquor from small, tasty mussels mingled with wine sauce and garlic into a broth that sopped nicely with good toasted bread â€” a lusty dish.,Chopped salad contained carrots, romaine, sweet red onions, Maytag blue cheese and lentils (lentils and beans seem to crop up in most dishes). On one occasion the salad was dressed with a wine vinaigrette that was perfectly balanced;  on another visit it was stingingly astringent.,A mountain of gorgeous fresh parsley and a scattering of pignoli and pomegranate seeds took grilled portobellos under a melt of Parmesan out of the ordinary. But the sautÃ©ed bits of calamari in another appetizer were a tad tough.,An entree of flat maltagliati pasta (the name means badly cut) with meaty Bolognese sauce was hearty and homey (a half portion as an  appetizer can be arranged). Other creditable dishes included salt-roasted salmon, the salt crust (removed before being served) capturing all the juiciness and flavor of the fish as it roasted. And hanger steak turned out to be a wonderful piece of meat. The two-inch-thick cut was grilled perfectly to medium rare; mashed Yukon golds and strings of fried onion shared the plate. The excellence of this steak made the fatty rib-eye mentioned earlier all the more puzzling. This rib-eye was also cut in a wedge, the thin end overdone and dry. Adding to the disaster were leathery outer leaves of onion and tough leaves of spinach.,The pig motif, most apparent on the upper floor, might make some diners uneasy, especially if theyâ€™ve ordered the pork loin. The fact is that this meat was fabulously tender, flavorful and juicy, a winner sided by a fluffy mash of potato and celery root.,For dessert. the sticky toffee pudding, lighter than most,  was truly luxurious when served with a scoop of ice cream. Or have the ice cream neat: vanilla, lovely; or  Calypso KahlÃºa, a personal favorite. Showered with chocolate and charmingly presented in towers, banana cinnamon fritters also made a pleasing finish to the meal., Bright, sunny dining areas during lunch. Contemporary main-floor dining area with glass walls. The pig motif is mostly in the otherwise characterless upstairs dining room. Both areas are noisy at peak times. Wheelchair accessible., Neat, casually dressed adults. Cold welcome and no grateful farewell from the hosts; friendly, willing wait staff., Small attractive bar at the entry of the main floor dining area., Lunch and brunch: main dishes, $10 to $15. Dinner: main dishes, $22 to $34; $14.50 for a burger. Major credit cards accepted., Vegetable soup, lemon shrimp, roasted mussels, maltagliati Bolognese, salt-roasted salmon, grilled hanger steak, pork loin, sticky toffee pudding, vanilla and Calypso KahlÃºa ice creams., Lunch: Tuesday to Friday, 11:30 a.m. to 3 p.m. Dinner: Tuesday to Thursday, 5 to,9 p.m.; Friday and Saturday, 5 to 11 p.m. Brunch: Friday and Saturday, 10:30 a.m. to 3 p.m. For lunch and dinner, reservations are always a good idea, especially for a table on the main floor.
column4: A Safe Landing, but a Little Bumpy

column1: Homemade fresh mozzarella ($7 a pound)  is the big attraction at Massimo Italian Delicatessen in Kenilworth. â€œI make it at least twice a day,â€ù  said Massimo Clemente, known as Max. â€œWe also prepare our own marinara sauceâ€ù ($4.25 a quart, plain; $4.50 with meat).,There are  homemade sausages    hanging from stainless-steel hooks. Hand-hewn wooden bins are filled with fresh-dried pastas like  cavatelli, spaghetti and fettuccine ($2.50 a pound).,Prepared foods include hearty Italian classics, mostly sold frozen:  sausage, peppers and onions ($6 a pound);  stuffed shells ($4); ravioli ($5); lasagna ($6); and manicotti with meat sauce ($6).,Customers  arrive with coolers to  fill  with roasted peppers and marinated mushrooms ($6 a pound), imported sun-dried tomatoes ($8.99), olives ($5), and cheeses from Italy like  Locatelli Romano ($8.99) and Parmigiano Reggiano ($14). Others stop  for a wedge of Asiago cheese,  which they grate over pasta or just eat  with crackers ($8.99).,Although he has been the deliâ€™s sole owner for three years, Mr. Clemente was previously a partner  for more than 30  years. â€œWeâ€™ve been doing the same thing since Day One,â€ù  he said.,Some add Gorgonzola ($8.99 a pound) and fresh mascarpone cheese ($8 a pound) to their pasta;  others eat sliced  provolone  ($10.99) with fresh pears.,â€œOur customers seem to buy the same thing week after week,â€ù said John Finamore, a member of the staff  who has been serving the public for 20  years.  Favorites include  the imported meats: soppressata (imported dried Italian  salami, $10 a pound), mortadella (Italian bologna, $6),  capicola (cured salami, $10)  and, of course, prosciutto ($14).,Sandwiches  are a big attraction, like the one  with prosciutto, fresh mozzarella, capicola and roasted peppers, drizzled with balsamic vinegar on a roll ($5). Shelves are filled with spices,  sauces and  condiments. You can also pick up everything from  a loaf of bread to  a box of Perugina chocolates (28 pieces, $18.75).,MILLICENT K. BRODY
column4: Paper, Plastic or Cooler?

column1: WHEN I last had fondue, it was at a bustling place in Geneva,  where the supercilious waiter knew we were tourists and treated us accordingly. I declared then  that I wouldnâ€™t be craving bread dunked in melted  cheese for a very long time.,A very long time turned out to be 16 months. But this time I didnâ€™t have to endure  an all-night flight and navigate a foreign language. Pheasants Landing, which has a Swiss chef, Andre Gross,  serves a fine  fondue and several other tasty dishes as well.,The restaurant is owned by Heinz Keller, who closed his Auberge Swiss in  Berkeley Heights  in 2001  to open this party-friendly place in Hillsborough the following year, according to  Vicky Starace, the  manager. Set well off the road and surrounded by  lawns,  it is brightly lighted and easily seen from a distance. Parking is plentiful, but first-timers are left wondering how to get in, because there are no signs directing diners to the entrance, in the back.,Inside,  the mood warms considerably. Floors are honeyed wood, lighting is hearthlike, and rooms are home-scale.,A cheese fondue seemed equally cozy,  and it was. Spiked with Kirschwasser (a cherry liqueur) and white wine, it  was served with bread and apples for dipping, and did double duty as food and conversation piece. Thereâ€™s a proper way to stir fondue,  with a queenly wave,  a  figure-eight motion,  to keep it from sticking on the bottom, said one member of our party. Then there was the discussion of etiquette surrounding the retrieval of food gone missing in the depths.,Appetizers, which lent themselves to  less social interaction,  were successful anyway. They  included a duck pÃ¢tÃ© with its fruity Cumberland sauce and accompanying salad of celery and walnuts;  roasted red peppers over fresh mozzarella,  drizzled with a basil vinaigrette; and  Swiss onion soup, topped with Emmenthal cheese.,The Caesar salad was more compelling than the Greek version, possibly because the Parmesan used in the Caesar was more noticeable   than the feta in the Greek. Crab cakes were overly seasoned and overworked, with no visible chunks of meat; house-made spinach dumplings were delicately flavored, once  they had been fished from their sea of sauce. The pasta encircling a  pheasant filling in the ravioli special, however, was less than tender.,Main dishes were more consistent, particularly the European specialties:   the slab of tender sauerbraten, marinated steak,  in brown gravy, accompanied by  a heap of steaming hot spaetzle  and marinated red cabbage; the hunter schnitzel, a tender disc of fried veal  served with a typical Burgundy-mushroom sauce, again with cabbage and spaetzle; and  the wiener schnitzel, the fried veal  without the gravy.,There were a few standouts  among the game specials, which are offered  in winter  and change weekly. Venison stew was delicious,  the meat made tender by a red wine marinade and braising with mushrooms, pearl onions and bacon and served with more of the spaetzle. A close second was the game sampler, which included a sweetish smoked duck sausage infused with apple brandy,  a tender venison loin  and wild boar medallions wrapped in bacon.,A New York strip steak was nicely cooked as well, though the garlic mashed potatoes seemed rote next to the beautiful, golden-brown, crisp-on-the-outside, tender-on-the-inside rÃ¶sti, a  Swiss version of hash browns that was enriched with bacon and onions. Pheasant, however, was a disappointment,  overcooked and dry on two separate visits.,Among the many menu items I didnâ€™t try,  the fish and chips, made with cod  in a beer batter, is atop my list. The best bet for dessert is not the house-made apple strudel, which had  a floppy crust and steaming filling, but Mr. Grossâ€™s   walnut and caramel-fudge tart. Order it when you place your meal order  and ask the server to allow your piece to sit out of the refrigerator during dinner. That way the flavors  enhance  each other  â€” just the way the satisfying food at Pheasants Landing complements a winter evening., Intimate and cozy,  with room for large and small groups. Complete wheelchair access., Convivial and casual; friendly, helpful servers;  few children were seen, but they would feel at home here. Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays in January and February are fondue nights; there is  a strolling accordion player on Thursdays., Small wine list with solid choices,   $21 to $70 a bottle; glasses, $5 to $6.50., Lunch,  about $9 to $10.50. Dinner entrees, $10 to $24. All major credit cards accepted., Swiss onion soup, roasted red peppers with mozzarella, Caesar salad, wiener schnitzel, sauerbraten, hunter schnitzel, cheese fondue, Swiss-style hash brown potatoes, venison stew, wild boar medallions, smoked duck sausage.,Lunch:  Tuesday to  Friday, 11:30 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. Dinner:  Tuesday to   Thursday, 4  to 9 p.m.; Friday and Saturday, 4  to 10 p.m.; Sunday, 4  to 8 p.m. Reservations recommended on weekends. Plentiful parking next to the building.,Reviewed Jan. 28, 2007
column4: Comforting Cuisine, With a Swiss Touch

column1: An imposing wooden Bigfoot statue stolen from outside a chiropractorâ€™s office was recovered on Thursday â€” minus its big feet. An anonymous tip led the police in Federal Way, just north of Tacoma, to the 400-pound sculpture beneath a pile of debris in a backyard about a block from where it was taken on Monday. Two people, a man and a boy, confessed and could face theft charges, the police said. The statue used to stand eight feet high, but its 16-inch-long feet had been sawed off at the ankles, leaving it 18 inches shorter. It was returned to the office of the chiropractor, Tom Payne, who said he planned to get Bigfoot some new feet. â€œIâ€™m sure I can find a chainsaw sculptor that might feel up to the task,â€ù Mr. Payne said.
column4: Washington: Bigfoot Is Recovered, Almost

column1: A Navy helicopter with four crew members aboard crashed into the Pacific Ocean about 50 miles off California, killing at least one person, a Navy spokesman said. It was unclear whether the three other crew members had survived. The helicopter, an MH-60S, or Seahawk, was based at Naval Air Station North Island. It was on a training mission off the Bonhomme Richard, an amphibious assault ship, near San Clemente Island when it crashed at 2:45 p.m., Cmdr. Jack Hanzlik said. Navy search-and-rescue efforts were under way as darkness fell. Commander Hanzlik said rescuers  had arrived at the crash site within minutes. The names and rank of those aboard were not being released, he said.
column4: California: Navy Helicopter Crashes

column1: A federal judge dropped charges against 13 peace activists arrested for protesting outside the headquarters of the National Security Agency in Fort Meade, between Baltimore and Washington. An N.S.A. security officer lacked the legal authority to charge the protesters and did not provide a statement of probable cause, the judge, Susan K. Gauvey of Federal District Court, ruled on Thursday. The law prohibits only illegal entry, not remaining on agency property, and the protesters were never told that the agency objected to their presence, Judge Gauvey said.
column4: Maryland: Charges Dropped in Protests

column1: IN the 1890s, Louis Seitz built three singular apartment houses in ,: the Imperial, at Pacific Street and Bedford Avenue; the Alhambra, at Nostrand Avenue and Macon Street; and the Renaissance, at Nostrand and Hancock Street.,As decades passed, each building went to a different owner. But all followed the downward path that overtook much of Brooklyn; a century later, they were disintegrating.,Under the supervision of the cityâ€™s Department of Housing Preservation and Development, they have now been rebuilt by  developers who have remained faithful to the originals, at least on the exterior. The buildings in their infancy catered to a wealthy clientele, but today most of the apartments are for moderate- or low-income tenants.,Born in 1860, Mr. Seitz left school at 16 and worked in a wholesale business of some sort before going into real estate in 1884.,The masterpiece of his trio, built in 1889, was the wild and woolly Alhambra. The blocklong building was set back 15 feet from Nostrand Avenue, with six towers, arcaded balconies, a garden and a croquet lawn. It mixed several styles, and in 1890, The Brooklyn Daily Eagle said it â€œmight best be described as Morrisian,â€ù an allusion to the pyrotechnics of Mr. Seitzâ€™s architect, Montrose Morris. The five-story building, which cost $200,000, had a resident engineer and 32 apartments of 8 to 10 rooms. It was instantly one of Brooklynâ€™s best apartment houses.,Two years later, Mr. Seitz and Mr. Morris completed two near twins: the Imperial, several blocks south in Crown Heights, and the Renaissance, a block north of the Alhambra.,According to an 1892 issue of The Eagle, Mr. Seitz told Mr. Morris to prepare plans for the Imperial regardless of cost, in order to make â€œa monument handsome beyond compare.â€ù And that monument, at Pacific and Bedford, is wonderfully rambunctious, its triple outsize turrets and pointed roofs like the three musketeers backed into a corner, swords flailing.,Although the exterior walls meet at right angles, the plot is slightly acute â€” perhaps only 80 degrees instead of the usual 90 â€” which animates the facade in a way seen in few other buildings. The whole is dominated by triple-height arches, topped by an irregular attic story, its slate roofs crowded together as if jockeying for position.,The Alhambra is in a moody palette of orange and brown and red, while the Imperial turned the corner of the new Renaissance style, airy and light in soft yellow and buff brick and terra cotta. Two-story-high fluted columns give the later building a Roman pomp. In 1892, The Eagle called it â€œan architectural dream in cream and white,â€ù generally patterned after McKim, Mead & Whiteâ€™s Hotel Imperial, which once stood at 32nd Street and Broadway in ,.,The 1892 Renaissance, at Nostrand Avenue and Hancock Street, is essentially the same as the Imperial, although less operatic.,An 1893 book, â€œThe Eagle and Brooklyn,â€ù singled out Mr. Seitzâ€™s efforts, noting his â€œdiscriminating artistic senseâ€ù and saying he had revolutionized the Brooklyn apartment market. Andrew Scott Dolkart, who has studied the career of Montrose Morris extensively, calls him one of Brooklynâ€™s great 19th-century architects.,In an 1899 account, The Eagle called the Imperial â€œone of the finest apartments in Brooklynâ€ù; in 1901, it reported that the 25 seven-room apartments each rented for $60 a month. According to the 1905 , census, tenants had occupations like lawyer, exporter, engineer and stockbroker.,By the 1970s, all three buildings were on the skids. The city took possession of the Imperial in 1979, because its taxes had not been paid. An article in The New York Times in 1983 estimated the buildingâ€™s expenses at $67,000 a year, while reporting that the rent roll could not have exceeded $57,000.,The buildings were designated landmarks in 1986, but within a decade the Renaissance was vacant, the Alhambra had only stores as occupants (much of its roof had collapsed from a fire), and the Imperial had only a few tenants.,Rebuilding work on the Alhambra and the Renaissance took place in the 1990s, but the Imperial did not reopen until last October, after a $6.3 million gut renovation similar to the those at the Alhambra and the Imperial.,There is no longer anything historic about any of the interiors, which are plain white and could be in a postwar building on Third Avenue in Manhattan. But in the Imperial some of the two- and three-bedroom apartments retain some original character because they occupy the turrets. A fifth-floor apartment at the northwest corner, with distant views of the Manhattan skyline, is now available at $1,800 a month at market rate, or as low as $700 for prospective tenants who meet certain income guidelines.,Outside, the buildingâ€™s developer, Larry Hirschfield, the president of ELH Management, has delivered interesting results. The masonry has been cleaned, but not too harshly, preserving the dings and nicks of time that give a building character. The slate roofs were kept intact, not rebuilt in modern materials, which would have removed more of the buildingâ€™s patina.,Mr. Hirschfield also had to reproduce much of the copper work in the triple-height window bays. But instead of either cleaning the old copper to look new, or patinating the replacement copper to look old, he left old and new together, so some parts are aged green and others are shiny brown â€” a bit odd, but thatâ€™s how old buildings often look in real life.,So the Department of Housing Preservation and Development has saved the shells of Mr. Seitzâ€™s three signature buildings from disaster and now can make some claim on the same kind of revolution he created in the 1890s.
column4: Three Singular Brooklyn Buildings, Each With a Second Chance

column1: A judge delayed a third execution in ,, again saying the state first needed to decide the role of doctors in carrying out death sentences. The judge, Donald W. Stephens of Superior Court, signed a preliminary injunction delaying the Feb. 9 execution of James A. Campbell, 45, who was convicted of killing a woman in 1993. On Thursday, Judge Stephens delayed the executions of Marcus R. Robinson, 33, who was scheduled to die at 2 a.m. on Friday, and James Edward Thomas, 51, who was set to die next week. The judgeâ€™s ruling on Thursday further complicated the debate over whether the state could carry out executions without the assistance of an attending physician. State law requires a doctorâ€™s presence at executions, but last week the North Carolina Medical Board said any participation by a physician violated medical ethics.
column4: North Carolina: Judge Delays 3rd Execution

column1: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Charleston said it would settle child sexual abuse claims in ,, designating as much as $12 million for damages. â€œIt is my fervent hope that this settlement will allow us, as the Catholic community of faith in South Carolina, to bring closure to an ugly period in our history,â€ù Bishop Robert Baker said. The class-action settlement has been given initial approval by a state judge, said Larry Richter, a lawyer for four victims whose claims were settled last summer. Peter Shahid Jr., a lawyer representing the diocese, said the church knew of at least eight other victims, although others may come forward. Under the settlement, abuse victims could receive $10,000 to $200,000, while spouses and parents of victims would receive $20,000.
column4: South Carolina: Diocese to Settle Claims

column1: One construction worker was killed and another injured when a one-story brick building collapsed in Nashville, the police said. The workers â€” Richard Whiteshield, 57, of Clewiston, Fla., who was killed, and John Kemper of Hendersonville, Tenn., who was injured â€” were part of a crew that was using a jackhammer to dig up a gas main to the building, which was being demolished, said Kristin Mumford, a spokeswoman for the Metropolitan Police Department. The building, in the cityâ€™s Berry Hill neighborhood, had been closed for some time, said Kim Lawson, the deputy fire chief.
column4: Tennessee: Man Killed in Building Collapse

column1: MONTAUK, the hamlet on the end of ,â€™s South Fork, has been a rustic un-Hampton summer destination for more than 50 years. But two new projects  suggest that Montauk may be heading for year-round status, and the recent sale of a former celebrity retreat has also put a spotlight on the hamlet.,A new condop â€” a co-op complex with condominium-style rules  â€” is under construction in Montauk on the site of the Panoramic View Hotel on Old Montauk Highway. The property, still operating as a hotel, has more than 1,000 feet of sandy beach on the Atlantic Ocean. The condop is a complete renovation of the hotel.,The developer, Distinctive Ventures, hopes to attract young , families who want a year-round getaway, but not the bustle and hype of East Hampton and Southampton, according to Adam Manson, a company spokesman.,When completed, the 75-unit complex, to be called Panoramic Villas, will have a full-service concierge, an outdoor heated pool and a fitness center. A mixture of two-, three- and four-bedroom duplexes and some triplexes, ranging in size from 2,000 to 4,000 square feet, is planned. If buyers donâ€™t have time to decorate, Mr. Manson said, they can choose from a variety of furniture packages and accessories, including â€œeverything from table cutlery to napkins in the kitchen ready to use.â€ù,The units, which will start at $1.5 million, will also have oak floors, hot tubs and flat-panel televisions, and granite counters and expensive appliances, Mr. Manson added.,Buyers will purchase shares in the complex, but there are no board  approvals, and owners can sublet the units anytime, Mr. Manson said.,Distinctive Ventures plans to start selling the first 27 units of the project this spring, and the units will be ready by fall, Mr. Manson said.,The company believes that wealthier second-home buyers who want year-round services are heading for Montauk. Clues came from the companyâ€™s research of Montaukâ€™s rental market, Mr. Manson said.,â€œA lot of rentals in the last few seasons were longer term,â€ù Mr. Manson  said. â€œPeople want to own out there, but thereâ€™s very little that is brand new.â€ù,When the pop artist Andy Warhol and Paul Morrissey, his manager and film collaborator, bought a 20-acre estate on the ocean in Montauk in 1971 for $225,000, they thought it was a good investment. Thatâ€™s what Mr. Morrissey said last September when the remaining 5.6 acres was on the market for $40 million.,Perhaps that overestimated price how good an investment it was. Earlier this month, Millard  S. Drexler, chief executive of the clothing company J. Crew, bought the estate for much less: $27 million, according to Paul Brennan of Prudential Douglas Elliman, who handled the sale.,(The Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts donated the other 15 acres to the Nature Conservancy after the artistâ€™s death in 1987. The conservancy created the Andy Warhol Preserve in 1993.),The sold property, called Eothen, ancient Greek for â€œat first light,â€ù sits in a valley among high cliffs in an area known as the Montauk moorlands. Mr. Morrissey listed it with several different real estate firms over the last five years, originally asking $50 million.,Eothen includes a compound of five Colonial Revival-style houses, a horse stable and a three-car garage. All of the houses have spectacular views of the Atlantic Ocean.,Mr. Drexler scouted Eothen for a friend who was interested, Mr. Brennan said, but then bought it himself when the friend passed on it. â€œHe said, â€˜Itâ€™s like a painting,â€™ a very unique property,â€ù Mr. Brennan said.,The five homes, with 15 bedrooms in all, were built in 1931 for the Church family, descendants of a founder of the Church & Dwight Company, makers of Arm & Hammer baking soda. Seven of the bedrooms are in the main house, a rustic wood-paneled structure with blue shuttered windows and a great room with two fireplaces, exposed beams and a vaulted ceiling.,â€œI would say he has very good tasteâ€ù to buy the estate, said Tina Fredericks, the East Hampton broker who sold Mr. Morrissey and Warhol the estate in 1971. As for the price, $40 million â€œalways seemed rather high,â€ù Ms. Fredericks said.,A developer is renovating the 1929 Shepherdâ€™s Neck Inn, a 65-room Montauk hotel, and plans to convert it into a year-round â€œresort hotelâ€ù called SolÃ© East. (Sole is Italian for â€œsun,â€ù although the Italians donâ€™t use an accent mark for the noun.),The hotel will have 60 rooms on 2.5 landscaped acres when it opens in the spring, according to Tom Feeley, an owner of the development firm Wavestone Properties. Wavestone has also bought the Shepherdâ€™s Beach hotel nearby and an adjacent five acres of vacant land, where the zoning was recently changed to permit residential development.,Wavestone has built condominiums and rental buildings in Jersey City and Hoboken, N.J., but this is its first project on Long Island.,SolÃ© East will be one of two branded hotels, Mr. Feeley said. The first, called SolÃ© on the Ocean, is a condominium hotel in Sunny Isles, Fla., which offers owners hotel-like services, including a concierge and housekeeping, and the ability to rent out their units as hotel rooms.,The look and feel of the Montauk hotel will come from Stephane Dupoux, whose interior design firm has designed highly stylized bars, nightclubs and hotels, including Buddha Bar and Cielo in Manhattan and the Gansevoort Beach Club hotel in South Beach.,The new hotel, Mr. Feeley said, will have high-definition flat-screen televisions, whitewashed walls, restored hardwood floors, cedar platform beds and black slate tile bathrooms with a large window in the wall separating the shower from the hotel room.,For winter visitors, there will be a 2,000-square-foot wine cellar and the developer will update the wood-burning fireplaces in the restaurant and in the lobby, Mr. Feeley said.,The Shepherdâ€™s Neck Inn was originally called Montauk Arms. It was built by Carl Fisher, the developer who, with a partner, created Miami Beach from swampland in the 1920s.,After that success, Fisher tried to build a similar resort in Montauk. A devastating hurricane and the stock market crash of 1929 left Fisher financially ruined, but not before he had planned an entire community in Montauk for the wealthy and partially created some of it, including private homes, grand hotels, a yacht club, a school and office buildings.,The inn was to serve as apartments for the managers of his resorts in Montauk, according to a history provided by the Montauk Library. â€œWe feel a connection with Carl Fisherâ€™s original concept and his connection to both markets where we are opening, in Miami and Montauk,â€ù Mr. Feeley said.
column4: Higher Price Tags in Montauk

column1: HARTFORD,THE tan house with the welcoming front porch at 56 Risley Street on the North End looks a lot like the other new homes in this inner-city neighborhood. But because it was designed with energy savings in mind, its ownersâ€™ utilities bill will be about $1,100 less a year than their neighborsâ€™.,The builder, Hartford Area Habitat for Humanity, set out to create a healthier, cost- and energy-efficient residence and to dispel the belief that building â€œgreenâ€ù is only for the rich. From photovoltaic solar panels on the roof to engineered-wood joists, more efficient toilets and Energy Star-rated appliances, little has been overlooked in the effort to create a replicable, eco-friendly home.,â€œThis is probably the greenest house in Hartford County right now,â€ù said Adam Ney, president of AuctorVerno, a marketing firm in Bethany that promotes green construction and that helped Habitat identify environmentally friendly products and supplies. Each side of the duplex is 1,250 square feet, with three bedrooms and one and a half baths. Habitat and United Technologies, which sponsored the environmental upgrades, say they  hope that aspects of the home will be copied by other Habitat affiliates in the Northeast as they build homes for needy families.,â€œWhat weâ€™ve learned here, we are already duplicating nearby,â€ù said Shea Hagy, the construction supervisor, referring to 16 other Habitat homes going up in a two-block radius and four more in New Britain.,While Habitat follows standards for green design elsewhere in the country, it has not done so in the Northeast because of the harsher climate and a reluctance to deviate from standard practice, Mr. Hagy said. â€œItâ€™s easy to put up solar panels in San Diego, where itâ€™s sunny all the time,â€ù he said. â€œThereâ€™s less payback here, but it still makes a difference.â€ù,Solar energy will provide 40 percent of the homeâ€™s electricity, yielding a savings of about $360 a year, preliminary estimates show. Conservation should reduce water and gas bills by at least an additional $700, the developers predict. â€œThe energy savings is one more leg up for our families,â€ù said Julie Donahue, executive vice president of Hartford Area Habitat.,Sunlight Solar Energy, of Milford, the installer of the solar system, took advantage of a rebate program started in October 2004 by the Connecticut Clean Energy Fund, which typically gives back 55 percent of the installation cost. To date, 100 homes have qualified. New homes account for some installations, but most are in existing homes, said Bryan Garcia, the fundâ€™s director of energy market initiatives. Interest in solar power is growing as electric rates skyrocket and fears of a fuel crisis loom, he said.,Upfront costs are often higher in eco-friendly construction; in this case, materials added about 15 percent. But Habitat anticipates that reduced electrical and water consumption, the solar panel  rebate, durability and longer product warranties will make the home more cost-efficient in the long term.,The â€œgreenâ€ù effort extends to framing, furnishing and landscaping. Using two-by-six studs spaced every 24 inches, instead of two-by-fours at 16-inch intervals,  created deeper cavities for insulation. Overall, Mr. Hagy said, wood use is reduced by about 30 percent.,Household products and appliances were evaluated for air quality and environmental impact, Mr. Hagy said. Linoleum won out over vinyl flooring and carpeting for the high-traffic first floor because it comes from renewable resources, is easy to maintain and emits fewer volatile organic compounds (V.O.C.s), which emit potentially harmful gases.  Low-V.O.C. paints were chosen, and on the second floor, low-V.O.C. carpet squares, rather than rolls of carpeting and padding, helped reduce construction waste. Water-saving measures include restricted-flow plumbing devices, a front-loading washing machine and rain barrels to capture water for gardening and car-washing.,In terms of eco-building, â€œweâ€™re only scratching the tip of the iceberg,â€ù Mr. Hagy said, â€œbut for us, itâ€™s a big step.â€ù
column4: Building â€˜Greenâ€™ a Luxury? Not at All, Habitat Shows

column1: Oakdale,Despite the less-than-scintillating title, â€œInventory Controlâ€ù brings to the Anthony Giordano Gallery at Dowling College an  appealing group of works by seven artists, most of whom exhibit frequently. Some viewers may even recognize individual works, for a few have made the rounds of group shows in and around New York City.,Judith Page, a Brooklyn-based artist and curator,  is behind this  exhibition, which invites us to think about the role of lists, records, databases, statistical charts and graphs  â€”  what you might call inventory  â€”  in our lives. The artworks she has chosen reflect  the process of making lists, reports or records, as well as the kinds of items and ideas listed in them.,As a subject for artworks, inventory is not new. As Ms. Page points out in the exhibition catalog, we might understand the first, prehistoric scribblings of animals, humans and spirits on cave  walls  as a â€œsystem of classification.â€ù  They are something like a symbolic inventory.,Inventories for religious, civic, scientific or other purposes continued to be given visual representation throughout history. Most obviously, the hieroglyphs  often found inside ancient Egyptian temples and tombs listed the  possessions that the deceased owned in their  time on earth or that they thought they would need to live comfortably in the afterlife.,A similarly detailed, itemized record  of things in their possession was made by some of the artists in this exhibition, among them Elise Engler, who during  1997 and 1998 produced a detailed visual inventory of everything she owned. It is an extraordinary list, not to mention an appealing artwork:  17 panels containing 13,127 minute color drawings of every imaginable household object.,Similarly, Susan Hamburger inventories her personal possessions in small, cropped paintings of different aspects of a  kitchen, while Dahlia Elsayed charts changing emotional states, making inventory-oriented topographical paintings that associate geographical locations with moods, thoughts and states of mind. Her work, â€œStart of the Pre-Seasonâ€ù (2005), was painted late last summer, at a time of pleasant anticipation of  the months ahead  â€”  the beginning  of the new art season, the return to school and the buildup to the football season.,Chris Bors collects and inventories imagery from the Internet, which he then uses to create image collages and videos about youth culture. â€œLeaving My Boots in the Mosh Pitâ€ù (2005) is a compilation of found imagery of youths dancing and fighting at rock concerts. Nearby is â€œSlayer...Slayer...Slayer...â€ù (2003), a video of the artist, face obscured, recounting in nauseatingly adolescent  detail an alcohol-  and LSD-fueled visit to a  concert by the metal band Slayer in upstate New York. Here the inventory is of a personal experience.,Other works are less stimulating,   like Josh Jordanâ€™s collection of 33 quick sketches of beautiful women seen on New Yorkâ€™s L train, or Jim Costanzoâ€™s virtual performance, in which he inventories his daily activities through written records, digital photographs and scanned receipts, which are posted online and printed out in daily update sheets for viewers.,Then there is Charley Friedmanâ€™s â€œCarpet Worldâ€ù (2006), a humongous globe made of detailed sections of colored carpet. Here the notion of inventory relates more to the materials used by the artist, though the work makes you think of  stores like Carpet World, with their endless range of  styles and colors.,Mr. Friedmanâ€™s fuzzy, cuddly carpet globe has a haunting, momentous presence, though it is not clear why. Is it a comment on changing country configurations?  (He has not fully delineated the newly independent, post-Soviet Union states in Central Asia, for example.) Or  is it a metaphor for the ultimate inventory,  life on earth?
column4: Material Things, Cataloged

column1: One of winterâ€™s luxuries is a sweet, seedless navel orange. But this month in California, where most of the nationâ€™s eating oranges are grown, navels met with a killing frost. Although West Coast citrus will be fleetingly available as the last survivors are shipped, orange eaters will have to look beyond the Golden State for their vitamin C.,â€œItâ€™s going to be tricky,â€ù said Richard Thorpe, the produce buyer for Whole Foods markets in New England. â€œRetailers will turn to Florida, and prices will go up across the board.â€ù Florida citrus, he added, is sometimes â€œa little rougherâ€ù in appearance than the unblemished fruit from California, something that consumers will have to get used to.,In addition to the usual juice oranges and grapefruit, Mr. Thorpe will be scouting red navels, honey tangerines, royal mandarins and Minneola tangelos (also sold as Honeybells). The brilliant orange Minneola, a hybrid of the Dancy tangerine and Duncan grapefruit, is particularly sweet, and an easy peeler for lunch boxes.,Mr. Thorpe is also shopping abroad. â€œMoroccan clementines this year are fantastic,â€ù he said. â€œTheyâ€™re cheaper than California clementines because theyâ€™re loaded on large ocean vessels, and bulk freight lowers our landed prices.â€ù,Oranges, no matter their country of origin, lend themselves to maceration, or soaking in their own sugared juice.  Red navels,  with their prom-pink flesh, make a particularly cheerful winter dessert. Using a sharp knife, peel the rind and membrane from the oranges; slice or section them, remove any seeds, toss with a heaping teaspoon of sugar per orange, and refrigerate for a few hours. (You can even  add juice from an extra orange or two.) Serve straight up, or with vanilla ice cream.
column4: Consider Your Citrus Options

column1: For four decades, John Hechinger ran a hardware and home supplies chain founded by his father in 1911. In 1978, as part of an expansion, he moved the corporate headquarters to suburban Washington, D.C. Soon after, he began  collecting art to humanize  the somewhat sterile building.   Believing in the relationship between the tools his company made and the work that artists produced, he hoped the art would inspire his workers.,Mr. Hechinger died in 2004, but the collection he established has continued to grow through  acquisitions overseen by International Arts & Artists, a Washington-based traveling exhibition service that was given control of the collection after his death.,Touring nationally since 2001,  â€œTools as Art: The Hechinger Collectionâ€ù has touched down at the ,,  filling the museumâ€™s main exhibition galleries with 64 works by almost as many artists. It is surprisingly poetic, optimistic and intriguing.,Tools have a small but appreciable place in art history, mostly in the context of labor imagery. Prehistoric cave paintings in France and Spain have schematic diagrams of primitive implements, evidence of the first stirrings of human tool making, and scenes of peasants working the soil are found throughout ancient art. Farming returned as   a popular theme in art,  beginning with medieval paintings and prayer books, like the Book of Hours,  and continuing on through the 19th century.,But it was not really until the 20th century that tools became the subject of artworks. As Sarah Tanguy, curator of the Hechinger collection, points out in the exhibition catalog, depicting tools became for artists a â€œmeans to bridge the gap between art and life, and to address the shifting definition of perception.â€ù She is right, though it may also have had something to do with questioning the traditional artistic process as an act of creation, an act of making.,Art critics do not talk much about craftsmanship these days, preferring to dwell on ideas or the clever statements an artist seeks to convey. This is largely because of Marcel Duchamp, who was probably the first artist to make an artwork out of real tools. With his ready-mades, beginning in 1914-15, he claimed the right of anyone to become an artist by choosing an object and putting it in a gallery. Among his early ready-mades was a snow shovel.,Several artists in this exhibition share Duchampâ€™s anarchic values, like Arman, the late French artist who made sculptures using mass-produced tools like wrenches, handsaws, pliers and paintbrushes. (He is also known for his public-destruction artworks, like dynamiting a sports car.)  Shown here is â€œBlue, Red, Brownâ€ù (1988), something between a painting and a collage â€” thick stripes of paint end in paintbrushes, stuck to the canvas.,Similarly, Tracy Heneberger uses hardware-store materials like hinges to concoct adorably original, elegantly constructed sculptures, and the Chicago-based, self-taught artist known only as Mr. Imagination makes shadowy, masklike portraits using paintbrushes and found materials. There is something very African about the paintbrush portraits, though the artistâ€™s sources of inspiration include Christianity, world affairs, politics and popular culture.,In addition to paintbrushes and hammers, saw blades are popular, both as  subject and material for artists. Ken Butler and Donald Lipski employ saw blades in assemblage sculptures that tend toward minimalism. Several artists also use the blades as a painting surface, including Jacob J. Kass, Howard Finster, Lou Horner, Oleg Kudryashov, Rico Solinas, Wim Delvoye and John Schlesinger. Others make replicas of handsaws out of paper and wood.,Mr. Finster, who was born in Alabama in 1916 and died in 2001, was one of Americaâ€™s best-known folk artists. The exhibition catalog tells us that he experienced visions from an early age and was later to become a revivalist Baptist preacher. He â€œheard the callâ€ù to paint â€œsacred artâ€ù only in 1976, subsequently cranking out crudely evangelical paintings and sculptures, commonly linking words and images. Shown here is a painted Stanley handsaw from 1990, dealing with the history of tools.,There are also older, historical works of art, including a lush black-and-white photograph of a New York hardware store, a sign in the front window advertising a sale on tools. Berenice Abbott took the photograph in 1938 as part of a government-sponsored project to document the city and its inhabitants. It makes for a splendid period piece, the storeâ€™s owner having lined the window and pavement outside the store with all manner of items and implements.,If   Abbott sought to convey a wealth of detail about the subjects she documented, Walker Evans, her contemporary, was interested in economical, precise images that conveyed elegance, simplicity and restraint. So it is with â€œWrenchâ€ù (1955), part of a series of photographs titled â€œBeauties of the Common Toolâ€ù that was originally published in Fortune magazine. It is a chilly, no-fuss, front-on portrait, the tool stripped and reduced to its bare essentials.,Evans introduced this series of photographs on the beauties of the common tool to readers of Fortune with a brief essay, in which he stated what Mr. Hechinger seemed to know all along:  â€œAlmost all basic small tools stand, aesthetically speaking, for elegance, candor and purity.â€ù
column4: Looking in the Toolbox and Seeing Art

column1: SQUIRRELS are cute enough when they are providing acrobatic entertainment swiping seeds from your bird feeder. But they can also be equally determined at getting into your house.,â€œSquirrels arenâ€™t just mean â€” theyâ€™re vicious,â€ù said Thomas Barnes, an extension professor of forestry at the University of Kentucky in Lexington.,Squirrels will rarely enter a house at ground level; they almost always go in at the roof line. In finished attics, they will nest in the walls or ceilings, where they sometimes hold noisy acorn-rolling tournaments. In unfinished attics, they will often nest between the attic floor and the ceiling of the room below.,Dr. Barnes said that while holes or gaps around the roof provide easy access for a squirrel that prefers your warm house to the scant comfort of a hollow tree, easy access hardly matters. â€œHeck, they can chew through hardware cloth and chicken wire,â€ù he said. â€œVinylâ€™s not even a challenge.â€ù,Squirrels typically breed at the end of winter, and that can create additional problems if they have nested indoors. â€œYou canâ€™t remove mama and leave the babies there,â€ù Dr. Barnes said. â€œAnd you donâ€™t want to mess with the nest while the mother is around. Iâ€™ve seen people whoâ€™ve had the tip of their finger taken off.â€ù,While squirrels will gnaw beams, tear out insulation and transport nuts, fleas and ticks into a house,  the most serious threat they pose is chewing on electrical wires, which could cause a fire.,James Dreisacker, the owner of Westchester Wildlife Control in ,, N.Y., says his squirrel strategy depends upon the circumstances. Since squirrels leave the house in search of food during the day, he often uses single-catch traps that fit right over whatever hole the squirrels are using.,When a squirrel family is involved, he will set out one or more â€œmulti-catchâ€ù traps on the roof. The most enticing squirrel bait, Mr. Dreisacker said, is store-bought peanuts.,Bob Meakin, the president of the , Wildlife Management Association, a trade group in Syracuse, said that since it was illegal to release captured squirrels on public or private land without permission, most experts euthanize any animals  they capture, which is legal. (Homeowners can do the same.),Chuck Kaczyk, the owner of Animal and Wildlife Control in Saddlebrook, N.J., holds the patent on a device that provides one-way access to squirrels, and that one way is out.,â€œThe One-Way Door is a cylindrical tube with a flapper valve that the squirrel can crawl through,â€ù Mr. Kaczyk said. â€œItâ€™s kind of like a check valve on a sewer line.â€ù,The One-Way Door is affixed to the opening the squirrels are using, and once a squirrel goes out, it canâ€™t get back in.,After all the squirrels have left, all potential entry points must be sealed tightly with plywood, heavy-gauge aluminum flashing or steel mesh. The cost to eliminate a family of squirrels from an average house starts at about $300, Mr. Kaczyk said.,The common gray or black squirrels are not the only nuisances. Douglas Stern, the owner of the Stern Environmental Group, a pest-control company in Secaucus, N.J., said, â€œWeâ€™re seeing more problems with flying squirrels,â€ù a smaller cousin that has a flap of skin between its front and back legs that allows it to glide long distances.,The problem, Mr. Stern said, is that flying squirrels, which are nocturnal, act more like mice than squirrels. As a result, pest-control people often use poisons to eliminate them. And that, he said, is illegal because rodenticides are not labeled for use on squirrels.,The best way to get rid of flying squirrels, Mr. Stern said, is to use  chipmunk traps baited with peanut butter. â€œEliminating flying squirrels can take a while,â€ù he said, â€œbecause youâ€™re basically catching them one at a time.â€ù
column4: Giving Squirrels the Heave-Ho

column1: DOUGLAS PINTER, a San Francisco real estate developer and the former chief executive of a long-forgotten Internet start-up, is used to the ups and downs of the business world, but his introduction to the pitfalls of , real estate has been a bit abrupt.,Just last month, Mr. Pinter closed on his $2.4 million 10th-floor apartment in a notable new condominium, the Urban Glass House, the last residential commission of Philip Johnson, modeled loosely on the architectâ€™s own home in , and marketed as a â€œmodernist luxury residence.â€ù,Mr. Pinter liked the buildingâ€™s light and airy look, even though its location, at Spring and Washington Streets, was in a grungy no-name land between Greenwich Village, TriBeCa and SoHo. It is across the street from ventilation shafts for the Holland Tunnel. Still, some upper-floor apartments have views to the south, and most of the apartments have views of the river to the north and west. At least for now.,But  in the last month, with most of the 40 apartments in the building sold or in contract, the New York City Sanitation Department said that it planned to take over a large parking lot just to the north and diagonally opposite the Urban Glass House. It would put up a garage as tall as a 15-story building and longer than a football field that promises to block much of the view of the river from many apartments.,Having a view blocked by a newer, bigger building is an old story in New York. But seldom has the view from such a distinctive building been threatened so soon after the ink on so many sales contracts has dried. The building opened in October.,Since then, Mr. Pinter and his neighbors, an affluent mix of models, minor celebrities and Wall Street executives who spent $2  million or more for their apartments, have been gathering information and organizing.,Mr. Pinter, who calls himself semiretired, said he was looking for â€œlike-minded residentsâ€ù to join him at a hearing called by the Sanitation Department to discuss plans for the new garage.,â€œItâ€™s a shame,â€ù Mr. Pinter said. â€œInvariably something would have been built there, but here is a building that was critically acclaimed architecturally, modest in size and scale and not gaudy, facing a consolidated sanitation garage.â€ù,The Sanitation Department plan was put forth in a 46-page document posted on the departmentâ€™s Web site. The document was dated Dec. 28 but was first spotted in early January by residents of the neighborhood. The plans call for putting up a garage 140 to 150 feet high on the lot, which is bounded by Spring, Washington and West Streets and to the north by a large office and warehouse building.   The Urban Glass House tops out at 137 feet.,The garageâ€™s ground floor would be used by the United Parcel Service, which now parks its trucks on the lot, while the rest of the building would be used by the Sanitation Department, consolidating three garages. A smaller garage just to the south of the parking lot and next to the ventilation shafts would be turned into a truck wash and refueling depot, storing 13,000 gallons of fuel and oil.,Vito Turso, a deputy sanitation commissioner, said that the garage was needed to replace garages along the river in the newly established Hudson River Park. â€œWe are trying to be as understanding and as good a neighbor as we can to that community,â€ù Mr. Turso said, â€œrecognizing that we still need to provide refuse collection, recycling and snow removal to that part of town.â€ù,Abe Shnay, a partner in the group that developed the Urban Glass House, said that buyers were still signing contracts and that most were aware that the parking lot could someday be developed. At one point, he said, there were rumors that a high-rise would go up on the site. â€œThe reality is that on the upper floors the best views are to the south, incredible views of the upper harbor and the Statue of Liberty,â€ù he said.,But Michael Shvo, the president of Shvo Marketing, a real estate company that is not involved with the Urban Glass House, said he always tells buyers,  â€œThere are only two views in New York that are guaranteed: if you are on a park, or if you are facing a brick wall.â€ù,CRAIG NEVILL-MANNING, the director of engineering at Googleâ€™s rapidly expanding New York office, knows how to find needles in what he calls a â€œ20 terabyte haystack.â€ù,Mr. Nevill-Manning, who invented Googleâ€™s Froogle shopping service, has now also threaded the real estate needle and landed one of downtownâ€™s most unusual and, for a while, hardest-to-sell properties: the rooftop English castle topped by a live-in copper dome at 150 Nassau Street, an ornate turn-of-the-last-century building that was once New Yorkâ€™s tallest skyscraper.,Mr. Nevill-Manning and his wife, Kristin, who also works at Googleâ€™s New York office, have just closed on one of the most expensive condominiums in the financial district, paying $6.45 million for the penthouse, which has 6,400 square feet of space spread over three floors atop a Romanesque and Renaissance Revival building, according to brokers briefed on the transaction.,The apartment has a 30-by-30-foot outdoor deck,  a private terrace that winds around the steep copper-clad roof, huge semicircular windows, 18-foot ceilings and a 360-degree view â€”  at least until the developer Forest City builds a 75-story skyscraper on the site of a parking lot for New York Downtown Hospital nearby. It has one major drawback, however: the space has no plumbing or electricity or interior walls, and it needs work estimated to cost $2 million or more, depending on the detail, before anyone can move in.,But if you want to know one version of what it might look like, you might look at the Spike Lee film â€œInside Man,â€ù released last year and starring Denzel Washington. The space was dressed up and appeared as the office of Jodie Fosterâ€™s character, a mysterious power broker.,The apartment was the last unsold unit in the 23-story building, a city landmark, built in 1895 as the American Tract Society Building. It happened to go on the market just days before the attack on the World Trade Center in September 2001.,Over the last few years, the apartment was offered through some of the largest brokerages in the city, Prudential Douglas Elliman and Brown Harris Stevens. It was finally sold by Adam Modlin and Reuben Davis of the Modlin Group, a small firm. Along the way, the asking price went from $12 million, including a $2 million credit toward the cost of the interior, to $6.9 million.,HOW much is celebrity really worth? Only two years after the actress Gwyneth Paltrow and her husband, Chris Martin, the British rocker, paid $7.95 million for a 7,000-square-foot condominium in TriBeCa, they have put it back on the market for an even $14 million.,The apartment on Harrison Street has 1,600 square feet of gardens and outdoor space, including a rooftop soaking pool, an elevator, a steam shower, six bedrooms and four and half baths. It also has  a finished basement with two washers and two dryers.,The listing broker, Carter Wilcox of the Corcoran Group, did not return telephone calls. But Stephen Huvane, Ms. Paltrowâ€™s publicist, said â€œconsiderableâ€ù work had been done on the unit. â€œI really doubt there is such a thing as â€˜celebrityâ€™ value at that price range,â€ù he said. â€œBut I am not a real estate professional.â€ù
column4: Few Views Are Forever

column1: WHEN it comes to affairs of the heart, Robert Romanoâ€™s newest romance is proving to be his most expensive. The object of his affection â€” his wife, Regina, describes it as an obsession â€” is the coupleâ€™s 1920s colonial style home,  a house where , lived and painted many memorable covers for The Saturday Evening Post.,In all, the artist lived here for 23 years, 13 of them on Lord Kitchener Road in the north end, in a tidy colonial with white shingles and a slate roof. It cost Mr. and Mrs. Romano $1.6 million to buy and $500,000 to restore, so far â€” and their work has just begun.,Special homes and intense feelings often go together, according to Bruce MacDonald, an architectural preservationist from Tarrytown, who said Mr. Romano is not alone in falling in love with a house.,Even when a structure is not serving as a museum or listed on a historic register, owners are sometimes moved to honor its original design or history, Mr. MacDonald said. His firm, Ashwood Restoration, is overseeing the rehabilitation of the Jay mansion in Rye, a Greek Revival house built in the 1850s by Peter Augustus Jay, the son of John Jay, the first chief justice of the United States Supreme Court.,â€œThe Rockwell house is a notable building, and just because it doesnâ€™t have a landmark designation now doesnâ€™t mean it wonâ€™t someday,â€ù said Mr. MacDonald, who has been hired by Mr. and Mrs. Romano as a consultant for the section of the house that was the artistâ€™s studio.,Obtaining landmark status, however, often entails returning parts of a building to their original state. And although the new owners are intent on faithfully restoring sections of the Rockwell home, they have not yet decided how much to do and whether to apply for such a designation.,For the Romanos, longtime New Rochelle residents, the story of their relationship to this Rockwell home  â€” during his lifetime, the artist also lived in Vermont and Massachusetts  â€” began two years ago.,To gain more space for entertaining, the couple, who have two children â€” a daughter, Tessa, 19, who is a college student, and a son, Andrew, 25, who lives at home â€” had drawn up plans to expand their previous home. â€œWe had been working for six months with an architect,â€ù said Mr. Romano, 55, a corporate lawyer in ,. â€œBut then one Sunday afternoon we saw this house, and we couldnâ€™t resist it because it had had so much light and so much history.â€ù,They knew the property had belonged to Rockwell â€” Tessa had once done a school project about him â€” and they liked his work. But it was the details of the house itself that initially won them over.,The 5,300-square-foot two-story home, which has four bedrooms and four and a half baths, is in an established neighborhood of older Tudors and colonials, where houses have recently sold for $869,000 to around $2 million, according to Kathleen McAteer, the manager of Century 21 Wolff in New Rochelle.,â€œWe moved here in November 2005,â€ù Mr. Romano said, pointing around the artistâ€™s studio, â€œand as you can see, weâ€™ve been in some form of renovation and reconstruction ever since. Everything in this house has turned out to be a big project.â€ù,The costly slate roof on the house had to be replaced, and the aluminum siding (which the couple considered out of character with the residence of a painter of homespun American scenes) was torn away, revealing the original, but rotting, shingles, which also had to be replaced.,Window frames around the house were in various states of decay. And in the artistâ€™s studio,  a sill underneath the largest window, which allowed the north light to flow in, was rotting.,â€œMy contractor kept saying, â€˜Tear the place down!â€™ â€ù Mr. Romano said. â€œHe said it would be cheaper and less trouble. And maybe heâ€™s right, but thatâ€™s not what weâ€™re doing.â€ù,Mr. Romano has spent many hours researching the history of the house, and he and his wife say they plan to continue restoring whatever they can afford to do.,Explaining why owners sometimes lose their heads over a house, Audra Brecher, a preservation specialist for Stephen Tilly Architect in Dobbs Ferry, said: â€œOften, people are captivated by living in a famous personâ€™s home. Our buildings tell us stories, and people have romantic notions about the past.â€ù,Researching the architecture of southern Westchester during the early part of the 20th century, Mr. and Mrs. Romano unearthed a 1926 article in Good Housekeeping magazine about their house. From the text and photos, Mr. Romano was able to design new garage doors that matched the originals.,To replace the rotting sill in the studio, the large window above it had to be broken, but the Romanos replaced it with a window that looks the same, although the new glass is insulated.,In the main part of the house, the large brass lock on the front door had long been broken, workable only from the inside. The hardware was repaired and the brass restored by Accurate Lock in Stamford, Conn.,Leaving as much in place as possible in the studio â€” including the large brick hearth and the wagon wheel chandelier  â€”  Mr. and Mrs. Romano will turn Mr. Rockwellâ€™s former quarters into a media room.,Aside from all the high-minded reasons for buying this house, Mr. Romano admits to another consideration: sitting unplugged in his living room is a four-piece set of high-powered cherry-wood Bowers & Wilkins speakers designed to be used in home media centers.,As Mrs. Romano remembers it: â€œFor 15 years, I wanted to move to a bigger home, and my husband always resisted. Then, when he bought the speakers, which were too loud for our old house, I told him we had to either move to a larger place or get rid of them.â€ù,Someday, when all of the work is completed in the studio, Mr. Romano said, he will finally plug in the speakers, pull down a screen, sink into a comfortable chair and experience some of his favorite films in their full glory.
column4: Falling in Love With a House and Its History

column1: GREENBELT, Md.,THE old section of this city in Prince Georgeâ€™s County, built by the federal government for affordable housing during the Depression, is not a gated community. Yet the way Phillip Payette describes it, it might as well be.,â€œI donâ€™t have to leave too much,â€ù said Mr. Payette, a self-employed illustrator who works from his home, a 1937 brick town house with a slate roof. â€œBut I donâ€™t like to go too far anyway.â€ù,A glance at his surroundings may explain this homebody tendency. From his door, an oak-lined path curves past a row of well-kept attached homes, to a small commercial center where he can shop, see movies or swim.
