Nearby, farmland, reached past parks and ponds, offers dirt roads for rides on  his mountain bike.,Even though Capitol Hill is 12 miles away, and the city border of Washington even closer, here it is leafy, walkable and clean, evoking the European-style â€œgarden cityâ€ù that it was built to resemble.,Yet, as much as old Greenbelters praise their neighborhood, they criticize the very un-Greenbelt way their city has allowed the haphazard development of some of its land.,Shopping centers like the Beltway Plaza Mall have replaced tobacco farms and forests, and the roads that lead to them, like Kenilworth Avenue, are frequently clogged with traffic. So is Interstate 495, the Beltway, which roars nearby.,To make matters worse, crime is also a problem. With about 22,000 residents, Greenbelt had 158 reported robberies and 247 stolen cars in 2006. Most of those incidents, police records show, took place at Springhill Lake, a 2,900-unit building that is among the East Coastâ€™s largest apartment complexes.,Now, in a city where us-versus-them tensions already run high, old Greenbelters are bracing for a wave of newcomers, courtesy of two developments, whose combined total will almost double the number of homes in the city.,For the first project, a $750 million plan from the Apartment Investment Management Corporation calls for tearing down Springhill Lake, a 157-acre property that the developer already owns, and replacing it with 5,800 homes and 10,000 square feet of commercial space. Around 35 percent of the units will be owner-occupied and the rest will be rentals, according to the developer.,The second, Greenbelt Station, is a $2 billion proposal from Metroland Development for 2,200 homes and 2.7 million square feet of commercial space across a 130-acre lot that is now mainly a gravel pit and parking lots. The development will also abut a train station that serves lines of Washingtonâ€™s Metro and MARC, Marylandâ€™s commuter train.,â€œYou can live, work and shop there,â€ù said Walter H. Petrie, the chairman of Petrie Ross Ventures, which is a partner in Metroland Development. â€œWeâ€™re basically building a new town.â€ù,To do so, Mr. Petrie and his architects said they studied old Greenbelt. Its collection of homes and shops, separated with bands of greenery, has design elements in common with a modern â€œlifestyle center,â€ù with its open-air commercial districts, central squares and small parks. Mr. Petrie is currently building four other lifestyle centers in Maryland, he said.,Greenbelt Station will also emphasize pedestrians over cars, featuring wide sidewalks lined with benches and plantings.,That developers found inspiration so close to their work site is a coincidence not lost on planners. â€œOne of the best examples in the country of a walkable development is right across the street,â€ù said Chad Williams, the planner coordinator for Maryland-National Capital Park and Planning Commission, which must approve both development proposals. â€œItâ€™s cyclical how the older ideas rise again.â€ù,In both projects, lighting will play a major role. While the glare canâ€™t be too harsh, developers said, it also must be bright and direct enough to deter criminals. This is of particular concern in Springhill Lake. Lighting choices will be weighed seriously so the new complex doesnâ€™t have as many shadowy, trouble-prone corners as the current one, said Patti Shwayder, a senior vice president for the Apartment Investment Management Corporation.,â€œThe security of our buildings is very important to us,â€ù she said.,In comparison to its neighbors, old Greenbelt, with 1,800 units, is small. About half of the units along its fishhook-shaped plot of land are owned by a co-op, which bought them from the federal government in the early 1950s. Recent listings put their prices at $210,000 to $315,000 for two-story homes with 1,000 square feet.,In addition, for a fee of about a $400 a month, maintenance workers will empty trash cans, trim hedges and patch roofs.,Scattered among them are rentals, built in the 1960s, and single-family homes that went up in the 1990s.,Despite the effect that thousands of new residents could have on their neighborhood, old Greenbelters generally support the two new projects.,For its part, Greenbelt Station will contribute ball fields, a community center and a pool to the city (promises that resulted from an eight-year battle, including a lawsuit).,And if Springhill Lakeâ€™s crime-prevention tactics pay off, residents say, it will be an improvement on the original.,â€œItâ€™s better to have owner-occupied units than the rentals, which attract more transients,â€ù said Sylvia Lewis, the co-opâ€™s president, who has lived in the same two-bedroom house since 1968. â€œIt will be better.â€ù,To hedge her bets, though, this fall, Ms. Lewis started the Greenbelt Community Foundation, which will provide grants of $500 to $2,500 for local not-for-profit groups working to improve the city, in line with old Greenbeltâ€™s utopian values, she said,â€œOur ideals are very fragile,â€ù Ms. Lewis said, â€œand they have to be strengthened with every new generation.â€ù,Greenbelt isnâ€™t the only Roosevelt-era planned neighborhood facing development pressure. Greenhills, Ohio, which was also built in 1937, faces perhaps a more severe threat.,In the last few years, developers in Greenhills have torn down 20 of the neighborhoodâ€™s original 700 homes to make way for larger ones, said Deborah Mills, president of the Greenhills Historical Society, which opposes the teardowns. Unlike the homes in Greenbelt, those in Greenhills are owned by the town, which can decide their fate.,â€œTheyâ€™ve torn down the International style homes and replaced them with ones that would fit on the South Carolina shore,â€ù Ms. Mills said.,In some ways, controversy has followed these â€œgreenâ€ù enclaves since Rexford Guy Tugwell, head of President Rooseveltâ€™s Resettlement Administration, dreamed them up as a way to offer families state-of-the-art rental housing, close to major cities, where unemployed adults might find work. (Greenhills is outside Cincinnati, while Greendale, a third such community, is a suburb of Milwaukee.),Ardent free-market capitalists criticized the governmentâ€™s involvement in the real estate business. The $10 million price to build Greenbelt was also called expensive.,Local Maryland farmers even worried that the workers for the project would steal their apples, according to Jill St. John, curator of the Greenbelt Museum.,Michael Sorkin, a New York-based architect who grew up in Washington, has included elements of garden cities like Greenbelt in his work for cities in the United States and abroad.,For him, the New Urbanist trend, which favors highly compact developments that resemble urban downtowns, owes a debt to neighborhoods like Greenbelt, which efficiently uses its space, he said.,â€œThe urban crisis of the moment is sprawl,â€ù he said, â€œSo Iâ€™m glad that the idea of the garden city has not yet run its course.â€ù
column4: Merging the Old With the New in a Washington Suburb

column1: RELOCATING from San Francisco, Andrew Wagner and Heather Bradley Wagner had few requirements for their new New York home.,They wanted a one-bedroom apartment within walking distance of Mr. Wagnerâ€™s office in SoHo that had â€œenough space to let us coexist in our second year of marriage,â€ù Mrs. Wagner said.,â€œThere werenâ€™t a lot of deal breakers at the outset,â€ù she said. â€œThe one thing we didnâ€™t want was a high-rise with no character. We were looking for a place that had interesting history and wasnâ€™t generic.â€ù,Mr. Wagner, 33, a founding editor of Dwell magazine, was relocating to take a job as editor in chief of American Craft, charged with reviving that 60-year-old magazine. Mrs. Wagner, 30, a freelance writer, contributes to the magazine Domino.,The two, who are native Californians, met through friends and married a year ago. She joined him in his two-bedroom, $1,200-a-month rental in Pacific Heights.,Mrs. Wagner was visiting New York in the fall for a relativeâ€™s birthday celebration. So she extended her trip to hunt for a home â€” an endeavor that, at that point, both thought would be enjoyable and exciting.,Though Mrs. Wagnerâ€™s sister, Pamela Bradley, lives on the Upper East Side, Mrs. Wagner stayed primarily with her sisterâ€™s boyfriend, Jack Jarowicz. He lives in Peter Cooper Village, which was much closer to the areas where she was hunting. And, unlike her sister, he had Internet access at home.,With Mr. Wagnerâ€™s new position, their budget allowed for $2,800 a month â€” or $3,000 at the very most. Compared with San Francisco, â€œwe were going to be at the upper end; we were kind of high-rolling,â€ù he said.,In Lower ,, however, it proved to be an awkward amount. One-bedrooms in that price range existed, but â€œeach place I looked at, I didnâ€™t want to stay a minute more than was polite,â€ù Mrs. Wagner said.,â€œI was uncomfortable being in the spaces, which seemed to portend bad things to come,â€ù she said.,Through friends, she heard of a $2,700 vacancy in Chelsea. â€œIt was sort of subterranean,â€ù with a sorry-looking backyard â€œwalled in by buildings and dead plants,â€ù Mrs. Wagner said. The backyard didnâ€™t compensate for the small size. â€œWe canâ€™t live in a backyard!â€ù she exclaimed.,Inside a Second Avenue place, she saw a â€œfrighteningly rickety loft-bed structure.â€ù Outside a SoHo building, she was asked for spare change and offered drugs.,In the East Village, she got the â€œhard sell like I have never experienced in my life.â€ù The apartment was filled with sawdust and construction workers. Only when she asked to see it again did she learn there were not, as she had been told, a dozen eager applicants. â€œThat was an eye opener,â€ù she said, the creation of fictional demand to rope you in.,â€œI think Iâ€™m pretty resilient, but the hunt beat me down,â€ù she said. â€œI was feeling pretty hopeless.â€ù,Her husband, wrapping up his work at Dwell, tried to calm her over the phone. â€œAs the days went on, I heard her voice change from enthusiastic to tearful, tearful, tearful,â€ù he said. â€œHeather gets mad at me to this day. I have no concept of how terrible it was other than vicariously.â€ù,They decided to take the first nice place she saw: a quaint one-bedroom, renting for $2,700 in a co-op building on a tree-lined West Village street. The 450-square-foot apartment had little closet space, but came with basement storage.,The coupleâ€™s sublease agreement was contingent upon approval of the co-op board. â€œThe broker kept saying, â€˜Iâ€™m sure you can do a phone interview; you are going to be fine,â€™ â€ù Mr. Wagner said. When they were told they had to meet the board in person after all, they scheduled a date to do so and booked a moving company.,Then came â€œthe most frustrating call Iâ€™ve ever received,â€ù Mrs. Wagner said. They had to fly out a week earlier to meet the board. They dropped everything to book a one-day trip.,With the emergence of so many glitches, they started to fear they would be rejected, â€œbut we had no other choice because thatâ€™s where we had put all our eggs,â€ù Mr. Wagner said. If need be, the movers could haul their stuff to a storage facility in ,.,They anxiously searched Craigslist, the Web site, for a backup place and found an unusual listing: a 900-square-foot TriBeCa one-bedroom, with 14-foot ceilings, for $2,800 a month. The landlords, a married couple, replied quickly to their e-mail message. They often rented to artists and architects, like themselves, and kept the rent low so they had a good choice of tenants.,The Wagners arranged to see the apartment during their one day in New York. It was â€œrough around the edges,â€ù Mr. Wagner said, but had character galore. The centerpiece was a big white cube, originally a darkroom, with a sleeping area on top. The landlord had designed it himself three decades ago, when he bought the building, which may have once been a textile warehouse.,The Wagners even knew one of the unitâ€™s previous occupants â€” Matthew Baird, an architect. â€œI love that cube,â€ù Mr. Baird said, calling it â€œa great â€™70s omnibus space dividerâ€ù with a â€œminimalist spirit.â€ù,The Wagners were offered a lease, though they felt bound to keep their appointment at the West Village apartment, which Mr. Wagner had not yet seen.,When they asked to see the storage space at that apartment, they were told it contained the ownerâ€™s stuff and wasnâ€™t available. That was the final indignity. They said â€œthanks but no thanksâ€ù to the board members, who â€œwere so nice it was like having tea at your grandmotherâ€™s house,â€ù Mrs. Wagner said.,They rushed back to the TriBeCa building, signed the lease and called the movers, who were at their San Francisco place, packing.,The West Village broker later complained that they willfully defaulted on the lease, but took no action against them. â€œNo one said it was our apartment until we said we didnâ€™t want it,â€ù Mr. Wagner said. â€œIf it was our apartment, we never would have flown out here on a momentâ€™s notice and dropped $1,000 to come out here for just one day.â€ù,Their new apartment, big enough to fit much of their furniture and artwork, feels both expansive and homey. Inside the cube is a small office and closet, where they plan to add a guest bed.,â€œI feel kind of a rube because I am so obsessed with the story of this place,â€ù Mr. Wagner said, â€œand now I realize every place in New York has a story like this.â€ù
column4: Finding a Cube, Feeling Like a â€˜Rubeâ€™

column1: IT was shortly after he appeared on the television show â€œQueer Eye for the Straight Guyâ€ù that Jeff Berman decided he couldnâ€™t continue sharing an apartment near Battery Park with four roommates.,He still liked his roommates, but suddenly, he didnâ€™t trust them with his furniture. The apartmentâ€™s fraternity house atmosphere, he said, hadnâ€™t worried him â€œwhen we had a couch that cost $140, which we had split five ways.â€ù,But now that â€œQueer Eyeâ€ù had furnished the place with stylish pieces from Desiron in SoHo, Mr. Berman started feeling protective. â€œIt is really nice stuff,â€ù he said, pointing to a zebra-wood desk and a dining room set that could be on the cover of House & Garden. â€œI felt like the nagging mother,â€ù he said.,So he was happy when a friend, Lauren Reece, asked him to share her 1,400-square-foot loft on Lower Broadway.,Ms. Reece, an owner of Billyâ€™s Bakery, a 1950â€™s-style Chelsea institution, had also been on â€œQueer Eye,â€ù not as a contestant, but as a dessert maven. At the time, she was Billy Reece and had not yet begun the transition from man to woman.,For  Mr. Berman, a young  lawyer who  had met Ms. Reece  â€” then Billy â€” at a bar in Chelsea two years before,  moving in with a transsexual required a leap of faith. He was worried that a host of changes, physical as well as psychological, would make the perky  Ms. Reece â€œa bit unstable.â€ù,As it turns out, domestic tranquillity reigns. The two roommates could pass for a suburban couple: Mr. Berman, 26, in workout pants and a T-shirt, Ms. Reece, 28, in a pink cardigan and  pearl necklace.,Home from work, Mr. Berman drinks a beer while Ms. Reece, who is  perfecting  her feminine figure, eyes a protein bar (not one of the cupcakes for which Billyâ€™s Bakery is famous).,Mr. Bermanâ€™s bedroom is enclosed, at one end of the loft; Ms. Reeceâ€™s is reached by a stairway and sits atop the bathroom and laundry room, at the other end. The space separating them, with 14-foot ceilings and large, south-facing windows, is filled with the â€œQueer Eyeâ€ù furniture.,â€œIt was a boondoggle,â€ù said Mr. Berman of his appearance on â€œQueer Eye.â€ù(He is gay; his episode was about making a gay man â€œgayer.â€ù),Ms. Reece, too, has received free furniture from a television show. In 2005, â€œLaw & Order: Criminal Intentâ€ù rented the loft for two days of shooting and in the process built a large storage unit, which the producers were glad to leave behind. These days, the shelves hold part of Ms. Reeceâ€™s collection of  jadeite dishes, mostly from the 1940â€™s.,Against another wall is a large collection of American cookbooks, including a rare second edition of  â€œJoy of Cooking.â€ù Cookbooks â€œtrace social history,â€ù Ms. Reece said, reflecting every change in society, from the Depression, to shortages in wartime, to new technologies.,She also has every issue of Everyday Food magazine, published by Martha Stewart, one of her idols. In fact, she appeared on Marthaâ€™s TV show last May; at the time, she was introduced as Billy, though with long hair and a somewhat feminine appearance as a result of hormone treatments.,â€œMartha was cool, but some of the stagehands were a little surprised,â€ù said Ms. Reece, who added that more recently, she had been rejected by TV shows after explaining that Billy no longer exists.,All of which intrigues the mild-mannered Mr. Berman, who came to New York in 2002 from Philadelphia to attend Columbia Law School. Before that, as an undergraduate at the University of Pennsylvania, he said, he was completely closeted, but by 2002 he was ready to explore life as a gay man in ,.,During law school, he first lived in student housing near Grantâ€™s Tomb, then moved with several of his classmates to the apartment downtown. In the process of coming out, he began blogging about his experiences. A producer at â€œQueer Eyeâ€ù read his blog, which mentioned the four straight roommates, and recognized a hook for an unusual episode.,It begins with the â€œQueer Eyeâ€ù cast  â€”  the Fab Five â€” meeting Mr. Berman and his roommates and trying to figure out which one is gay. (They didnâ€™t pick Mr. Berman.),At the time, the apartment had no discernible style, and Mr. Berman was flabbergasted when, in just four days,  Thom Filicia and his team transformed it into a trendy bachelorsâ€™ pad. (He also received thousands of dollarsâ€™ worth of clothes, including a white dinner jacket, and cooking lessons at the French Culinary Institute.),In the meantime, Billy Reece had some good luck of his own. After working at the Magnolia Bakery, an impossibly popular spot in the West Village, he left to start Billyâ€™s with two partners. The business was a success almost from the day it opened in December 2003. Also in 2003, a friend, Tad Beck, invited him to share the loft.,In the late 1990â€™s, the owner of the building, which houses several theater companies as well as residential tenants, went bankrupt; the banks that took over the building tried to evict the tenants, Mr. Beck said. The tenants hired lawyers and ultimately won a settlement allowing them to stay in the building for life at rents far below market. Mr. Beck, the actual leaseholder, pays about $2,200 a month and is subject to only tiny annual increases.,He and Ms. Reece were roommates until Mr. Beck decided to attend art school in California. Thatâ€™s when Ms. Reece asked Mr. Berman to move in, which involved bringing his â€œQueer Eyeâ€ù  furniture, now intermingled with Ms. Reeceâ€™s midcentury kitchen appliances and her giant armoire by Martha Stewart for Bernhardt.,But the armoire will be going; Ms. Reece plans to leave New York later this year. Her partners in Billyâ€™s Bakery are buying her out, and she plans to move to the Midwest, not far from where her mother lives. Her family, she said, has been â€œamazingly supportiveâ€ù of her sex change.,That will leave Mr. Berman as Mr. Beckâ€™s only subtenant, which he says will be a welcome respite after years of roommates. Not that the place is quiet. The jeans store right downstairs plays â€œthumpa thumpa musicâ€ù too loud, he said, and you can hear it through the floorboards until the store closes at 7 p.m.,But Mr. Berman rarely leaves his  office at Debevoise & Plimpton in Midtown before 7,  and otherwise the place is spacious, light and, by New York standards, a steal.,And it only took litigation, a reality series, a roommateâ€™s sex change and two peopleâ€™s out-of-state  moves for him to get it.
column4: In the Right Place at the Right Time

column1: LOVE the neighborhood, hate the house. That is a common enough complaint from both current homeowners and prospective homeowners.,Lenders have an increasingly attractive alternative for people in this situation: renovation loans. With these, a borrower who wants to move into an existing home need not compromise on quality, and the homeowner who has outgrown the house but does not want (or cannot afford) to move can upgrade more economically.,â€œWeâ€™re seeing a huge increase in demand for these, and weâ€™re foreseeing another record year in 2007,â€ù said John Sway, a vice president of Wells Fargo Home Mortgage.,Mr. Sway said that because house values are growing more slowly, or slumping, in many markets, homeowners cannot simply wait a year and use the increased equity to upgrade their houses. â€œThey need to rely on the future value of the home to make improvements,â€ù he said.,Renovation loans cover the costs of the upgrades, but the total loan amounts are based on the predicted value of the house after the work has been completed.,For example, a family with a three-bedroom house worth $400,000 and a mortgage of $300,000 may want to spend $65,000 to renovate and pay for the new loanâ€™s closing costs.,For renovation loans, lenders require borrowers to submit architectural drawings of the proposed renovations, and these are used to estimate the homeâ€™s future value.,If the lender appraises the future value of the house at $500,000, the new loan will be for $400,000 (since the owners already had $100,000 in equity in the home). Assuming they had a 30-year fixed mortgage at 6 percent,  monthly payments before the renovation loan were $1,798.,Interest rates on renovation loans run slightly higher than those on 30-year fixed mortgages, to reflect the slightly higher risk that banks take when lending money on what amounts to a partly completed house. Assuming, then, a 6.75 percent interest rate on 30-year fixed renovation loan of $400,000, the owners would pay $2,594 for the new loan (and for the â€œnewâ€ù house). The borrowers  should also expect an eventual property tax increase.,Mr. Sway says renovation loans have been popular in the New York area, particularly among buyers who do not want to move into outdated homes.,Wells Fargo, for one, offers three types of renovation loans. The most popular is for an amount of $417,000 or less on single-family properties, for which the typical down payment is 5 percent.,Bruce Hirschfeld, the president of Montvale Mortgage, a mortgage brokerage in Montvale, N.J., said the local market for renovation refinance loans had also been steady. â€œAlthough prices arenâ€™t rising the way they were, weâ€™re still not to the point where someone can go from a three-bedroom house to a five-bedroom house as easily as they could by just doing the work themselves,â€ù he said.,Lenders, Mr. Hirschfeld said, usually break up payments into six stages during construction and require borrowers to demonstrate completion of the previous stage before they issue a check for the next.,One attractive element of such loans, Mr. Hirschfeld said, is that lenders fold the first six months of interest into the overall loan amount, freeing borrowers from payments during the construction period.,The lack of a mortgage payment  helps. â€œThen, you just have to deal with the construction,â€ù Mr. Hirschfeld  said, â€œand figuring out whether or not you can live in hell for six months.â€ù
column4: Hate the House? Then Renovate

column1: Some blocks of Manhattan give the impression that, say, Italian food is everywhere. Then there are pockets like the small Japanese restaurant scene around Second and Third Avenues in the 40s, a short walk from the United Nations for visitors, immigrants and anyone else craving sushi, noodles, grilled meat and fish.,Aburiya Kinnosukeâ€™s tables are usually filled with Japanese businessmen with banquets of food in front of them and broad smiles on their faces.,The menu is divided into many parts, including house-made tofu, salads, sashimi, and rice and noodle dishes. But grilling occupies center stage. Under the heading â€œShichirin Grill,â€ù the restaurant serves meat and fish that diners can grill over bincho-tan charcoal, which produces little smoke.,Riingo is a warren of sleek red and black rooms, each more enticing than the last. The menu is a synthesis of many cuisines, emphasizing Japanese.,The conventional sushi, like yellowtail and fluke, is excellent, but it is impossible to pass up selections like tuna foie gras, smoked char and rice-puff-crusted shrimp.,This restaurant, hidden away in the basement of a Midtown office building, lures enthusiasts to its subterranean locale with its expansive sake list of more than 200 bottles. The sprawling multipage menu offers cleanly executed dishes meant to accompany the sake, including standards like boiled edamame, and the filling rice balls called onigiri that you would expect at any izakaya, or Japanese pub.,The mood is quiet, contemplative, austere. But Sushi Yasuda has a lot of downtown in its soul. The exemplary service is open and friendly.,At the same time, the menu is dead serious, a puristâ€™s paradise of multiple choices among fish species â€” nearly 40, a startling number for a small restaurant â€” and elegantly presented appetizers and side dishes.,The first time you make a reservation at Tsukushi â€” and reservations are all but necessary to ensure youâ€™ll get a table or a berth at the bar â€” the woman on the other end of the line will let you know that thereâ€™s no menu, that everything is omakase, chefâ€™s choice. Fortunately the chef, Norihiko Manabe, has a real talent for orchestrating a meal.
column4: Island Within an Island

column1: SOME might find living in the Times Square area unimaginable. The traffic is often at a standstill, the sidewalks are often impassable and the lights are on â€” and blinking â€” 24/7.,To Charles Kipps, however, it is absolute paradise. A writer of novels and film and television scripts, Mr. Kipps moved last June into a two-bedroom, two-bath condominium at 1600 Broadway, the only residential building in that gleaming swath of the Great White Way between West 42nd and West 53rd  Streets. He thrives on the pace and the bustle, and wonders why he spent 16 years renting in the relative calm of 48th Street and Eighth Avenue, across the street from a busy firehouse.,â€œItâ€™s exciting, and every night except one, the place is buzzing with activity,â€ù said Mr. Kipps, a Virginia native, whose credits include segments of â€œLaw and Order: Criminal Intent.â€ù He pointed out, â€œNothing says New York like a great row of neon lights.â€ù,What may say it even more  is the dropping of the ball on New Yearâ€™s Eve, which Otis Davis, a neighbor of Mr. Kipps, watched from the terrace of his penthouse, along with the estimated million people gathered on the sidewalks outside. The parties inside the building were even more fun than the party below. â€œEverybody was home, everybody had their doors open and every single person had a party,â€ù said Mr. Davis, a court stenographer, who moved from a house on ,. â€œYou could just walk from party to party.â€ù,Completed last summer, the 25-story condo at 1600 Broadway is the latest arrival on a growing residential scene in the theater district, which is roughly bordered by 41st Street on the south, Eighth Avenue on the west, West 53rd Street on the north, and the blocks between Seventh Avenue and Avenue of the Americas on the east, but not including the office buildings that line Avenue of the Americas.,On the border of Hellâ€™s Kitchen (also known as Clinton), Eighth Avenue is gaining the most new buildings, almost all luxury high-rises. In addition to rentals like the Biltmore, the Ritz Plaza, the Gershwin and Longacre House, there are the 215-unit Link and the 654-unit Worldwide Plaza. Brokers are marketing the 60-story, 550-unit Orion as part of the theater district,  though it is near the Port Authority Bus Terminal and outside the theater zoning district designated by the city.,Future projects, all to be completed from 2008 to 2010, include the Platinum, a 43-story, 220-unit tower being built by SJP Residential Properties, at the corner of Eighth Avenue and 46th Street. There are also a 40-story, 120-unit condo at 785 Eighth Avenue being built by Esplanade Capital; a 46-story, 271-unit tower on West 46th Street and Eighth Avenue built by Tribeach Holdings; and a 34-story, 400-unit rental being built by the Witkoff Group on 43rd Street, with 20 percent put aside for low- and moderate-income families. The Related Companies has bought a parking facility on Eighth Avenue between 45th and 46th Streets but has not finalized development plans, a company representative said.,On side streets between Avenue of the Americas and Eighth Avenue, many four- and five-story walk-ups contain rental units.,Many longtime residents have been connected with the theater, but new arrivals buying into the luxury towers are a mix: young professionals working for financial companies in Times Square like Morgan Stanley or Lehman Brothers, and out-of-towners wanting pieds-Ã -terre, as well as people in entertainment. There are few families. But both newcomers and longtimers seem to choose the neighborhood for its easy connections to city and suburbs.,â€œItâ€™s extremely convenient for someone like me who has to go to ,, Long Island and ,,â€ù said George Stilo, an interior designer who moved to the Ritz Plaza from , 13 years ago. â€œYou have access to the subway, the L.I.R.R., Port Authority and the bus to the airport.â€ù,According to Mr. Stilo, who also loves the restaurants, the only drawback to living in the area is the noise level. â€œThere are people who have moved out of my building who couldnâ€™t take the noise,â€ù he said. â€œIt can be very, very noisy, and that would be my only reservation.â€ù,Uzma Akhand, a Columbia University doctoral student who lives at the Ritz Plaza, got used to the noise. â€œMy parents live in Connecticut,â€ù she said, â€œand when I visit them, I canâ€™t sleep because itâ€™s too quiet.â€ù,At 1600 Broadway, condominium prices range from $795,000, for a studio that measures about 600 square feet, to $1.845 million, for a 1,325-square-foot two-bedroom, two-bath unit with space for a home office. The 900-square-foot penthouse, with one bedroom, one bath, a home office space and a balcony, is listed at $1.375 million.,The Link, on West 52nd Street, has two apartments available, each with two bedrooms and two and a half baths. One on the 19th floor is listed at $1.745 million; a slightly larger one on the 41st floor lists for $2.3 million. The buildingâ€™s amenities include a fitness center.,The Orion Condominium has four one-bedroom apartments available, at prices of $715,000 to $735,000. The building has a gym, three exterior decks, pool and hot tub, and offers a free Starbucks breakfast to residents every day, said Jason Karadus, a vice president for the Corcoran Group.,Rentals run the gamut from old-style four- and five-story walk-ups on side streets to all-rental high-rises on and around Eighth Avenue, like the 53-story, 464-unit Biltmore or the 44-story, 479-unit Ritz Plaza, which was one of the first residential towers in the area when it opened in 1990. According to Marc Kaplan, director of leasing at the Ritz Plaza, there is a studio available for $2,650 a month. He also mentioned two renovated one-bedroom, one-bath units, for $3,395 and $3,495.,Extensive rental listings at , Apartments include a studio in a walk-up for $1,650 a month and a two-bedroom in a doorman building for $6,695, said Adjina Dekidjiev, rental operations manager.,According to the Encyclopedia of ,, the Times Square area has been the theater district since just before World War I, when music, drama, cabaret, dance halls and the like moved uptown from the Bowery and Lower Broadway.,Once the preserve of families like the Vanderbilts and the Astors, Times Square proper was known as Long Acre Square until the turn of the last century, when the name was changed to commemorate the opening of the new New York Times headquarters in the square.,It was The Timesâ€™s publisher, Adolph S. Ochs, who staged the first New Yearâ€™s Eve extravaganza. The area started to decline after the stock-market crash in 1929, when burlesque shows, penny arcades and the pornography business started crowding out the legitimate theater. Erotic entertainment became increasingly popular during World War II with the influx of servicemen on leave. The industry was largely forced out in the early 1990s.,Pearl Caruso and her husband, Stephen, who works in the financial industry, have front-row seats at 1600 Broadway for the Macyâ€™s Thanksgiving Day Parade and annual New Yearâ€™s festivities in Times Square, but it was the theater scene that brought the couple to the neighborhood. â€œWe go to the theater once or twice a week now,â€ù said Mrs. Caruso, a special education teacher who also volunteers for Broadway Cares, an AIDS charity. She wants her daughter, Laurel, 2, exposed to the theater in the hopes that she will one day perform on Broadway. Mrs. Caruso has scouted out childrenâ€™s programs at Carnegie Hall, Jazz at Lincoln Center, Alvin Ailey and â€”  her favorite â€”  the School for Strings.,Duffy Square, newly refurbished, will reopen this spring, and with it the Theater Development Fundâ€™s TKTS booth, the discount theater ticket sales center, relocated to the Marriott Marquis hotel during refurbishment. The area, called â€œthe bowtieâ€ù because of the criss-cross intersection of Broadway and Seventh Avenue, will undergo a $10 million renovation over the next few years, said Tim Tompkins, president of the Times Square Alliance business improvement district.,Chain restaurants like Red Lobster and Applebeeâ€™s dot the main arteries, but there are many more intimate places on Eighth and Ninth Avenues. Retailing on Broadway is dominated by tourist spots like the M&M emporium, and chains like Sephora cosmetics. There is a supermarket, a Food Emporium, on Eighth Avenue; the Times Square Alliance is seeking more resident-oriented retailing.,There is one school in the theater district, the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis High School on West 46th Street, but David Diamond, chairman of Community Board 5, said more may be added as the neighborhood evolves. â€œCommunity Board 5 probably has the fewest schools of any board because we are the central business district,â€ù he said.,The high school teaches Grades 9 through 12. Students in 2005 averaged 399 on the SAT verbal section, versus 497 statewide, and 404 on the math, versus 511 statewide.,For middle schoolers, there is the Clinton School for Writers and Artists on West 21st Street in Chelsea. Of eighth graders in 2005, 67.6 percent scored at or above grade level in math, compared with 40.8 percent citywide, while 63.9 percent scored at or above grade level in English, compared with 32.9 percent citywide.,Public School 212 on West 48th Street teaches kindergarten through Grade 5. Of fourth graders in 2005, 88.5 percent performed at or above grade level in English, compared with 60.4 percent citywide, while 92.4 percent did so in math, compared with 78.3 percent citywide.,Times Square is Manhattanâ€™s major hub for subway connections and buses out of the city from the Port Authority Bus Terminal on Eighth Avenue and 42nd Street. Subways stopping at Times Square include the 1, 2, 3, 7, N, Q, R, S and W trains. Local buses include the M42, M104, M27 and M50 cross-town lines, which connect to lines going north on Sixth and Eighth Avenues and south on Broadway and Seventh Avenue.,Itâ€™s busy, bright and bustles constantly. For theater buffs and night owls, no neighborhood offers more in the way of performing arts, bars and restaurants of all descriptions.,Luxury residential towers mark the final phase in the gentrification of what for most of a century was one of the cityâ€™s grittiest, flashiest areas.
column4: Those Neon Lights? Just as Bright as They Say

She graduated from the Parsons School of Design.,She is the daughter of Connie Reeve Boyd and George Morley Boyd of Northborough, Mass. Her mother teaches science to seventh and eighth graders at the Forest Grove Middle School in Worcester, Mass.,The bride is a descendant of William Bradford, a governor of the Plymouth Colony.,The bridegroom, 46, was until October a portfolio manager at Silver Point Capital, a hedge fund in Greenwich, Conn., after which he established his own firm, called Yin Harbor Drive Capital, a  hedge fund operating out of the offices of the CRT Capital Group  in Stamford, Conn. He graduated  from Princeton and received an M.B.A. from Harvard.,He is the son of Dr. Fay Hoh Yin of Wilmington, Del., and the late Dr. Theodore Peng-Jung Yin. His mother retired as a senior research virologist at E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company in Wilmington, where she studied a possible way of interfering the growth of the AIDS virus.  His father also worked there, as a senior research chemist studying the properties of plastics.,Ms. Boyd and Mr. Yin met in November 2004 at the White Horse Tavern in the West Village, where Ms. Boyd, who had been a waitress there during college, had stopped by for a drink. She was chatting with a group of people when Mr. Yin struck up a conversation with them. And at the end of the evening Ms. Boyd and Mr. Yin exchanged telephone numbers.,Several weeks later, they went on their first date, to Chez Michallet,  another West Village restaurant. â€œWhen he first walked into the restaurant, he was all dressed up in a suit with a James Bond look,â€ù she said. â€œI had a quick thought, â€˜I am going to marry this guy,â€™ and then I discounted it.â€ù,Within a few months they started seeing each other exclusively, and last September, during a trip to Newport, R.I., Mr. Yin proposed.,They began envisioning a spring or summer wedding, but every place they called in Massachusetts and New York was booked solid for 2007 with the exception of some questionable dates like Super Bowl Sunday.,When Jan. 27 became available at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, a place that they had been particularly drawn to, they pounced on it.,â€œAll my life I wondered what kind of person chooses to get married when itâ€™s freezing outside,â€ù Mr. Yin said. â€œNow I know the answer: a man who proposes to his girlfriend too late to reserve a reception venue the following summer.â€ù,Then they stumbled on an auspicious fact: Jan. 27 falls in the Chinese lunar leap year of 4703, which continues until Feb. 17. The current Year of the Dog is considered particularly conducive to weddings because it contains two lunar springs, a phenomenon that foretells a happy marriage and that has occurred only 11 times since 221 B.C.,â€œWhen I found out that Duncan and I were going to be married in the luckiest year possible, I thought, â€˜This is so perfect, itâ€™s so Duncan,â€™ â€ù Ms. Boyd said. â€œHe is just the sort of person on whom fortune seems to smile, and I feel fortunate to be along for the ride.â€ù

column1: LONG ago, in that dark, clamorous age before the â€™90s really got under way â€” sometime after Wham! dropped off radio playlists, but before Vanilla Ice had evaporated â€” most people did not have e-mail or cellphones, and there were no such things as Match.com, instant messaging, text messaging, BlackBerry or MySpace. Back then, men and women had to actually meet in person, or phone each other, if they wanted to talk. But scientific advances have brought remarkable progress to the dating game, right? Not necessarily.,In â€œThe Joy of Text: Mating, Dating and Techno-Relating,â€ù the foxy young relationship pundit Kristina Grish (the author of â€œBoy Vey!â€ù â€” tips for non-Jewish women who hope to snare Jewish boyfriends â€” among other advice guides) shows that the great leap forward in communication has dragged along with it a blight of text-driven power games and misunderstandings.,For instance, when a woman abruptly logs off an I.M. exchange, does she mean it to sting or to tantalize? How long do you wait to respond to an e-mail message (up to three days is not insulting, Ms. Grish believes) and text messages (more than a few hours is probably a brushoff)?,Also, she cautions, be careful how you word your techno flirtation: misspellings can be cute, or can make you look like a moron, while quirky punctuation can make you seem unstable. If you use too many exclamation points in your BlackBerry messages, youâ€™ll look slap-happy. If you use ALL CAPS, your iChats can resemble death threats. â€œLike it or not, you are what you type,â€ù Ms. Grish declares. Shrewdly and wittily, she points the way on alphanumeric dating.,Her recommendations are often strikingly specific. An especially useful one: What should you do when a cyber-Cyrano sends you long, eloquent missives, but never asks you out? Pull a few words from his e-mail message that could be â€œeasily misconstruedâ€ù and tease him with them. Ms. Grish instructs: â€œYour only response is one sentence: â€˜Iâ€™m sorry, but you just used the words â€œhot,â€ù â€œpursuingâ€ù and â€œstrappedâ€ù in that last e-mail and Iâ€™m still recovering. ... Is there something you wanted to ask me?â€™ â€ù,But be careful of the passions you whip up, she warns, and remember that once you hit â€œsend,â€ù you cannot prevent your correspondent from hitting â€œforward,â€ù or worse, posting your steamy prose on his blog, where it can be salivated over â€œby strangers with a bucket of popcorn.â€ù,LIKE Ms. Grish, the relationship counselor Terrence Real recognizes that the last decades have seen a revolution in the dealings between men and women that has flummoxed both sexes. â€œFor most of us, whatever we learned growing up about relationships is simply not sophisticated enough to deliver all that we hope for,â€ù he writes.,He adds consolingly, â€œYou have been trying to negotiate a 21st-century relationship using 20th-century skills.â€ù In â€œThe New Rules of Marriage,â€ù he provides a set of â€œoperating instructionsâ€ù for modern couples, illustrated by compassionately told case studies of embattled clients he has led away from the brink of divorce.,Mr. Real isnâ€™t afraid to make breathtakingly bold statements. â€œIn the last generation women have radically changed, and men, by and large, have not,â€ù he writes. As a result, â€œMen are not all that unhappy in their marriages. They are unhappy that their women are so unhappy with them.â€ù  Women, on the other hand, â€œwant radical transformation.â€ù They want their marriages to be â€œintimateâ€ù (new paradigm), not â€œcompanionableâ€ù (old paradigm).,If this in fact is what women want (sounds about right to me), many of them have an awfully strange way of going about it, as Mr. Realâ€™s true-life stories show.,Venting, criticizing, blaming and complaining â€” all in the name of â€œhonest expressionâ€ù â€” too many women provoke resentment, not sympathy, in their mates, he explains.  The men respond by giving in to their worst impulses, like withdrawal, bullying, arrogance or stonewalling, hoping to ride out the storm.,How can we all get along? By replacing accusation with understanding, Mr. Real suggests, and continually posing the question: â€œWhat can I give you to help you give me what I want?â€ù,Mr. Real blames psychotherapy, in part, for the communication impasse: too many Americans, he believes, have been encouraged to seek â€œpersonal empowermentâ€ù rather than â€œrelationship empowerment,â€ù putting themselves first, and not trying hard enough to appreciate their partnerâ€™s good points.,He identifies five major pitfalls that trip up the over-empowered individual: Unbridled Self-Expression, Needing to Be Right, Controlling Our Partner, Retaliation, and Withdrawal. And he provides exercises so couples can assess their own flaws (no, donâ€™t surprise your partner by showing him your bullet-pointed list of , failings), and strategies to increase â€œcherishing.â€ù,Mr. Real knows that readers may feel overwhelmed by his unsparing solutions to tough-love woes. He writes, â€œA part of you may be wondering, â€˜Has the game of love really grown so technical that I need an intimacy coach just to have a decent relationship?â€™ â€ù In a word: Yes. Luckily, you should be able to track one down on the Internet.
column4: Mars and Venus, Coping With the 21st Century

column1: AS a child, John W.  Warner IV loved explosions, cartoons, army uniforms, pranks involving frogs and ice cream â€” he called health food â€œseeds and twigs.â€ù,Mr. Warner, the son of Senator John Warner, Republican of Virginia, and Catherine Conover, the daughter of the philanthropist Paul Mellon, also loved wearing kilts  because of his Scottish heritage.,Although his parents divorced when he was young, they lived next door to each other in Washington. He was known to ride his motorized minibike there  as fast as it would go, sometimes with Senator Warnerâ€™s second wife, the actress Elizabeth Taylor, as a very vocal passenger.,After Mr. Warner graduated from the University of Virginia, where his fraternity, Chi Phi,  voted him â€œhellmasterâ€ù four years in a row, he became a professional race car driver, naturally. â€œItâ€™s a blood sport,â€ù said Mr. Warner, now 44. â€œItâ€™s a thrill going around the track 6 inches from the wall at 180 miles per hour, but itâ€™s frightening. You grow up very quickly.â€ù,His father said, â€œHe wanted his own identity and he found it.â€ù,In 1998, Mr. Warner moved to Westport, Conn., living alone in a big old  house that was decorated with 18th-century furniture and always filled with friends, usually playing pool in the dining room. â€œJohn is all-inclusive,â€ù Tommy Walker, an old friend, said of his parties. â€œHe invites not only the people heâ€™s close to, but also the guys doing the gardening at his house.â€ù,Mr. Warner created Americanstock.us, a Web site offering Nascar and stock car racing history and collectibles. He also began making documentaries  like â€œThe Wendell Scott Story,â€ù  about the first black  driver  to reach the top level of stock-car racing.,Through it all he remained a die-hard and distinctive bachelor, sometimes picking dates up in his 1936 Packard or his 1966 Aston Martin. But he grew to dislike breaking hearts as much as he hated eating tofu. â€œJohnny never wants to let anyone down,â€ù said Jill Mullen, a friend.,He also became disillusioned, always questioning the motives of the women he dated. By the time he was in his early 40s,  he had broken two engagements and pretty much given up hope.  â€œA lot of women in New York and L.A. are in it for the dollar, not for a healthy relationship,â€ù he said wearily.,Then, in November 2004, Jodi Edmonds, another old friend of Mr. Warnerâ€™s, set him up on a blind date with Shannon Ford Hamm, a first-grade teacher at the Spence School in New York, who had taught her two daughters. Mr. Warner, who still loves frogs and other slimy creatures, suggested that they meet  by the reptiles at the American Museum of Natural History in New York. â€œHe had such a wide-eyed view of the worldâ€ù Ms. Hamm said. â€œIt was wonderful to meet someone like that, especially at our age.â€ù,He, on the other hand, was unsure about Ms. Hamm, whose family founded the Hammâ€™s Brewing Company, which was based in Minnesota. She was nothing like the wild supermodels and party girls he had been dating. Ms. Hamm has unflashy clothes, jewelry and ways and is the opposite of high-maintenance.,She is never one to speak first or loudest, and though beautiful, seems to deflect attention. Her parents, Jean Hamm of Wayzata, Minn., and Edward Hamm of Jupiter Island, in Florida, describe her as a solid Midwestern girl who doesnâ€™t need flattery.   But, underneath her  cool demeanor, friends say she has a wicked sense of humor.,Nevertheless, he wasnâ€™t interested in a second date with her.,Then, one year later, tired of young, temperamental beauties, he called. Ms. Hamm wasnâ€™t miffed and agreed to see him. â€œI feel strongly that you never want to close any doors,â€ù she said. â€œYou never know.â€ù,This time, they went to the Guggenheim, and then to  lunch, then to a party and a late dinner. â€œWe had such a great time,â€ù Ms. Hamm, now 41, said of their 12-hour date.  â€œWe just had to wait until the first kiss to see how that went.â€ù,Mr. Warner was surprised he had much in common with a schoolteacher. Like him, she collected antiques and had a come-one-come-all attitude about parties. And, he said, â€œher family grew up with wealth, and theyâ€™re eccentric and funky and I feel totally at home. She gets it when I tell her all the weird things about my family, and I get it with her family.â€ù,He recalled  falling in love with her when he visited her classroom at  Spence.  â€œSheâ€™s just beautiful with children,â€ù he said, adding that she seemed so guileless and good-hearted, especially in comparison to him. â€œI never thought sheâ€™d like a bad boy like me.â€ù,Soon after they started dating, friends noticed a change in Mr. Warner. He put his pool table up for sale, and started shopping for dining room furniture, now that he had someone to dine with regularly. â€œHe used to watch all these war movies, ,of war movies,â€ù said Ramon Ruiz, another friend. â€œThen, one day he said, â€˜Change it to the antiques channel.â€™ Thatâ€™s when I knew it was serious.â€ù,For the first time in his life, Mr. Warner said he felt unconflicted about getting married, and last May, six months after their 12-hour date, he proposed in Paris. â€œThereâ€™s an old adage that you wait for the right one,â€ù Senator Warner said. â€œAnd if ever there was a case of a man waiting, it was John.â€ù,The couple wed on Jan. 13 in Jupiter Island, where the brideâ€™s family has a vacation home  with a sign on the front door that reads: â€ùFriends Welcome. Relatives by Appointment Only.â€ù  It is an immaculate place with  homes that are pastel-colored, like Mentos, and as low profile as its residents seek to be.,The coupleâ€™s Episcopal ceremony took place at the beach-cottage-like Christ Memorial Chapel of Hobe Sound, where the Rev. David Prior, its chaplain, officiated with  the Rev. William Billow, senior chaplain at St. Albans School in Washington,  which the bridegroom attended.,After the service, the couple and their 170 guests followed a sandy path lined with hurricane lamps down to a white tent set up on the beach. Inside, the tent looked like a chic new Manhattan hotel lobby. It was decorated with seashell-white couches, carpeting, chandeliers, candles and  flowers.,The bridegroom, whose back still hurt from a recent motorcycle crash, greeted guests Ã  la Truman Capote, while lounging (in a kilt) on one of the couches. The bride, meanwhile, looked completely natural in her sleeveless gown and her hair pulled back as if for tennis.,â€œThese two people are just so meant for each other,â€ù observed Bernard Rogers, a guest. â€œShe is enormously patient, and heâ€™s enormously impatient and it really goes together.â€ù
column4: Shannon Hamm and John Warner IV
