In the era of NoÃ«l Coward and Terence Rattigan, where the most useful stage furniture was usually a cocktail cabinet, the sight was remarkable.,That and Jimmyâ€™s vituperation of the repressed, torpid, humbugging nature of English life (especially English womanhood, though that wasnâ€™t generally noticed or condemned at the time) were enough to give â€œLook Backâ€ù a â€œpoliticalâ€ù reputation that now looks to be a category mistake. Osborne wasnâ€™t a radical with an analysis, never mind a program for change. His play is almost pure autobiography, and as John Heilpern makes clear in his biography, the anger in it is so deeply personal, with such singular causes, as to make nonsense of it as politics.,Osborne wrote the play in a month, less than a year after his first marriage had ended bitterly. The onstage marriage of Jimmy and Alison Porter faithfully reproduces the histrionics of Osborneâ€™s marriage to the actress Pamela Lane. The script incorporates one of Laneâ€™s letters, and the game of â€œsquirrels and bears,â€ù whose feyness never ceases to embarrass audiences, is the same playfulness that Osborne and his wife devised to relieve their mutual hatred by escaping into a second childhood.,More important is Osborneâ€™s father, to whom the play is dedicated. In the play, he becomes a victim of the Spanish Civil War, whom 10-year-old Jimmy watched die from his wounds at home in England. (â€œYou see, I learnt at an early age what it was to be angry â€” angry and helpless.â€ù) The 10-year-old Osborne had also watched his father die, though more prosaically of tuberculosis. By using Osborneâ€™s private notebooks, Heilpern establishes beyond reasonable doubt that Osborne thought of this death and that of his only sibling, an older sister â€” also from tuberculosis, before Osborne could remember her â€” as the most formative events in his life and work.,Being dead, and therefore idealized and uncomplicated, Osborneâ€™s father and sister set a standard that few people in his life ever lived up to. Osborne detested and ridiculed his long-surviving mother, a London barmaid whom he would often bring along to smart parties for comic effect (â€œA year in which my mother died canâ€™t be all bad,â€ù he wrote in 1983). Wives came and went. After Pamela Lane came the actress Mary Ure and then the writer Penelope Gilliatt and then another actress, Jill Bennett. Only with his fifth wife, the critic Helen Dawson, was the experience prolonged and agreeable. Osborne married the first four before he was 40 and only Lane reached the age of 65. When he heard of Bennettâ€™s suicide in 1990, he hastily revised a volume of autobiography to include the wish that he could stand over her open coffin and â€œdrop a good, large mess in her eye.â€ù,Heilpern knew Osborne slightly and this book was authorized by his widow, who died in 2004. It is, insofar as such a thing is possible, a sympathetic biography of an unsympathetic man. Heilpern supplies plenty of ghastly detail, but does his best to balance it with evidence of Osborneâ€™s financial generosity, shy charm, frequent depressions and underlying terror (â€œI was born with a sense of loss, a feeling of things withheld and banishedâ€ù). Even so, itâ€™s hard to reach any other conclusion than that Osborne was inexcusably cruel to people in general, and criminally so to those who may have imagined they had some claim to his friendship and love. Put simply, he was awful: a poor friend, a bad son and husband, a worse father. Nolan, his daughter by Gilliatt, came to stay with him when her mother was no longer considered fit to take care of her. Four years later, when she was 16, Osborne expelled her from the house after some ordinary adolescent behavior, cancelling her school fees and her bank account. They never spoke again. The long letter he wrote to her is lyrical in its high-flown damnation of her character (â€œthe grasping ingrate you undoubtedly areâ€ù), almost as though Osborne was enjoying the role of a villainous stepfather in a Victorian melodrama.,The trouble lay in his gift for invective. His four best plays â€” â€œLook Back in Anger,â€ù â€œThe Entertainer,â€ù â€œLuther,â€ù â€œInadmissable Evidenceâ€ù â€” all depend on a central character whose anger, grief and ridicule canâ€™t be shut up. Similarly in life, Osborne didnâ€™t know where to stop. He enjoyed articulating grievance and seized any excuse to manufacture it. He had a vicious self-pity. In the words of the director Peter Hall, â€œWhen he had a pen in his hand it was like giving a kid a machine gun.â€ù To Hall (and several others) he was â€œa charmer, a sweetheartâ€ù as well as â€œa bastard and a liarâ€ù and worse.,In the 1950s and â€™60s he was also easily Britainâ€™s best-known playwright. He grew rich â€” as co-producer and Oscar-winning screenwriter of Tony Richardsonâ€™s â€œTom Jonesâ€ù (1963), he earned more money than he knew what to do with. He bought a house in Belgravia and a Bentley, employed secretaries, servants and chauffeurs. By the 1970s, he was swallowing one bottle of vodka and a couple of bottles of wine every day, along with unreckonable amounts of Champagne and codeine and amphetamine. He never again wrote anything so good or popular as the four plays mentioned above, the last of them finished in 1964, and spent his last years in a big house near the hilly Welsh border, struggling with bad health and debts.,He died just after his 65th birthday, on Christmas Eve 1994, and was buried in his Turnbull & Asser smoking jacket with his old copy of â€œHamletâ€ù stuffed in a pocket. (It had every part crossed out except Hamletâ€™s.) He died a club man, an Anglican, a country gentleman, a collector of teddy bears. Not the world he was born into, or that which his early work seemed to inveigh against, but a vanishing world that Osborne identified as England. Only those who had missed the nostalgia in â€œLook Back in Angerâ€ù saw him as a sellout. As Jimmy Porter says of the remnants of Edwardian England in 1956, â€œif youâ€™ve no world of your own, itâ€™s rather pleasant to regret the passing of someone elseâ€™s.â€ù
column4: Coming-of-Rage

column1: WASHINGTON, dashed to Iowa this weekend to hang an open-for-business sign on her new campaign operation. , is besieged by admirers begging to join his team. And , has already dipped his toes into each of Iowaâ€™s 99 counties â€” and started his second lap.,So is the Democratic stable too full for a dark horse presidential candidate to emerge?,The current thinking suggests that only famous candidates, Democrat or Republican, can seize their partyâ€™s nomination. But it has never been a wise bet to rule out the dark horse, a staple of American politics since James K. Polk went to the Democratic convention in 1844 and became the presidential nominee by accident after the favorite, former President Martin Van Buren, lost Southern support.,But perhaps more than any other presidential contest, 2008â€™s could help determine whether the dark horse, a term borrowed from English racetrack lingo, is on the verge of extinction, particularly since the entry fee in the race for the White House has been raised yet again.,For the first time since 1928, neither a sitting president nor vice president will be a candidate in the race, theoretically creating a wide-open fight for both nominations and making it possible for a dark horse to pull stealthily ahead. But the contest is front-loaded as never before â€” California and other big states are rushing to wedge their caucuses and primaries into early February â€” so little-known candidates concede they have an even more difficult task.,Already, the leading contenders are making plans to reject public financing in the primary and general election campaigns for the first time since Watergate. The cost of preparing for a race, strategists believe, could swell beyond $75 million this year alone, which most dark horse candidates may struggle to meet, given the calendar.,â€œIt makes it almost impossible for a dark horse to win,â€ù said Dayton Duncan, who worked on the 1984 and 1988 Democratic presidential races of Walter Mondale and Michael Dukakis and wrote â€œGrass Roots: One Year in the Life of the New Hampshire Presidential Primary.â€ù â€œBut it might be the only chance for a dark horse candidate if they really caught lightning in a jar and were catapulted to the national stage.â€ù,The window will be narrow for a second-tier candidate. With rapid back-to-back primaries, a promising showing in Iowa or New Hampshire is critical to advancing.,But even before the rules and the calendar take shape for the 2008 race, dark horse candidates have one piece of storybook history to hold onto: ,, 1976.,After Mr. Carter declared his candidacy on Dec. 12, 1974, a Harris poll listed 35 prospective presidential candidates. Mr. Carter, a one-term Georgia governor, was not among them. Yet 13 months later, after spending day after day traipsing from the Missouri to the Mississippi, he won the Iowa caucuses, that all-important first test of a candidacy. The victory replenished his bank account and sustained him through the rest of the primary campaign.,But now, with the campaignâ€™s cost significantly higher and less time to raise money and attract supporters between primaries, it is hard to imagine a candidateâ€™s emerging from the shadows on persistence alone.,â€œWithout a doubt, itâ€™s more difficult for someone to emerge today since youâ€™ve got people who can raise tens of millions of dollars at the drop of a hat,â€ù said Senator Charles E. Grassley, an Iowa Republican, who as a young congressman watched the 1976 campaign with interest. â€œLittle guys like Carter could never compete with that.â€ù,The Iowa caucuses not only created the lore of Mr. Carter, but Mr. Carter added to the lore of the Iowa caucuses. And for the last three decades, his out-of-nowhere victory has lured ambitious politicians convinced that they, too, could pull off the  feat.,In 2004, the brief  rise of Howard Dean again illustrated that little-known candidates could catch fire and raise money to compete with candidates blessed by the political establishment, but it also reinforced  Iowaâ€™s importance. He finished third, his chances to become the nominee collapsing.,Mr. Dean tapped into the promise of the Internet like no other. And the next evolution of Internet fund-raising and activism â€” combined with old-fashioned discipline â€” might resuscitate the dark horse.,â€œThe Internet can spontaneously combust a dark-horse candidacy that can take everyone out,â€ù said Joe Trippi, who managed Mr. Deanâ€™s campaign. â€œEverybody is sure itâ€™s going to be Hillary, Edwards or Obama, but my guess is that someone no one is talking about right now is going to give these three the scare of their life.â€ù,The Internet could be the great equalizer. First, candidates who struggle to raise money through traditional means could tap into the grassroots to close the gap. Second, if a front-runnerâ€™s stumble is caught on camera it is sure to be widely disseminated on YouTube and its ilk, which could clear a path for an outsider.,With the rush of candidates announcing their bids in the last few weeks, you could  almost forget that the first primary votes wonâ€™t be cast for another year. Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Obama are among the hopefuls whose high profile will deny them the advantage of learning on the fly, a privilege reserved for the dark horse. If, for example, former Gov. Tom Vilsack of Iowa missteps, he might be able to pick himself up without attracting as much notice as one of his more prominent rivals.,â€œA lot can change in a month,â€ù said Senator Tom Harkin, also of Iowa, who in 1992 sought the Democratic presidential nomination. â€œOne of the problems of being a front-runner like Hillary and Barack, if they make a mistake, it will be magnified way beyond its own dimensions. If others stumble, itâ€™s not a big deal.â€ù,As he left the Senate floor to begin a weekend of campaigning, Sam Brownback of Kansas, one of many Republican candidates in the field, stopped for a moment to chat about his prospects. After describing himself as the â€œtrue conservative in the field,â€ù he acknowledged finding solace in the legends of Democratic dark horses.,â€œYou have people like Jimmy Carter, who came out of nowhere. And Bill Clinton! They were not household names when they started this process,â€ù Mr. Brownback said. Asked when he was heading to Iowa, he paused for barely a beat and replied, â€œNext week.â€ù
column4: The Faint Hoofbeats? Thatâ€™s the Dark Horse

column1: FIFTEEN years ago, Roy Brown, a hard-drinking man with a criminal record, was convicted of stabbing, beating, biting and strangling a social worker in upstate New York. The case rested largely on one piece of forensic evidence: bite marks on the victimâ€™s body that the prosecutionâ€™s witness, a local dentist, said matched Mr. Brownâ€™s teeth.,On Tuesday, Mr. Brown was released from prison, after DNA testing on the saliva left by the biter proved his innocence and implicated someone else in the crime. At the time of his conviction, Mr. Brown, 46, was missing two front teeth. The bite marks, meanwhile, had six tooth imprints.,The prosecutionâ€™s expert testified that Mr. Brown could have twisted the victimâ€™s skin to fill the gaps his missing teeth would have left on the bite mark. Despite rebuttal from the defense, whose expert said the bite marks excluded Mr. Brown, it took jurors five hours to return a guilty verdict.,What happened to Mr. Brown is hardly an aberration. Prosecutors have invoked bite-mark matches to secure convictions in numerous cases, only to see these convictions overturned when DNA or other evidence has become available.,In spite of the evolution of other forensic sciences, bite-mark analysis remains an inexact tool. A 1999 study by a member of the American Board of Forensic Odontology, a professional trade organization, found a 63 percent rate of false identifications.,Why is it, then, that bite-mark analysis remains part of the forensic arsenal? There is, experts say, a mix of ignorance on the part of jurors and defense lawyers about the evidenceâ€™s scientific shortcomings and the overzealousness of prosecutors and their expert witnesses, who are seen as too quick to validate an unproven technique.,As the pace of overturned convictions increases, however, the courts are growing more skeptical of the absolute conclusions drawn by bite-mark experts and, in turn, are becoming more receptive when defense lawyers rebut the analysis.,Lawyers, for their part, are taking steps to counter what they call the â€œC.S.I. effect,â€ù when juries become overly impressed by forensic evidence. During jury selection, it is not uncommon for them to ask potential jurors about their television-watching preferences to weed out those who seem unable to separate fact from fiction.,The key, experts say, is for lawyers to know enough about the subjective components of bite-mark analysis to refute it effectively in court.,â€œIf you say that this bite fits this person and nobody else in the world, and if you use the bite mark as the only piece of physical evidence linking an attacker to his victim, thatâ€™s not science â€” thatâ€™s junk,â€ù said Dr. Richard Souviron, chief forensic odontologist at the Miami-Dade Medical Examinerâ€™s Office.,As people age, Dr. Souviron said, their jaws expand, changing the position of their teeth. Teeth can be chipped, broken or just pulled out; skin shifts when it is bitten. And, one must ask, was the victim moving? If the bite was on the chest, was the arm stretched above the head or resting next to the torso?,â€œThere are just too many variables,â€ù said Dr. C. Michael Bowers, author of â€œForensics Dental Evidence: An Investigatorâ€™s Handbook,â€ù published in 2004.,And there is also what David L. Faigman, a professor at the University of California Hastings College of the Law, calls the â€œcontext effect.â€ù Because most forensic scientists learn a lot about the suspect before analyzing the bite mark, â€œitâ€™s easy for them to see what they are expected to see,â€ù Mr. Faigman said.,Experts, he added, â€œcan basically be prepped to see a match.â€ù,Bite marks, however, can be helpful in excluding someone as a suspect, or determining that the suspect could be the one who inflicted the bite, many experts and defense lawyers agree.,â€œIf you limit bite-mark analysis to its accepted validity, itâ€™s not inappropriate for an expert to say that a certain suspect is not the biter,â€ù said Christopher Plourd, a lawyer in San Diego who has represented several suspects whose trials revolved around bite-mark evidence. â€œBut thatâ€™s as far as you should go.â€ù,In 1995, forensic odontologists moved to avoid using the term â€œmatchâ€ù in their analysis, so as to avoid giving the impression that the bite mark belongs to a specific suspect and no one else. But similar, if nuanced, phrases still find their way into court, causing confusion. The courts, however, do not have guidelines restricting the use or presentation of bite-mark analysis.,â€œI feel very strongly that if the courts were a little bit more vigilant or perhaps simply a little bit more informed that they would come very close to excluding a lot of this evidence,â€ù Mr. Faigman said. â€œOr, at the very least, they would tell that the evidence could come in, but for very modest purposes.â€ù
column4: Evidence From Bite Marks, It Turns Out, Is Not So Elementary

column1: BILLINGS, Mont., Jan. 27 (AP) â€” Wolves in the Northern Rockies will be removed from the endangered species list within the next year, the , said Friday.,The agency also will remove from the list wolves in the Western Great Lakes region. Announcements on the two proposals are planned for Monday, said Sharon Rose, an agency spokeswoman.,If the Northern Rockiesâ€™ proposal skirts expected legal challenges, it would open wolves in the region to trophy hunting for the first time since an intensive wolf restoration effort began in the late 1980s.,The Great Lakes wolves would be protected from public hunting for at least five years.,The action caps a sharp turnaround for the wolf. By the 1930s, following a prolonged government-sponsored eradication effort, gray wolves were virtually eliminated across the West. The animal was declared endangered in 1974, shortly after passage of the Endangered Species Act.,Federal and state biologists previously have said that each of the states in the Northern Rockies, ,, Idaho and Wyoming, will be required to maintain a minimum of 100 wolves, including 10 breeding pairs, or the animal would again come under federal protection.
column4: 2 Wolf Groups to Lose Endangered Status

column1: SEATTLE, Jan. 27 (AP) â€” A bridge in Seattle is becoming hazardous to the mental health of the office workers below, who keep seeing people jump to their deaths.,Thirty-nine people over the past decade have committed suicide off the 155-foot-high Aurora Bridge â€” eight in 2006 alone â€” and counselors are regularly brought in to help office workers deal with the shock of seeing the leap or the aftermath.,City and state officials are adding suicide-prevention signs and telephones in hopes of reducing the death toll.,The bridge, built in 1931, carries up to 45,000 vehicles a day on one of the main north-south highways through Seattle, passing over a narrow ship channel to Lakes Union and  Washington.,Some jumpers hit the water; others land on the pavement or other solid ground. Either way, they almost always die.,The area under the bridge used to be filled with docks and warehouses, and the suicides went largely unnoticed. But in the technology boom of the past two decades, it changed into a trendy area of office buildings, shops and restaurants, and people began to see the bodies fall.,â€œThey end up in our parking lot,â€ù said Katie Scharer, who works at Cutter & Buck, a sportswear company. â€œNobodyâ€™s ever totally used to it.â€ù,Grief counselors visited Cutter & Buck as recently as a month ago.,A few weeks ago, officials installed six emergency phones and 18 signs that give the number of a 24-hour crisis line in bold yellow type.,â€œAny time you can interrupt a suicide thought process, you have a good chance of success, at least temporarily,â€ù said L. J. Eddy, who leads the police hostage negotiation team.,Transportation officials said installing nets or raising the sides of the bridge could interfere with safety inspections and could catch the wind, making the bridge dangerously unstable. Any plans to alter the bridge would have to go through a public approval process because it is a national historic landmark.,Few suicides occur on Seattleâ€™s other major bridges â€” the Ship Canal Bridge, which carries Interstate 5, and the West Seattle Bridge â€” because they are closed to pedestrians.,The Aurora Bridge serves as a pedestrian link between two densely populated hilltops. But the state has considered moving the pedestrian walkway to an enclosed structure below the bridge.
column4: Suicides Take Toll on Unwitting Audience

column1: In the wake of the 2004 tsunami that devastated shorelines around the Indian Ocean, the relief group , won plaudits for its decision to halt fund-raising for the disaster once it had collected enough donations to accomplish the mission it had set for itself.,Other relief organizations raised as much as they could and consequently faced criticism from French and British regulators and others for being unable to spend all of it expediently.,Doctors Without Borders, a French medical charity, has long practiced an unusual form of discipline that may cause other nonprofits to squirm. For more than a decade, it has politely declined financial support from corporations whose activities conflict with its mission and principles, recently adding some medical device makers and biotechnology companies.,It even declines money such companies make to match donations from their employees. â€œWeâ€™re not making moral judgments,â€ù said Alyssa Herman, director of development at the organizationâ€™s New York affiliate. â€œThe policy is really an effort to avoid potential conflicts or barriers to our mission.â€ù,Nonprofit circles have been buzzing lately over a two-part series in The Los Angeles Times highlighting conflicts between the goals of the Gates Foundation and the activities of some companies in which it invests.,Foundations and charities have long confronted such questions. A few years ago, some museums and other organizations were fighting questions over their acceptance of donations made by corporate leaders tainted by scandals, like L. Dennis Kozlowski, the Tyco International executive who gave millions to the Whitney Museum of American Art, and Kenneth L. Lay, the Enron founder, whose name adorned facilities and programs in Houston and Aspen, Colo.,Doctors Without Borders is not alone, though its policy may be the most stringent. Last year, the American Diabetes Association adopted a tougher policy to govern its relationship with food and drug companies, and many charities prohibit the acceptance of gifts from tobacco companies and their subsidiaries.,Critics note, though, that beyond tobacco, such policies are usually nuanced. The American Heart Association, for instance, does not allow wine and alcohol companies to use its brand for marketing and image-building purposes, but it will accept money raised on its behalf through wine auctions and tastings.,Similarly, it does not allow the use of its name or logo by candy and chocolate makers but will accept money from them â€œas long as no strings are attached,â€ù said David Livingston, the heart associationâ€™s corporate secretary and counsel.,About 18 percent of the associationâ€™s revenues in the year that ended June 30, 2006, came from companies, compared with about 7 percent of the $122 million the American unit of Doctors Without Borders raised in 2005.,â€œCorporations are not per se bad,â€ù Mr. Livingston said. â€œThey have different interests than we do, but where our interests overlap and where doing so would not have an impact on our integrity and credibility, we think itâ€™s appropriate to work with them on behalf of what we do.â€ù,As the number of charities rises at a much faster pace than giving, it is difficult for any nonprofit group to look a gift horse in the mouth. â€œItâ€™s a very thorny subject,â€ù said Diana Aviv, president and chief executive of the Independent Sector, a trade association representing about 550 nonprofit organizations. â€œWhere do you draw the line? Some of our largest foundations were created by individuals who have been described as robber barons. Should charities look askance at that money?â€ù,Rushworth M. Kidder, president of the Institute for Global Ethics, said he did not think a blanket prohibition on gifts from corporations was necessary but that charities should be thinking more about the issue. â€œWeâ€™re a nonprofit, and we have drawn the line, for instance, with some foundations that are clearly aligned with a political position,â€ù he said. â€œWeâ€™re here to help people understand how to think, not what to think, and to the extent that people see us as coming from a particular position because of the money we receive, it dilutes out mission.â€ù,The Doctors Without Borders policy has existed informally since the early 1990s, Ms. Herman said, and was formally approved by the board later that decade. The organization does not solicit or accept funds from any companies or their foundations that derive income from tobacco, alcohol, weapons, pharmaceuticals, medical equipment, biotechnology, oil, mineral, gas and other extractive industries, like diamond mining.,â€œTo take money from an economic entity whose influence goes beyond the economic to influence politics and government in the areas where we work could complicate the negotiations we have with governments, rebel groups and others,â€ù said Nicolas de TorrentÃ©, executive director of the Doctors Without Borders affiliate in the United States.,Mr. de TorrentÃ© noted, for example, the far-reaching influence of diamond mining in Western Africa, and of the oil industry in Nigeria and Sudan. â€œYouâ€™ll often hear of oil companies trying to set up clinics, but we are there just to do humanitarian work, not to promote or help anyone with their image,â€ù Mr. de TorrentÃ© said.
column4: Nonprofit Groups Draw a Line at Some Donors

column1: MANCHESTER, N. H., Jan. 27 â€” , sounded nearer than ever to being a presidential candidate on Saturday, repeatedly talking about the prospect of running, and inviting  voters to judge him by his record as mayor of New York City.,Though he has long been thought to be a presidential contender, he has fallen behind other candidates in declaring his intention, and the language he used on Saturday, while suggesting a run, also contained built-in escape hatches. Speaking to a convention of the , ,, he advised the delegates on â€œwhat you should look for in whatever decision you make in presidential primaries,â€ù and added, â€œwhen I promise you things, if I do, when I do, as I do, Iâ€™ll promise them because Iâ€™ve done them before.â€ù,He returned to that theme moments later, and as he has done in recent days, drew a direct analogy between fighting crime in his home city and establishing peace in Iraq.,â€œWhen I say to you that we should reduce taxes to stimulate the economy, Iâ€™ll say it to you because I did it and I saw it work,â€ù he said. â€œWhen I say we have to bring peace and security as sort of the beginning of anything, whether itâ€™s in Baghdad or in other parts of the world or here at home, Iâ€™ll say that to you because I saw that happen in New York, and I made it happen. I did it.â€ù,In his first trip since last fall to the state that holds the earliest presidential primary, Mr. Giuliani stepped closer than he has before to suggesting that he will run.,â€œGovernment has got to work in order to allow people to have confidence in it,â€ù he said. â€œAnd as I look at this, I believe there is something I can do about that.â€ù,Whether or not he is serious about a campaign, he may need to send such a signal to keep his options open. He has raised money, traveled extensively and put together a more robust organization in recent weeks, but as other candidates enter the race, many Republicans â€” and some publications â€” have questioned whether he will go through with it.,On this trip, he met privately with several elected officials, including the mayor of Manchester, Frank Guinta â€” the kind of personal courting people here expect, and that other top contenders have done more than Mr. Giuliani has. â€œHeâ€™s going to have to spend a lot more with these people,â€ù said Senator John E. Sununu.,When he speaks, Mr. Giuliani normally walks around the stage and does not refer to notes, joking and making matter-of-fact arguments. But Saturdayâ€™s speech, at the old Palace Theater, was unusually formal for him  â€” he stayed behind the lectern and worked from notes â€” and also more overtly boastful and partisan, and more designed to rouse his audience.,Mr. Giuliani has taken the politically risky position of supporting President Bushâ€™s unpopular decision to send more troops to Iraq, as have the other Republicans who rank highest in early polls, Senator John S. McCain and Mitt Romney, the former Massachusetts governor. But for the second time in as many days, Mr. Giuliani cautioned Saturday that the strategy might not work, and that it should not be viewed as the last word in the war.,â€œWe hope and we root for and we pray for a successful outcome in Iraq,â€ù he said. â€œBut our ultimate victory is not going to be a military victory. Our ultimate victory against terrorism is going to be a victory of ideas.â€ù,But he stayed away from the divisive social issues that put him at odds with much of his party, like his support of , rights and gay civil unions. Some delegates here said they had hoped Mr. Giuliani would explain support his past support for gun controls in New York that would be unpopular here.,Still, Republican officials here take him very seriously as a presidential contender, based primarily on his reputation for leadership in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks.,â€œI would say his chances are excellent,â€ù said State Representative John Reagan. â€œEveryone knows he has been severely tested.â€ù
column4: Giuliani Is Sounding More Like a Candidate

column1: For decades, the best women in chess came from Eastern Europe, partly a result of state support of chess. But since the Soviet Unionâ€™s collapse, while Eastern European men have maintained their place among the elite, the women have slipped. Of the top 10 active women, half are from Eastern Europe.,Chinese women have rushed to fill that vacuum. Three of the top 10 are from China, although one, Zhu Chen, No. 4, who was world champion from 2001 to 2004, now lives in Qatar.,Chinese men have improved, too, taking the silver at the world team championships last year, but havenâ€™t kept pace with the women. The best Chinese man, Wang Yue, is No. 60.,Mao banned chess during the Cultural Revolution, and it was not until the late â€™70s that it began to gain a following. Up to then, Chinese had played a (still popular) version of chess that has several big differences, including having pieces called canons, but no queens.,The first great Chinese player, Xie Jun, easily made the switch to the Western-style game. In 1991, she won the world championship by beating Maya Chiburdanidze of Georgia. Xie held the title until 1996, lost it, and then regained it in 1999 before ceding it to Zhu in 2001.,The newest talent is Hou Yifan, who is just 12. The worldâ€™s eighth-ranked female player, she already has a rating high enough to qualify for the grandmaster title (not the watered-down womenâ€™s title, but the menâ€™s). She had been turning in an impressive performance at the elite Corus tournament, which ends today.,In the third round, Hou displayed calm beyond her years, defending a difficult position against the Dutch grandmaster John van der Wiel. Unable to crack Houâ€™s defense, van der Wiel pushed too hard and lost a piece. Hou quickly wrapped it up.,Â•,Hou chose the Najdorf Variation of the Sicilian Defense, and van der Wiel responded aggressively.,Houâ€™s 7 ... Qc7 is not considered the main response to 7 f4 (more usual is 7 ... Be7), but it is playable.,With 9 f5, van der Wiel sought to open the position, but this move has generally not had good results for White. More common is 9 Qd2, seeking to complete his development.,After 10 fe, Blackâ€™s king was destined to stay in the center, but experience has shown that Black does quite well in this position.,Houâ€™s 11 ... Nd4 took the game into almost uncharted waters. After 16 ... Rd7, the players had bishops of opposite colors, a situation that favors the attacker. Van der Wiel improved his position steadily, but after 22 ... Kd7, Hou was still O.K.,Van der Wiel miscalculated with 29 ef, overlooking that after 31 ... Bf6, he cannot take the bishop with the queen because then the rook on g4 is unprotected and he cannot take it with the rook because of 32 ... Re1.,After 37... Rf5, he gave up.
column4: Here Come Chinaâ€™s Women (and One Rising Star Is Just 12)

column1: Not breaking from the laid-back demeanor that has made him a calming presence in the Yankee locker room for 16 years, , said yesterday that he was not sure what he would do if he could control his future.,Though Williams previously indicated that he wanted to return to the Yankees, they have made it clear they have little interest in re-signing him.,â€œThe Yankees expressed a very not secure position regarding my situation with the team and at that point they said they may not offer me a contract,â€ù Williams said at a fund-raiser for Hillside Food Outreach in New Rochelle.,â€œThat was three or four weeks ago. Things may have changed, but I donâ€™t know.â€ù,Unfortunately for Williams, 38, little has changed in the Yankeesâ€™ outfield. Johnny Damon, Bobby Abreu, Hideki Matsui and Melky Cabrera are still on the roster, and it does not appear the team will trade Cabrera.
column4: Bernie Williamsâ€™s Future Still Unclear

column1: NAIROBI, ,, Jan. 27 â€” Two Americans, including an elderly woman, were shot to death on Saturday afternoon by carjackers in Nairobi, the capital, according to American and Kenyan officials.,The two victims, relatives of an American Embassy employee, were traveling in an embassy car with three other Americans when a truck  cut them off, police officials said. Four men jumped out with Kalashnikov assault rifles and ordered the occupants out of their car.,â€œApparently, the driver and an elderly woman sitting in front did not move fast enough,â€ù a police spokesman said. â€œSo the bandits shot them.â€ù,Nairobi has been plagued by violent crime, and American officials said they did not believe the attack was related to terrorism.
column4: U.S. Citizens Killed in Kenya

column1: JOHANNESBURG, Jan. 27  â€” More than a year after a virulent strain of , killed 52 of 53 infected patients in a rural South African hospital, experts here and abroad say the disease has most likely spread to neighboring countries, and some say urgent action is essential to halt its advance.,Several expressed concern at what they called ,â€™s sluggish response to a health emergency that, left unchecked, could prove hugely expensive to contain and could threaten millions across sub-Saharan Africa.,The director of the governmentâ€™s tuberculosis programs called those concerns unfounded and said officials were doing everything reasonable to combat the outbreak.,The form of TB, known as XDR for extensively drug-resistant, cannot be effectively treated with most first- and second-line tuberculosis drugs, and some doctors consider it incurable.,Since it was first detected last year in KwaZulu-Natal Province, bordering the Indian Ocean, additional cases have been found at 39 hospitals in South Africaâ€™s other eight provinces. In interviews on Friday, several epidemiologists and TB experts said the disease had probably moved into Lesotho, Swaziland and Mozambique â€” countries that share borders and migrant work forces with South Africa â€” and perhaps to Zimbabwe, which sends hundreds of thousands of destitute refugees to and from South Africa each year.,But no one can say with certainty, because none of those countries have  the laboratories and clinical experts necessary to diagnose and track the disease. Ominously, none have the money and skills that would be needed to contain it should it begin to spread.,Even in South Africa, where nearly 330 cases have been officially documented, evidence of the diseaseâ€™s spread is mostly anecdotal, and epidemiological work needed to trace its progress is only now beginning.,â€œWe donâ€™t understand the extent of it, and whether itâ€™s more widespread than anyone thinks,â€ù Mario C. Raviglione, the director of the Stop TB Department of the World Health Organization in Geneva, said in a telephone interview. â€œAnd if we donâ€™t know what has caused it, then we donâ€™t know how to stop it.â€ù,Cases of XDR TB exist elsewhere, in countries like Russia and China where inadequate treatment programs have allowed drug-resistant strains of the disease to emerge. The South African outbreak is considered far more alarming than those elsewhere, however, because it is not only far larger, but has surfaced at the center of the worldâ€™s , pandemic.,Although one third of the worldâ€™s people, by W.H.O. estimates, are infected with dormant tuberculosis germs, the disease thrives when immune systems are weakened by H.I.V. At least two in three South African TB sufferers are H.I.V. positive. Should XDR TB gain a foothold in the H.I.V.-positive population, it could wreak havoc not only among the five million South Africans who carry the virus, but the tens of millions more throughout sub-Saharan Africa.,People without H.I.V. have a far smaller chance of contracting tuberculosis, even if they are infected with the bacillus that causes TB. But because tuberculosis is spread through the air, anyone in close contact with an active TB sufferer is at some risk of falling ill.,Most if not all of the 52 people who died in the initial outbreak of XDR TB, at the Church of Scotland Hospital in a KwaZulu-Natal hamlet called Tugela Ferry in 2005 and early 2006, had AIDS. Most died within weeks of being tested for drug-resistant tuberculosis, a mortality rate scientists called unprecedented.,Since then, South African health officials say, they have confirmed a total of 328 cases of XDR TB, all but 43 in KwaZulu-Natal. Slightly more than half the patients have died.,Those numbers are deceptive, however. The Tugela Ferry outbreak was reported in part because the hospital there was part of a Yale University research project involving H.I.V.-positive patients with tuberculosis. Because South Africaâ€™s treatment and reporting programs for tuberculosis are notoriously poor â€” barely half of TB patients are cured â€” virtually all experts contend the true rate of infection is greater.,â€œWeâ€™re really concerned that there may be similar outbreaks to the one in Tugela Ferry that are currently going undetected because the patients die very quickly,â€ù said Dr. Karin  Weyer, who directs tuberculosis programs for South Africaâ€™s Medical Research Council, a semiofficial research arm of the government.,Some other researchers and experts say they share Dr. Weyerâ€™s concern. They say South African health officials have lagged badly in assembling the epidemiological studies, treatment programs and skilled clinicians needed to combat the outbreak, and say the government has responded slowly to international offers of help.,Dr. Weyer said the council â€œshares the concern that not enough is being done, quickly enough, to get on top of the problem.â€ù In particular, she said, officials have yet to carry out epidemiological studies or address a â€œshockingâ€ù  lack of infection controls in  hospitals that could allow TB and other infections to spread freely among H.I.V.-positive patients,â€œItâ€™s an emergency, and weâ€™re not reacting as if it were an emergency,â€ù said Dr. Nesri Padayatchi,  an epidemiologist and expert on drug-resistant TB for Caprisa, a Durban-based consortium of South African and American AIDS researchers. â€œI think we have the financial resources to address the issue, and weâ€™ve been told the Department of Health has allocated these resources.â€ù,Although the government was first told of the outbreak 20 months ago, in May 2005, â€œto date, on the ground in clinics and hospitals, we are not seeing the effect,â€ù she said.,In KwaZulu-Natalâ€™s major city, Durban, the sole hospital capable of treating XDR TB patients has a waiting list of 70 such cases, she said.,Dr. Weyer said the waiting list indicates that â€œcapacity is becoming a problemâ€ù in KwaZulu-Natal, the outbreakâ€™s center.  â€œIâ€™m quite sure we may find a similar situation in other provinces,â€ù she added.,A spokesman at the hospital said it could not easily determine how many patients were awaiting treatment.,But the manager of South Africaâ€™s national tuberculosis program, Dr. Lindiwe Mvusi,  said such complaints were misplaced. The Durban hospital in question, she said, is under renovation, and officials are â€œlooking for accommodations in other hospitalsâ€ù while construction proceeds.,Hospitals in other provinces have enough beds now for XDR TB patients, and some are expanding isolation wards to handle any spread of the disease, she said.,She said other responses to the outbreak were under way, including a rough assessment of TB cases in hospitals nationwide.  A more comprehensive national survey of TB cases may be conducted late this year, she added, and health officials in KwaZulu-Natal have begun surveillance programs to detect new cases of drug-resistant TB in the province.,Dr. Mvusi also rejected the notion that the tuberculosis had moved beyond South Africaâ€™s borders. But in interviews, a number of TB experts and epidemiologists raised that concern, including Mr. Raviglione at the world health organization, Dr. Padayatchi, Dr. Weyer and Dr. Gerald Friedland, director of the AIDS program at the Yale University School of Medicine.,Dr. Raviglione of W.H.O. said that South African health officials were cooperating on responses to the outbreak, and that an official of his organization would arrive in Pretoria within days to discuss placing a team of global TB experts in the country.,â€œW.H.O. is ready to come to South Africa and to help in any place, for anything, whether surveillance, or detection, or infection control,â€ù he said. However, those arrangements have not been completed.,Dr. Mvusi, the governmentâ€™s TB program head, said  global health experts were welcome, but â€œin an advisory role, because we want the capacity locally.â€ù
column4: Virulent TB in South Africa May Imperil Millions

column1: SAN DIEGO, Jan. 27 (AP) â€” The Navy called off a search on Saturday for three missing crew members of a helicopter that crashed in the ocean about 50 miles off Californiaâ€™s southern coast.,The crash during a training mission on Friday left one sailor dead, and the Navy had searched for the remaining crew members through the night and into the afternoon.,â€œThe cold water temperature and the time that elapsed since the crash occurred led Navy officials to conclude that aircrew survivability is extremely unlikely,â€ù said Lt. Cmdr. Elizabeth Meydenbauer of the Navy.,Lieutenant Meydenbauer said the Navy knew the location of the sunken helicopter, but had not decided if the wreckage would be brought up from the ocean floor.
column4: Search for Missing Helicopter Crew Ends

column1: Representative , and a number of city officials urged President Bush yesterday to reconsider  a proposed change to Medicaid that could cost the cityâ€™s public hospital network millions of dollars in annual financing.,â€œWe want to make sure the president knows how damaging his health care proposal will be to our Health and Hospitals Corporation,â€ù the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, said,  referring to the agency that runs the cityâ€™s 11 public hospitals and dozens of diagnostic centers and health clinics.,Agency officials estimate the presidentâ€™s plan would cost the corporation about $350 million a year, about 7 percent of its annual budget.,Ms. Quinn joined Mr. Rangel and more than a dozen other elected officials and health care representatives at City Hall yesterday to protest the presidentâ€™s proposal.,â€œIsnâ€™t it embarrassing we have to do this,â€ù said Mr. Rangel, who promised to join other Democrats and use his post as chairman of the powerful Ways and Means Committee to cut off funds to the presidentâ€™s health care plans.,â€œHow can a great nation like ours explain that we canâ€™t take care of our own,â€ù he said, adding that the presidentâ€™s proposals come as â€œmillions are being spent on a war that nobody wants.â€ù,Mr. Bushâ€™s proposal would end a longstanding regulation that allowed public hospitals to receive more money from Medicaid, the health plan for the poor, than private hospitals receive for the same services.,Federal officials have said that  the resulting savings could be sent to the states in the form of â€œaffordable choice grantsâ€ù and used to provide the uninsured with  private health insurance.,Alan D. Aviles, president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation, said that the rule was in place to help public hospitals that provide treatment to the indigent, and that losing it would â€œshred the safety net of the safety net providers.â€ù,The City Council plans to send a letter to the president this week opposing the proposal.
column4: Rangel and Others Condemn Bush Medicaid Plan

column1: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 23 â€” The peers who elected , as the first black president of the , Law Review say he was a natural leader, an impressive student, a nice guy. But in the 1990  Revue â€” the graduating editorsâ€™ gleeful parody of their elite publication â€” they said quite a bit more.,â€œI was born in Oslo, Norway, the son of a Volvo factory worker and part-time ice fisherman,â€ù a mock self-tribute begins. â€œMy mother was a backup singer for Abba. They were good folks.â€ù In Chicago, â€œI discovered I was black, and I have remained so ever since.â€ù,After his election, the Faux-bama says, he united warring students into â€œa happy, cohesive folk,â€ù while â€œempowering all the folks out there in America who didnâ€™t know about me by giving a series of articulate and startlingly mature interviews to all the folks in the media.â€ù,In his two memoirs and the biographical video on his Web site, Senator Obamaâ€™s legal education is barely a blip, one of the least known chapters of his life. But for the Illinois Democrat who is all but certainly running for the presidency, Harvard was the place where he first became a political sensation.,He arrived there as an unknown, Afro-wearing community organizer who had spent years searching for his identity; by the time he left, he had his first national news media exposure, a book contract and a shot of confidence from running the most powerful legal journal in the country.,As the ribbing in the Revue suggests, Mr. Obama was realizing the power of his own biography. He proved deft at navigating an institution scorched with ideological battles, many of which revolved around race. He developed a leadership style based more on furthering consensus than on imposing his own ideas. Surrounded by students who enjoyed the sound of their own voices, Mr. Obama cast himself as an eager listener, sometimes giving warring classmates the impression that he agreed with all of them at once.,Friends say he did not want anyone to assume they knew his mind â€” and because of that, even those close to him did not always know exactly where he stood. It is a tendency that could prove perilous on the campaign trail, as voters, rivals and the news media try to fix the positions of a senator with only two years in office.,â€œHe then and now is very hard to pin down,â€ù said Kenneth Mack, a classmate and now a professor at the law school, referring to the senatorâ€™s on-the-one-hand, on-the-other-hand style.,Charles J. Ogletree Jr., another Harvard law professor and a mentor of Mr. Obama, said, â€œHe can enter your space and organize your thoughts without necessarily revealing his own concerns and conflicts.â€ù,Many of his former professors and classmates say they are cheering on Mr. Obama, 45,  in his candidacy. But the skills he displayed in law school may not serve him as well in American presidential politics, which sometimes rewards other qualities â€” like delivering sound bites instead of deliberateness or fidelity to a base of supporters instead of compromise.,The law review is â€œfairly disconnected from the breadth and the rough and tumble of real politics,â€ù said Bruce Spiva, a former review editor who now practices civil rights law in Washington. â€œItâ€™s an election among a closed group. Itâ€™s more like electing a pope.â€ù,Mr. Obama declined to comment about his time at Harvard. He arrived at the law school in 1988 with a well-inked passport â€” he had grown up in Hawaii and Indonesia, son of a black Kenyan father and a white American mother â€” and years of community organizing experience in Chicago, making him, at 27, an elder statesman among the students who had tested and term-papered their way straight there.,Mr. Obama spent much of his time alone, curtailing his dating life after his first summer, when he met his future wife, a Harvard Law graduate named Michelle Robinson who was working in Chicago. He often played pickup basketball, replacing his deliberative off-court style with sharp elbows and aggressive grabs for the ball.,Along with 40-odd classmates, he won a precious spot on the law review at the end of his first year through grades and a writing competition. But the next year, when other students implored him to run for the presidency, he demurred; he wanted to return to community work in Chicago, he said, and the credential would be no help. Late in the process, he finally agreed, saying he might be uniquely able to heal the reviewâ€™s partisan divisions.,The election was an all-day affair with the ego-crushing drama of a reality TV show. Inside Pound Hall, the editors picked apart the intellectual and social skills of the 19 contenders, eliminating them in batches. At the last moment, the conservative faction, its initial candidates defeated, threw its support to Mr. Obama. â€œWhatever his politics, we felt he would give us a fair shake,â€ù said Bradford Berenson, a former associate White House counsel in the Bush administration.,The two finalists were invited back into the room. But before the winner could be announced, Mr. Mack, a black student who had rejoined the editors after being eliminated, lunged toward Mr. Obama, so moved by the barrier that had just fallen that he embraced him tightly, tears streaming down both menâ€™s cheeks.,Newspapers and magazines swarmed around the first black student to win the most coveted spot at the most vaunted club at one of Americaâ€™s most prestigious institutions. In interviews, Mr. Obama was modest and careful. (In a rare slip, he told The Associated Press: â€œIâ€™m not interested in the suburbs. The suburbs bore me.â€ù) He signed a contract to write a memoir. A prankster posted a cast list for a movie version of his life, starring Blair Underwood. When Mr. Underwood visited the school, he questioned Mr. Obama for material for  â€œL.A. Law.â€ù,â€œPeople were always asking me, do young black attorneys really exist like that?â€ù Mr. Underwood said in a recent interview. â€œI would refer to Barack.â€ù,Winning the job was simpler than doing it. The president had to reject articles by some of the schoolâ€™s famous professors and persuade a divided group of editors to stop arguing and start editing.,â€œI have worked in the Supreme Court and the White House and I never saw politics as bitter as at Harvard Law Review in the early â€™90s,â€ù Mr. Berenson said. â€œThe law school was populated by a bunch of would-be Daniel Websters harnessed to extreme political ideologies.â€ù They  were so ardent that they would boo and hiss one another in class.,Even trickier, Mr. Obama was the most prominent minority student on a campus shaken by racial politics. A group agitating for greater faculty diversity occupied the deanâ€™s office and sued the school for discrimination; Derrick Bell, a black law professor, resigned over the issue.,The law review struggled to decide whether affirmative action should factor into the selection of editors, and how much voice to give to critical race theorists, who argued that the legal system was inherently biased against minorities. That drew the ridicule of conservative students.,And it left the new president with a difficult choice. If he failed to use his office to criticize Harvard, Mr. Obama would anger black and liberal students; by speaking out, he would risk dragging himself and the review into the center of shrill debates.,People had a way of hearing what they wanted in Mr. Obamaâ€™s words. Earlier, after a long, tortured discussion about whether it was better to be called â€œblackâ€ù or â€œAfrican-American,â€ù Mr. Obama dismissed the question, saying semantics did not matter as much as real-life issues, recalled Cassandra Butts, still a close friend. According to Mr. Ogletree, students on each side of the debate thought he was endorsing their side. â€œEveryone was nodding, Oh, he agrees with me,â€ù he said.,As the president of the review, Mr. Obama once again walked a delicate line. He served on the board of the Black Law Students Association, often speaking passionately about the tempest of the week, but in a way that white classmates say made them feel reassured rather than defensive. He distanced himself from bombast; he did a mischievous impersonation of the Rev. Jesse Jackson when he  came to speak on campus,  recalled Franklin Amanat, now a federal prosecutor in Brooklyn. Mr. Obamaâ€™s boldest moment came at a rally for faculty diversity, where he compared Professor Bell to Rosa Parks.,But mainly, Mr. Obama stayed away from the extremes of campus debate, often choosing safe topics for his speeches. At the black law studentsâ€™  annual conference, he exhorted students to remember the obligations that came with their privileged education. His speeches, delivered in the oratorical manner of a Baptist minister, were more memorable for style than substance, Mr. Mack said.,â€œItâ€™s the inspiration of the speech rather than the specific content,â€ù he said.,Just as he does now that he is a senator, Mr. Obama spoke then about his own biography â€” initially, Mr. Ogletree said, to correct anyone who assumed he had acquired his position with ease. His message, Mr. Ogletree said, was, â€œDonâ€™t look at my success and assume that I have had a silver spoon in my mouth and gold coins in my hand.â€ù,During the constant arguments about race and merit, everyone could point to Mr. Obama and find justification for their views. He had acknowledged benefiting from affirmative action in the past, so those who supported it saw him as the happy product of their beliefs.,But those who opposed it saw his presidency as the triumph of meritocracy. He was a black man who had helped one of Harvardâ€™s most celebrated professors, Laurence H. Tribe, with an article on law and physics, and would graduate magna cum laude.,Another of Mr. Obamaâ€™s techniques relied on his seemingly limitless appetite for hearing the opinions of others, no matter how redundant or extreme. That could lead to endless debates â€” a mouse infestation at the review office provoked a long exchange about rodent rights â€” as well as some uncertainty about what Mr. Obama himself thought about the issue at hand.,In dozens of interviews, his friends said they could not remember his specific views from that era, beyond a general emphasis on diversity and social and economic justice.,Instead, they wonder how the style of leadership they observed on campus could translate to another kind of historic presidency.,â€œThe things that make law school politics fractious are different from the things that make American  politics fractious,â€ù said Ron Klain, who preceded Mr. Obama at the  law review and later served as Vice President Al Goreâ€™s chief of staff. Mr. Klain has watched the senatorâ€™s rise.,â€œThe interesting caveat,â€ù he said, â€œis that is a style of leadership more effective running a law review than running a country.â€ù
column4: In Law School, Obama Found Political Voice

column1: UNEMPLOYMENT is low and the job market is strong, according to surveys. But just where are the jobs in 2007?,As the population ages, jobs continue to go wanting in health care. And as more products and services go digital, competition for information technology workers is intense. Demand is also increasing for workers in the sales, clerical, education, financial services, accounting and customer service categories.,â€œUnemployment is at a historically low level,â€ù said Brent Rasmussen, chief operating officer at ,, an online job site that surveyed employers about where they expected to add jobs this year. â€œI think in 2007 weâ€™ll see steady growth, much more of an employee market.â€ù,And  nearly half the employers surveyed said they expected to increase initial salary offers to new employees â€” about one-sixth of those by 5 percent or more.,With baby boomers starting to retire and shortages of skilled workers in some areas, demand is expected to result in not only higher salaries, but also in more career advancement and opportunities for flexible work environments.,Mr. Rasmussen noted that  40 percent of  the more than 2,600  employers surveyed for his company by Harris Interactive  currently had job openings for which they could not find qualified candidates.,Competition is particularly fierce for nurses, with thousands of openings that paid $51,000, on average, in 2006. ,, for example, currently has about 4,000 nursing positions open.,â€œThe reality is there are more nursing positions in this country than there are qualified nurses,â€ù said Carol Maxwell, senior director of executive recruiting for Tenet, which is based in Dallas and owns 64 hospitals in 12 states.,â€œWe are trying new strategies every day to recruit and retain our employees,â€ù Ms. Maxwell said.,That means reaching out to people looking for second careers and offering training to help them refocus their skills.,Demand for health care workers stretches beyond nursing into a number of areas like pharmacology, radiology and many types of therapy, including physical and occupational. Salaries for available jobs in the field vary significantly. For example, according to the  Bureau of Labor Statistics, a midrange salary for a pharmacy aide is about $18,900 while a pharmacist may make more than $89,000 a year.,According to the Labor Department, the fastest-growing occupations in the next seven years will be in health and technology. The department, which makes its predictions every 10 years, projected in 2004  that the biggest growth rate would be in the  number of home health aides  â€” up  56 percent, to 974,000, by 2014. A group with much higher pay, network systems and data communications analysts, was expected to grow by  55 percent, to 357,000. Next were medical assistants, physician assistants, computer software engineers, physical therapist assistants and dental hygienists.,â€œThe fastest-growing jobs are dominated by a lot of technical level occupations that one can qualify for with limited post-secondary education,â€ù said Jon Sargent, an occupational outlook economist with the Bureau of Labor Statistics. â€œIn this day and age of expensive education, they represent affordable opportunities to get into a reasonably well-paying occupation in high demand.â€ù,After the technology boom and bust of the late 1990s and early 2000, information technology jobs have rebounded, and salaries are increasing along with opportunities.,â€œI get at least one call a month from a recruiter outside of my own firm trying to fill a job,â€ù said Rachelle Turner, a technical writer and trainer who works for Robert Half Technology, a recruitment and staffing firm in Menlo Park, Calif., specializing in placement of technology professionals.,â€œRight now, based on my experience, itâ€™s an employeeâ€™s market. There are more jobs than there have been in a very long time,â€ù she said. â€œPeople who are good, who have kept their skills sharp, generally donâ€™t stay available very long.â€ù,A survey conducted for Robert Half on I.T. hiring found that 16 percent of 1,400 chief information officers planned to add technical staff in the first three months of the year. Only 2 percent said they were planning to cut back.,Another Robert Half survey also found that the average starting salary for technology professionals would increase 2.8 percent in 2007, while starting pay for high-demand positions like software and Web developers is expected to climb by at least 4 percent. Salaries for chief information officers are expected to range from $120,250 to $200,000 in 2007; those for senior Web developers, from $71,000 to $102,000; and those for entry-level help desk operators, from $27,500 to $37,000.,The technology skills in greatest demand, according to the survey, were Windows administration,  followed by network administration and database management. Companies also said that Web developers and programmers were highly prized,  as well as people with network security and project management skills.,â€œWeâ€™re seeing companies investing in technology to make them better, faster and stronger,â€ù said Katherine Spencer Lee, executive director of Robert Half Technology. â€œThey need people who can help them get the technology to work.â€ù,Another high-growth area is energy, said Nariman Behravesh, chief economist at Global Insight, a consulting firm. Refinery and drilling jobs have increased, he said, as have jobs in  alternative and synthetic fuels. While the overall number of added jobs  may be small when compared with other sectors, he said, the growth has been significant.,Doors are also opening for executives, said Chris Ohlendorf, a senior partner at the  McKinley Group, an executive search firm based in Minneapolis.,â€œWhatâ€™s been missing over the past few years is the ability for managers and others in leadership positions to have a productive job search,â€ù Mr. Ohlendorf said. â€œEverybody was filling soldier roles.â€ù,But recently, companies have been looking for people to manage those workers.,â€œHiring is much more aggressive, much more real,â€ù he said.,The hottest areas for executive jobs,  according to McKinley, are sales, engineering and accounting and finance (particularly for those familiar with accounting changes in the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 or with compliance reporting to the Securities and Exchange Commission) with strong growth in marketing and information technology.  Mr. Ohlendorf said that in information technology,  there was particularly strong demand for senior-level project managers, professionals with experience in software quality assurance and Microsoftâ€™s .Net technology.,FOR college graduates in general, the job outlook is also good, according to the National Association of Colleges and Employers, an organization of college career advisers and staffing professionals.,A recent survey found that employers hope to hire 17.4 percent more graduates in 2007 than in 2006. Employers in the service sector predicted the largest increase,  19.8 percent, with manufacturers planning to increase hiring of graduates by 9.5 percent. For  government and nonprofit employers, the projected gain was 9 percent.,But that doesnâ€™t mean finding a job is effortless. Jonathan G. Sugar, who later this year will be graduating from a masterâ€™s program in mechanical engineering at the University of California, Los Angeles, said that pounding the pavement or, perhaps more aptly in 2007, hitting the job boards, was still crucial for graduating college students.,A recent visit to a job fair that included many of the major military  contractors was little more than a meet-and-greet, he said.,â€œAll the big companies just tell you to go online and apply,â€ù he said.  â€œI just go to the job fairs for the free pens.â€ù
column4: From Tech Workers to Nurses, an Employeeâ€™s Market

column1: ON the surface, it seemed like the perfectly executed job search. Every day, a 40-year-old saleswoman based in New York would scan Internet job boards like Monster, HotJobs and CareerBuilder and would send e-mail messages to contacts and potential employers. She faxed her rÃ©sumÃ© and checked online trade news. In short, she did everything she could to find a more fulfilling job than the one she had held for seven years.,There was just one catch: she conducted much of her job search last year right under her employerâ€™s nose, using the companyâ€™s computer, fax machine, business e-mail account and office supplies.,â€œI was doing a lot of stuff that could have gotten me in trouble,â€ù acknowledged the saleswoman, who spoke on condition of anonymity because she was still working for the same small business. â€œMy opinion was, let them fire me. I would have been disappointed to hurt their feelings, but on the other hand I had to do what I had to do.â€ù She did erase her computerâ€™s history as often as possible to cover her tracks.,Her story is not unusual. In workplaces where high-speed broadband Internet access is typically available and 60-hour workweeks are commonplace, many employees believe that the office is the most convenient or effective place to do a job search. And people who are unhappy with their jobs sometimes believe that they are entitled to use the workplace to find something better.,There are no statistics on the extent of the practice, but according to workplace experts and employees, it is widespread. The problem is that such activity is often against company policy and may even lead to dismissal.,â€œItâ€™s something that should be avoided, particularly when company employment policies specifically forbid resources and communication devices for any personal use, much less for a job search,â€ù said Ben Dattner, principal of Dattner Consulting, a Manhattan-based firm with large and small corporate and nonprofit clients. â€œItâ€™s important to abide by the terms of oneâ€™s employment and not to burn bridges.â€ù,The chances of being caught, Mr. Dattner added, have climbed  as more companies monitor computer use and e-mail. He said that instead of using company time and property for a job search, employees could conduct the hunt on their own time with their home computers and cellphones. And it is not difficult to go to a nearby print center at lunchtime to make copies, he noted.,Noah Pickus, interim director for ethics at the Kenan Institute for Ethics at Duke University, recommends that job seekers use common sense in their pursuit of new employment while at the office. That means not spending hours job-searching while neglecting work duties or putting the office phone number on your rÃ©sumÃ©.,â€œThere is an important distinction between an occasional e-mail and spending half a day looking for another job,â€ù Mr. Pickus said. â€œThe most difficult ethical dilemmas are often between two rights. Itâ€™s right to look out for yourself and your family and itâ€™s right that you have an obligation to your current employer.â€ù,John A. Challenger of Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the placement firm based in Chicago, says that most employees, especially those under 40, see themselves as â€œfree agentsâ€ù who will search for jobs from their offices as a matter of course. Employees working 50- or 60-hour weeks, he said, are often too exhausted to look for jobs when they are outside the office.,He says he does believe that job-hunting from the office crosses an ethical line when employees begin using office supplies for rÃ©sumÃ©s and cover letters.,It can also be dangerous. Mr. Challenger suggested that if an employer caught an employee job-searching on company time, it could lead to a loss of â€œplum assignments and promotions.â€ù,An organization that is downsizing may be quicker to fire an employee who has been caught faxing his rÃ©sumÃ©, and occasionally it may lead to dismissal of a worker who is already on thin ice, Mr. Challenger said. Occasionally, though, it could have the opposite effect, he said â€” spurring an employer to try to reconcile differences with a disgruntled but valuable employee.,There is one situation when it may be acceptable to look for a job from the office, Mr. Challenger said: when layoffs are expected or have been announced.,That was the case for Adrienne Lewin, 34, now a freelance writer based in New Jersey who was a staff reporter for , in 2001, when the company announced major layoffs. Many of the employees to be laid off, including Ms. Lewin, remained in the companyâ€™s offices in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan for about two months after the announcements and took advantage of the opportunity to use FoxNews.com resources to find another job, she said.,â€œI searched job sites from the office,â€ù Ms. Lewin said. â€œI also used the fax machine printer, copier and phone to reach journalism contacts and respond to job postings. And there was a small amount of satisfaction in using whatever I could from the employer who was letting me go, to find something better.â€ù,MS. LEWIN said she would be too nervous about getting caught to use company computers or e-mail to hunt for jobs from the office again. But she has seen it done often at other jobs she has held.,â€œIâ€™ve found job listings and rÃ©sumÃ©s resting on printers at work,â€ù Ms. Lewin said. â€œThough I havenâ€™t done it, I think people treat it like shopping online during work hours. Itâ€™s not seen as an ethical violation.â€ù,A 52-year-old hospital health care professional based in New York says she was initially torn about searching for new work from the office of an employer she has been with for 12 years. On one hand, she said, she occasionally felt guilty job-hunting from her office at lunch hour or using moments to update her rÃ©sumÃ© and to check online job boards.,On the other hand, she said the qualms she felt about looking for a new job while at work were superseded by anger toward her employers for making her feel â€œanonymous and replaceable.â€ù She believes that her talent and masterâ€™s-level education are not being utilized in her current job, she said, and that the two hours a week she spends job-hunting from the office does not affect her work.,While she is comfortable using her office computer to job-search, she said, she does not feel right sending e-mail messages to prospective employers.,Just as job-seeking from the office often requires secrecy, so can going on interviews. In 2004, Mary Catanzaro realized after just two weeks that an office-manager job she took with a New York-based fashion showroom was a mistake. Almost immediately, she began searching for another job and going on interviews. But the showroomâ€™s dress code was so casual that showing up in a work suit would have looked suspicious.,â€œWearing a blue suit was a red flag that you were interviewing,â€ù Ms. Catanzaro, now 37, recalled.  Instead, she packed her blue suit into her gym bag and changed clothes and applied makeup in a nearby McDonaldâ€™s restroom.,Ms. Catanzaro, whose current job as an office manager for a New York photography studio includes interviewing prospective employees, said that she empathized with people who look for jobs while at work. â€œIf youâ€™re not happy with a place, you donâ€™t care about protocol,â€ù she said. â€œYouâ€™re trying to go forward with your own career. Itâ€™s not necessarily ethical, but itâ€™s sometimes necessary.â€ù
column4: The Pluses and Pitfalls of Job-Seeking at Work

column1: The (variously) one-eyed, one-horned, purple, red and green people eaters called Uglydolls are among the most successful of a new wave of vinyl, plastic and plush â€œdesigner toys.â€ù Originally conceived by the New York design school graduates David Horvath and Sun-Min Kim, the Uglydoll line has grown into a monstrous franchise with dozens of iterations, collected (ostensibly for their kids) by baby boomers, like me, who have yet to fully embrace maturity. Uglydolls are, however, but one brand among scores â€” if not hundreds â€” of patently quirky and deliberately unsightly toy/object characters that have exploded into a minor global phenomenon.,Starting in Hong Kong and Japan during the mid-1990s, when comic illustrators fiendishly began tearing off and substituting heads and appendages on G.I. Joes, Barbies and other mainstream dolls and toys with mangled (and melted) body parts, these hybrids were sold at comic-book conventions, where people went wild for them. Soon toy factories in Guangdong Province in China were commissioned to produce limited editions of around 250 each, and the â€œdesigner toy movementâ€ù erupted.,In â€œI Am Plastic: The Designer Toy Explosion,â€ù Paul Budnitz, founder of Kidrobot, one of the most prodigious retailers of designer toys in the United States, and co-creator of the Dunny doll (a balloonlike head with rounded ears atop a stumpy teddy-bear body, produced in various customized versions), showcases many of the more adventurous toy designers and their wares. While much too short on descriptive text â€” it could also have benefited from more historical analysis â€” this large, sumptuous display of alluring oddities shows the extent to which independent artists and designers have aggressively and satirically pushed the limits of convention beyond the benign world brought to life in the animated film â€œToy Story.â€ù,Small toy companies â€” with rock-band names like Secret Base, Tokyo Guns, Cube Works, Rough Toyz and the Creatures in My Head, featuring bizarre (sometimes sarcastically cute) toys by illustrators and artists like Frank Kozik, Tim Biskup, Gary Baseman, Sara Antoinette Martin and Jim Woodring â€” have since flooded art and design galleries and alternative toy stores with collectibles in a wide price range. These radical, ribald objects are influenced by all manner of pop culture genres, from the gangsta rap used in Misha & Shaunaâ€™s Missing Link to the heavy metal in Takumi Iwaseâ€™s Rock Rabbit. In the outlaw tradition, there are plenty of scurrilous defacements of corporate symbols: the artist Filth transforms Mickey Mouse into a monster mouse with Devil 666 Bear Qee; Ron Englishâ€™s MC Supersized is a stubby, bling-wearing Ronald McDonald.,Many among this new breed of toy designer were weaned on Japanese manga comics and anime films, as well as American cartoons like â€œRen & Stimpy,â€ù â€œThe Simpsonsâ€ù and â€œSouth Park.â€ù Some also emerged from the skateboard and graffiti cultures, where they were hard-wired to attack or analyze everything in mass culture. For them anything is artistically possible, especially challenging the convention-bound toy industry. Yet Budnitz notes that despite their influences, one thing is certain: these toys are not nostalgic. â€œAs far as I am concerned nostalgia is a creativity killer, and a life killer,â€ù he says. And while some toys overtly riff on TV shows and movies (like Nathan Cabreraâ€™s R2-D4, in which a can of the popular lubricant WD-40 is made to look like the body of the â€œStar Warsâ€ù character R2-D2, and his Breakfast at Tiffanyâ€™s, Starring French Kitty, featuring a sassy, wide-eyed plastic cat in Audrey Hepburnâ€™s famous cocktail dress), a vast majority are unique, conceptual comic absurdities made, more or less, from whole cloth (or fresh plastic). To-Fu Oyako, a 10-inch piece of tofu in a spaceman outfit, made by Devilrobots, and Gloomy Bear, a sad-eyed pink creature clinging to a lifeless friend named Pity, designed by Mori Chack, are among the most imaginative creatures in a book filled with many surprises.,Although designer toys emerged on the pop culture scene with a kind of D.I.Y. underground cred, most are intricately and professionally produced, with well-articulated parts and accessories. Le Messieâ€™s Zombies â€” a series of brightly colored creatures with sardonic expressions, whose bodies resemble large gel caps with arms, legs and removable heads that cover their deformed brains â€” are typical of an obsessive attention to detail. In fact, designer toys are also more sculptural than their mainstream counterparts. Even the cardboard and bubble-wrapped packages (sadly, not reproduced in the book) are graphically alluring. â€œWhat draws a person to an object is not always an idea â€” it might just be an intense love for the material reality of the object itself,â€ù Budnitz writes.,Heâ€™s right. Over the past five years Iâ€™ve bought dozens of toys, not for bathtub play but for arrangement in pristine displays (kept out of reach of my son) that are a pleasure simply to look at. â€œI Am Plasticâ€ù proves that as this art form grows, there will be many more toys worth collecting.
column4: Toy Story

column1: I recently wandered through my home library in Montana and rediscovered Karl Shapiroâ€™s â€œBourgeois Poetâ€ù (1964), a book of prose poems I first read during the vile winter of 1966. My wife and I had moved back to northern Michigan, after Iâ€™d left behind a good job in Boston on the promise of my first book of poems, â€œPlain Song,â€ù having been accepted by Norton. I donâ€™t recall what shape I expected the promise to arrive in: I ended up trimming Christmas trees and working construction for two and a half bucks an hour. Our rented house was only $35 a month, but it was drafty, the furnace was faulty and frequently the place couldnâ€™t be brought up to 55 degrees. All of these numbers can actually describe a life.,Reading Shapiroâ€™s prose poems under such conditions was wonderful in that I was decidedly not bourgeois. As a young Francophile, mostly because high school textbooks of American and English literature in the â€™50s were so dreary, I was sympathetic with the prose poem, essentially a French genre. Shapiro seemed to be deranged by the prosperity of his academic position â€” he was a professor at the University of Nebraska â€” and since I had flunked out of graduate school for reasons of arrogance I was familiar with the atmosphere he was evoking: â€œNow when I drive behind a Diesel-stinking bus / On the way to the university to teach / Stevens and Pound and MallarmÃ© / I am homesick for war.â€ù,I was empathetic to Shapiroâ€™s travails up to a point, but then my wife and I were eating altogether too much macaroni and cheap cheese and he sounded like a man who had had a huge porterhouse and half a cheesecake for dinner and was complaining about indigestion. The subtext, unworded but looming, was that, like coal miners, poets have to make a living, and Shapiro had children.,It should be remembered that bourgeois was a volatile word in the 60s, frequently an insult. After our horrid winter I ended up teaching at Stony Brook on Long Island, where I occasionally noted professors in bell-bottoms with long hair saying, â€œAll power to the people,â€ù whoever they might be. Obviously our workday clothing is also a costume signifying who we wish to be, and professors at the time could be nervous about being bourgeois.
