Only a Republican would wear a clean trench coat.,Shapiro (1913-2000) had gotten the title for his book at a party, after giving a reading in Seattle, when Theodore Roethke called him a â€œbourgeois poet.â€ù The question is why it caused Shapiro such severe unrest that he poured heart and soul into what is really one very long poem?,I suspect Shapiroâ€™s evident misery started early in his life with a heroic notion of the poet. Any poet knows that to become immortal all you have to do is write a single great poem. This is unlikely indeed. Perhaps there are tens of thousands of mules and draft horses across the countryside who dream of winning the Kentucky Derby. Better yet, a bartender in Seville told me last March, â€œWe have thousands of aspiring Lorcas but only one Lorca.â€ù Very early on a poet is struck by the cruelty and lack of democracy in the arts â€” so few get it all, and the hordes receive nothing but the pleasure and pain of an overdeveloped consciousness. Ted Kooser, the former United States poet laureate and a friend of Shapiroâ€™s at the time â€œThe Bourgeois Poetâ€ù was written, told me Shapiro was obsessed with the French symbolist poets. This explains a lot, since Shapiroâ€™s notion of what a poet was implies the outsider, the outcast, the outlier, one who purposefully deranges his mind to write poems like Rimbaud, or one who could not walk, so borne down was he by his giant wings, to paraphrase Baudelaire. I must here imagine myself an English department chairman, who has to deal with these troublesome creatures, and say that a poet is hubris through and through in the same manner that an unruly pig is solid pork.,Shapiro was massively famous in the 1940s and â€™50s, in the manner of Robert Lowell or Allen Ginsberg in the â€™60s and â€™70s, though his fame seemed to dip after â€œThe Bourgeois Poet.â€ù He served in World War II, then published â€œV-Letter and Other Poemsâ€ù and won the , at 32. He became consultant in poetry, now known as poet laureate. Later, on a prize committee made up of famous poets, he was one of only two who voted against awarding Ezra Pound the Bollingen Prize, and it was a grand literary scandal at the time. Shapiro cast his vote as a Jew in opposition to a renowned anti-Semite. He was also voting against the wishes of T. S. Eliot, the virtual pope of poetry during the postwar years. I would suggest the possibility of anti-Semitism in the decline of Shapiroâ€™s reputation. But when you begin your career as grandly as he did, where can you go but down?,â€œThe Bourgeois Poetâ€ù is disturbingly brilliant though occasionally it is inadvertently comic. How can you be , much less stridently Whitmanesque, on a campus in Nebraska? A poet must discover that itâ€™s his own story that is true, even if the truth is small indeed. The work is marvelous in small pieces but deflates a bit in the face of Shapiroâ€™s heroic posturing over what a poet is. There is a wonderful carelessness possible only because it is the kind of poem in which every sort of effluvium fits into the plan. The danger here is that it must be interesting effluvia.,Often in the poem Shapiro refers to himself as â€œThe Beepâ€ù:,He also writes, the torpor overwhelming:,And:,Perhaps as a corrective and a cautionary, â€œThe Bourgeois Poetâ€ù should be taught to the thousands taking M.F.A.â€™s in creative writing who wish to become poet-professors. As I said I tried it myself but found the work too hard. Thereâ€™s a subdued but relentless hurly-burly in academia that swallows up discretionary time. Itâ€™s like living with a slight backache, not fatal but enervating. Besides, academic salaries are falling behind and itâ€™s become questionable if poet-professors have truly achieved bourgeois status. Maybe lumpen bourgeois.,In the â€™60s I was actually on a committee in New York City with R. V. Cassill from Brown and Ben DeMott from Amherst, among others, trying to figure out how to get universities to hire more poets and novelists. Through no fault of our own it worked out that way.,Historically, of course, the scales are tipped in favor of the non-bourgeois poet. Yeats warned that the hearth was more dangerous for a poet than alcohol. Rilke said, â€œOnly in the rat race of the arena, does a heart learn to beat.â€ù Well off the margins of the page in â€œThe Bourgeois Poetâ€ù thereâ€™s an invisible Greek chorus singing, â€œYouâ€™ve got to earn a living.â€ù,Ultimately for a poet the fence is so high the top is invisible, but it is what we are designed to reach for. Everything else is mere scaffolding. You will most likely get the back of the museâ€™s hand whether you have a chair at Harvard or are pumping septic tanks in Missouri. I must say my sympathies are still with CÃ©sar Vallejo, a grander poet than anyone now living on our bruised earth. In Paris between the world wars Vallejo and his girlfriend would pick out the empty wine bottles in trash receptacles to earn their keep.
column4: Donâ€™t Feed the Poets

column1: Jules Verneâ€™s â€œJourney to the Center of the Earth,â€ù a survey of mid-19th-century geological controversies thinly disguised as a ripping yarn set in a dinosaur-inhabited subterranean realm, was a best seller when it was first published in France in 1864. Five years later, an upstate New York alternative healer named Cyrus Teed had a vision revealing that the earth is hollow and that weâ€™re all living on its concave inner surface. He eventually renamed himself Koresh, and established a thriving colony of hollow-earthers in the wilds of Florida. Then, in 1871, â€œThe Coming Race,â€ù by Edward Bulwer-Lytton, in which the narrator discovers an advanced civilization underground, helped give rise to dozens of science-fiction novels in which travelers penetrated the icy polar realms and descended into a well-lighted netherworld via a whirlpool or tunnel.,Where did the outlandish notion that the earth is hollow come from, and why did it capture the imagination of 19th-century Americans? In his entertaining new book, the journalist David Standish traces Americaâ€™s hollow-earth craze to one John Cleves Symmes, a St. Louis trader who in 1818 self-published a circular gravely announcing that â€œthe earth is hollow and habitable within; containing a number of solid concentric spheres, one within the other, and that it is open at the poles. ...â€ù The zone of ice near the poles, he argued, was merely a frozen ring surrounding a warm open sea leading to the interior.,The kookiest thing about Symmesâ€™s theory is how believable many found it. Not that it was without a semi-respectable scientific pedigree. As Standish recounts, several pioneering modern scientists and thinkers, including the English astronomer Edmond Halley, the German Jesuit Athanasius Kircher and the Boston cleric Cotton Mather, had also advanced hollow-earth theories. (Since God would probably not have wanted to waste any space, Mather argued, an inhabitable hollow earth made perfect sense.),Symmes was less persuasive as a scientist, however, than as an advocate for a national expedition to locate the polar opening. One of his converts, an Ohio newspaper editor named Jeremiah Reynolds, joined Symmes on his lecture tour and later embarked on a failed polar expedition. Reynoldsâ€™s speeches and writings would in turn inspire the young Edgar Allan Poe to write â€œMs. Found in a Bottle,â€ù a career-launching story about a traveler sucked into an immense whirlpool at the South Pole. Poe later reprised the idea in â€œThe Narrative of Arthur Gordon Pym,â€ù which in turn inspired Jules Verne.,Standishâ€™s research is impressive, taking in everything from the British Enlightenment and American religious utopianism to such hollow-earth literature as Jacques Casanovaâ€™s five-volume 1788 novel â€œIcosameronâ€ù (about a society of nudist hermaphroditic dwarves) to Edgar Rice Burroughsâ€™s Pellucidar novels, in one of which Tarzan descends into a â€œSymmesâ€™s Holeâ€ù via zeppelin. But his efforts to explain the popularity of hollow-earth-ism â€” a Koreshan remnant survives today with the cult newsletter Hollow Earth Insider â€” are weak. Standish rather lamely suggests it â€œcan be seen as a sort of ultimate metaphysical retreat to the womb.â€ù As for the proliferation of hollow-earth fiction from the 1870s on, it can be chalked up to the fact that writers needed â€œsomewhere to set improbable romances now that formerly remote, unknown corners of the earth were becoming less believable as settings the more they were explored.â€ù Ho-hum!,In the topsy-turvy America of the 19th century, in which the Civil War, industrialization, and urbanization caused all that was solid to melt into air (as a contemporary of Symmes put it), what could have made more sense than an inside-out world? Today, when utopian literature is so often dismissed as proto-totalitarian, we need dismissive explanations of hollow-earth mania like we need a Symmesâ€™s Hole in the head. If Standishâ€™s larger ideas are less than satisfying, itâ€™s not because heâ€™s wrong. Itâ€™s only because we surface-dwellers have lost the capacity to imagine that another world is possible.
column4: Journeys to the Center

column1: â€œItâ€™s the cooking, the cleaning, the crying!â€ù wails Oscar in â€œThe Odd Coupleâ€ù when Felix has pushed him too far. In Rachel Cuskâ€™s latest novel, itâ€™s the cooking, the cleaning and the fact that beyond oneâ€™s own snarled household a million other women are doing the same. Her characters are quietly going berserk. Arlington Park isnâ€™t the end of the world; itâ€™s just suburbia. But, with a little exaggeration, the two become interchangeable.,Juliet was once thought exceptional and now is hardly noticed as she picks her way through traffic in the rain. Her husbandâ€™s failure to defend her against the oafishness of their host at a dinner party has led her to the conclusion that all men are killers. â€œThey take a woman, and little by little they murder her.â€ù Julietâ€™s impotent rage eventually finds expression in a haircut.,Amanda has a nasty contretemps with her tiny son when he asks awkward questions about a deformed man. She really seems to hate this kid. Her neighbor, Jocasta, is much kinder, marveling at the taupe coffin her daughter has prepared for a pet rabbit. (â€œDarling, how ,!â€ù) Amanda and her husband derive satisfaction only from the removal of interior walls: â€œTheir conversations on the subject of knocking through were so numerous and so energetic ... that the walls seemed almost to fall down by themselves.â€ù,Maisie has a kitchen she cannot bear to enter and companions she feels nothing for. â€œSheâ€™d get ... hysterical if someone stole her hair dryer,â€ù Maisie says of a woman her husband has made the mistake of praising. â€œSheâ€™d get pretty damned jumpy if her husbandâ€™s salary didnâ€™t come rolling in like a Pacific breaker every month, or if people stopped thinking she looked like Felicity Kendall.â€ù Not overtly competitive, these women freely grind one another into the dust in private.,Christine, nouveau riche and crass, is content â€” not with her husband or children, far from it, but with Arlington Park, in particular the mall. She even likes the way it looks from the parking lot. Cusk is hardest on Christine, simmering with contempt for the womanâ€™s lowly concerns: spending money, wearing purple and writing to the local paper. By the last chapter, Christine has more or less turned into the objectionable Beverly from Mike Leighâ€™s â€œAbigailâ€™s Party.â€ù (But Beverly was funnier.),Cuskâ€™s many female characters are far too similar, and you wish sheâ€™d stuck with one. Each exhibits low-level feminist outrage and ambivalence toward her family, but these traits are so muted and ineffectual they only add to the ennui. The novel comes straight out of the kitchen-sink school of British realism, thrashing through any sentimentality you might harbor about family life and suggesting that very little holds such structures together besides routine, nostalgia, financial dependence and an unthinking sense of duty. These are empty experiences, on offer to people who are not empty and who therefore suffer inordinately. Cusk laments this. â€œTo look at that view youâ€™d think that a human life was meaningless. Youâ€™d think that a day meant nothing at all.â€ù,The book eventually becomes one long postpartum gripe, though neither humane nor funny enough to be enjoyable as social satire. Why must the wife of an obnoxious man be â€œhorse-facedâ€ù? Another dope has a â€œcapacious chest.â€ù Denoting character flaws through physical defects seems beneath a writer of Cuskâ€™s intellectual bent. Too often, sheâ€™s grandiose when she could be friendly, convoluted when she needs to be clear, snooty when you want something tender. Sheâ€™s discerning about people and the passing thought, but she can be snobbish about class and overly fond of descriptive passages, telling us repeatedly of sagging skies and clouds. O.K., itâ€™s raining â€” we got it!,There are some great moments, but she tends to over-egg the pudding with metaphor, simile and melodramatic hyperbole when all sheâ€™s describing is a set of materially advantaged women getting through the day. None of the many hints of impending disaster lead anywhere. So when she writes: â€œThe empty black mouth of the fireplace stood open in frozen protest. In front of it an Indian rug lay twisted in an attitude of torment,â€ù you wish sheâ€™d lighten up. Thereâ€™s nothing worse than wasted ominousness.,Do these couples like one another at all? The husbands are a problem, but itâ€™s the children these women really canâ€™t stand. As in Cuskâ€™s nonfiction book on motherhood, â€œA Lifeâ€™s Work,â€ù children are seen here as vampiric usurpers of their mothersâ€™ bodies and souls. But sometimes the mothers fight back. â€œI could kill you!â€ù fumes one woman at someone elseâ€™s kid, who has just drawn on her white sofa with Magic Markers. â€œYouâ€™re ruining my life!â€ù rages another as she propels her daughterâ€™s lunchbox across the room. â€œElla,â€ù says Christine to her child, â€œif you donâ€™t shut up Iâ€™m going to rip your tongue out of your throat.â€ù Thatâ€™s telling her.,â€œArlington Parkâ€ù is the kind of book that makes you burn things on the stove and berate your husband. Cusk is good at identifying what she fears and reviles. The challenge would be to say what she cares about, even if it makes her sound silly. Dignity isnâ€™t everything. Honesty is.
column4: Suburban Squall

column1: Among the many perverse diversions and delights of Jesse Kellermanâ€™s unnerving new thriller, , are his clinically detailed descriptions of all the variables that could drive a third-year medical student like Jonah Stem crazy. The sleep deprivation from putting in 16-hour days, six days a week, might do it alone. But compounding that constant assault on the nervous system are the abusive egomaniacal surgeons, the disgusting scut work on the colorectal ward and the staggering psychic misery of observing all the human suffering. That Kellerman maintains such a grimly hilarious perspective on his subject is its own twisted tribute to the survival instincts of writers who go down to the depths to entertain their readers. In Jonahâ€™s words, when he finds himself on the psych wing: â€œYou had to laugh. If you didnâ€™t, youâ€™d drown.â€ù,As this psychologically complex story develops, it isnâ€™t the normal crush of work and study that finally pushes this sensitive hero to the limits of his mental endurance. Itâ€™s a woman who calls herself Eve Jones. Jonah thought he was rescuing Eve from a violent death when he fought and killed a man he saw attacking her on a dark street on the far West Side of Manhattan. (Indeed, he has his moment of fame as a media hero: â€œSuperdoc Battles Sicko W/ Knife.â€ù) But Eve works her way into his bloodstream like a slow-acting poison, challenging his devotion to an ex-girlfriend who suffers from a debilitating neurological disorder and wickedly manipulating Jonahâ€™s emotional neediness to satisfy her own sadistic sexual tastes. Before Jonah realizes that this pain artist means it literally when she says â€œI love you to death,â€ù she has taken control of his life.,Eve may be too much of a monster to pass as a credible human being, but sheâ€™s a memorable character, with her mad theories on the aesthetics of pain and her genius at recognizing the wolfish impulses Jonah has repressed under his nice-guy persona. (â€œShe knew,â€ù Jonah acknowledges. â€œShe could divine latent rage.â€ù) Her feats of pure, guilt-free perversity also make her a wonderful foil for the amusingly clueless friends and family members against whose behavioral norms Jonah is subconsciously rebelling.,â€œHe needed to see how it felt to say no,â€ù Jonah says, when he first blows off one of his routine duty calls on his ex-girlfriend. â€œAnd now he knew: it felt O.K.â€ù But in a very short while, it will not feel O.K. at all, and Jonah can only wish he were back on the colorectal ward.,Thomas H. Cook is one of the most literary of psychological-suspense authors, and sometimes, as in , he allows his lyrical style to swamp his story. But while the suspense is minimal in this first-person account of an underachieving small-town lawyer who fears for the sanity of his gifted but unstable sister, the narrative is sustained by its thematic richness and the subtlety of its psychological portraits of tormented characters.,As children, both David Sears and his older sister, Diana, were subjected to grueling intellectual drills by their father, a paranoid schizophrenic given to frightening rages when a little boy stumbles over his lessons in Greek mythology. But unlike David, who resigns himself to being the dunce of the family, Diana is every bit as brilliant as her father â€” and perhaps as mad. That suspicion, first raised when Diana accuses her husband of having murdered their mentally disturbed son, becomes an obsession with David when she initiates his teenage daughter into her fanciful way of thinking. Although Cook is maddeningly coy about who actually killed whom, he writes eloquently about the fears that lead people to equate intelligence with madness, suppressing the imagination and taking refuge in mediocrity.,When Iâ€™m casting about for an antidote to the sugary female sleuths who solve crimes without disrupting their social calendars, Kate Shugak, the Aleut private investigator in Dana Stabenowâ€™s Alaskan mysteries, invariably comes to mind. In more than a dozen novels, Kate has demonstrated that she can shoot a rifle, butcher a moose, overhaul an engine and survive in remote regions of the Alaskan wilderness. More amazing yet, her outdoor skills donâ€™t alienate the rugged men in her life. , finds Kate under pressure from her relatives to get tough with a serial wife-killer whose luck at eluding the law has demoralized their entire village. For once, Kateâ€™s straight-arrow methods fail her, truth being an arbitrary concept in a community where local custom dictates justice. So forget all those hair-raising treks into the wild; joining the tribal council may well be the most dangerous move Kate has ever made.,Meanwhile, thousands of miles away on an Indian pueblo in New Mexico, a young female agent with the Bureau of Land Management puts some muscle into a homicide case with eerie mystical overtones. Making her striking debut in Sandi Aultâ€™s , Jamaica Wild watches a man trampled in a buffalo stampede. Despite the expression of rapture she saw on his face, she refuses to accept the Tanoah tribeâ€™s judgment that his death was a suicide and doggedly pursues an investigation that strains her relationship with the â€œpueblo motherâ€ù whoâ€™s initiating her into the Tanoah customs. Scenes of the high, dry, glittering landscape are as clean as a sun-bleached bone, and there are thrills galore when Jamaica is trapped in a flash flood that tears down the canyon walls of an ancient mountain sacred to the tribe. But Ault is no less artful at depicting the marriage customs, funeral rites and religious ceremonies that have drawn Jamaica to this tightly knit world and made her lose her heart to its people.
column4: Pain Artist

column1: Around the time of the War of Independence, Americaâ€™s main contact with the Middle East consisted in trading Caribbean rum for Turkish opium. Itâ€™s hard not to wish, reading the epic story of this 230-year relationship, now usefully condensed into a single well-researched volume, that things could have remained as simple as the swapping of your recreational poison for mine.,But things never were quite so simple. Even then the potential for friction loomed as large as the possibility of mutual gain. Before the end of the Napoleonic wars, Christian sailors risked capture and enslavement by Muslim pirates from the Barbary ports of Algiers, Tunis and Tripoli. Governments could either front protection money, cough up ransom or threaten force.,America tried all three approaches, and its erratic policy echoes with sad familiarity in the 21st century. We find the same wrangling in Washington between those who counsel appeasement (the cheaper, saner option) and those who demand armed action (the more glorious); bickering among Western capitals over whether to act singly or in concert (Thomas Jefferson tried to corral a coalition, but Congress balked); and daring strikes carried out with near-fatal clumsiness (an attempt to blockade Tripoli led to the capture, in 1803, of the U.S.S. Philadelphia and its 308-man crew, and a subsequent, heroically farcical attempt to free them by effecting regime change).,Michael B. Oren, an American-born Israeli scholar and the author of a well-received study of the 1967 Arab-Israeli war, recounts such exploits with admirable detachment. â€œPower, Faith, and Fantasyâ€ù is hugely ambitious, drawing on hundreds of original sources to create a finely balanced overview of this enormously complex subject. Out of understandable necessity, the later chapters, dealing with more recent times and Americaâ€™s role as a superpower, preoccupied with a multilayered and often contradictory agenda in the Middle East, grow sketchier and less conclusive.,Yet it is a diverting tale over all, full of forgotten twists and memorable characters. Who remembers now, for instance, that the Statue of Liberty was initially conceived by her French sculptor as an Egyptian peasant girl, intended to adorn the entrance to the Suez Canal? Or that the first Zionists to settle in Palestine were in fact American Protestants, who planted successive, ill-fated colonies aimed at â€œrestoringâ€ù the Holy Land to Jews, so that their subsequent conversion to Christianity would speed the Second Coming? Or that Civil War veterans officered Egyptian campaigns in Sudan and Abyssinia? Or that before landing in North Africa during World War II, the United States Army dropped leaflets advertising the arrival of â€œHoly Warriors ... to fight the great jihad of freedomâ€ù?,Some of these episodes may sound trivial or obscure, but Oren cleverly weaves them into the overarching themes of his title. Consider Americaâ€™s missionary effort. The printing of native-language Bibles, and the founding of schools, clinics and three universities, in Cairo, Beirut and Istanbul, that remain among the best in the region, failed to win more than a trickle of converts. Yet a hundred years of American mission work produced some unexpected change.,It was, in part, the missionary doctorsâ€™ reputation for altruism that persuaded the Saudi king to offer his oil patch not to British, but to American prospectors. And while the proto-Zionist restorationist movement faded to the fringes of Protestant preaching â€” at least, until its revival by some modern evangelicals â€” a sentimental attachment to the ancient Hebrews infused the religious upbringing of Harry Truman and Lyndon Johnson, the two presidents who did most to cement American ties with ,.,Such underlying trends have seldom been so well explored, but Oren occasionally overstates their importance. Trumanâ€™s own words reveal that â€œfaithâ€ù was perhaps a secondary motive behind his crucial decision to back the creation of Israel. â€œI have to answer to hundreds of thousands who are anxious for the success of Zionism,â€ù Oren quotes Truman as explaining. â€œI do not have hundreds of thousands of Arabs in my constituents.â€ù,Important context is missing from some of the bookâ€™s pages. Oren artfully touches on Middle Eastern influence on American popular culture, from the hootchy-kootchy dance to Camel cigarettes, but tends to dissociate this from the wider Western tradition of Orientalism. There is much gory detail about the Armenian genocide, but scant mention of the fact that Ottoman Turkey faced repeated invasion by a Russia whose czars, disastrously for the Ottomansâ€™ Armenian subjects, claimed leadership of all Orthodox Christians. At several junctures, Oren paints Europe as stubbornly resistant to American policy, without adequately substantiating the charge or explaining European motives. We hear nothing of how Americaâ€™s fateful, post-World War I decision to restrict , helped push desperate Jewish refugees toward Palestine.,While correctly noting the peculiar mix of cultural disdain and romantic fascination that has marked American attitudes to Muslim Middle Easterners, Oren curiously declines to distance himself from some unflattering views. We hear, for instance, of an 18th-century diplomat whose â€œexperience had taught him that in the Middle East power alone was respected,â€ù as if this were a quality unique to the region. And a hint of distaste sometimes infuses his language. The landmass of the Middle East curves â€œscimitar-like through Arabia.â€ù Elsewhere, Oren speaks blithely of â€œnameless Middle Eastern thugsâ€ù and â€œthe ubiquity of Arab terror.â€ù Such shopworn phrases tend to compound, rather than dispel, preconceived notions of the Middle East as a kind of unfathomable Badland.,Commendably, in a work of such scope, there are very few errors of fact or omission. Yet, as a reserve major in the Israeli Army, Oren ought to know that Israelâ€™s 1982 invasion of Lebanon was not provoked by the P.L.O. â€œregularly strikingâ€ù at Galilee. ,â€™s group was certainly an elemental threat to the Jewish state, but had actually been observing a long, American-brokered cease-fire before ,â€™s drive to Beirut. It is also odd that the author hardly touches upon the influence of the pro-Israel lobby, or on the issue of United States financial and military aid to Israel, factors undeniably crucial to any understanding of Americaâ€™s involvement with todayâ€™s Middle East.,Oren mostly avoids the temptation to seek historical parallels to modern events. The occasions when he succumbs reveal the peril for historians of this habit. Toward the bookâ€™s conclusion, for instance, he avers that â€œby protecting themselves from Middle Eastern threats while simultaneously trying to assist native people, U.S. forces in Iraq were, in effect, revisiting the earliest American involvement in the region.â€ù Surely, as we now know, the threat to America posed by Saddam Husseinâ€™s Iraq was more fantastical than real, until, that is, American forces hit the ground there.,Such subtle reinforcement of Americaâ€™s self-image as an innocent among Middle Eastern sharks mars an otherwise exemplary work. This is a pity, since, as Oren amply illustrates, it is Americaâ€™s failure to be clear and honest about its own motives, as much as its serial failure to interpret the Middle East, that has so often befuddled relations with the region.
column4: Midnight at the Oasis

column1: are at once the most amazing and frustrating of medical miracles. A new kidney or heart can cure someone who would otherwise die or, even in less than ideal circumstances, extend life and improve well-being. The surgical skill and pharmaceutical innovation required to make transplantation work are wonders of human ingenuity.,But there is still no such thing as a truly new organ. Unlike insulin or artificial hips, organs so far cannot be successfully manufactured. They come only pre-owned, usually from young, healthy people who have died suddenly in traumatic accidents that destroyed their brains. Rainy weekends increase the organ supply. Helmet laws reduce it. The more than 94,000 Americans on the waiting list for organs are, in effect, waiting for someone else to die so that they can live.,This grisly calculus posed enormous cultural problems for early transplant advocates, as Kieran Healy, a sociologist at the University of Arizona and a contributor to the blog Crooked Timber, notes in â€œLast Best Gifts.â€ù â€œPublic ambivalence about transplantation was overcome, in part, by arguing that donation was the â€˜gift of life,â€™ â€ù he writes. â€œThe success of this idea now makes it more difficult to garner support for a market for organs.â€ù By emphasizing altruism, transplant advocates gave comfort to the bereaved, conferring meaning on a tragic event and justifying what might otherwise seem like desecration. This early success helps explain why, even in the face of a critical shortage of organs, many leaders in the transplant field oppose any financial incentives for organ donors, including tax credits or payment toward funeral expenses.,The â€œgift of lifeâ€ù story is useful but, according to Healy, oversimplified. Shaped by a strongly anticommercial ideology, it places too much emphasis on the division between giving and selling. It doesnâ€™t acknowledge the diverse ways in which people define the social meanings of exchange, regardless of whether money is involved. The fable of heroic altruists also misleadingly emphasizes the motives of the donor (or the donorâ€™s family) over the system in which the decision to give or not takes place. â€œThe voluntary donation of human goods is an organizational accomplishment,â€ù Healy argues.,Just as businesses in the same industry may have different rates of profit, organ procurement organizations â€” the regional groups charged with managing cadaver organs â€” have different rates of success in persuading families to part with the organs of their loved ones. Some of those results depend on regional characteristics, from population density (which makes it easier to get organs to recipients quickly) to race (blacks, for example, are somewhat less likely to donate organs or support the idea of donation more generally). But along with such basic organizational differences as budget and number of referring hospitals, environmental differences like these account for only about half of the variation. Clearly something more â€” call it â€œmanagementâ€ù â€” is at work.,Consider the South Carolina Organ Procurement Agency, which has increased its donation rate by 83 percent since 1997. The agency not only expanded its field staff from eight to 21, it changed its methods. â€œThe person who explained to families that their loved one was brain dead, and who spent a considerable amount of time (perhaps a whole day) helping them with this realization, was no longer the person who requested consent for donation,â€ù Healy writes. This separation of roles may sound like common sense, but it requires organizational insight into the emotional state of donor families.,As an economic sociologist, Healy adds important dimensions to the intensifying debate over organ procurement. He reminds both advocates and opponents of markets that commercial transactions are embedded in social structures and as likely as any other exchanges to have social meaning. To succeed, incentives must show sensitivity to those meanings. A direct payment to a funeral home, for example, could honor a donor familyâ€™s decision without making them seem to profit from their loved oneâ€™s death. Or healthy adults could make binding contracts to be organ donors if they die in the right circumstances, with life insurance paid for by transplant centers, the government or a private foundation going to their heirs.,The bookâ€™s major shortcoming is its failure to address the fastest growing source of organs: living donors. More than two-thirds of the people on the national waiting list â€” about 68,000 â€” need kidneys. There are nowhere near enough brain-dead accident victims to fill that demand, regardless of family beneficence or organizational efficiency. Fortunately, nobody has to die to supply a kidney. They can come from living donors, who can live perfectly normal lives with a single kidney and who now account for nearly 40 percent of all kidney transplants. With the kidney shortage at crisis proportions, the debate over financial incentives is really a debate over whether living adults should be allowed to sell their own organs or, at the least, receive a tax credit or some other indirect compensation.,Although he barely mentions living donors, Healyâ€™s sociological message resonates through that debate. Financial incentives would operate within complex organizational structures, as well as contract and liability law. Bureaucratic institutions, notably hospitals and insurers, would shape the environment in which transplants take place. Many kidney sellers would still have humanitarian motives. â€œThe idea that markets inevitably corrupt,â€ù Healy writes, â€œis not tenable precisely because they are embedded within social relations, cultural categories and institutional routines.â€ù Commerce isnâ€™t antithetical to culture; it is part of it.
column4: Grim Harvest

column1: Rather than cloning the original art-filled Chambers boutique hotel in New York, the Midwestern outpost, which opened in September, strikes an independent profile in a gallerylike compound  fashioned from two neighboring pre-1910 brick low-rise office buildings with a   a courtyard-cum-lounge in between. Interiors and exteriors showcase the estimable contemporary art collection of the owner, the , developer Ralph Burnet, helping to increase Minneapolis's emerging stature as the artiest town on the prairie.,Pedestrian friendly. The Chambers's downtown locale is walking distance of theaters, the Target Center sports arena, warehouse district restaurants and retail-centric Nicollet Avenue.,The high-tech rooms are a bit cold. A throw rug over the black-stained wood floors  would have warmed up my gallery-white standard room, No. 512. But cloudlike feather bedding, down pillows and high-thread-count linens compensate. Business travelers and e-mail users are well served with  an expansive desk and countertop that lines an entire wall, as well as with  free Wi-Fi and D.S.L. A painting by the local artist Rod Massey, decorative vases and a video art channel on the 42-inch plasma television confirm the art theme.,Functionally stylish. An opaque window wall in the shower plays peek-a-boo with the entry foyer on the other side. A German-made metal â€œrampâ€ù sink by Alape slopes back toward the blue-glass-tiled wall, heated tiles pave the floor and a 13-inch flat-screen television faces the toilet.,The Chambers's chief asset is its $7 million art collection spanning painting, sculpture, photography, neon and hybrids like a wall hanging of Indian chipati tongs by Subodh Gupta. Works by Damien Hirst and other marquee  artists  are displayed in an adjacent gallery that rotates Mr. Burnet's collection, while video art flashes in the lobby, lounge and guestroom corridors.,The Ã_ber-chef ,Jean-Georges Vongerichten created the menu at the paper-lantern-lighted Chambers Kitchen, where the local fish, walleye, is dressed  up with basil and jalapeno ($18). A glass-walled and balcony-ringed bar on the top floor draws a hip, partying crowd, but soundproof doors seal the noise from guestroom hallways.,The outdoor courtyard has a large fire pit and screenings of experimental films on the whitewashed walls. The lobby's shopping nook sells  Barbara Kruger tote bags ($65); skateboard decks by a local artist, Sean Tubridy ($58); and Yoshitomo Nara clocks ($250). The basement fitness center was overheated at 75 degrees and offered no privacy from  staff members passing in a service corridor.,Guests must call for morning coffee ($4 per cup) â€” there is no maker in the room â€” but delivery is speedy. (My order arrived in less than 10 minutes.) All food comes from the Chambers Kitchen, which bears Mr. Vongerichten's stamp even in breakfast basics like a bagel and smoked salmon, which comes with an endive salad dressed in sherry vinaigrette ($16).,Guests on a Friday night looked like the 40-something sophisticates who might buy the modern art on the walls, whereas the younger, bohemian lounge set looked like those who had created it. With the exception of one indifferent bar host, the helpful hotel staff is free of attitude.,Art-focused lodgings are poised to appeal to travelers in search of design-forward Minneapolis. The 60 rooms start at $199 and go to $3,500 for the 1,000-square-foot Rock Star Suite with skyline views.,, 901 Hennepin Avenue, 612-767-6900; ,.
column4: Minneapolis: The Chambers Minneapolis

column1: Chris Abani has done an end-run around the immigrant novel. In two previous books, Abani, who was born in Nigeria, traced a path from third world to first: â€œGraceLand,â€ù his bustling novel set in Lagos, closed with a young manâ€™s departure for the United States; his novella â€œBecoming Abigailâ€ù followed the title character from Nigeria to London. Abani now teaches at the University of California, Riverside, and his strange new novel is set in Los Angeles. Rather than adopting the perspective of a newcomer, though, he gives us Black, a mural artist raised in California, the son of a Nigerian father and a Salvadoran mother. Black was called Obinna as a boy, but after his father went missing in Vietnam, he lost his name along with any connection to his African ancestry.,Now 36 and at loose ends, he dresses himself from time to time in a filched wedding gown, and in that guise is repeatedly mistaken for an apparition of the Virgin of Guadalupe. But really thatâ€™s the least of his troubles: tormented by dark memories, suicidal impulses and persistent, unrelieved erections, heâ€™s obsessed with a transsexual stripper named Sweet Girl, and is being stalked by the Angel Gabriel, who sometimes assumes the form of a pigeon. His best friends are Iggy, a tattoo artist and psychic (and the owner of the wedding dress) who rents him a room behind her cafe, and a Rwandan named Bomboy who owns a slaughterhouse â€” though these two are little more than bystanders to his crisis.,Black is all desire and no direction, and his story takes shape as a mystery of identity, as he wanders the city trying to reconcile himself to his memories and his peculiar urges. Above all itâ€™s the matter of his roots that haunts him: â€œHe was trying to reinvent an origin to bury so he could finally come into this thing he wanted to be.â€ù His deceased parents represent not only different cultures but the poles of science and faith: his father was an arrogant postdoctoral researcher for NASA who disparaged religion, his mother a devout Catholic who went around the bend after her husbandâ€™s death and would beat Black in front of an altar. But his father also had him wear a white dress as a young boy, to ward off a family curse, and Black carries a picture of himself so attired in a pouch strung around his neck. His wedding dress fixation has something to do with the undigested legacies of both parents, as does the fact that heâ€™s built a blimplike hideout for himself â€” his spaceship, he calls it â€” with an altar inside.,His art, meanwhile, engages questions of what is socially offensive. He covers one wall of Iggyâ€™s shop with racist and sexist jokes collected from public restrooms, interspersed with lines of poetry; he decorates the wall of Bomboyâ€™s business with a painting of a 50-foot Muslim woman, totally covered, strangling a dove with one hand and carrying an AK-47 in the other.,Abani likewise traffics in the outrageous when Bomboy wears a T-shirt with a picture of a lynching and the slogan â€œJust Hanging,â€ù or when a certain stripper is mentioned for her ability to shoot Ping- Pong balls out of her labia. But what heâ€™s really interested in are people on the margins, and he samples both Raymond Chandler â€” a dwarf waiter at Iggyâ€™s cafe named Ray-Ray parrots lines from â€œFarewell, My Lovelyâ€ù â€” and Diane Arbus, who is quoted in the epigraph. Abaniâ€™s Los Angeles is at turns desolate and luminous, showered with ash from distant brush fires, â€œa city constantly digesting its past and recycling itself into something new.â€ù This metropolis is one where unlikely-looking Virgins draw crowds, bullet-ridden bodies go unnoticed in swimming pools and unwanted dogs are tossed from cars off a bridge. Itâ€™s also a perpetual blank canvas, which Black loves because it allows him to be whatever he wants â€” if only he could figure out what that was.,Cross-dressing, sexual confusion and the melding (or meltdown?) of cultures also figured prominently in â€œGraceLand,â€ù and that book also tapped into the energy of its urban setting. Abaniâ€™s portrayal of Lagos was richer and more authoritative than his version of Los Angeles, however, and the chaotic third-world terrain could better accommodate his sudden shifts from misery to comedy to violence. The combination is jarring here: in one scene, Bomboy tells of having taken part in a massacre of Tutsi women and children in Rwanda; in another, heâ€™s scheming to sell call-to-prayer alarm clocks to Muslim countrymen back home. Black converses with a divine pigeon and tries to calm an erection with a bag of frozen peas; he also recalls watching his mother masturbate while she was dying of AIDS.,Just as Black combines racist jokes and lines from Wallace Stevens in a work entitled â€œAmerican Gothic â€” The Remix,â€ù so Abani imagines a place that is horrifying and tender and absurd in equal measure. But with its uneven tone and meandering story, the book doesnâ€™t quite hold together. The language veers from portentous to reportorial, and sometimes falls flat, as in a dull first-date scene between Black and Sweet Girl. As a result the final conflagration carries less impact than it might have.,Still, these are the missteps of an ambitious writer with an original perspective. In â€œThe Virgin of Flamesâ€ù he audaciously stakes his claim on a city not his own. And wisely, he doesnâ€™t so much try to reveal its hidden side as to give it a costume, or a paint job, of his own making.
column4: The Recycled City

column1: In daily life, obsessive, all-consuming, world-annihilating rage is not a healthy emotion, but for horror fiction itâ€™s motherâ€™s milk. In horror, very bad things have to happen to people â€” or, at the least, to impend ominously â€” and the perpetrators of those atrocities tend to be in extraordinarily foul moods, especially when, as in the case of ghosts and zombies, they have recently risen from the dead. They always wake up cranky.,It makes sense: having oneâ€™s eternal rest interrupted is bound to be annoying. But the sort of rude reawakening that occurs in horror stories isnâ€™t usually involuntary. The genreâ€™s dangerous deceased have more typically roused , from the Big Sleep by an unnatural act of will, which implies a degree of motivation that a normal, well-adjusted ex-person would be unable to muster. To bust out of the prison cell of death, whose doors arenâ€™t meant to be opened from the inside, a soul has to be mighty uneasy â€” angry as hell and prepared to do some serious damage.,A significant percentage of horror fiction, that is, consists of cosmic revenge fantasies, tales of wrath long nurtured and suddenly, catastrophically released. Some of the genreâ€™s venerable monster species, like vampires and werewolves, are colder-blooded than that â€” doing violence just because theyâ€™re hungry, and losing their tempers only when theyâ€™re thwarted â€” but in the books Iâ€™ve been reading lately most of the agents of destruction are entities that feel, as the English say, hard done by: bitter, resentful, victimized. We live in angry times, and the chip-on-the-shoulder surliness of horrorâ€™s current crop of supernatural avengers can seem disturbingly familiar.,But the level of real-world resonance in the genreâ€™s raging revenants varies widely. Itâ€™s pretty low, for example, in Joe Schreiberâ€™s first novel, , and John Saulâ€™s umpteenth, , in both of which the choleric chickens coming home to roost are the spirits of dead serial killers and multiple murderers.,In Saulâ€™s book, the aggregate lethal fury of Jack the Ripper, Ed Gein, Jeffrey Dahmer and Lizzie Borden is reanimated in a Wisconsin lakeside resort at high season. In Schreiberâ€™s shorter, livelier campfire tale, the mayhem is perpetrated by a fictional late-18th-century New England serial killer named Isaac Hamilton, who has managed to resurrect himself with some regularity for better than two centuries. These novels are constructed as efficient, relentless terror-,generating machines, and as such donâ€™t require (much less encourage) the reader to think about the sources of the florid homicidal rage they put on display. Thatâ€™s just as well, really. The grievances of narcissistic sociopaths, while impressively comprehensive, get old fast: narcissists are always aggrieved about ,By relying on evildoers whose nihilistic anger is almost unrecognizable as an actual human impulse, however, these writers miss a chance to unnerve their readers more profoundly. â€œIn the Dark of the Nightâ€ù toys with the provocative notion that the malign spirits of famous old murderers have some sort of mysterious allure for the middle-class, well-brought-up teenage boys who are its main characters. But in the end Saul prefers to transfer the bloodthirsty urges of the dead maniacs to an aging local maniac rather than to any of his young heroes, who snap out of their dark serial-killer enchantment before theyâ€™ve done anything that might raise a red flag on their college applications. To call this a failure of the novelistâ€™s nerve would be to understate the case. Itâ€™s infuriating to read a horror story that sets up a genuinely disturbing premise and then pulls back from its nastier implications. (We readers can get a little hot under the collar too.),Schreiber doesnâ€™t run the same risk because the wrath of his Isaac Hamilton is never presented as anything but alien, aberrant, utterly beyond the pale â€” nothing an ordinary person might feel sneakily attracted to, or find huddled in the dim, hard-to-get-at corners of his own miserable soul, which are the places horror fiction is supposed to illuminate. So â€œChasing the Deadâ€ù isnâ€™t disappointing in the way Saulâ€™s novel is â€” just frivolous, like a teen-market slasher picture.,Pure fear-mongering sensationalism has, of course, a perfectly honorable tradition in this genre, but these days it seems kind of beside the point. The problem with books and movies that traffic in what Coleridge called â€œmotiveless malignityâ€ù is that the malignities weâ€™re currently most afraid of are all overstuffed with motive, positively engorged with it. Everybodyâ€™s nursing a grudge; no act of violence comes without fervent self-justification; and rage with reasons â€” feeding on itself, gathering awful strength â€” is beginning to look like the fire that will consume the world.,In , the reliably apocalyptic Bentley Little imagines that sort of ferocious, score-settling historical anger as a network of trains that become â€œa single supernatural force capable of crisscrossing the nation in endless pursuit of vengeance.â€ù These trains, itâ€™s quickly apparent, have a political agenda: one plows into the White House and another into Mount Rushmore. Their passengers are â€œthe wronged, the massacred, the deadâ€ù â€” the spirits of the Chinese immigrants whose ill-paid labor built the transcontinental railroad.,Itâ€™s a well-chosen metaphor, and the fact that the vengeance being exacted is based on an unarguably legitimate beef gives â€œThe Burningâ€ù a nice edge of nervous ambivalence. The suspense of the narrative is actually less compelling than the suspense of the argument Little seems to be conducting with himself: heâ€™s trying to reconcile his respect for the exploited peopleâ€™s urge for retribution with the proper revulsion at the expired victimsâ€™ scorched-earth methods. Mixed into this steaming compost of self-doubt, I suspect, is a pinch of guilt on the writerâ€™s part about having perhaps discharged his genre obligations too vigorously: it is, after all, Little himself who dreamed up those terrible things for the dead Chinese to do and for the book â€” finally, dutifully â€” to condemn.,And some of the requisite horror effects do feel a bit arbitrary. Thereâ€™s a fuzzy black mold that turns people into racists, a pair of naked Chinese ghost nymphets who seduce a park ranger and a swarm of bees that arranges itself, for no earthly (or plausibly unearthly) reason, in the shape of George Washingtonâ€™s face. The book is a mess, a snarl of half-formed ideas, but at least it has ideas, and Little certainly canâ€™t be accused of failing to give rage its due. In a sense, his whole career â€” 16 previous novels and a short-story collection â€” has been an elaborate self-conducted anger management program, from which he has yet to graduate. â€œThe Burningâ€ù is just the latest in a series of Little novels in which boiling-mad victims of one social injustice or another set out to redress the wrongs done to them, and go way too far. And in all his books the writer appears to be working extremely hard to keep his sympathy for these angry devils from getting the better of him. In every novel, he maintains a running auto-critique, heckling himself like a drunken doppelgÃ_nger in the audience, with the invective intensifying noticeably as the act nears its conclusion.,At the big, wild climax of â€œThe Burningâ€ù â€” rather late in the game, youâ€™d imagine, for second thoughts â€” Little allows one of his characters to muse: â€œAs crazy as everything else was, the concept of a politically correct monster seemed the most ridiculous and hardest to believe.â€ù Little sounds ticked off at his own concept, steamed that his horror trains, with their cargo of righteous indignation, have somehow jumped the tracks. The fury of â€œThe Burningâ€ù is so deep, so anguished and so general that it refuses to spare even its author.,The most satisfying of the genreâ€™s recent rage extravaganzas, though, is Sarah Langanâ€™s first novel, , Like Little, Langan is interested in the release of pent-up anger from reasonable gripes: in this case, the source is the indignity visited, year after grinding year, on the residents of a fictional New England factory town.,The story begins a month after the closing of the Clott Paper Mill in Bedford, Me. The town â€” whatâ€™s left of it at the end of a decade or so of layoffs and wearying attempts to deny the writing on the wall â€” is depressed, uncertain, quietly panicky. Among the many unhealthy forms this collective unease takes, along with alcoholism, domestic abuse and a pervasive meanness of spirit, are shared nightmares, which focus on the most visibly wretched member of the community: a mute, disturbed, flagrantly promiscuous young woman named Susan Marley. While sheâ€™s alive, sheâ€™s the embodiment of her neighborsâ€™ fears for themselves â€” and when she dies, her hold on the sad, sick town becomes even more powerful. In death, Susan Marley comes into her own, and so, in an appropriately abandoned, self-immolating way, does Bedford.,â€œThe Keeperâ€ù â€” which is richly populated with small-town characters at varying stages of emotional crisis, from numb puzzlement to unshakable bitterness to abject despair â€” is as angry as any of the other novels Iâ€™ve been discussing, but itâ€™s the only horror story Iâ€™ve read recently that finds adequate metaphors for the self-destructive properties of anger.,â€œTheir rage at what had been done to them had no place to go but within,â€ù Langan writes of the people of Bedford, and you can feel it throughout â€œThe Keeper,â€ù growing like a cancer and debilitating the town until this entire complex social organism has no will but the will to merciful oblivion. And thatâ€™s when rage becomes truly horrifying: when everyone has forgotten how the poison got into the system and no one knows, or cares, how to get it out.
column4: Bitter Spirits

column1: Somewhere off the coast of Vietnam in the mid-15th century, in a stretch of cantankerous ocean where typhoons raged and pirates plied their trade, the Dragon Sea claimed a kitchen girl who cowered in the galley of a junk. The ship groaned and buckled, and as it sank the icy seawater thundered through the galley. Eventually â€œthe girlâ€™s struggles stopped. ... Life faded from her eyes as around her the water grew dark with depth.â€ù,Surely this girl, probably a domestic or a slave, had no claim to the porcelain that plummeted along with her to the floor of the sea. But she was the lost cargoâ€™s lone sentry until, nearly 500 years later, the treasure was salvaged by a marine archaeologist, Mensun Bound; a Malaysian businessman, Ong Soo Hin; and a multinational crew of 160 seamen, archaeological draftsmen, cooks and saturation divers.,Frank Pope, a protÃ©gÃ© of Boundâ€™s and the expeditionâ€™s archaeological manager, has written an engaging account that delves into the ethical conundrums of marine salvage, the deadly physics of the deep ocean and the roiling waters of professional subterfuge.,â€œDragon Seaâ€ù is laced with drama largely because of the conflicting motives of the expeditionâ€™s leading figures. Bound, the headstrong, sometimes prickly director of Oxford Universityâ€™s Maritime Archaeological Research and Excavation unit, advocates the purest methodology in the recovery and insists on adding to the historical record. Ong, whom Pope describes as a corner-cutting financier with a smash-and-grab track record in marine salvage, wants pay dirt. As Pope tells the story, Ong needed Boundâ€™s credibility to cut international red tape. Bound needed the funding Ong could bring and got in bed with market forces (a racy move for an academic). After all, Pope writes, â€œwrecks were fast disappearing at the hands of dredgers and cable-layers as well as treasure-hunters, while archaeologists stood by helplessly, lacking the funds to work.â€ù,The idea was to bring up the booty, conserve and analyze it properly, then auction off a part of it to pay for the excavation (and make a tidy profit). The rest would be preserved for museums and history.,They made their pact. And then lived to regret it.,Ho hum, you might think, as I initially did, at the thought of old, wet porcelain. But Popeâ€™s impassioned, detailed reporting draws us into the story of ceramics and Vietnam, a country that has spent much of its past in the shadow of China, but enjoyed a brief self-ruled â€œgolden ageâ€ù during which artistic and political independence flourished. A central question of the book becomes: Are these relics from that short renaissance in the mid-15th century? If so, theyâ€™d hold clues that could rewrite a part of history.,But the archaeological and historical mysteries are eclipsed by the physiological ones because saturation diving to retrieve ceramics entombed 230 feet underwater is a complex, expensive â€” and somewhat wacko â€” endeavor.,This high-stakes, high-risk job requires a breed that makes North Sea fishermen look like wussies. Talk about pressure. They work on the seabed in wet suits, tethered to the ship above by a life-sustaining umbilical cord. At the end of an exhausting 12-hour shift of moving debris through giant vacuums, and digging out and packing porcelain, as well as negotiating dark waters, site grates and instructions from above by those who are video-monitoring, they enter a cramped pressurized bell and are hauled shipboard. That bell is affixed to another small bell, where they stay until going underwater again 12 hours later. They never leave the bells, and thus never depressurize. For two months.,The hazards are many. An infinitesimal leak caused by a faulty seal or loose screw in a pressurized bell and theyâ€™re instantly, and dramatically, dead. Gas â€œexplodes from the chest, rupturing the lungs if it is unable to escape the throat. Gas bursts from the sinuses, ripping open the eardrums. Vapors trapped inside the bowels expand. ... Explosive decompression is not a pleasant way to die.â€ù,Toward the end, the book begins to fizzle. Popeâ€™s crack job of blending storms and tension, regional history, the gruff cast of characters â€” and even the occasional cliffhanger and red herring â€” creates expectations. Weâ€™re half-waiting for M.C.D., Massive Catastrophic Decompression, either literally or metaphorically. So when the climax is merely ill will, a dashed romance of treasure hunting and trust â€” not, thankfully, â€œPerfect Stormâ€ù-like tragedy â€” weâ€™re both relieved, and slightly guilty for wanting more.,More than 250,000 intact pots were successfully excavated from the seabed before an encroaching typhoon season brought the expedition to an undramatic close.,The bookâ€™s final message is an elegiac plea that the estimated three million wrecks still lying untouched in the worldâ€™s oceans be addressed with integrity. But weâ€™re not left with any real hope that that will be the case.,The Internet frenzy of 2000 figures into the porcelainâ€™s final chapter. Brushing aside traditional auctioneers like Sothebyâ€™s and Christieâ€™s, Ong tries to cash out via the sexy new player: eBay. A saturated market and botched auction saddled with fuzzy historical information (which enrages Bound) all contribute to a huge financial loss. Ong spent $14 million to recover the cargo and bring it to auction, and in the end the porcelain cleared just under $3 million.,Five years later, to complete the circle, and see the final act of consumerism colliding with historical significance, I logged on. Now itâ€™s a fire sale. For $55, plus $9 shipping and handling, I purchased a blue-and-white round ceramic box. Itâ€™s gorgeous, but I only want to slide it back into the ocean, and return it to the kitchen girl.
column4: What Lies Beneath

column1: WHEN night falls in New York or Paris, one goes clubbing or bar hopping. In a Texas park, the choices include bat detecting; in the Channel Islands of Britain, full-moon tidal treks; and in St. Louis, candlelight museum prowls.,More and more resorts, spas and tourist attractions are offering creative alternatives to dining and drinking the night away. Keyed to the science and mood of darkness, and inaugurated by activities like turtle-nesting watches in Costa Rica and guided stargazing in Hawaii, the new breed of night programs breaks from the mold of ghost-telling tours and pub crawls in nocturnal outings that range from novel to educational. Here are some of the latest offerings aimed at keeping you up at night.,The popularity of night-vision technology has lit up the recreational world, allowing scope-toting hikers to see nocturnal creatures and more stars than the naked eye allows. For instance, , combines two military-turned-civilian inventions in its night-vision-assisted drive through the Sonoran Desert near Scottsdale, Ariz., after dark. After issuing riders night-vision monoculars, guides wearing three-pound night-vision headsets drive an eight-mile desert trail without headlights, looking for coyote, bobcats, rattlesnakes and other critters. Ultra-violet lights on the desert floor illuminate tarantulas and scorpions, and guests pass around a thermal-image scope, allowing the eye to capture all warm-blooded creatures within 500 feet. Offered nightly, tours cost $125 for adults, $100 for those 6 to 16; (866) 374-8637; ,.,At the new Hyatt Regency Lost Pines Resort and Spa near Austin, Tex., guests explore the neighboring McKinney Roughs Nature Park in interpretive night hikes led by a naturalist. Guests share night-vision equipment to spy possums, armadillos and deer while a â€œbat detectorâ€ù picks up the echolocations of darting bats. Tours daily in summer, weekends the rest of the year; $12; (512) 308-1234; ,.,From 9 to 11 nightly, guests of Disney's Animal Kingdom Lodge in Orlando, Fla., can glimpse some of the resort savannah's 200 animals and birds. Guides lend night-vision glasses for looks at zebras, wildebeests and giraffes as close as 15 feet away; (407) 938-3000; ,.,As night-vision scopes are to adult adventures, flashlights are to children's programs. Zoos and aquariums around the country including the , in Florida (Pack Prowls: $20; 904-757-4463; ,) and , in Hawaii (Aquarium After Dark: $10; 808-923-9741; ,) offer special evening tours by flashlight. The , lets adults in on the action in an after-hours peek at snakes and reptiles in its St. Patrick's Day-themed Adventure Social complete with beer March 15 ($40; 615-833-1534; ,).,At , in Jackson Hole, Wyo., a resident naturalist, Kurt Johnson, leads on-property hikes to call for owls, playing recorded owl cries and noting any responses. Owl Hoots are offered as part of a summer astronomy program, free to guests twice weekly; (307) 733-8833; ,.,Nighttime walks in the Francis Beidler Forest, the world's largest virgin cypress-tupelo swamp forest, some 50 miles west of Charleston, S.C., venture into the eerie quiet of the 1,000-year-old woods. Trekkers follow a one-and-three-quarter-mile boardwalk over the swamp listening for owls and otters and, with flashlights, spot alligator eyes and spider nests. Night walks, $8, are held monthly; (843) 462-2150; ,.,Taking a cue from night scuba dives, snorkelers too can witness the nocturnal action on the oceans' reefs. Squid, moray eels and Caribbean lobsters emerge after dark on the reefs around St. Thomas in the United States Virgin Islands where the guide, Homer Calloway of Homer's Scuba and Snorkel Tours, supplies mask, fins, wet suit and underwater flashlight. Tours Tuesday to Saturday, $38; (866) 719-1856; ,. The Sheraton Keauhou on Hawaii's Big Island offers nighttime snorkeling and diving trips to the manta ray feeding grounds just offshore, setting up lights on the ocean floor. Tours Monday through Friday, $79 adults, $59 ages 4 to 12; (808) 930-4900; ,.,Guests at the new Anantara Resort Maldives, opened in September on a five-acre island in the South Male Atoll, can shove off at sunset to fish from an indigenous dhoni sailboat, trailing local tackle â€” that is, a baited hook on a fishing line. The catch is wok-fried by the chef back at the resort. Two-hour fishing outings take place three times a week for $49 a person; (66) 2877-5803; ,.,Cycling in the dark at the Boulders Resort in Carefree, Ariz., is far less suicidal than in urban traffic. Led by a guide and supplied with a 15-watt light, bike and helmet, riders follow the halogen-lighted paved golf-cart paths, looking for coyotes and hares and stopping for a bit of stargazing. The 90-minute tours cost $95; (866) 397-6520; ,.,Where downhill skiers have slopes illuminated by flood lamps  to boost their vertical mileage, snowshoers and cross-country skiers rely on moonshine. The Mammoth Mountain ski resort in California organizes full-moon snowshoeing and cross-country skiing at its Tamarack Cross Country Ski Center in the company of a naturalist. The tours, which cost $35, conclude with dessert by the lodge's fireplace and are held on six dates January through March; (800) 626-6684; ,.,Moonlight massages promise relaxation under the stars for couples in a candlelit poolside spot at Peninsula Spa in the ,. Cost is $350; 310-551-2888; ,. During candlelight watsu at ,'s Sanctuary Spa in Paradise Valley, Ariz., votives ring the heated, outdoor pool encircled by walls that frame the stars above. Winter only; from $135; (480) 948-2100; ,.,Come full moons, the tides on the British Channel Island of Jersey recede up to two miles. During these events, most dramatic at the spring and autumn equinox, Derek Hairon, a guide with Jersey Kayak Adventures, offers â€œmoonwalks,â€ù two-and-a-half-hour night hikes on the lunarlike, drained ocean bed. The cost is  Â£12 ($24 at $2 to the pound); (44-1534) 853033; ,.,While beating the summer desert heat, two-hour night tours of ,, the seasonal home and studio of Frank Lloyd Wright, offer the beauty of viewing Wright's organic buildings lighted from within like lanterns arrayed on the 600-acre campus. Last year the organization expanded from Fridays only to also include Thursdays from March through September. Tours cost $30; (480) 860-2700; ,.,On Friday and Saturday nights, the innovative City Museum in St. Louis, an artist-designed children's museum that appeals to all ages, fills the subterranean and vertical climbing tunnels with candles placed strategically in the mouths of relief sculptures of gargoyles and dragons. Admission is $8 after 5 p.m. and the museum stays open until 1 a.m. for night prowls; (314) 231-2489; ,.,At Conner Prairie, a living history museum near Indianapolis, participants are offered the disturbing experience of acting as fugitive slaves following the Underground Railroad, encountering re-enacted slave sales and slave hunts in the dark of night. Offered weekends in April and November, the often-harrowing event is limited to participants over the age of 12. Cost is $16; (317) 776-6006; ,.,This winter the Museum of Neon Art in Los Angeles begins its Poet's Beat Neon Tour featuring the spoken-word performer Mike Sonksen on a drive through the neon corridor of illuminated bowling pins, a bakery and theater marquees from downtown to Hollywood. En route the bus stops at three bars with admirable neon outdoors and libations within. The monthly winter itinerary supplements the Saturday night Neon Cruises held by the museum weekly June through October in an open-air double-decker bus. Poet's cruise, $25; neon cruise, $45; (213) 489-9918, ,.,Miniaturizing the drive-in to living-room level, ,, a Rosewood Resort in Los Cabos, Mexico, newly offers guests private movie screenings on the beach at night. Guests get their own private serape-topped beach lounge chairs, 50-inch plasma TVs, a 219-title DVD selection and â€œcinema butlersâ€ù to fetch lime-chili-cilantro popcorn, guacamole and drinks. Thursday evening screenings are $250 a couple; (888) 767-3966; ,.
column4: Itâ€™s Night. Shall We Snorkel, Cycle or Hike?

column1: There are all sorts of books about lions. Accounts of lions who come to stay are always popular, as Joy Adamson discovered when she wrote â€œBorn Freeâ€ù and its sequels. These books succeed because the idea of sharing oneâ€™s life with such a creature is, at some deep level, very appealing. Then there is writing in which lion imagery is used to make a point about the human rather than the leonine situation. In such a context, the lion is symbolic of vigor, of the masculine, of the untamable. Indeed, so burdened are lions with symbolism that itâ€™s surprising they manage to stagger even a few paces, let alone spring at their prey.,I came to â€œA Tale of Two Lions,â€ù by the Mexican writer Roberto Ransom (translated by Jasper Reid, son of the well-known Scottish essayist and translator Alastair Reid), in a mood of enthusiastic anticipation, being well-disposed toward lions and their literary depiction. Ever since I read Russell Hobanâ€™s remarkable â€œLion of Boaz-Jachin and Jachin-Boazâ€ù some years ago, I have been looking for another piece of leonine magic realism.,Lion books need not be long, but they do need meat. And while Ransomâ€™s book is charming, it is perhaps a bit too brief to explore its theme of lions lost and found. Two main stories are brought together, to an extent, in a third, but â€œA Tale of Two Lionsâ€ù is really just one long short story, or a shortish novella. The Thurberesque drawings that punctuate the book donâ€™t add a great deal to a story that, on its own, is perfectly engaging. There might also have been fewer pages of preliminaries, one of which bears a single sentence reminding us of the line used in old maps to fill unknown spaces: â€œHere there are lions.â€ù (Perhaps this is a warning about the virtually blank pages weâ€™ll encounter later on?),The first story takes the epistolary form and concerns a lion â€” small enough to pass for a cat, but leonine in its exuberant habits â€” that travels in an aircraft from Italy to the United States and then goes missing. In the next story, we are in a museum where a lion on display suddenly leaps out of an exhibit. (This is a lovely idea, and the relationship between the museum attendant and the lion is poignantly described.) Finally, we find ourselves in a circus, where the two lions meet. The first lion, Cattino, speaks Italian (a nice conceit), but all too soon both animals disappear. We are left wondering just who was who.,Itâ€™s all very whimsical, but that, of course, is what a picaresque novel can be. Ransomâ€™s lions are elusive, and deliberately so: we see them, and then they appear to be something else; they are gone, yet they are somehow within us. Itâ€™s like a half-remembered dream â€” or an unexpected sighting of a real lion in the bush.
column4: Big Cats

column1: In the late 1940s and early 1950s, broadcasting experts predicted that the advent of television would kill off radio. Many of them didnâ€™t especially want it to survive, since it could only hold back the acceptance of TV. In fact, the radio those experts knew didnâ€™t survive. By the mid-1950s, the national networks that had dominated since the â€™20s had all but evaporated, replaced by more than twice as many local stations. Television took over presenting broadcast drama and comedy, variety shows and in-depth news.,Yet radio itself survived. Radio outstrips television as a means of conveying intimacy and, precisely because it doesnâ€™t show but can only tell, may stir the active imagination more deeply. Itâ€™s cheaper to operate a radio station, and in those years broadcasting equipment was much more mobile, making it perfect for local presentations. With recorded music (before the advent of TV, most radio programming consisted of live performance), stations found a cheap programming source that attracted enough listeners to generate its lifeblood â€” advertising revenue â€” even after TV took hold.,In â€œSomething in the Air,â€ù Marc Fisher takes the story from there, arguing that radio â€” those who programmed and performed on it, and the music they played â€” inspired his entire generation to come together: â€œWe grew up dancing and dreaming to the same soundtrack, and we were therefore somehow united,â€ù he writes. â€œUntil the Great Unraveling of the late 1960s and early â€™70s, this shared pop culture was a meeting ground for our nation, a commons that we only years later realized we had lost.â€ù,But Fisher canâ€™t deliver on this premise, because it simply isnâ€™t true. Different groups of people experienced that period differently, and they listened to radio differently too. The kids in Fisherâ€™s neighborhood, and mine, spent 1963 listening to the Chiffons and Motown and were led to dream of a better world. The black kids in Birmingham, Ala., spent part of that year listening to local radio not only for those hit records but for coded messages about where to gather for illegal demonstrations that concretely changed their world for the better. Those are not equivalent experiences.,But most of â€œSomething in the Airâ€ù isnâ€™t concerned with its broad premise, and therein lies the bookâ€™s value. It provides a history of the development of radio in the postwar era, but it works best when it backs away from the general and settles upon particular broadcasters who fascinate Fisher. He writes engagingly about the late-night giants Jean Shepherd and Bob Fass, the shock jock Tom Leykis, the National Public Radio co-founder Bill Siemering, the Long Island radio rebel Paul Sidney and the white R & B disc jockey Hunter Hancock.,There are reasons to quarrel with the history. Fisher likes to settle on a single source for each section, which would be fine if heâ€™d written a collection of profiles rather than a book billed as a comprehensive historical survey. Giving a history of Top 40 radio with only a single paragraph about the programmer Bill Drake (inventor of the hyperkinetic â€œBoss Radioâ€ù) is like writing a history of hit singles with only a single paragraph about Phil Spector. Writing about New York City radioâ€™s response to the arrival of the Beatles through the eyes of WABCâ€™s Bruce Morrow, without even mentioning â€œthe Fifth Beatle,â€ù WMCAâ€™s Murray the K, is just bizarre.,In his chapter on satellite radio, Fisher grows so fixed on the programmer Lee Abrams of XM that the rival Sirius network all but vanishes. (Disclosure: I am the host of a show on Sirius.) The chapter on shock jocks focuses so completely on Leykis that the portions on the much more important Rush Limbaugh and Howard Stern (who gets only three pages) feel like intrusion.,Fisher has little to say about anything that happened outside the East Coast. B. Mitchell Reed, the great Los Angeles disc jockey who inspired Joni Mitchellâ€™s â€œYou Turn Me On, Iâ€™m a Radio,â€ù is mentioned only briefly, for his work in San Francisco. Thereâ€™s nothing about CKLW, in Windsor, Ontario, which was the No. 1 station in both Detroit and Cleveland for more than a decade. Wolfman Jack is mentioned for his role in â€œAmerican Graffitiâ€ù and his brief dalliance with WNBC in New York, but there is only a passing acknowledgment of his long career in Mexican border radio, which could be heard from San Antonio to Buffalo. Fisher adores late-night radio, but he says nothing about the legendary John R. and Hoss Allen of WLAC Nashville, who also had an audience across broad swaths of the nation.,Fisher describes how disco divided the rock radio audience and galvanized black and Latin listeners, who had been written off by FM rock radio, though he writes about such matters superficially. He claims that black disc jockeys simply â€œmimicked Top 40â€™s style,â€ù which I presume means he never heard Martha Jean the Queen, Butterball, Georgie Woods, the Magnificent Montague or, for that matter, the young Sly Stone. If anything, the mimicry ran in the other direction. Readers will finish â€œSomething in the Airâ€ù with no insight into how Spanish-language disc jockeys played the key role in delivering hundreds of thousands of immigration-rights supporters into the streets of Los Angeles and other cities last year, because Fisher says absolutely nothing about Latin radio in general and its crucial role in the Chicano community in particular. Turning out those demonstrators was a much greater accomplishment than the â€œRush Roomsâ€ù that sprang up in restaurants across the nation in Limbaughâ€™s heyday, which Fisher does mention.,Fisher provides a good deal of useful information about satellite and Internet broadcasting, and there are solid discussions of the consequences of the Federal Communications Commissionâ€™s laissez-faire policy toward fairness and community service and on the Clinton administrationâ€™s successful efforts to change the rules that prevented large corporations from owning large blocks of stations. He writes a devastating account of one of the focus groups that many big-city stations use to pick their playlists, arguing that such questionable research (each recording is judged by a seven-second sample) leads to unimaginative programming. He also has the courage to defend payola: â€œDespite the ugly underside of the promotion business,â€ù he writes, â€œthe old payola had a desirable result: a wider variety of music got on the air.â€ù,The problem, in the end, is the vastness and mutability of the radio culture that developed in the half-century since TV took over as the family hearth. Fisherâ€™s book is at its best when he lets himself speak about passions that are almost but not quite private: the importance of his first transistor radio; the way that radio and its successors blew musical winds of change into his life; the near magical effect of listening to someone who is committed not to playing good music or making political points but simply making good radio, whatever form it may take. In such moments, readers will find that they and Fisher have much to share â€” not as a generation, but simply as lovers of a medium that, however scorned and abused, retains its fascination.
column4: Radio Days

column1: When Thomas Hardy drew his first chancy breaths inside a Dorset cottage in 1840, Wordsworth had yet to become Englandâ€™s poet laureate. By his ninth decade, still writing, Hardy enjoyed listening to the wireless with his dog, Wessex, and had seen the silent-film adaptation of his own â€œTess of the Dâ€™Urbervilles.â€ù The authorâ€™s life span seems somehow even vaster than it was, a match for the cosmically long view Hardy took of his fictional characters, fateâ€™s playthings set in motion on a â€œblighted star.â€ù,His mother, Jemima, is described by Claire Tomalin in this excellent new biography as having been â€œpowerful, rather than tender,â€ù with a â€œdark streak of gloom and anger.â€ù A literate, book-hungry servant, Jemima had been exposed briefly to London life before her shotgun wedding to Hardyâ€™s father, a rural builder who proved, like his wife, a conscientious parent to their clever, undersize son, whom they provided with a nonconformist education and then apprenticed to an architect.,Much of Hardyâ€™s work in that early position derived from Englandâ€™s 19th-century vogue for â€œindiscriminate church restoration,â€ù an ahistorical endeavor he came to regret. From religion itself he never fell fully away, Tomalin argues. In the midst of his later meditations on the universeâ€™s blind cruelty, he â€œcherished the memory of belief,â€ù as if it were an original stone church underneath all the neo-Gothic gimcrackery.,Lucky enough to secure a place with Arthur Blomfield, â€œone of the most successful architects in London,â€ù Hardy nonetheless began seriously to pursue his ambition of becoming a novelist. Finding something to say about the manners, economics and morality of his society was hard enough work; convincing himself that he had the right to say it â€” at a time when his lack of property meant he was not entitled to vote â€” must have been an even taller order. Class was the vise in which he lived his early life, and Tomalin makes her readers feel the squeeze, as Hardy manages his slow rise into the middle class and then toward the upper echelons of authorship.,This new biography makes its subject a fascinating case study in mid-Victorian literary sociology. Hardy struggles â€” with an industriousness befitting the age â€” against editorial rejection, rapacious contract terms and enforced prudery. Leslie Stephen, known chiefly to the 21st century as Virginia Woolfâ€™s father, edited his magazine, The Cornhill, under the watchful, prissy eyes of so many others that he sometimes made â€œfew suggestions beyond bowdlerizationsâ€ù when working on Hardyâ€™s copy. Serialization often forced the author â€œto pack in far too much plotâ€ù and thereby throw novels like â€œThe Mayor of Casterbridgeâ€ù significantly off-kilter. Finally, there were reviewers to contend with; Hardy remained overly sensitive to all they had to say.,Tomalin herself examines the novels with the confident judgments of a critic, not the hedged and sometimes overawed appraisals of a scholar.
