Clarke, a Brooklyn Democrat who resigned from the City Council after she was elected to Congress in November, endorsed Mathieu Eugene yesterday to succeed her on the Council. column1: A 53-year-old man was found dead yesterday morning in his small room inside a nine-story building run by a nonprofit group in Morrisania, the police said. The man, whom the authorities did not identify, was killed by blunt trauma to the torso, the police said. The killing occurred shortly before 4 a.m. at a building, known as Webster House, at 1075 Webster Avenue, the police said.  The building is run by the  group, Volunteers of America, under an agreement with the city. Residents  said the man, who  they said was named Thomas and was also known as Mac, was found lying with the door to his room open. â€œI heard rumbling and fighting,â€ù said Umberto Sanchez, who lives in a nearby room. A spokeswoman for Volunteers of America referred calls to the cityâ€™s Department of Homeless Services. Nobody at that agency could be reached yesterday.
column4: Bronx: Man Found Dead in Room

column1: Of the 2,114 sex offenders who live in New York City and are listed in the stateâ€™s publicly available database, 85 percent live within five blocks of a school and 32 percent within two blocks of a school, according to a report released yesterday by Representative Anthony D. Weiner, a Democrat who represents parts of Queens and Brooklyn. Mr. Weinerâ€™s staff used mapping software to analyze records from the database, which was expanded in July and lists Level 2 and Level 3 sex offenders, who must register for life. (Sex offenders are assigned a risk level from 1 to 3 based on  the nature of the crime, the victimâ€™s age and an offenderâ€™s prior record.) Though there is no law that restricts where a  sex offender may live, Mr. Weiner has pushed for action. In addition to seeking  federal aid to study and monitor sex offenders, Mr. Weiner called for requiring offenders to notify the  authorities if they have  profiles   on social-networking Web sites like MySpace, and if they live near schools, to submit to monitoring using global positioning satellite technology.
column4: Manhattan: Sex Offenders Study

column1: â€” It was â€œthe golden age of foreign correspondents,â€ù  the historian Hugh Thomas wrote, a period in the late 1930s when the literary elite descended on , armed with a lust for adventure and belief in a cause.,The lure was the Spanish Civil War. In February 1936 Spanish voters elected, by a small plurality, a center-left coalition of Socialists, Communists, Republicans and Anarchists. Then in July, Gen. Francisco Franco led an uprising against the five-year-old Spanish Republic that plunged the country into civil war.,Mussolini and Hitler supported Franco, while Stalin sent advisers and arms to his opponents. The United States, Britain and France sat on the sidelines.,The writers and foreign correspondents who came to Spain invented a new kind of war journalism, reporting in first-person, eyewitness accounts the brutal feel of the battlefield.,Their two-and-a-half-year chronicle became something more, an intimate encounter with the great ideological battles of the time: between church and state; rich and poor; the aristocracy and the classless; democracy and fascism.,A traveling exhibition organized for the inauguration of the new headquarters of the Cervantes Institute in Madrid commemorates that journalism with original news clippings from publications as different as Esquire and Pravda. Titled â€œCorrespondents in the Spanish Civil War 1936-1939,â€ù it is part of a vast soul-searching throughout Spain over  the terror of the 1936 uprising and civil war that brought General Franco to power and kept his dictatorship in place until his death in 1975. The exhibition, which runs until Feb. 25 in Madrid, was shown last year at the instituteâ€™s New York offices and in Lisbon. It will travel next to three cities in France, two cities in Poland and one each in Stockholm and Moscow.,â€œThe best writers came to tell the world what was happening in Spain,â€ù said the exhibitionâ€™s curator, Carlos Garcia Santa Cecilia, a former journalist. â€œThey felt a compulsion to be here, to bear witness, to fight for their beliefs. It was the first time journalists said, â€˜I must write what I see, what I feel.â€™ â€ù,The aviator and author Antoine de Saint-ExupÃ©ry flew in on his own plane. George Orwell took his pen to the battlefield and nearly died when he was shot through the neck. Arthur Koestler was locked up by Franco supporters.,Kim Philby, The Times of London correspondent, was already a Soviet agent gathering information under the cover of his job as a reporter. Ernest Hemingway posed for one report for The New Republic holding a rifle while lying on the battlefield.,In recent years Spain has begun to shake off the collective amnesia that had gripped it since Francoâ€™s death. Books, exhibitions, documentaries, television series and films have given stark, eloquent testimony to the Francoâ€™s silent victims.,A project to locate and dig up the hundreds of mass graves left by the firing squads of Franco rule is actively under way. Parliament is locked in a contentious debate over legislation to recognize the suffering of the victims.,The exhibition captures the power of the written word in telling the stories. â€œThis is the most painful story it has ever been my lot to handle,â€ù The Chicago Tribuneâ€™s Jay Allen wrote at the start of his report on the massacre in Badajoz in August 1936. â€œI write it at four in the morning, sick at heart and in body in the stinking patio of the pension central.â€ù,Badajoz was one of the first big towns to fall to Francoâ€™s offensive from the south, and Mr. Allen managed to find an alternate way to send his story after it was blocked by government censor. â€œThey are burning bodies,â€ù he wrote. â€œFour thousand men and women have died at Badajoz since Gen. Francisco Francoâ€™s rebel Foreign Legionnaires and Moors climbed over the bodies of their own dead through its many times blood-drenched walls.â€ù,A two-page exclusive interview with Franco by Felix Correia for Diario de Lisboa, in Portugal, in August 1936, a month after the civil war began, revealed the rebel leaderâ€™s plans for a dictatorship that would protect the Roman Catholic Church and private property.,In her dispatches Barbro  Alving, a Swedish foreign correspondent known as Bang, described how schools and hospitals struggled to stay open during the war. Martha Gellhorn, Hemingwayâ€™s lover and his future (third) wife, chronicled daily life in Madrid in a four-page article in Collierâ€™s in 1937 that established her as a serious journalist.,Not all the correspondents took the Republican side. Harold Cardozo of The Daily Mail, a Franco supporter, traveled with him.,Three journalists â€” Edward J. Neil of The Associated Press, Richard Sheepshanks of Reuters and Bradish Johnson of Newsweek â€” died near Teruel in northern Spain after their car was hit by Republican fire while they tried to report from Francoâ€™s side. Mr. Philby, who was also in the car, survived. Franco gave him a medal.,In a two-part series headlined â€œSpilling the Spanish Beansâ€ù in The New English Weekly in July 1937, Orwell laid bare the divide among anti-Franco republicans between the workers he defines as true revolutionaries and the counterrevolutionary Communists he accused of selling out to â€œbourgeois reformism.â€ù,His complex, often ambiguous analysis won him the vitriol of both the left and the right. It also formed the basis for his book â€œHomage to Catalonia,â€ù in which he wrote, â€œAs for the newspaper talk about this being a â€˜war for democracy,â€™ it was plain eyewash.â€ù,Langston Hughes, the American poet, playwright and novelist, came  to Spain â€œto write for the colored press,â€ù he wrote in The Afro American newspaper. â€œI knew that Spain had once belonged to the Moors, a colored people ranging from light dark to dark white.â€ù He described the importation of Moorish soldiers from Spanish Morocco and their slaughter on the front lines on the side of the Franco offensive.,The exhibition captures the high-stakes international diplomacy of the war. The German aerial bombing that destroyed the Basque village of Guernica in 1937 was the worst atrocity of the war, the first blitzkrieg; it also may have been the most sensitive military operation.,The Times of London buried George L. Steerâ€™s powerful eyewitness account â€” alerting the world that Hitler was helping the Spanish Fascists â€” in a single column on Page 17; The New York Times ran it at the top of the front page. â€œBritain didnâ€™t want to upset the Germans,â€ù Mr. Garcia Santa Cecilia said.,Most of the journalists took refuge in Madrid at  the  Hotel Florida, which was shelled regularly. It is now the site of a department store.,John Dos Passos wrote an article  for Esquire in 1938 from there, â€œRoom and Bath at the Hotel Florida,â€ù that included the line â€œWhen the shells keep coming in, a man somehow feels safer to be shaving and sniffing the familiar odor of the soap.â€ù,It was here that Hemingway, whose connections with both the Spanish government and the Russians kept him stocked with food and brandy, would have breakfast prepared for him every morning. It was also here that he romanced Ms. Gellhorn.,â€œThere was not one journalist in Spain who spoke well of Hemingwayâ€ù  Mr. Garcia Santa Cecilia said. â€œHe betrayed his friends. He was arrogant. He hoarded food. He was the only one with a car â€” and gasoline.â€ù,The hotel was close to the Telefonica building, where journalists had to submit their articles to an official censor before dictating them back home. The exhibition has reconstructed the operatorâ€™s desk, with one telephone headset for the journalist and another one for the censor.,It took 18 months to locate the photographs and articles â€” most of them originals â€” for the exhibition. Along the way the researchers tracked down Geoffrey Cox, who was then 26 covering local news when The  News Chronicle of Britain sent him to Madrid. He is now 96 and living in a British nursing home.,â€œI had no doubt that I was reporting on an event of capital historical importance,â€ù  Mr. Cox said in an interview included in the exhibition catalog. â€œFor the first time a force rising from the people was capable of resisting fascism.â€ù,Spain, he added, â€œwas our story.â€ù
column4: When Reporters Chose Sides: Spain Looks Back at Its Civil War

column1: Warning: Your reading of this newspaper may be hazardous to someoneâ€™s health. (Donâ€™t worry â€” not yours.) Equally fraught with danger is the casual reach for that morning coffee, the purchase of a new pashmina, a night out at the theater.,In â€œThe Fever,â€ù his corrosive exercise in theatrical conscience-baiting, , argues that virtually every transaction undertaken by an American city-dweller rests on a sturdy foundation of moral turpitude. Going about our everyday business â€” hailing a taxi, scoring a reservation at a hot restaurant, taking a nice write-off for a donation to the opera â€” we are condemning unseen victims in violence-ridden third world countries to lives of want and suffering.,So put down that venti latte, for heavenâ€™s sake.,Mr. Shawn previously performed this 90-minute monologue in private readings, beginning in 1990. Although it later moved on to less exclusive runs at various theaters in New York and abroad, â€œThe Feverâ€ù essentially and inevitably became a high-end cultural product in its own right, much as Mr. Shawnâ€™s similarly themed â€œDesignated Mournerâ€ù did a decade later in London and New York.,Mr. Shawn has amusingly chosen to acknowledge this paradox in the new production that opened last night at the Acorn Theater, directed by Scott Elliott for the New Group. The evening begins with a Champagne reception (Pommery, no less) held on the stage a half-hour before showtime. Mr. Shawn can be seen mingling with hoi polloi, the dome of his bald head bobbing genially as he exchanges chitchat with audience members. (At the reviewed performance, not-so-hoi polloi gathering onstage included the novelist William Kennedy, the playwright Tina Howe and the actor Ethan Hawke.),Think twice before you reach for that flute, however, since Mr. Shawnâ€™s aim is to make you regret every sip by inducing a bout of moral indigestion. â€œThe Feverâ€ù offers an intimate tour of the tortured consciousness of an angst-ridden, well-to-do American, but Mr. Shawnâ€™s real goal is to hold an unflattering mirror up to his well-meaning, liberally inclined audience. Itâ€™s sort of like Joseph Conradâ€™s â€œHeart of Darkness,â€ù with you, dear viewer, cast in the distasteful role of Kurtz.,But Mr. Shawnâ€™s literary models are more likely Kafka and Dostoyevsky, and at its best, â€œThe Feverâ€ù does achieve the hypnotic force of those explorers of the uncanny. The hallucinatory narrative circles back to a traumatic night spent in a hotel room in an unnamed country riven by civil war. Racked with fever, the narrator replays in his mindâ€™s eye a disturbing reel of memories from his past life. Shivering on the floor of the bathroom, as scary bugs crawl around him, he is drawn into an anguished recognition of the interior drives â€” and the brutal economic order â€” that have supported his obliviously contented, guilt-free existence. His diagnosis: a severe case of self-interest abetted by self-justification, with a smidgen of self-delusion  on top.,Mr. Shawn recounts this tale from a cozy berth in a comfortable armchair, a setting that neatly telegraphs the ultimate destination of this moral adventurer. He is framed by a truncated slice of a handsome apartment (the set is by Derek McLane), and as the monologue shifts tones, from aggrieved to inquisitive to angered, Jennifer Tiptonâ€™s lighting moves across its own spectrum, from stark to shadowy to cozy. Mr. Shawnâ€™s distinctive voice â€” it is as if a clogged sinus is speaking directly to us â€” also ranges in tone, from soft, babyish lament to a choked cry of outrage.,For the narrator of â€œThe Feverâ€ù doesnâ€™t travel a smooth path from benighted indifference to human suffering toward committed engagement in fighting the good fights. He eventually shifts from spasms of contrition for his part in the worldâ€™s injustices to coolly logical arguments for maintaining the status quo. Regarding the violence and squalor of the countries he visits, he wavers between sympathy and discomfort, compassion and repulsion.,The strength of â€œThe Feverâ€ù lies in the slippery grasp the narrator has on his own convictions, as Mr. Shawn captures with impish wit the tortuous reasoning of a mind trying to find its way back to acceptance of a state of affairs  it has discovered to be morally untenable. Mr. Shawn exposes the contradictions and compromises of the urban liberal mind with a mercilessness that is sly and at times hilarious.,Despite the density and richness of its language, however, â€œThe Feverâ€ù doesnâ€™t go very deep in its analysis of the fundamental causes of the worldâ€™s inequities or posit any rational ideas about how they could be eased. Mr. Shawn is limited by the scope of the narratorâ€™s experience, of course â€” an economist or political scientist he is not â€” but  the resulting narrative   circles around a few basic conclusions that seem thinner and more obvious the more they are illustrated or simply repeated.,â€œMy feeling in my heart a sympathy for the poor does not change the life of the poor,â€ù our narrator unsurprisingly says toward the playâ€™s conclusion. At least Mr. Shawn displays a self-knowledge to match his narratorâ€™s when he has him continue, â€œAnd artists who create works of art that inspire sympathy and good values donâ€™t change the life of the poor.â€ù,The playâ€™s damning conclusion â€” that only blood spilled on their doorsteps will bring the complacent rich to change their selfish ways â€” allows no wiggle room for incremental but steady progress in alleviating the worldâ€™s grievous economic imbalances. Its simple finger-pointing at the egoism and materialism of the complacent bourgeoisie seems reductive.,More to the point, I think Mr. Shawn overestimates his audienceâ€™s taste for self-flagellation by a good half-hour. â€œThe Feverâ€ù would cut deeper into the consciousness if it were shorter. He should know that a 90-minute monologue gives too much rein for straying thoughts about dinner plans and how best to catch a taxi after the performance.,And perhaps â€” who knows? â€” a few audience members might put that half-hour to better use, studying or working for gradual improvements in the lives of others rather than lamenting their own egoism over glasses of Champagne.,By ,; directed by Scott Elliott; sets by Derek McLane; costumes by Eric Becker; lighting by Jennifer Tipton; sound by Bruce Odland; production supervisor, Peter R. Feuchtwanger/PRF Productions; production stage manager, Valerie A. Peterson; managing producer, Barrack Evans; associate artistic director, Ian Morgan. Presented by the New Group, Mr. Elliott, artistic director; Geoff Rich, executive director. At the New Group at Theater Row, Acorn Theater, 410 West 42nd Street, Clinton, (212) 279-4200. Through March 3. Running time: 1 hour  30 minutes.,WITH: Wallace Shawn (the Traveler).
column4: The Worldâ€™s a Mess, and Itâ€™s All Your Fault

column1: Rent-to-own stores charge exorbitant prices for televisions, appliances, mattresses and other items and disproportionately take aim at black, Hispanic and low-income consumers who have limited access to credit, according to an investigative report that the City Council released yesterday. A 1986 state law exempted rent-to-own companies from small-loan usury caps; and under the law, because the stores retain legal title to rented items until  the final payment is made, the product can be repossessed if a payment is missed. Senator Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat of New York, introduced a bill in Congress last year that would force the industry to disclose more information about prices and hidden fees, and to abide by state limits on interest and financing charges. Assemblyman J. Gary Pretlow, a Westchester Democrat, introduced a similar bill last year in the Legislature. The  Council members who released the report â€” Maria del Carmen Arroyo of the Bronx and Leroy G. Comrie and Eric N. Gioia of Queens â€” said they supported both bills. Officials at Rent-A-Center of Plano, Tex., the countryâ€™s leading rent-to-own operator, did not respond to e-mail and phone messages requesting comment.
column4: Manhattan: Rent-to-own Stores

column1: For all that hotels have done to make their bedding more luxurious, their dÃ©cor more stylish and their lobbies smell better with a signature scent, one area that hasnâ€™t gotten much of a makeover is the in-suite dining experience, otherwise known as room service.,Certainly, hotels have tweaked their menus to keep up with changing dietary trends, offering low-fat, low-cholesterol or Atkins-friendly options as the weight-loss winds have shifted. And some high-end hotels deliver food  from a fancy restaurant on site, like the Trump International Hotel and Tower in New York, which lets guests enjoy meals from Jean-Georges and will even send a chef to cook in your in-suite kitchen (for an extra $75 an hour).,But at the hotels where most business travelers stay, room service has not gotten the kind of attention that has been lavished on  fancy spas and high-thread-count linens  â€”  at least not yet.,That may be about to change, as more hotels focus on their food and beverage services, with an eye toward keeping up with their guestsâ€™ increasingly sophisticated palates, nonstop work schedules  and desire for healthful meals.,For instance, Loews Hotels plans to eliminate artificial trans fats from its restaurants, room service menus and minibars by June, replacing deep-fried snacks with  PowerBars and other options. Westin Hotels and Resorts has been testing a Travelersâ€™ Renewal Menu in 20 properties that includes a smoothie to combat jet lag, oatmeal cookies and warm milk to ward off insomnia and a â€œHavana treat plateâ€ù  â€”  bananas, rice, applesauce and toast  â€”  to calm an upset stomach.,Marriott Hotels and Resorts, which has offered health-conscious â€œFit for Youâ€ù options for several years, promises to â€œrevolutionizeâ€ù in-room dining with improvements  this year that will  include new menu items that are consistent across its hotels, more regional specialties and, potentially, meals that are packaged to go, like a breakfast that can be eaten on a plane.,â€œFor many years, room service was looked at as, â€˜Gee we have to do it,â€™ but now I think more hotels are looking at it as, â€˜How can we solve our customersâ€™ problems?â€™ â€ù said Michael Beam, managing director at HVS/American Hospitality Management, a consulting firm that spent several months last year researching travelersâ€™ room service preferences.,Among the findings: people who travel 10 to 15 days a month order room service the most, and cravings are the No. 1  criteria when  they select from the menu â€” the research found hamburgers to be among the top choices â€” followed by healthfulness. But the latter category does not mean a preference for bland tofu stir-fry or poached salmon.,â€œIf anything, itâ€™s a move away from traditional â€˜healthyâ€™ items to what Iâ€™d call balanced,â€ù Mr. Beam said. â€œItâ€™s reasonable portions of good things that you wouldnâ€™t necessarily call health food.â€ù,Business travelers, it seems, would welcome any moves in that direction.,â€œIâ€™d love to be able to get a chicken breast and vegetables and some light starch thatâ€™s prepared nicely, or a selection of healthy soups,â€ù said Gabriel Levy, an executive with a digital music company in New York City, noting that these options are especially scarce on late-night menus. â€œYou can get burgers and sandwiches and that kind of stuff, but thatâ€™s exactly what I donâ€™t want to eat when itâ€™s late.â€ù,Scott Kraft, the executive vice president for marketing for a San Francisco software company, echoed that desire for well-prepared vegetables and appetizing mixed greens, adding that he would like to see more distinctive dishes. â€œYouâ€™re paying $250 a night minimum in most of these places, and then youâ€™re getting this generic room service experience,â€ù he said.,Others point to the seemingly outrageous prices sometimes charged for the smallest room service order. But despite the high charges â€”  and hotels sometimes add  a delivery charge on top of a 15 to 20 percent service charge  â€”  room service is not a cash cow.,â€œAt best, itâ€™s only marginally profitable and at worst, itâ€™s costly,â€ù said Kirby D. Payne, president of HVS/American Hospitality Management. â€œRoom service is a real complicated logistical deal. You have the normal prep time that you have in a restaurant, then you have to transfer the food to a table that has to be perfectly set, then you have to roll it some distance around the hotel.â€ù,Plus, there is the challenge of making sure soup arrives hot and ice cream cold, in the time frame promised when the order was placed.  According to research by Mr. Payneâ€™s firm, travelers tended to think that orders took  40 to 45 minutes to arrive, though in reality they usually arrived within 30 minutes.,Nevertheless, Marriott has been testing technology that lets guests use interactive touch-screens to place  orders, which may speed up delivery, and Marriott and Hilton have  introduced services that allow guests to pre-order  items to be waiting in their room upon check-in.,Another hurdle for hotels is that travelers expect to be able to nosh around the clock. But the person who cooks an order at 1 a.m. may not have the same qualifications as the chef on duty at 7 p.m., which is a lesson Lewis Peyton, a Los Angeles photographer, learned firsthand. Mr. Peytonâ€™s first job was working as a room service attendant at a luxury hotel in Australia, which he said also involved some cooking duties after the chefs went home.,â€œBe really careful about what you order after midnight,â€ù he advised, suggesting items that do not involve much skill to prepare, like a salad or a club sandwich.,For travelers on a budget, Janet Feldstein, a fund-raiser for a nonprofit organization who lives in Los Angeles, has another tip. â€œI go to Whole Foods or a takeout place and bring food back to my room  â€”  like sushi, a salad or chips and guacamole  â€”  and sometimes I order pizza,â€ù she said.,Although some hotels  do not allow food deliveries, Ms. Feldstein says she avoids that problem by giving  her cellphone number so she can pick up her pizza box outside. That raises another thorny point: what to do with the remains of your meal once you have finished dining.,Mr. Payne, the hotel consultant, said hotel staff should call to see if a guest is ready to have the tray picked up  â€”  and failing that, travelers should call to ask for a pick-up, rather than just pushing the tray into the hall.,On that note, he offered some advice most travelers have probably heard at home: â€œRemember, itâ€™s a relationship of mutual respect  â€”  these arenâ€™t servants there to pick up after you.â€ù
column4: Rewriting the Room Service Menu

column1: Elected officials from Manhattan and the Bronx  urged Consolidated Edison yesterday to reconsider plans to install a 9.5-mile underground electric transmission line that would extend from Yonkers, along Riverdale Avenue in the Bronx, under the Harlem River and into Inwood, in northern Manhattan. In a statement, the officials said the power line would â€œhave a severe negative impact on vital neighborhood services and residentsâ€™ overall quality of lifeâ€ù and identified an alternative route that they said would be less disruptive. Michael S. Clendenin, a Con Ed spokesman, said that the line was essential to expand the capacity of the networks serving the area  and that the proposed route  was the most feasible. The State , is expected to decide the issue shortly.
column4: Manhattan: Power Line Proposal

column1: In July 2005, Jeff Carenza and his girlfriend were enjoying a getaway weekend in Miami when food poisoning landed them both in the hospital. Blood tests showed that Dr. Carenza, then 29, had iron-deficiency ,.,â€œItâ€™s probably nothing,â€ù the doctor told him. â€œBut have it checked when you get home.â€ù,This type of anemia can be caused by blood loss from the intestinal tract. So back in St. Louis, where Dr. Carenza was a radiology resident at Barnes Jewish Hospital, his doctor sent him to a gastroenterologist.,One possibility was that he had a growth in his colon. But the gastroenterologist was dismissive. â€œThis is going to be a waste of my time,â€ù he said before performing a colonoscopy.,Half an hour later, Dr. Carenza received bad news.,â€œThereâ€™s a large , in your transverse colon,â€ù the gastroenterologist said. â€œItâ€™s so big I couldnâ€™t even get my scope around it. Itâ€™s probably been there for some time.â€ù,Dr. Carenza recalled, â€œMy stomach and heart were on the floor.â€ù,The diagnosis, he added, â€œwent against what weâ€™re trained to think in medical schoolâ€ù â€” that â€œ, happens to older people.â€ù,Cancer is indeed less common in adolescents and young adults than in older people. But in some ways it is more alarming.,The rates of some cancers,  including colorectal, thyroid and testicular,  are rising in people ages 20 to 39, according to the American Cancer Society. And a report released in August by the National Cancer Institute and Lance Armstrong Foundation found that even as cancer survival rates continued to improve in adults of middle age and older, the survival rates for people ages 15 to 39 had not risen substantially in more than two decades.,Cancer is the fourth-leading killer in that age group, behind accidents, , and homicides. In 2006, there were approximately 55,200 new cases of cancer in Americans 15 to 39, and 9,300 cancer deaths in that same group, according to the American Cancer Society.,â€œCancer in adolescents and young adults presents distinctive issues,â€ù said an author of that report, Dr. Karen Albritton, director of adolescent and young adult oncology at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston. â€œThe gaps in our knowledge are huge.â€ù,Some experts say more information is needed before devoting extra resources to adolescents and young adults. Dr. Bruce A. Chabner, clinical director of the Massachusetts General Hospital Cancer Center, notes that overall survival rates of young adults are still better than those of older adults, reflecting the differences in tumor types and better tolerance of treatment in younger patients.,As of 2003, the last year for which statistics were available, the five-year survival rate was 78.5 percent for people ages 20 to 39, and  68 percent for those 40 to 69, according to the American Cancer Society.,But Dr. Albritton and others say research is needed to learn why some young adults are predisposed to cancer, why the rates of some cancers are rising in this age group and how young people may respond differently to treatment regimens â€” many of which have been tested mostly in older adults or in children.,Young peopleâ€™s tumors may have distinct genetic and biological features, these researchers say. And survivors face unique psychosocial issues â€” as they think about future ,, finishing school or starting a career.,Dr. Carenza said that looking back, he should have paid more attention to warning signs. An avid runner, he was accustomed to jogging five or six miles several days a week but for months had been unable to do so. He had also grown noticeably pale.,Still, he recalled, even his mother brushed that aside, saying: â€œWell, heâ€™s a radiologist. He works in a dark room all day.â€ù,Dr. David Dietz, the colorectal surgeon at Barnes Jewish Hospital who treated Dr. Carenza, says cancer in younger patients is typically diagnosed at a later stage because neither they nor their doctors expect them to have it. Nor do they receive routine screening, as older people do.,Dr. Carenza  has no family history of cancer, and tests after the tumor was found were negative for all known hereditary colorectal cancer syndromes.  (He completed , last March and has since been in remission, though he  sees an oncologist every three months.) Still, genetic factors may be more likely to play a role when young people get the disease,  Dr. Dietz said, adding, â€œThat is something we would like to know more about.â€ù,Asha Mevlana of Los Angeles had a family history of cancer. She found a lump in her breast at 22, but her cancer was not diagnosed for more than two years.,Ms. Mevlana received a , early on, but the results were inconclusive, as they sometimes are in younger women whose breast tissue is denser.,â€œMy doctor said, â€˜Donâ€™t worry about that; youâ€™re way too young for ,,â€™ â€ù she said. â€œWhich is of course what I wanted to hear, so I let it go.â€ù,But as the lump grew and began to hurt, Ms. Mevlanaâ€™s mother insisted she go to another doctor and get a biopsy, which confirmed that she had breast cancer.,â€œIt changes your perspective on everything,â€ù she said. â€œYou think: â€˜Wow, I could be dead next year. And there are so many things I havenâ€™t done.â€™ â€ù,Ms. Mevlana hoped to begin a career as an electric violinist. And in considering treatment options, one priority was to avoid drugs that cause neuropathy, a numbness and tingling in the hands or feet that is a side effect of some chemotherapy drugs.,The choices were â€œcompletely confusing,â€ù she said. Several doctors suggested different regimens but told her that most of them had not been well studied in younger women.,One doctor she consulted was Nadine Tung, director of the cancer risk and prevention program at Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center in Boston. In an interview, Dr. Tung agreed that there had been few clinical trials to assess treatment regimens specifically in young adults.,â€œThat has been a problem,â€ù she said, adding that some important research was â€œfinally happening.â€ù,Unlike most young breast cancer patients, Ms. Mevlana had a tumor that was stimulated by ,. In such cases, Dr. Tung said, an important question is whether menstruation should be artificially blocked after chemotherapy, by giving the patient a shot or by removing her ovaries.,Ms. Mevlana said one doctor advised ovary removal. But she decided against it because she did not want to face the prospect of not having children.,â€œIt was just too much to give that up,â€ù said Ms. Mevlana, who is now 31 and is a professional violinist.,Dr. Albritton of Dana-Farber says that adolescents and young adults often respond differently to treatments, and that there is a â€œdisparity of attentionâ€ù to them in the medical community.,There need to be â€œmore clinical trials and more providers trained specifically for young adults,â€ù she said.,Researchers also say further work is needed to understand why the rates of certain cancers are rising among young adults.,Testicular cancer, for example, is most common among young men, and its rate is increasing. â€œWe do not know why this is the case,â€ù said Dr. Tongzhang Zheng of the Yale School of Public Health, who recently received a $5.5 million grant from the National Cancer Institute to study potential genetic and environmental risk factors for the disease.,Nor is it clear why the rate of thyroid cancer, which largely affects young people, is rising, said Dr. R. Michael Tuttle, an endocrinologist and thyroid cancer expert at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.,â€œThe only thing we know of that causes thyroid cancer is ,,â€ù  Dr. Tuttle said, noting that people living downwind of Chernobyl had higher rates of this cancer. â€œBut the spike in the U.S. is not being caused by radiation.â€ù,Dr. Archie Bleyer, a specialist in adolescent and young-adult cancer at the CureSearch National Childhood Cancer Foundation,  says there is a â€œuniquenessâ€ù to cancer in this age group that goes beyond the scientific and clinical issues. Not only do young patients face a distinctive array of cancers and therapies, but they are also confronted with personal challenges that are different from those affecting either older adults or children.,Young people are more likely to be uninsured or underinsured, he said â€” one reason their diseases tend to be diagnosed later. They are also more likely to feel stigmatized, since fewer of their peers have had experience with cancer.,And they face huge developmental challenges â€” entering society, joining the work force, contemplating marriage and starting a family â€” which can be overwhelming even without the burden of disease.,â€œOne of the biggest struggles in doing anything medically is to overcome the psychosocial challenges,â€ù Dr. Bleyer said.,A growing number of advocacy and outreach groups have been founded for young adults â€” many of them by cancer survivors. The Colon Club, for instance, aims to raise awareness about colon cancer in young people through projects like creating a yearly calendar of survivors. The Young Survival Coalition focuses on awareness and advocacy regarding breast cancer in young adults. And the SAMFund provides financial support to young survivors making the transition to post-treatment life.,More than 50 organizations dedicated to cancer-related issues for young adults are cataloged on a new Web site, ,, started by Steps for Living, a nonprofit communications, advocacy and support organization for young adults with cancer.,â€œWhen I was diagnosed with cancer, all I really wanted was to connect to other people my age,â€ù said the groupâ€™s founder, Matthew Zachary, 32,  of Brooklyn, who learned at 21 that he had pediatric brain cancer.,Lauren Terrazzano, who writes a weekly column for Newsday called â€œLife, With Cancer,â€ù said that for a younger person, â€œcancer can be the ultimate form of identity theft, if you let it.â€ù,Ms. Terrazzano was told she had advanced lung cancer in 2004 and has since undergone three operations, including an extrapleural pneumonectomy, in which her right lung and part of the lining of her heart were removed. She has also undergone extensive chemotherapy and radiation.,â€œOne day youâ€™re a healthy 36-year-old with long hair, black mascara and low-rider jeans,â€ù she said. â€œYouâ€™re going through the rhythms of life, going to work, going to dinner, hanging out with friends. And the next minute youâ€™re Cancer Girl.,â€œItâ€™s a hard thing to reconcile.â€ù
column4: Too Young for This: Facing Cancer Under 40

column1: A new study suggests that having many siblings may increase the risk for certain stomach cancers and that younger siblings may be more at risk than older ones.,Researchers gathered blood samples from 7,429 Japanese-American men living in Hawaii from 1967 to 1975 to determine whether they were infected with Helicobacter pylori, a childhood infection known to increase the risk for stomach , much later in life. They followed the men for 28 years, during which 261 developed gastric cancer.,From that group, the researchers selected the cases of those infected with H. pylori â€”  239, or 92 percent â€”   and compared them with a group of cancer-free, but also infected, controls. The team then looked at family size and birth order in both groups.,Among the cases with the most the virulent strain of H. pylori, called cagA, those from families with seven or more children were more than twice as likely to develop cancer as those from families with one to three children, and younger children had a higher risk than older ones.,The , appears in the January issue of PloS Medicine.,â€œItâ€™s remarkable that something thatâ€™s happening in the early years of life affects the risk of a cancer happening seven decades later,â€ù said Dr. Martin J. Blaser, the lead author and a professor of medicine at New York University. â€œItâ€™s my hypothesis that this may be a model system for other cancers.â€ù,The authors acknowledge that some factor other than family size or birth order may be the cause of the findings. But they suggest that the germ is transmitted among siblings, and that the immature immune systems of younger children may make them more susceptible.
column4: At Risk: Some Cancers May Be Tied to Family Size

column1: Daily use of a common class of antidepressant may double the risk of fracture in people older than 50, a Canadian study reports.,Researchers randomly selected 5,008 people older than 50 and followed them for five years. At the start of the study, they interviewed the subjects about medications and general health. The subjects filled out yearly questionnaires reporting fractures caused by falling from a bed, chair or standing height. (A co-author of the study has received grants and honorariums from several drug companies.),One hundred and thirty-seven people, or 2.7 percent of the subjects, were daily users of selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, or S.S.R.I.â€™s, a rate similar to that of the general populations of the United States and Canada. After controlling for the use of other psychotropic medicines, age, sex, education, height, weight, , status and other variables, daily users of S.S.R.I.â€™s were 2.1 times as likely to suffer fractures as those who did not use the medicine. The , appears in the Jan. 22 issue of The Archives of Internal Medicine.,â€œWeâ€™re not recommending that people stop their S.S.R.I.â€™s,â€ù said Dr. David Goltzman, a professor of medicine at McGill University in Montreal and the senior author of the study. â€œBut people should realize that this is a risk and that they might want to undertake lifestyle changes like participating in exercise and making sure their , is appropriate in calcium and vitamin D.â€ù,Using S.S.R.I.â€™s was also associated with an increased risk of falls and with decreased mineral bone density. But after controlling for falls and low bone density, the risk of fracture persisted. The scientists speculated that other pathways leading to impaired bone quality might be at work.
column4: Hazards: Antidepressant Linked to Fractures in Older People

column1: A passer-by glancing through a rear window of the sanctuary at St. Thomas Church on Sunday evening might not have noticed anything amiss. The pews were filled with people whose heads were bowed in concentration, eyes closed tight; a few faces were turned heavenward in amazement or rapture.,But what had so transfixed this throng was â€œHarmonies,â€ù an Ã©tude by the Hungarian composer Gyorgy Ligeti, performed midway through a recital by the organist John Scott, a concert presented by the Miller Theater at Columbia University.,Mr. Scott, the music director at St. Thomas, recently embarked upon a complete traversal of the German Baroque master Dietrich Buxtehudeâ€™s organ works here, parceled out in 10 installments. Ligeti, by contrast, required only half of a single concert, with sufficient room remaining for the complete organ music of Jonathan Harvey, a British modernist.,Mr. Scott played Mr. Harveyâ€™s music on the churchâ€™s vast Arents Memorial Organ, a Skinner instrument built in 1913. â€œLaus Deoâ€ù offered a brisk interplay of frantic exclamations and gentler ruminations. Brittle figures flashed and spiraled upward like sparks over a campfire at the beginning of â€œFantasia,â€ù which thoroughly explored the instrumentâ€™s registrations. Surging arpeggios clashed with recorded rhythms in â€œToccata, for Organ and Tape,â€ù building to a barbarous climax.,Mr. Scott switched to the churchâ€™s Loening-Hancock organ, a more compact instrument built according to German and Dutch Baroque custom, for Ligetiâ€™s â€œRicercare: Omaggio a Girolamo Frescobaldi.â€ù The deliberately monotonous parody of 12-tone music served as a palate cleanser; what followed was unearthly, disorienting and never less than gripping. Ligeti called for the organ to be played with reduced wind pressure in â€œHarmonies,â€ù resulting in sounds that suggested by turns a consort of model-train whistles, a ghostly choir and a swarm of crotchety bassoonists.,Mr. Scott produced a jarring flurry in â€œCoulÃ©e,â€ù a perpetual-motion study that gradually ascends in pitch until the player runs out of keyboard. Saved for last was â€œVolumina,â€ù whose notorious opening chord has been responsible for the death of more than one organ. Happily the St. Thomas instrument survived, producing dissonant clusters that rippled like heat haze and bass notes that rumbled as if the subway below the church had suddenly risen to within inches of the floor.
column4: Lifting Ligeti With the Force of an Organ

column1: As he notes in his remarkable new memoir, â€œWish I Could Be There,â€ù the composer Allen Shawn suffers from a veritable rainbow of ,: â€œI donâ€™t like heights,â€ù he writes. â€œI donâ€™t like being on the water. I am upset by walking across parking lots or open parks or fields where there are no buildings. I tend to avoid bridges, unless they are on a small scale. I respond poorly to stretches of vastness but do equally badly when I am closed in, as I am severely claustrophobic. When I go to a theater, I sit on the aisle. I am petrified of tunnels, making most train travel as well as many drives difficult. I donâ€™t take subways. I avoid elevators as much as possible. I experience glassed-in spaces as toxic, and I find it very difficult to adjust to being in buildings in which the windows donâ€™t open.â€ù,In short, he concludes, â€œI am afraid both of closed and of open spaces, and I am afraid, in a sense, of any form of isolation.â€ù,These phobias, Mr. Shawn goes on, have meant that he ends up â€œmissing things and harming, or losing relationships.â€ù They have circumscribed his life, and turned ordinary undertakings â€” going on a trip, visiting friends, doing errands â€” into a daunting obstacle course. The prospect of a trip makes him â€œalmost frozen with anticipatory anxiety for weeks or months in advance,â€ù and even small jaunts, like a walk down a road, require him to equip himself with â€œsafety items,â€ù like a supply of Xanax, a bottle of ginger ale, a cellphone and a paper bag â€œof the type I breathed into once, many years ago, to calm myself when I suffered a concussion.â€ù,In probing the consequences and possible causes of his phobias, Mr. Shawn has written a brave, eccentric and utterly compelling book thatâ€™s as revelatory and candid as anything ever written by Joan Didion, and as humane and scientifically fascinating as any one of Oliver Sacksâ€™s case studies.,Mr. Shawn is unsparing in his dissection of his phobias and the self-preoccupation they entail,  and he intercuts his research into the psychology of his affliction with some painfully recalled childhood memories that unfold into a thoughtful, philosophical meditation on Freud and families and identity.,The son of the famed New Yorker editor William Shawn, Allen Shawn has an older brother, Wallace, the playwright and actor; and a twin sister, Mary, who is autistic and lives in an institution in Delaware. The diagnosis of his sisterâ€™s condition and her departure, when she was 8, for a special school on Cape Cod seem to have triggered a severe case of separation anxiety in Allen, as well as fears that â€œone could be turned out of the house for being too difficult to handle,â€ù for â€œbeing too inefficient mentally, or for being too wild.â€ù,These fears amplified his own â€œterror of ,â€ù  â€”  the fear that,  being Maryâ€™s twin, he too was somehow damaged or different.,Mary had been Allenâ€™s closest companion when they were small children, and he says that his parentsâ€™ desire that he simply move on with his own life backfired: he had remained Maryâ€™s twin, â€œfinding ways to make my life parallel to hers.â€ù,â€œI canâ€™t help noticing that she, like me, is subject to â€˜attacks,â€™ â€ù Mr. Shawn writes, â€œlives within a fixed routine, resists even minute changes from what she expects, is extremely limited in her ability to travel. She is institutionalized, I am out here, â€˜freeâ€™ and â€˜functioning,â€™ yet I have managed to build some invisible walls around myself.â€ù,There were other factors that fed Allenâ€™s phobic inclinations as well: a hereditary predisposition toward phobias; a childhood desire to emulate his father (who suffered from an array of phobias, including a distaste for airplanes, bridges and elevators); and a tendency to internalize his overprotective motherâ€™s warnings about the perils of the world. Mr. Shawn recalls that she kept a watchful eye on him as a child, â€œdelaying seemingly forever the moment when I would be allowed to cross the street by myself, and cultivating a sense that I wasnâ€™t ready to â€˜handleâ€™ this or that activity, this or that scary scene in a movie.â€ù,In addition, the Shawn household, with its emphasis on discretion and denial,  seems to have been an â€œincubating environmentâ€ù for future phobias, a petri dish of unspoken emotions. The authorâ€™s father carried on a four-decade extramarital affair, and his reticence about his complicated double life (â€œit wasnâ€™t uncommon for him to eat, or at least, ,four or even five meals a day to accommodate all the important people in his lifeâ€ù) created an atmosphere in which secrecy and repression flourished.,â€œBeneath my sunniness,â€ù Mr. Shawn writes of his younger self, â€œthere was also rage that my family was somehow a sham, that I was a twin who wasnâ€™t supposed to feel like one, that we were Jews with an Irish name. I felt that huge passions and angers that somehow couldnâ€™t be mentioned were seething within me and within the house and that the world was raw and crude but had to be referred to politely in perfect sentences. There were blinding hatreds in the air that couldnâ€™t be named; there was sex that couldnâ€™t be spoken of; there were deep mysteries that had to be sanitized and secularized; there was deep competitiveness and there were deep character flaws that couldnâ€™t be acknowledged.â€ù,Mr. Shawn says he â€œheld in my feelings and my problems, and they grew without my even knowing it.â€ù Although he wasnâ€™t agoraphobic as a child, he began, after college, to build his â€œlife around the experiences in which I felt calm.â€ù Since then, he now realizes, he has been dragging his childhood along with him like a giant, melancholy shadow.,With phobias, of course, itâ€™s impossible to point to one precipitating cause, one formative event, and in Mr. Shawnâ€™s case, a constellation of events, experiences and environmental influences helped reinforce any existing tendency to bury his difficulties inside. In â€œWish I Could Be There,â€ù his inquiry into his affliction becomes an inquiry into his own past, and that inquiry, in turn, becomes an eloquent meditation upon the mysteries of personality and family, and the ingenious, often debilitating ways in which the human mind can try to cope with the exigencies of the world.,â€œIn a way,â€ù Mr. Shawn writes, â€œI had been raised to feel that the world was a kind of Pandoraâ€™s box that was simply too frightening to ever fully open. As an adult I found a way to open it a bit, while sitting on top of it too.â€ù
column4: Recalling a Literary Family, and Phobias

column1: The telephone calls and e-mail messages started streaming in just hours after the first news articles  reported that a uterine transplant might be in the works. One caller was a 25-year-old Alabama woman who was born without a uterus. Another was a 33-year-old Illinois woman who had a hysterectomy at 24.,All of the women, desperate to carry a child of their own, had heard that doctors at New York Downtown Hospital had harvested wombs from eight brain-dead human donors, laying the groundwork for the first human uterine transplant in the Western world. They wanted to be candidates for transplants. (One caller even offered to be a living donor, saying she had already had children and no longer needed her uterus.),The hospital has no immediate plans for a uterine transplant, but even the possibility has been greeted with opprobrium by many medical ethicists, , doctors and patient advocates. They said that a uterine transplant is a radical and potentially dangerous solution to a problem that is not life-threatening and that can be resolved in other ways, like using a surrogate. The risks, they said, extend not only to the mother but also to the unborn child.,When and where an actual transplant of a uterus might take place is anyoneâ€™s guess. Dr. Bruce D. Logan, the president of New York Downtown Hospital, said the hospital was supportive of the research but did not expect to perform a uterine transplant â€œany time in the foreseeable future.â€ù,The only human uterine transplant to date was carried out in Saudi Arabia in 2000 and used an organ from a live donor, which is not being considered by the New York researchers, but the uterus failed after three months and had to be removed.,Still, Dr. Giuseppe Del Priore, the lead author of the study that described the uterus harvesting in this monthâ€™s issue of the journal Obstetrics and Gynecology, said doctors needed to be able to offer fertility patients more options. Dr. Del Priore, a , specialist, explained that he became interested in uterine transplants after seeing young women whose surgical treatments left them unable to bear children, and who were desperate to start a family. â€œThis is where we get our inspiration,â€ù he said.,While the risks would be enormous, he said, some women would be willing to assume them in exchange for the mere possibility of having a baby. Many women who have had transplants of other kinds â€” life-saving kidneys, hearts and lungs â€” have been able to carry pregnancies to term.,â€œYouâ€™ve got to put this in its proper context,â€ù Dr. Del Priore said. â€œTransplant patients have babies, sick patients have babies, and it generally turns out well. The mothers-to-be are willing to take that risk.â€ù,But while the desire to bear a child may be an intense and passionate one, fertility advocates and medical experts called for more research on animals before another uterine transplant is attempted in humans. â€œFor many women, experiencing , is a central part of being a woman, and they will go to many extremes to have that experience,â€ù said Pamela Madsen, executive director of the American Fertility Association, a nonprofit education and advocacy group. â€œBut just because we want it, does that mean it is worth the risks? There are two lives involved here.â€ù,For women who do not have a uterus or a properly functioning uterus, Ms. Madsen said, â€œIt feels like a loss, and it is a loss.â€ù,â€œBut how far do we go?â€ù Ms. Madsen said. â€œEspecially when there are other kinds of solutions that may not fill the emotional gap of experiencing pregnancy but will result in a healthy baby, with very little risk.â€ù,Studies have yielded pregnancies and live births in mice that received uterine transplants, but the rodents received organs from donors that were very closely related or genetically identical, the experts said.,A transplant patient who became pregnant would face many potential complications. She would be required to take immunosuppressive medications that could be toxic and may harm the unborn child, she may develop infections or other complications from surgery, and there is always a risk the organ would fail or be rejected. About half of all , patients who become pregnant have preterm births and low birth weight babies, and many of the women develop high , and pre-eclampsia, a dangerous condition in which a pregnant womanâ€™s blood pressure threatens her health and the childâ€™s.,With a uterus transplant, there is an additional layer of complexity, because the pregnancy would be occurring within the transplanted organ, and no one knows how the transplant would adapt to pregnancy.,â€œThis is very complex, and one woman dying from this is going to be really one too many,â€ù said Dr. Tommaso Falcone, chairman of obstetrics and gynecology at the Cleveland Clinic and a reproductive endocrinologist who has done research on ovarian transplantation. â€œIf we were going to cure cancer and save humanity, Iâ€™d say take the risks and take it to humans as quickly as possible. But weâ€™re looking at patients with essentially a nonlethal condition.â€ù,These patients are also a distinct minority, he said, estimating that fewer than 1 percent of his patients are infertile because they lack a uterus.,Willing patients would be put through a grueling process, according to a description provided by Dr. Del Priore and his colleague Dr. Jeanetta Stega. Any candidate for the surgery would first have to undergo in-vitro fertilization, and have a ready supply of frozen embryos for implantation after the transplant. The doctors said they would not want to put a woman through a transplant only to discover later that she was infertile for another reason, like an inability to produce eggs. And in any case, intercourse might be prohibited after the transplant, to minimize the risk of infection.,The surgery would have to take place quickly after a compatible  organ donor was identified.,The transplant surgery would involve a vertical abdominal incision in the patient. The cervix of the donated uterus would be attached to the patientâ€™s vagina and the uterus would be connected to four blood vessels, two on each side, Dr. Stega said. She estimated that that part of the surgery would last one to two hours. After surgery, the patient would be started on a regimen of immunosuppressive medications to prevent rejection of the new organ.,Once the womanâ€™s condition was stable, she could have embryos implanted in the uterus, a procedure that is not always successful. If she became pregnant, she would be considered a high-risk patient, and would be closely monitored by a team of medical experts throughout her pregnancy.,The plan would be to deliver the baby by Caesarean section, and perform a hysterectomy to remove the uterus and prevent any additional risk of transplant-related complications, the doctors said.,One of the many unknowns involves the health of the babies. Though registries that track pregnant transplant recipients report relatively low rates of birth defects, critics say the registries are voluntary, the follow-up on the children is spotty and little is known about developmental and cognitive delays in the children.,Even Dr. Del Priore says a uterine transplant is â€œthe last option.â€ù,â€œWe want to discourage people from thinking this is an easy option,â€ù he said. â€œThe entire family unit needs to understand the magnitude of the decision and the experimental nature of the procedure.â€ù,Aimee Sheppard, a 25-year-old from Falkville, Ala., said she was aware of the risks but still wanted a chance to bear her own child. She found out when she was 13 that she was born without a uterus; her sister served as a surrogate and carried Ms. Sheppardâ€™s daughter, who is now 18 months old.,â€œIâ€™ve read up about it,â€ù Ms. Sheppard said. â€œTo me itâ€™s a small price to pay to be able to carry my own child.â€ù
column4: Prospect of Womb Transplant Raises Hopes and Red Flags

column1: Quick weight gain may be among the birth-control pillâ€™s most dreaded side effects. But how much does it really add to your waistline?,Last year, a group of researchers carried out what may be the most extensive study on the subject to date. Their conclusion: In most women, neither the pill nor the patch seems to add any pounds at all.,Of 44 previous studies that the researchers combined and analyzed, 3 found no difference between women who took hormonal contraceptives and those who took a placebo. The other studies looked at women taking different types and doses of hormonal contraception, and came to the same  overall conclusion.,The claim may have had some truth many years ago, when the pill contained high levels of ,, which can cause water retention and increased appetite. Nowadays, most versions of the pill have only half the amount found in early versions.,Some studies have shown that while the pill may add a couple of pounds at first from water retention, the added weight disappears as the body adjusts to the ,.,Another factor has nothing to do with the pill: most women start birth control as teenagers and continue it through their 20s, a period when women naturally tend to gain weight.,  The link between the pill and weight gain is exaggerated at best.
column4: The Claim: The Pill Can Make You Put On Weight

column1: I had run way too far for my level of training, and I knew it. But I had gotten lost, and the fastest way back to my car was to run. The next day, my left forefoot hurt so much I could hardly walk, so I did just what you might expect â€” I checked the Internet to see what sort of injury I might have and what to do about it.,My  search was frustrating and unhelpful. But  I ended up getting just the advice I needed from an unexpected source. And I came away with this lesson: These days, when it is oh so easy to order sophisticated medical tests, sometimes the best test, and the best treatment, can be low-tech.,After I was hurt, I did just what doctors worry that their patients will do. I searched medical Web sites for a diagnosis I could accept. When I did not like the one I found, I tried to convince myself that it had to be  wrong.,The Web  diagnosis was a stress fracture, a hairline crack in a bone. It sounded bad. It could take months to heal. I might need to immobilize the entire foot and walk around on crutches and then    go through weeks of rehabilitation.,I told myself that I didnâ€™t have a stress fracture, that there were aspects of my injury that did not seem to fit. I kept running, four to six miles every other day. Still, I was not getting better.,Finally, in December, six weeks after the injury, I gave in and called one of the few orthopedists in my area who accepts my health insurance. The first available appointment was for Jan. 16. I took it.,Then I wrote about my injury, as part of a longer article for The New York Times about running while hurt. As soon as it appeared, on Jan. 11, I began getting e-mail from readers. A podiatrist told me that I definitely had a stress fracture and had better stop running. A trainer said I had injured a tendon attached to my big toe (he had no way of knowing that the injury was at the base of my third toe).  And Paul A. April, a rheumatologist in Tulsa, Okla., said he thought it was either a stress fracture or something called extensor tendinitis. â€œIâ€™d love to hear what the doctor finds,â€ù he added.,I looked up extensor tendinitis online:  an inflammation of a tendon that straightens the toe. I hadnâ€™t found that injury when I first searched the Web, but it sounded right.,On Jan. 16, I finally saw the orthopedist and, of course, mentioned extensor tendinitis. All I got was a cursory exam and an X-ray. When the X-ray showed normal bone, the orthopedist said I needed an M.R.I. His office said someone  would call me when my insurer approved it. Then I could schedule it. Then I could return to see the doctor and learn what the scan showed.,I e-mailed Dr. April in Oklahoma telling him what had happened. â€œGratuitous advice may be worth nothing, but here goes,â€ù he replied. â€œ, examination should have revealed tenderness in the distal forefoot and even an increase in pain with forced downward pressure on the toes. If that was the case, then a local injection of a corticosteroid in a small amount with lidocaine or something similar into the extensor tendon sheath would produce relief of pain within minutes and hopefully this would last.â€ù,That sounded great. I could rule out a stress fracture and cure the inflammation all at once. If that did not work, I did not have extensor tendinitis.,I called the orthopedist to see whether he would give an injection. All I could get was an assistantâ€™s voicemail saying not to expect a reply for 48 hours because she was busy and, by the way, she does not work on Fridays. It was a Wednesday. (Thirteen days later, I still have not heard from her.)  I also called my internist to see whether she would give an injection. The answer, her nurse said, was no.,Finally, I called an orthopedist who does not accept my insurance and asked whether he would inject cortisone into the tendon sheath of my foot. His assistant knew just what I was talking about.,â€œYou want to rule out a stress fracture?â€ù she asked.,The doctor would do it, for $277. I said that I would be there the next day and that  I would pay.,The injection cured me. It also saved my insurer more than $1,000 for an M.R.I. and subsequent doctorsâ€™ appointments. But how much simpler to do what the Tulsa doctor recommended and the second orthopedist did: carefully examine my foot, ask about the injury, see that my symptoms seemed more like tendinitis than a stress fracture and simply give the injection.,As for Dr. April, my correspondent in Tulsa, he has learned something, too.,â€œThe idea of telephone medicine seems to be an easy way to make a living if I were inclined to that,â€ù he wrote. â€œIn your case, I was intrigued by a simple problem, the solution of which seemed to be stalled. It really was no big deal, but I loved doing it.â€ù
column4: When the Simple Solution Is the Right One

column1: A bellow of Southern pride, tinny in a cellphone speaker, sounds at the bedside of a sleeping teenager. Itâ€™s â€œSweet Home Alabama.â€ù This is morning in Hoover, Ala., home of sublime high school football, as well as of MTVâ€™s pious reality series â€œTwo-a-Days,â€ù which begins its second season tonight. The song is a wake-up call.,Mark, the lunky and sweet defensive end, stirs. Shutting off the phone, he also shakes off the memory of last nightâ€™s loss â€” by two touchdowns, on the home field. For the Hoover High School Buccaneers, this loss precludes a top national ranking. Nothing the team does now, in Markâ€™s senior year, will make up for that loss. The best it can hope for is to win state, but Hoover always wins state. So, actually, the best they can hope for is not to , state. What a drag of a way to start the day.,And what a drag of a way, really, to start a show. â€œFriday Night Lights,â€ù NBCâ€™s as-yet-undefeated fictional series about high school football, also started by putting its team way in the hole: on the debut episode, the quarterback ended up paralyzed. But an existential blow like that is the kind that drama was invented to address. A disqualification from national rankings in Game 1, on the other hand, is just a closed door. It puts dramatic limits, not possibilities, on a television series.,Nonetheless, the boys of Hoover who are also reality stars now obediently seek more reasons to play football. Or should I say to play â€œthis ballgame,â€ù or â€œthis football gameâ€ù? These phrases come from Rush Propst, the teamâ€™s picturesque coach, who combines tough and tender so tastily that in him it seems to be a blend of pop.,The wonderfully nonterse, redundant way that sports people refer to their object of affection â€” this ballgame, this ball club, this football program â€” reaches a crescendo in his oratory style. Coach Propst is always ready to revisit first principles, to build the sport from the ground up. What are these padded kids even doing there? Foot. Ball.,Just as â€œLaguna Beachâ€ù was originally MTVâ€™s reality answer to Foxâ€™s fictional â€œOC,â€ù â€œTwo-a-Daysâ€ù (the title refers to a teamâ€™s days of double practice sessions) could be viewed as a documentary counterpart to â€œFriday Night Lights.â€ù Like that NBC show, MTVâ€™s show features cheerleaders, an almost exclusively white Southern team, and boys from modest homes who turn gladiatorial on the football field.,And, of course, thereâ€™s a speechifying and self-sacrificing coach. At one point Mark says, â€œI do love Friday nights, when those lights turn on.â€ù,But donâ€™t expect â€œTwo-a-Daysâ€ù to wallop â€œFriday Night Lights,â€ù as â€œLaguna Beachâ€ù did â€œThe OCâ€ù As a â€œFriday Night Lightsâ€ù obsessive, I intend to use â€œTwo-a-Daysâ€ù instead as a companion piece, and Iâ€™ll watch it as long as â€œFriday Night Lightsâ€ù stays on the air. High school football makes a plangent subject for fiction â€” particularly television and film â€” but it requires art to cut against the sportâ€™s intrinsic wordlessness, as well as the reticence of the players. It needs art to give it lift.,Without the script and generous camerawork of â€œFriday Night Lights,â€ù all the good lines on â€œTwo-a-Daysâ€ù go to the coach â€” and the plays, unchoreographed and unmiked for the television audience, are hard to decipher.,Dave Sirulnick and Amy Bailey, executive producers for MTV; Jason Sciavicco and Jesse James Dupree, executive producers, Humidity Entertainment.
column4: In High School Football, Crunch Time Can Be Literal

column1: Sixty years ago, a group of physicists concerned about nuclear weapons created the Doomsday Clock and set its hands at seven minutes to midnight. Now, the clockâ€™s keepers, alarmed by new dangers like ,, have moved the hands up to 11:55 p.m.,My first reaction was a sigh of relief. After all, the 1947 doomsday prediction marked the start of a golden age. Never have so many humans lived so long  â€”  and maybe never so peacefully  â€”  as during the past 60 years. The per-capita rate of violence, particularly in the West, seems  remarkably low by historical standards.  If the clockâ€™s keepers are worried once again, their track record suggests weâ€™re in for even happier days.,But thereâ€™s one novel twist that gives me pause. When the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists announced two weeks ago in Washington that it was adjusting the clock, it was joined in a trans-Atlantic press conference by scientists at the Royal Society in London. One of them was the societyâ€™s president, Martin Rees, a new breed of doomsayer.,Dr. Rees, a cosmologist at Cambridge and Britainâ€™s astronomer royal, doesnâ€™t just issue gloomy predictions. He doesnâ€™t just move the hands of an imaginary and inscrutable clock. (Its keepers have never explained what one of their minutes equals on anyone elseâ€™s clock or calendar.),No, Dr. Rees is braver. He gives odds on doomsday and offers to bet on disaster. In his 2003 book, â€œOur Final Hour,â€ù he gives civilization no more than  a 50 percent chance of surviving until 2100.,Dr. Rees is not a knee-jerk technophobe  â€”  he expects great advances as researchers around the world link their knowledge  â€”  but he fears that progress will be undone by what he calls the new global village idiots. Heâ€™s sure enough of himself to post an offer on Long Bets, a clever innovation on the Web that Stewart Brand helped start with money from Jeff Bezos, the founder of ,.,Long Bets is a nonprofit foundation that calls itself an â€œarena for competitive, accountable predictions.â€ù It lets anyone make a prediction and take wagers on it, with the proceeds going to a charity named by the winner. The bets made so far are from $200 to $10,000, on topics ranging from the driving habits of Americans in 2010 to whether the universe will stop expanding. Mitchell Kapor, the software guru, is betting that in 2029 no computer will have passed the Turing test (by conversing so much like a human that you couldnâ€™t tell the difference).  The physicist Freeman Dysonâ€™s money is on the first extraterrestrial lifeâ€™s  being found somewhere other than a planet or its satellite.,Five years ago, Dr. Rees  posted ,: â€œBy 2020, bioterror or bioerror will lead to one million casualties in a single event.â€ù He reasoned that â€œby 2020 there will be thousands  â€” even millions â€” of people with the capability to cause a catastrophic biological disaster. My concern is not only organized terrorist groups, but individual weirdos with the mindset of the people who now design computer viruses.â€ù,He didnâ€™t get any takers on ,, which seems to me a missed opportunity. So Iâ€™ve posted an offer there to bet him $200  â€”  not a huge sum, but enough to put both our reputations on the line. I realize that betting on disaster may sound ghoulish, but neither of us will personally profit (if I win, the money goes to the International Red Cross). And I think bets like this serve a purpose.,Besides stimulating public debate, they focus the issue and discipline prophets. No matter how good their intentions, prophets face strong temptations to hype. In the current issue of The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, Dr. Rees wryly describes what happened in 2003 when he turned in a manuscript titled, â€œOur Final Century?â€ù,â€œMy British publisher removed the question mark from the bookâ€™s title,â€ù he recalls, â€œand the U.S. publisher changed it to â€˜Our Final Hour.â€™ Pessimism, it seems, makes for better marketing.â€ù,It doesnâ€™t make for better public policy though. Heralds of the bioterror apocalypse have actually worsened the problem of bioterror, as Milton Leitenberg points out in a 2005 report for the Strategic Studies Institute of the United States Army War College.,Mr. Leitenberg is a scholar at the University of Maryland who has been studying biological weapons for decades â€” and debunking wild predictions. Dr. Rees is not alone. Senator Bill Frist called bioterrorism â€œthe greatest existential threat we have in the world todayâ€ù and urged a military effort that â€œeven dwarfs the Manhattan Project.â€ù,Such rhetoric, Mr. Leitenberg says, has had the perverse effect of encouraging terrorists to seek out biological weapons. But despite  the much-publicized attempts of Al Qaeda and a Japanese group to go biological, terrorists havenâ€™t had much luck, because itâ€™s still quite hard for individuals or nongovernmental groups to obtain, manufacture or deploy biological weapons of mass destruction.,Mr. Leitenberg says the biggest threat is of a state deploying biological weapons, and he notes the encouraging decline in the number of countries working on this technology. Meanwhile, though, America has been so spooked by the horror-movie scenarios that itâ€™s pouring money into defense against biological weapons. Dr. Leitenberg says thatâ€™s a mistake, both because it diverts resources from more serious threats  â€”  like natural diseases and epidemics  â€”  and because it could start a new biological arms race as other countries understandably fear that the United States is doing more than just playing defense.,Itâ€™s possible, as Dr. Rees fears, that terrorists will get a lot more sophisticated at biotech in the next decade, or that researchers will make some terrible mistake. The technology is getting cheaper and spreading rapidly. But so are the tools for preventing and coping with mistakes.,Whatever happens, I donâ€™t expect biotechnology to pose an â€œexistential threat.â€ù The disaster predicted by Dr. Rees would be horrific, but humanity has survived worse, like the , epidemic of 1918 that killed tens of millions of people. I know there are fears  of new microorganisms or nanobots gobbling up our species, but Iâ€™m confident  weâ€™d somehow stop the Doomsday Clock from striking midnight.,In fact, the wager Iâ€™d really like to make with Dr. Rees is that weâ€™ll make it to 2100. Iâ€™ve posted , on Long Bets, and Iâ€™d be glad to give him better odds than the 50-50 chance he gives civilization of surviving the century.,I even think one of us might survive to see the payoff, although my techno-optimism has its limits. I hope some version of me will be around in 2100, but I wouldnâ€™t bet on it.
column4: Can Humanity Survive? Want to Bet on It?

column1: Inserting tubes in children with persistent fluid in the ear does not lead to better developmental outcomes as the children age, a new ,.,Tympanostomy, or the insertion of tubes to drain the fluid and improve hearing, is one of the most common pediatric operations and is generally believed to help prevent developmental problems. But this study, published on Jan. 18 in The New England Journal of Medicine, suggests that   tubes in otherwise healthy children has no effect on development through age 11.,The researchers studied 429 children younger than 2 months with persistent episodes of fluid in the middle ear. The children were randomly assigned in a clinical trial to undergo tympanostomy promptly or six to nine months later. At the same time, researchers randomly selected a comparison group of 241 children who had persistent fluid in their ears but were not eligible for the clinical trial; almost none of  those children received ear tubes.,Examinations at ages 9 to 11 with  tests of hearing, speech and academic skills showed  no significant difference between the children who received early tube placement and those who received later placement. Among the children not eligible for the trial, correlations between the duration of episodes of fluid in the ear for various periods in the first three years of life and developmental outcomes at ages 9 to 11 were generally insignificant.,â€œThese findings do not apply to children with acute infections,â€ù said Dr. Jack L. Paradise, the lead author and a professor of , at the University of Pittsburgh. â€œBut with children whose only problem is fluid in the ear, we should be conservative and wait at least a year before considering tubes.â€ù
column4: Child Care: Ear Tubes Not Found to Affect Development

column1: Beethovenâ€™s three most famous piano sonatas have names. You know what they are. The more-than-casual listener will identify three, arguably four more, also with poetic titles attached. Add to these the last three sonatas, which no one interested in this composerâ€™s late period will have avoided. This leaves 22 Beethoven piano sonatas that, aside from music students, hardly anyone knows at all.,Garrick Ohlssonâ€™s three-recital series at Alice Tully Hall, which began on Sunday afternoon, is valuable, among other reasons, for its use of this underused resource. Classical-music recording executives and programmers comb the past for fresh repertory, but these splendid products of a great manâ€™s workshop seem rarely to make it outside the teacherâ€™s studio.,Mr. Ohlsson used two of the Big Three as bookends for Sundayâ€™s program, the â€œPathÃ©tiqueâ€ù and the â€œAppassionata,â€ù with lesser-known works (Op. 22 and Op. 10, No. 2) in between. The Opus 22 Sonata in B flat is a maze of virtuosity, its acrobatics and intricacies capable of publicly humiliating established performers. Other musicians, I am sure, keep its difficulties (and unfortunately its charms) to themselves. Certainly Beethoven must have been a very good pianist.,The Opus 10 Sonata in F, light as a feather, is more manageable and was treated here as a kind of comedy routine, with cross-handed passages as rim shots followed by pratfalls. For 14-year-old pianists wondering what the racing finale really ought to sound like, Mr. Ohlsson offered instruction. Elsewhere the playing offered drama without histrionics and heart-on-sleeve feelings with no loss of dignity. Mr. Ohlsson remembers that Beethoven the wild-eyed revolutionary was also a spiritual child of Haydn and a more decorous time.,This was pianism technically clear and confident, and unafraid to turn the finale of the â€œAppassionataâ€ù into a calculated frenzy. The last movement of Opus 22 seemed almost perversely  slow, as if some point about oneness of tempo were being made. Iâ€™m also not used to the heavily accented, long appoggiaturas at the end of the slow movement of the â€œPathÃ©tique,â€ù but maybe Mr. Ohlsson has some musicology up his sleeve Iâ€™m unaware of.,The second program, on Feb. 25, offers the splendid early Sonata in C; the endearing, much later two-movement F sharp Sonata, of which Beethoven was fond; and Lisztâ€™s arrangement of Beethovenâ€™s Fourth Symphony. For a little â€œMoonlight,â€ù you will have to wait until April 1, but to judge from Sundayâ€™s big crowd, getting in might be hard.
column4: Digging Past the Familiar to Find Beethoven Treasures, Some Knotty and Some Nice

column1: A long-anticipated encounter between two giants of avant-garde theater is currently taking place in New York City â€” not on a stage but at an art gallery.,One of the works in ,â€™s â€œVoom  Portraitsâ€ù at the Paula Cooper Gallery â€” an exhibition (also at the Phillips de Pury & Company gallery) of high-definition video portraits of celebrities posed nearly motionless in drolly theatrical costumes and settings â€” is a 30-minute, continuously looped, stunningly beautiful video of Winona Ryder as the character Winnie in Samuel Beckettâ€™s play â€œHappy Days.â€ù,The collection of portraits (which includes Brad Pitt, Mikhail Baryshnikov and Isabella Rossellini) is the product of a commission Mr. Wilson accepted several years ago from Voom HD Networks, a company devoted to  high-definition television channels, which provided the technology and production expertise for the shows.,â€œWinona Ryder,â€ù however, a 15-by-27-foot image projected in Paula Cooper Galleryâ€™s large, main space, is truly a work apart. It shows Mr. Wilson at his most perceptive concerning the implications of both his means and his subject, and it deserves to be considered one of his most penetrating theatrical creations.,Mr. Wilson has made frequent admiring comments about Beckett over the years but, to the disappointment of many, has never directed one of his plays.
